webTitle: Batistuta and co are given a licence to thrill

fields.headline: Batistuta and co are given a licence to thrill
fields.standfirst: Argentines are keen to impress with World Cup qualifiers looming
fields.trailText: Kevin Keegan clearly believes David Beckham can run a football match more smoothly than he ran last week's impromptu babysitting service and there will be few better chances to find out than tonight.
fields.body:
Kevin Keegan clearly believes David Beckham can run a football match more smoothly than he ran last week's impromptu babysitting service and there will be few better chances to find out than tonight.

Argentina's midfield is not one in which Dennis Wise could expect to find a slot. As if the bite of Diego Simeone and the brilliant skills of Juan Veron were not enough, just in front of the Lazio pair lurks the mesmerising Ariel Ortega of Parma. If Beckham shines, Keegan can afford a broad grin.

At the moment one senses it is Argentina who are beaming. Simeone believes Beckham is at his best on the right flank. The coach Marcelo Bielsa sounded grateful not to be facing a barrage of his crosses.

"We analysed Beckham with his ability to influence games from the right," he said. "We are well aware of his capacity for putting in great crosses. We have not seen him in this central role but I'm sure he will adapt."

Tactics aside, what particularly astounds the Argentines is the scorn poured on the Manchester United player by his fellow countrymen. "The most important thing is that Beckham is a great player," Ortega said. "I don't understand why such a player should receive criticism like he has done since France. In the modern tactical world you need talented players who can unlock defences and do something special, give fantasy."

Fantasy is central to Bielsa's philosophy.

Argentina remain largely unchanged from that night in St Etienne but the tactics have altered since he replaced Daniel Passarella last year. He prefers a greater emphasis on attack.

If Argentina have a weakness it is arguably in goal, where German Burgos is seen as unpredictable. The Mallorca player is short of match practice having been given a long ban in Spain for punching an opponent.

Argentina, who won 2-0 in Spain in their last match three months ago, will be keen to impress before their World Cup qualifiers start next month.

Gabriel Batistuta must be looking forward to his return to Wembley having scored there against Arsenal in the Champions League in October. He has also scored against United this season and hinted that this country might see more of him next. He is learning English and says he would like to come to the Premiership.

Boca Juniors are keen to take him home, but he prefers the sound of United. "It is the best team in the world and as well as being a cool club they have always been looking for me."

fields.headline: England 0 - 0 Argentina
fields.trailText:
Teams
England: Seaman, Dyer, Southgate, Wise, Campbell, Keown, Beckham, Scholes, Shearer, Heskey, Wilcox. Subs: P. Neville, Martyn, R. Ferdinand, Parlour, Sinclair, Phillips, Cole.
fields.body:
Teams
England: Seaman, Dyer, Southgate, Wise, Campbell, Keown, Beckham, Scholes, Shearer, Heskey, Wilcox. Subs: P. Neville, Martyn, R. Ferdinand, Parlour, Sinclair, Phillips, Cole.

Argentina: Cavallero, Ayala, Arruabarrena, Sensini, Simeone, Chamot, Kily Gonzalez, Zanetti, Batistuta, Ortega, Veron. Subs: Burgos, Vivas, Pocchettino, Husain, C. Lopez, G. Lopez, Crespo.

Referee: M Merk (Germany)

1 A lot of noise greeted the teams as they came out and Kevin Keegan must be hoping that this spurs on his team to great to great things against a country that is rapidly assuming a position long held by Germany in the nation's psyche. England kick off; Alan Shearer plays it back as Argentina come sprinting upfield. Dennis Wise gets an early touch as he lays the ball out left for Jason Wilcox. He crosses for Shearer in the box but the England captain can only get a faint touch.Shearer will be hoping for more of that.
3 Daniel Otega makes a great run down the right and fires in a vicious cross that skims off the head of Gareth Soutgate for a throw.
6 Paul Scholes passes to Emile Heskey on the edge of the Argentina area, Heskey lays it back for David Beckham but the Man U man of the moment loses the chance. England win a free kick, Beckham takes but the ball misses everybody.
9 Shearer wins a free kick on the left; Beckham takes again and Argentina almost foul up when Ayala and Cavallero collide at the clearance, but Ayala manages to head the ball out. The ball falls kindly for Ortega who quickly feeds Gabriel Batistuta running into the England half. Top opportunistic moment that, luckily for England, is stifled by a dodgy offside call.
11 England's first chance. Shearer rises well to a Beckham corner and heads the ball down and just wide of the right-hand upright under pressure from Ayala.
18 Booking: Beckham for a high challenge.
21 England come close again as Heskey charges off down the left, cuts inside, plays the ball through the legs of Sensini and finds Shearer in the box. Shearer is already falling over and can only 'crotch' the ball wide. Did he fall or was he tripped by the trailing leg of Sensini, who, having realised Shearer had got behind him, stuck out a hopeful foot? Argentina may have been lucky to have avoided a penalty.
22 England having the best of the play as Argentina get pinned back in their own half. Heskey gets his head to deep cross but the save is easy for Cavallero.
24 Booking: Rodolfo Arruabarrena for a crunching tackle on Beckham
26 England's best chance so far when a Beckham free kick from all of 30 yards out misses the left upright by a whisker.
28 Argentina free-kick; Veron takes but Beckham heads the ball clear. Falls for Wise who lays it off for Kieron Dyer. Sensini closes to retrieve possession but Heskey races upfield to harrass the Argentinian defender into giving away a throw. Heskey full of energy and looking like he is on a mission.
32 Wise finds Wilcox out on the left who makes good ground before passing back to Wise, who then plays in Heskey on the edge of the area. Argentina muster well.
33 Beckham's corner is played straight at Veron and the clearance allows Ortega to make break own the right. He links up with Veron and the speed and subtlety of their play sees them to the edge of the penalty area before England manage to clear.
34 Substitution: Pocchettino on for Sensini.
40 Booking: Ortega takes a dive on the edge of the England penalty area.
42 Heskey latches on to a long ball, races left before cutting inside and lays it back to an Argentinian defender when he perhaps should have shot with his left.
44Veron's free kick from just outside the England area is headed well clear by Shearer.
45 A well-worked move by Argentina allows Veron to get in a deep cross from the left corner flag. Seaman saves and immediately puts a bad throw out to Wilcox who, under pressure, needlessly concedes an corner. Shearer again heads clear. Half-time.

46 Substitution: Rio Ferdinand on for Martin Keown. Argentina get the second half underway.
47 Booking: Wise for a late challenge.
48 The second 45 is being played at a much more leisurely pace the first as Argentina content themselves with a knock around at the back, perhaps in the hope of lulling England into a false sense of security.
49 Shearer and Heskey both get lucky touches on the edge of the area and provoke Argentina into movement.
51 Wilcox again the catalyst as he picks up where he left off on the left. He races away and gets in a good cross that is well cleared.
53 England push up. Heskey uses his pace again to find space down the left and decides to go one on one with Ayala; he beats him but his cross his deflected away by Zenetti.
56 Ortega on the edge of the England area finds Veron who then plays the ball left for Gonzalez to fire in a shot at the near post. Seaman gets down to make the save.
59 Substitution: Phillip Neville on for Dyer. Booking: Chamot for a tackle on Heskey.
60 Wilcox again down the left, determined to make his mark in England's prennnial trouble spot; he fires in another excellent cross for Heskey to head just wide of the left-hand upright.
65 Shearer creates space on the right and makes a run to the penalty area but his shot is blocked. He plays across the park to find Wilcox who immediatley fires in for Heskey to head wide yet again.
69 Nelson Vivas has sauntered over to the left and is played into lots of space. His centre is overhit and a promising Argentinian move breaks down again.
72 Substitution: Parlour for Beckham.
74 Heskey and Ayala clash heads as they both go for a high ball. The Leicester frontman leaves the field with stars in his eyes. He rejoins the fray after his head clears.
76 Ortega and Simeone link up well in midfield to send Gonzales through the middle his shot is well struck bnut travels wide of Seaman's left-hand post.
77 Substitution: Kevin Phillips for Alan Shearer; Andy Cole for Emile Heskey. Great cheers for Heskey after an excellent performance.
79 Ray Parlour picks out Andy Cole on the right of the visitors' area. Cole turns and shoots in one fluid movement but Cavallero is equal to the task. His shot rebounds of the keeper's body and is cleared.
80 End-to-end stuff as Ortega works his magic on the right of the England area, beating Wilcox and crossing to Vivas who heads back to Crespo. The Parma hitman swipes at the ball and cannot make any contact 10 yards out and England can breathe again. Frantic stuff.
83 Ortega playing in on the right of the England box this time, and he forces a corner. Dangerous moments for the home side.
84 Juan Veron takes the corner, but his outswinger swings out of play. Veron suggests to the linesman that glasses would help his myopia.
87 Argentina enjoying a lot of possession during these late stages. Finally Phillips has a chance to run at Ayala but his control lets him down and Argentina win a throw.
90 A yellow card for Ayala for time-wasting. Phillips is up-ended on the left touchline but possession is lost.
91 Substitution: Lopez for Ortega.
92 The late, late pressure is coming from the visitors as they hold the ball and press forward.
93 Full time: England 0 - 0 Argentina.

Wiseacres proved wrong

webTitle: Butler ready to serve the Republic

fields.headline: Butler ready to serve the Republic
fields.trailText: Republic of Ireland v Czech Republic
fields.body:
Paul Butler will make his debut for the Republic of Ireland in tonight's friendly against the Czech Republic at Lansdowne Road.

The 28-year-old Manchester-born Sunderland central defender was also eligible to play for Wales but turned down approaches from Bobby Gould and Mark Hughes. The Irish provided him with a passport through his step-father although he would eventually have qualified, as he is married to a Kildare woman.

His wife and family, he said, were annoyed at reports that questioned his allegiance. "I intend to show my commitment to the Irish fans against the Czechs," he said.

The Ireland manager Mick McCarthy prefers Butler on this occasion to Coventry's Gary Breen. He will play Ian Harte of Leeds at left-back, leaving Liverpool's Steve Staunton on the bench.

It is a side that is close to full strength, in preparation for the World Cup qualifying matches, which start with the away game against Holland in September.

"There may be an opportunity to try out several players as substitutes, the manager Mick McCarthy said. "But essentially we want to win this to preserve our excellent home record."

The Irish have not lost a competitive match at Lansdowne Road since they were defeated 3-1 by Austria in a European Championship tie in 1995.

The Czech coach Jozef Chovanec should play his usual 3-5-2 formation with Liverpool's Vladimir Smicer in attack and Patrik Berger in midfield alongside the former Manchester United man Karel Poborsky.

 The 19-year-old Leeds midfielder Matthew Jones will make his first senior start for Wales this afternoon in the game in Qatar. Two other youngsters, Neil Roberts of Wigan and Simon Davies of Tottenham, are on the bench.

webTitle: McIlroy opts for a captain of industry

fields.headline: McIlroy opts for a captain of industry
fields.trailText:
Luxembourg v Northern Ireland
Steve Lomas, the West Ham United midfielder, was yesterday reappointed Northern Ireland captain on the eve of Sammy McIlroy's first match as manager of his country.
fields.body:
Steve Lomas, the West Ham United midfielder, was yesterday reappointed Northern Ireland captain on the eve of Sammy McIlroy's first match as manager of his country.

Lomas, also captain during Lawrie McMenemy's 18-month reign in the job, leads the side in tonight's friendly against Luxembourg, the first of four games in the build-up to the World Cup qualifiers. It follows a disastrous Euro 2000 qualifying series that produced a solitary win in eight games.

"Steve possesses leadership, has the utmost respect from players, skippers his club and of course is a superb dedicated professional," McIlroy said.

Northern Ireland, without the Leicester pair Gerry Taggart and Neil Lennon, excused because of Sunday's League Cup final, will be looking to win by a commanding margin.

"This can be the launching pad to restore our pride and prestige," said Lomas. "It is imperative we have wins not only in this game but against Malta, Hungary and possibly Yugoslavia, which would be a fantastic boost for the World Cup starting in September." McIlroy, who made 88 appearances for Northern Ireland, believes his team have the talent to rise from 80th in the Fifa rankings and earn a place in the World Cup qualifying play-offs. "What we possessed in full measure, especially in the 80s, was team spirit," he added. "That's what I am attempting to restore and the response has been excellent."

However McIlroy admits to a lack of firepower, which could be a problem. "We have no proven goalscorer, someone who can knock in 20 a season at club level," he said.

"We have a couple of youngsters of promise: James Quinn of West Brom and David Healy, who has joined Port Vale on loan from Manchester United. They look the part but it's unfair to add pressure on them."

The European Championship was a disaster for Luxembourg, a mix of semi- professionals, amateurs and the odd pro, who finished bottom of their qualifying group with no points from seven games, 23 goals conceded and only two scored.

Northern Ireland will probably use all 18 players with Roy Carroll, the Wigan goalkeeper, preferred to Maik Taylor in the starting line-up. His team-mate Pat McGibbon, under treatment for a dead leg, should be fit.

Michael Hughes of Wimbledon, who had a groin operation five weeks ago, came successfully through two training sessions yesterday but may play for only 15 minutes.

fields.headline: England to take Cyclopson trial
fields.trailText: England will be the testing ground, possibly before the end of this season, for technology to end controversies over whether the ball has crossed the goalline.
fields.body:
England will be the testing ground, possibly before the end of this season, for technology to end controversies over whether the ball has crossed the goalline.

A bleeper device, similar to tennis's "Cyclops", would notify the referee by sound whether the ball is over the line.

The FA's executive director David Davies said: "It may well be tried at training grounds here but would not be brought into match use until next year at the earliest."

Two Portsmouth players, Rory Allen and Aaron Flahavan, yesterday admitted being abusive to police after a drinking spree when they were each fined £750 at a Fareham court.

webTitle: More slap than tickle for United's frosty frontmen

fields.headline: More slap than tickle for United's frosty frontmen
fields.trailText: Comment Teddy Sheringham and Andy Cole are finding it painful even to share a football pitch. But is that necessarily for the worst? United may profit from their estrangement.
fields.body:
Laurel and Hardy, as film fans will know, occasionally used to share a bed in their films. It is safe to assume that Manchester United's Teddy Sheringham and Andy Cole will not be following their lead. Indeed, as keen readers of body language will confirm, at the moment the pair are finding it painful even to share a football pitch.

But is that necessarily for the worst? History is littered with examples of double acts who were not necessarily bosom buddies, but who blossomed together. Simon and Garfunkel are a good example, as you will know if you have heard the album Simon and Garfunkel In Concert. Creative tension, it is sometimes called, although in the context of what goes on between the average Premiership footballer's ears that is probably not a fruitful line to pursue.

It is interesting, though, that for all the importance attached to team spirit you will occasionally find two people wearing the same colour shirt operating quite effectively despite an off-the-field relationship that's not so much Tom and Nicole as Tom and Jerry.

Old Trafford has seen a few of these relationships. Remi Moses and Jesper Olsen were seen to view each other with steely contempt on those occasions they played together and later staged a celebrated training ground fracas. And Bobby Charlton formed one of the most successful partnerships in history with George Best despite never finding it in himself to go out on the pull with Bestie to Tramps.

It is not even a new experience for Cole to be involved in a Manchester United cold war. Relations between him and Eric Cantona were less than cordial after the Frenchman gave his talents distinctly lukewarm notice after the striker's move from Newcastle.

This is perhaps why Cole made public his delight at sharing the striking duties with Dwight Yorke, a partner he could relate to at work and play. However, since one of the results of their off-the-field friendship was allegations in a Sunday paper that they had invited a young woman to join them in a Laurel and Hardy style sleeping arrangement, such social intercourse might well be considered by the club to be overrated.

The fact that there is a little more friction at Old Trafford than elsewhere could be because of the talents involved. I am not saying that gifted individuals are any more prone to tantrums and sudden enmities than the rest of us, it is just that the general conception leans that way. And while it does smart guys like Eric will make the most of it to test the strength of their own position.

On the other hand, maybe Cole accidentally scratched one of Teddy's high-performance vehicles in the car park. Maybe they just don't like each other. They are probably not the only ones, but the fact they are partners up front makes their falling out that bit more interesting.

We are fascinated by partnerships. Speculating on other people's marriages is a hugely popular pastime, which may explain the column inches devoted this week to the private life of Mr and Mrs Beckham, closely followed by those on the subject of whom Alan Shearer will be joined with for England tonight.

Kevin Keegan, I suspect, did not subject Emile Heskey to a Dateline questionnaire before choosing him to keep the skipper happy, and if the pair do not spend their time on trips abroad sharing a quiet pint and a fire extinguisher I don't suppose it will bother him. Heskey has been described by one reporter as "a muscle-bound lump", so I think we can assume he has been picked to replicate the role Duncan Ferguson plays alongside Shearer at Newcastle. If they don't get on, who cares? Greg Rusedski and Tim Henman, whose partnership was reportedly marked by a certain tension, had some Davis Cup success in the doubles for Britain, while Steven Redgrave and Andrew Holmes won the 1988 Olympic coxless pairs despite a relationship the temperature of a frozen pizza.

Speaking of which, Torvill and Dean... about them we will never know, but what fun we had guessing. Even now, inquiries about their relationship are met with a polite request for questions to be put in writing. The important thing is they sparkled in competition, and even on the ice it is doubtful things ever got as frosty between them as they have for Cole and Sheringham.

webTitle: Firebrand has chance to light up midfield

fields.headline: Firebrand has chance to light up midfield
fields.standfirst: Dennis Wise is handed a last opportunity to prove himself
fields.trailText: Martin Thorpe takes a look at 33-year-old Dennis Wise, handed a last opportunity by Kevin Keegan to prove himself at international level.
fields.body:
The sceptics are already moving away from wondering whether England can actually beat Argentina tonight and beginning to think it will be a bonus if the national side can finish the game with 10 men.

David Beckham was already 25-1 with the bookies to see the red card that famously blighted his last appearance against the South Americans two years ago. Yesterday Kevin Keegan prompted another flurry of bets when he picked Dennis Wise alongside Beckham in central midfield.

Sir Alex Ferguson once said of Wise: "He could start an argument in an empty house." So as each Argentine possesses an honours degree in wind-up technique, one can only fear for Wise's reaction when pinching in the clinches and hair-pulling behind the referee's back starts.

However, it is testament to Keegan's plight when it comes to the shortage of quality midfield players that he is willing to gamble on such a loose cannon. For there is no doubt that on purely footballing ability, Dennis is a menace with the ball. His contribution to a Chelsea team packed with foreigners is that of the Englishman who knits everything together. He rarely gives the ball away, can pass with the best and nips in for the odd goal. As Keegan rightly pointed out: "When he hasn't played for Chelsea they haven't been the same team".

Although Wise's rocky disciplinary record and fall-out with Glenn Hoddle has restricted his international appearances to a series of short comebacks - his last England start was four years ago - he has thrived in the Champions League this season, and when he came on against Belgium in England's recent friendly victory at Sunderland, he looked right at home.

Indeed, Keegan will be hoping Wise shows more of his European side tonight, for in 10 games this season he has not been so much as booked. But the suspicion remains that he will revert to type in the white heat of battle.

Keegan said he had a two-minute chat with Wise yesterday morning, telling him: "Look, I'm going to play you and I want all the good things."

Wise probably replied: "Of course, boss. Trust me." But we have heard that before. After being sent off for stamping in August 1998, Wise declared: "I'm fed up with being banned. I won't be getting sent off again." Two months later he launched a two-footed tackle on Aston Villa's Darren Byfield and bang went the promise.

Keegan retains a mystical belief that this time, the argumentative, quick-tempered 33-year-old will show his mature side. "I just think I can trust him," he said yesterday, though he did not seem to know why. "I cannot give you evidence. I mean you watch him a lot more week in week out than I do, but I have seen bits on television."

Real-life experience would suggest Keegan's eternal optimism has entered dreamland. Certainly he will be pilloried unmercifully if the gamble backfires while Wise will definitely have seen the end of his international career. But if it works, England might at last have found someone with the energy and ability to give and move that the torpid midfield has been crying out for.

"He has this opportunity," said Keegan. "And it is against Argentina, so it is a good game for him to answer all the questions that have been asked of him for a period of time." The nation will be praying there is a first time for everything.

webTitle: Beckham also missed Christmas Day training

fields.headline: Beckham also missed Christmas Day training
fields.trailText: 'Illness in the family' revealed as tried and tested.
fields.body:
The case for David Beckham's defence assumed a distinct air of vulnerability yesterday after it emerged he failed to turn up for training on Christmas Day in preparation for Manchester United's game against Bradford City on Boxing Day.

He spent the previous night 170 miles away at the Hertfordshire home he shares with his pop-star wife Victoria Adams and he gave the same excuse to the club that he used for missing training last Friday - that there was an illness in the family.

Last Friday Beckham contacted the club at 10.10am - only 20 minutes before training - with the same excuse. Beckham was withdrawn from the Bradford City game at Old Trafford, with his manager Sir Alex Ferguson telling the media that his right-sided midfielder had been suffering from a hamstring problem.

Usually players with that sort of injury can expect to be missing for two or three weeks. Beckham played in the 2-2 draw at Sunderland only two days later.

After Beckham's banishment from training on Saturday, and his subsequent omission from the champions' game at Leeds United the following day, his London-based public relations team was anxious to portray Ferguson as the instigator of the problem, claiming he had been guilty of nothing more than showing natural concern for his ill child, Brooklyn.

But the latest revelations will add weight to Ferguson's belief that the strain of Beckham's personal life threatens to damage his career.

webTitle: Giles forced to spend an age as Aquarius

fields.headline: Giles forced to spend an age as Aquarius
fields.trailText: There is now a substantial chance that Ashley Giles, the best-known water carrier since Aquarius, will complete his one-day tour of South Africa and Zimbabwe without playing a single match.
fields.body:
There is now a substantial chance that Ashley Giles, the best-known water carrier since Aquarius, will complete his one-day tour of South Africa and Zimbabwe without playing a single match.

Even if the captain Nasser Hussain relents this morning and picks him for the final match here today, it is likely that the Warwickshire left-arm spinner will be nobbled by Cyclone Eline, which has devastated areas of Mozambique and has now crossed to Zimbabwe. There would have been no play yesterday.

"In terms of matches played I reckon I'm better paid than David Beckham," said the jocular twirler, whose fee for this leg of the tour is £12,000. "But I'm not giving the money back because I've already spent it."

More seriously, he added: "It's been frustrating for me. I came out here with high hopes. I am the only spinner on the tour. But my back injury was a setback because once you miss the first match the side takes shape and it becomes difficult to get back in."

Giles, 26, injured his back in England as he bent over to have a shave, but has been fit to bowl for the past month. Moreover he has been in the squad for 34 one-day internationals only to be left out of the final XI on 29 occasions.

He said: "I've got five wickets from five matches but if I'd played in all those that I've been considered for I would be pushing for 50 wickets now. It just hasn't worked out.

"I played second fiddle to Crofty [Robert Croft] for quite a long time and didn't play, and I thought I would get my chance this winter. No one is to blame. Even though I felt frustrated, it's better to be here and in the shake-up than sitting on my backside at home watching the boys on telly."

Giles, who can also be a useful late-order batsman, was due to play in Bulawayo before a last-minute change of pitch led to him being left out again. "For the other guys a day off is a day off, and they can let their hair down before building up to play in the next game.

"But for Gavin [Hamilton] and myself we follow the same trend all the time. It's difficult to get motivated sometimes. And it can be really frustrating when I see the Zimbabwe spinners doing well and Graeme Hick coming on the other day when the pitch turned. I'm desperate to play.

"But it's important to keep a happy face. It's no good dragging your chin around the dressing-room. And this has been one of the happiest tours I've been on. Everyone gets on."

Giles proved that he has not lost his sense of humour when he drove the buggy out to the middle at Harare on Sunday only to discover that Hick had unhitched the drinks trailer. "It was embarrassing, but a very funny moment," he added.

Zimbabwe, meanwhile, are preparing to leave for their two-Test tour of the Caribbean. After a triangular tournament involving West Indies and Pakistan, followed by another Test tour and three-cornered one-day series in England, they will not arrive home until late July.

"We will have to get our batting sorted out," said the coach Dave Houghton. "Our top-of-the-order men haven't performed recently. We are also looking to bring a leg-spinner to England because in the one-day matches your batsmen have struggled against our spinners."

webTitle: Football legend Stanley Matthews dies at 85

fields.headline: Football legend Stanley Matthews dies at 85
fields.standfirst: Obituary: Sir Stanley Matthews
fields.trailText: Sir Stanley Matthews, one of England's greatest players and twice European footballer of the year, has died aged 85.
fields.body:
Sir Stanley Matthews, one of England's greatest players and twice European footballer of the year, has died aged 85.

Matthews, who turned professional with Stoke aged 17, was capped 54 times for England and made 710 Football League appearances for Stoke and Blackpool.

Knighted in 1965, Matthews made his last Football League appearance in the same year at the record-breaking age of 50 years and five days. In his retirement, Matthews became an ambassador for football and received a FIFA Gold Merit Order in 1992.

Sir Stanley died at North Staffordshire Nuffield Hospital following a short illness, the hospital said.

A spokesman for the private hospital in Newcastle under Lyme said: "Sir Stanley Matthews died peacefully this evening after a short illness related to health problems that had first seriously affected him three years ago. "We have no further statement at this time."

It is understood Sir Stanley may have had an accident of some sort on the island of Tenerife before being flown to the Nuffield for treatment. A spokesman for Stoke City football club said the former star regularly went to Tenerife to escape the British winter. The spokesman said that he understood Sir Stanley had gone to the island in the Canaries in December last year and had been due back some time now.

Matthews made his international debut at the age of 19 and collected his last cap in 1956 when, aged 41, he mesmerised the Brazilian defence in England's 4-2 win at Wembley.

Matthews spent his 33-year league career with two unfashionable north of England clubs, Stoke City and Blackpool. But he won 54 international caps and was the first man to be named European footballer of the year. He won the affection of football fans throughout the world who marvelled at the right-winger's ability to ghost past defenders.

Matthews' rewrote many record books with his feats but his shining moment came in the 1953 FA Cup final. Twice a losing finalist with Blackpool in 1948 and 1951, Matthews stood 20 minutes away from a third defeat with his team 3-1 down to Bolton. Then his dazzling footwork carved out the last two goals of a hat-trick for Stan Mortensen, and Matthews went on to set up the winner for Bill Perry with 20 seconds left. Despite Mortensen's treble it was a game which would always be remembered as "the Matthews final".

Matthews was born in Hanley on February 1 1915, the third of four sons. He joined Stoke in 1929 at the age of 14 as an apprentice and spent his time cleaning boots and sweeping out the dressing rooms. Within five years, Matthews won his first England cap against Wales while still a teenager. And in 1937 he hit his only international hat-trick in a 5-4 win over Czechoslovakia.

At Matthews' 80th birthday celebrations, former England captain Jimmy Armfield praised his skills and sportsmanship. "You could kick him and do anything with him and he would never retaliate," said Armfield. "He was the perfect example of self-discipline. I never remember a referee speaking to him once - and he didn't speak to them either."

Matthews, known as 'the Wizard of the Dribble', was a crowd-pleaser to generations and tempted a British record crowd, 149,547, to Hampden Park in Glasgow. But he never earned more than £50 a week, plus £25-a-game bonus. Lord Wilson of Rievaulx, who was Prime Minister when Matthews was knighted, wrote in a foreword to his autobiography: "Stanley Matthews was a symbol of the country which gave football to the world, and internationally a symbol of English sportsmanship in the days when that was a quality acknowledged worldwide."

Sir Tom Finney led the tributes to Matthews tonight. England team-mate Sir Tom said: "I've so many memories of Stan and he was the greatest in my era in terms of close control.

"In those days you weren't expected to go back and tackle and his game was attacking the full-back.

"He was a humble man and he never got carried away by how well he played."

Former England manager Sir Walter Winterbottom said: "Stan was very fit and one thing he had was that he was very quick off the mark.

"Wingers in those days just stayed on the wing and Stan had that unique way of dribbling past people."

Tonight, Newcastle boss Bobby Robson, speaking at Wembley ahead of the England friendly against Argentina, said: "He was one of, easily, our greatest, greatest players.

"He would have played in today's game, he would have adapted - don't you worry about that.

"He had immense skill - great skill off the ball, a beautiful dribbler. I'm very sad at the news."

David Davies, executive director of the Football Association, described Matthews as "a legend who did not disappoint."

Despite Mortensen's treble it was a game which would always be remembered as "the Matthews final". Matthews was born in Hanley on February 1 1915, the third of four sons. He joined Stoke in 1929 at the age of 14 as an apprentice and spent his time cleaning boots and sweeping out the dressing rooms. Within five years, Matthews won his first England cap against Wales while still a teenager. And in 1937 he hit his only international hat-trick in a 5-4 win over Czechoslovakia. At Matthews' 80th birthday celebrations, former England captain Jimmy Armfield praised his skills and sportsmanship. "You could kick him and do anything with him and he would never retaliate," said Armfield. "He was the perfect example of self-discipline. I never remember a referee speaking to him once - and he didn't speak to them either." Matthews, known as 'the Wizard of the Dribble', was a crowd-pleaser to generations and tempted a British record crowd, 149,547, to Hampden Park in Glasgow. But he never earned more than £50 a week, plus £25-a-game bonus. Lord Wilson of Rievaulx, who was Prime Minister when Matthews was knighted, wrote in a foreword to his autobiography: "Stanley Matthews was a symbol of the country which gave football to the world, and internationally a symbol of English sportsmanship in the days when that was a quality acknowledged worldwide." Sir Tom Finney led the tributes to Matthews tonight. England team-mate Sir Tom said: "I've so many memories of Stan and he was the greatest in my era in terms of close control. "In those days you weren't expected to go back and tackle and his game was attacking the full-back. "He was a humble man and he never got carried away by how well he played." Former England manager Sir Walter Winterbottom said: "Stan was very fit and one thing he had was that he was very quick off the mark. Tonight, Newcastle boss Bobby Robson, speaking at Wembley ahead of the England friendly against Argentina, said: "He was one of, easily, our greatest, greatest players. "He would have played in today's game, he would have adapted - don't you worry about that. "He had immense skill - great skill off the ball, a beautiful dribbler. I'm very sad at the news." David Davies, executive director of the Football Association, described Matthews as "a legend who did not disappoint."

fields.headline: England all blackwashed
fields.standfirst:
England 86 (Pullar 4-11; 37.2 overs)
New Zealand 63-4 (Reynard 2-4; 25.4 overs)
New Zealand won by six wickets (revised run rate)
fields.trailText: England were beaten by six wickets in a rain-affected final match in Napier yesterday and have now lost 11 out of 12 games on their tour of the southern hemisphere.
fields.body:
Charlotte Edwards demonstrated yesterday that despite the mishaps that have afflicted her England colleagues on this fractious tour she at least has learned something from it.

The England No4 made a classy 25 and it needed an amazing catch at long-leg by the Cook Islands schoolgirl Munukoa Tunupopo, who will be 16 today, to remove her.

However the tourists were beaten by six wickets in this rain-affected final match and have lost 11 of their 12 games, the only win coming against a weak Wellington side in their first match in New Zealand.

But there have been some plus points. The bowling and the fielding have improved: New Zealand had to fight to make an adjusted figure of 63 in 29 overs following rain - which had delayed the start by two hours and which interrupted their reply at 29 for one chasing 86 all out.

Rain makes a habit of plaguing international matches here in Napier and though having the floodlights stolen, or part of them at least, was not enough to hold up play, the downpours were.

The umpires somehow dredged up the long-abandoned average-runs-per-over system, though, and the end was a joke. For England, a bad one.

fields.headline: Sir Stanley Matthews
fields.standfirst: Sir Stanley Matthews dies at 85 - news report
fields.trailText: Stanley Matthews, who has died aged 85, was the first ever European Footballer of the Year, and arguably the outstanding British player of his generation. He was nicknamed the Wizard of Dribble in Britain, and known abroad as Der Zauberer - the magician.
fields.body:
Stanley Matthews, who has died aged 85, was the first ever European Footballer of the Year, and arguably the outstanding British player of his generation. He was nicknamed the Wizard of Dribble in Britain, and known abroad as Der Zauberer - the magician.

His remarkable career stretched from well before the second world war to the 1960s; he was still playing League football at 50. At 41, at Wembley, he was capable of demolishing as famous a left back as Brazil's Milton Santos. Afterwards, in the England dressing room, in a rare moment of spleen, he said that when he read that he was too old he was sometimes tempted to tear the paper across.

But the truth is that throughout his magical career, Matthews was constantly being accused of being too this, that or the other. Too unpredictable. Too individualistic. Too slow to release the ball. In one wartime Wembley international at Wembley there was a small scandal when it was alleged that he had deliberately been starved of the ball. At the end of the war, when football officially restarted, he was excluded from the England team for most of the 1946/7 season in favour of Tom Finney, an outside right with almost as remarkable a body swerve. Only to return in triumph in Lisbon, Matthews on the right, Finney on he left, Portugal routed, 10-0.

As early as November, 1934, when England won the bruising Battle of Highbury against an Italian team which ran amok when its Argentine captain, Luisito Monti, limped early off the field with a broken foot, Matthews was damned in the Daily Mail. Geoffrey Simpson, its sports columnist, wrote: "I saw Matthews play just as moderately in the recent inter-League match, exhibiting the same slowness and hesitation. Perhaps he lacks the big match temperament."

Matthews was born at Hanley in the Potteries, the son of a formidable boxer Jack Matthews, a formidable boxer known as "the Fighting Barber of Hanley". Jack encouraged Matthews and his other children to keep physically fit, doing deep breathing exercises in front of an open window even on the coldest mornings. In later years, Matthews would devise his own regimes based on long runs across the Blackpool beaches. It used to be said that if you passed his house at 9pm, the lights of his bedroom would be out.

His swerve was something which defied analysis; just as it defied attempts to counter it. He would take the ball up to the opposing left back who, even if he were mentally prepared for it, would still "buy" the dummy when Matthews swayed slightly to the left, putting the opponent off balance, only to wriggle round to the right, flick the ball up the touchline with the outside of his right foot, and sprint away. Catch him if you could. Over those vital first ten yards or so, he was beyond pursuit. "Don't ask me how I do it," he once said of the swerve. "It just comes out of me under pressure."

Having sped past his left back and reached the goal line, Matthews would then pull the ball back into the goalmouth; the most effective pass in the game. He seldom scored himself, but he could do so when necessary. Not least when playing at Tottenham for England against Czechoslovakia in 1937. Injury reduced England to 10 fit men, and their unbeaten home record against foreign teams seemed in jeopardy. But Matthews, moving to inside-right, scored three times, and England won, 5-4.

Much later, in the 1954 World Cup in Switzerland, when England were struggling in their opening game against Belgium, Matthews moved to inside-forward, galvanised the team, and helped it to gain a 4-4 draw. Over the years he would time and again fall foul of the England selectors, troubled by so maverick a talent. It is true that he began badly, a 19-year-old, in his first two internationals against Wales and Italy but it wasn't long before the "big match temperament" was asserting itself.

In May 1939, in the Berlin Olympic Stadium, he had one of his finest games for England just when they needed it most. Forced to give the Nazi salute before they played the German international side, England proceeded to cut them to ribbons, with Matthews rampant, irresistible against a full back who had played him out of the game when last the teams met. Muenzenberg could do nothing with him that day and England won, 6-3.

An outstanding schoolboy footballer, he once scored a dozen goals in a game from centre-half. He played for England schoolboys, joined his local club Stoke City straight from school, worked in the office, and made his league debut for them soon after he had turned 17. But even before the war, his relations with the club degenerated with the appointment as manager of Bob McGrory, a former Stoke defender. It has been suggested that McGrory was displeased by the fact that Matthews had replaced his friend, Bobby Liddle, on the right wing. Relations didn't improve when Matthews returned to Stoke after the second world war.

During the war, he had played as a guest for Blackpool, a town where he and his wife, Jean, had opened a small hotel. Things came to a climax early in the 1946/7 season when Matthews was kept out of the Stoke team by the young winger, George Mountford. Eventually Stoke agreed to transfer him to Blackpool, for the sum of £11,500. Matthews would stay there happily, forming famous wing partnerships with Stan Mortensen and Jackie Mudie, until his romantic and belated return to Stoke, in 1961.

The war ate up much of his "official" career, but he found an ideal partner in the England team in Sunderland's Raich Carter, even though Carter once complained that when he gave Matthews the ball, he never got it back. Tactfully, his captain, Stanley Cullis, responded that having passed he should move into the middle. The England attack, which included Tommy Lawton and Denis Compton, was an outstanding one, with an 8-0 win over Scotland at Maine Road, Manchester, to its credit.

Losing then regaining his place in the England team in the first official post war season, 1946/7, Matthews excelled in Lisbon against Portugal and, a year later, in Turin, reduced poor, blond Eliani - standing in as Italy's left back for Maroso - to tatters. England won 4-0.

But when it came to Cup Finals, a winner's medal persistently eluded Matthews. In the 1948 Final, Blackpool lost 4-2 to Manchester United, despite taking the lead through a penalty kick by Eddie Shimwell. In 1951, two spectacular goals by Jackie Milburn enabled Newcastle United to win, 2-0. 1953 would almost surely be the last chance. Blackpool were to meet Bolton, and this time, luck favoured them when Bell, left-half - and thus a direct opponent for Matthews - was hurt and had to limp along the left wing.

Even then, Blackpool made very heavy weather of it. They conceded an absurd early goal when their Scottish international keeper, George Farm, pitifully misjudged a shot by Nat Lofthouse after a mere 75 seconds. Lofthouse hit the post, Bell tore a muscle and Bolton were already down to ten active men. Stan Mortensen would later say that Bolton lost the game when they decided to move their English international left winger Bobby Langton inside, rather than let him contest space with Matthews, on the wing. Blackpool's equaliser, 10 minutes from the break, was a fluke, the ball going in off their emergency left-half, Harold Hassall. But Bolton gallantly hit back with two goals, one by Moir, with Farm at fault again, the second a brave header by Bell himself. There were only 20 minutes left.

It was now that Matthews, strangely obscure till then, at last came into the game. Tommy Banks, Bolton's left back, was exhausted by his efforts to halt Matthews, contracting cramp in his shins, and four times leaving the field for treatment in the final quarter hour. One more Matthews run, a cross which would have gone out of play had Hanson, Bolton's keeper, not flapped at it, reached Mortensen on the far post and went in. 3-2. Mortensen equalised breathlessly from a free kick.

Then clasically, Matthews got away again on the right, beat Banks, took the ball up to the centre half, Barrass, and pulled back an exquisite cross not to Mortensen but to the South African left winger Perry free on the far post. A right-footed shot and the Matthews Final had been won by Blackpool. Would England have prevailed in the most humiliating match of their history, that defeat by the USA at Belo Horizonte in the 1950 World Cup, had Matthews played? Perhaps; but he didn't. Indeed it was only at the last moment that he was grudgingly recalled from an FA XI tour of North America to play in Brazil at all. He did play the last England game, lost against Spain in Rio 1-0, but the die was cast by then.

Matthews's long marriage to Betty ended in 1968. Matthews remarried, this time a, Czech linguist, Mila Winter, cultural assistant at the US embassy and wife of a well known Czech painter.

He and Betty had two children, Jean and Stanley junior. The latter became three times British Junior tennis champion, and won the Wimbledon Junior Invitation title. He never quite fulfilled his early promise, and eventually turned to coaching in the United States.

Knighted in 1965, a month before his 50th birthday, Matthews altogether made 698 appearances in the Football League for 71 goals, and played 54 full internationals for Englands for 11 goals. In 1963, he had the great satisfaction of helping Stoke City regain the 1st Division.

A period as manager of Port Vale, after Stoke had rather sullenly parted company with him, reducing his wages and refusing him complimentary tickets, was ill-starred. The club fell foul of regulations concerning the signing of young players and Matthews was unfairly found culpable.

He went on to live in Malta, where he played for the Hibernians team at 55, and to coach widely abroad, especially in South Africa, where he had first worked in 1954, and in Canada. He was known in Soweto as "the white man with a black man's face".

fields.headline: Republic of Ireland 3 - 2 Czech Republic
fields.trailText:
Republic of Ireland: A. Kelly, G. Kelly, Harte, Butler, Cunningham, R. Keane, Kennedy, Kinsella, Quinn, R. Keane, Kilbane.
Substitutes: McAteer, Connolly, Staunton, Babb, Kiely, Breen, Carr, Finnan, Holland.
Czech Republic: Maier, T. Repka, Rada, Nedved, Gabriel, Bejbl, Nemec, Poborsky, Kollar, Smicer, Berger.
Substitutes: Latal, Rosicky, Suchoparek, Horvath, Cerny, Kuka, Wagner.
fields.body:
Republic of Ireland: A. Kelly, G. Kelly, Harte, Butler, Cunningham, R. Keane, Kennedy, Kinsella, Quinn, R. Keane, Kilbane.
Substitutes: McAteer, Connolly, Staunton, Babb, Kiely, Breen, Carr, Finnan, Holland. Czech Republic: Maier, T. Repka, Rada, Nedved, Gabriel, Bejbl, Nemec, Poborsky, Kollar, Smicer, Berger.
Substitutes: Latal, Rosicky, Suchoparek, Horvath, Cerny, Kuka, Wagner.

1 min Kick off in an intriguing friendly between the second-best team in the world according to the most recent FIFA rankings and a Republic of Ireland team unbeaten at home since 1995. An attacking Irish line-up features the left foot of Ian Harte at left-back in favour of Staunton, who warms the bench. Both sides were saturated by the rain lashing Lansdowne Road within moments of emerging onto the pitch.
2 Cunningham in hard but seemingly fair with a high-velocity sliding tackle. The referee informs him that he wants to see none of that during this game and awards a free kick to the visitors. Even Berger looks puzzled with that decision.
3 An early scare for the Irish as Butler is skinned by Kollar by a through-ball on the right flank as the remainder of the Irish defence appeal for offside. Butler recovers well to force a corner.
4 GOAL Republic of Ireland 0 - 1 Czech Republic Horrible defending from the home team as Kollar gets two chances to roof the ball into the Irish net from 10 yards at the far post. Accusing glances all long the Irish back four as the distant Harte tries to avoid making eye contact with any of the 30,000 spectators. A bad, bad start.
8 Kinsella feeds Roy Keane from the centre circle and the United captain advances and tries his luck from 25 yards. His luck's out and the ball barely makes the dead ball line. Goal kick.
11 Ireland are trying to be a little too cute and walk it out of their defence. The Czech's are proving too good a side to disrespect like that and the visitors are winning back possession with alarming regularity.
12 Again Kollar races through the Irish offside trap, seemingly by osmosis and Gary Kelly saves Ireland's blushes with a timely interception.
16 GOAL Republic of Ireland 1 - 1 Czech Republic Two corners, two goals. An excellent, inswinging corner hit with pace delivered by Kennedy on the right is deflected off the head of Karel Rada and past Maier for an own goal.
18 The Irish are reinvigorated. A free kick on the left is played quickly to Harte, who likes to hit them from distance with his left peg. The contact is not so good, put the shot is well placed and Maier does well to hang on as Quinn and Robbie Keane are ready to pounce should Maier fail to hold on.
20 The home side break again, this time on the right flank through Kennedy, who races into the Czech box. His centre is played out by Rada as far as Quinn, who from 15 yards chests the ball to control it, but can only spoon his shot over the crossbar.
23 Robbie Keane and Poborsky are 'enjoying' a personal battle of wills on the left wing. So far the Coventry forward's changes of pace have yet to shake off Poborsky's attentions.
26 Poborsky reminds the Irish not to push up too far as he runs the length of the pitch, beating and/or holding off three, four Irish defenders only to shoot wide from just inside the box.
27 So far an excellent friendly - relentless end-to-end stuff. A corner to Ireland, taken short but poorly thought out and the advantage is lost. Ian Harte miss-times a tackle and is booked.
30 So close to two-one. Robbie Keane runs on to a great flick from Niall Quinn but Maier does everything right to deny the young striker. The Czech keeper enjoys the luck of the Irish as the rebound falls to Repka, who clears.
33 The Czechs counter again, this time from Smicer on the right. He jinks and cuts back and jinks again, all to no avail as he loses possession in the Irish penalty area.
35 GOAL Republic of Ireland 1 - 2 Czech Republic A beautiful, simple goal made all the more simple due to the lack of any meaningful marking by the home side. Berger spreads the play out right to Poborsky with the outside of his boot. His cross is met with power by Kollar and Kelly has no chance. Ireland playing catch-up once more.
39 Czech possession results in a Kollar knock-down on the edge of the Irish area to Smicer. His volley is a poor one and leaves the field at a tangent to the Irish goal.
42 Kennedy beats Gabriel but Rada cuts out his cross for a corner. The inswinger is a good one but Repka manages to clear.
43 GOAL Republic of Ireland 2 - 2 Czech Republic The ball is eventually played back in by Gary Kelly and what looks like a simple catch for Maier becomes impossible as Kollar challenges his own keeper for the ball. It sails past both of them and into the path of Ian Harte, who cannot miss from 10 yards into an empty net.
46 Half time in a very entertaining match. It's even stopped raining.

45 Here's hoping the second half is as full of incident as the first. Ireland restart the match.
45 Republic of Ireland substitution: McAteer for Butler; Babb for Kennedy.
48 Ireland playing with the wind this half. Ian Harte overhits a pass by 30 yards and it sails out of play. Goal kick.
50 Phil Babb's first contribution is a cross from deep that Quinn just fails to knock down. An optimistic start to the second half by the home side.
52 The tenacious Kilbane wins a corner on the right. Kinsella delivers and football pinball ensues in a crowded Czech box. The ball emerges and heads goalwards. Nedved clears from off, or perhaps behind his own goal line and as the Irish players appeal the ball is played back in but Maier is fouled and play breaks down. The Czechs are lucky to not be trailing for the first time in this match.
56 Czech Republic substitution: Wagner for Smicer.
57 Robbie Keane is played through on the right flank by his namesake Roy. Once again, he uses his great pace and once again he loses the ball. He does that a lot.
59 Maier hates it when Kinsella crosses. A corner to Ireland and Maier comes for it, fumbles and can only lie on the floor and watch as his defenders get him out of yet another fine mess.
61 Czech Republic substitution: Latal for Nemec.
63 Kilbane does all the hard work on the left, beating three players and then crosses the ball over Quinn, Maier and the crossbar.
66 Some head tennis in the Czech area ends with the ball in the net, but the ref's whistle had halted play just moments prior to Roy Keane crashing the ball into the goal.
69 Czech Republic substitution: Kuka for Kollar.
70 Kilbane again on the right, beating his man and choosing to ignore the waving arms of Robbie Keane and Niall Quinn, strikes a weak shot wide of Maier's right-hand post.
71 Once more it's that man Kilbane, who chooses to cross to Robbie Keane. He wins his header over the penalty spot, but his direction is poor. Goal kick.
72 Czech Republic substitution: Horvath for Berger.
74 The Czechs break through the middle and are impeded by Babb. The free kick is taken and the visitors play it around but with no real purpose.
77 Kelly in the Irish goal is forced to advance and close down Nedved, who is played in behind the Irish defence. His first touch was great but his second not so and Gary Kelly can clear.
80 McAteer meets a cross and cushions his header for the advancing Nedved, but the Czech is too surprised by this random act of kindness.
82 Czech Republic substitution: Rosicky for Nedved.
83 Republic of Ireland substitution: Staunton for Kilbane.

Butler recovers well to force a corner. 4 GOAL Republic of Ireland 0 - 1 Czech Republic Horrible defending from the home team as Kollar gets two chances to roof the ball into the Irish net from 10 yards at the far post. webTitle: Football legend Stanley Matthews dies at 85

fields.headline: Football legend Stanley Matthews dies at 85
fields.standfirst:
Obituary: Sir Stanley Matthews
<A HREF="http://www.footballunlimited.co.uk"Football Unlimited
fields.trailText: Sir Stanley Matthews, one of England's greatest players and twice European footballer of the year, has died aged 85.
fields.body:
Sir Stanley Matthews, one of England's greatest players and twice European footballer of the year, has died aged 85.

Matthews, who turned professional with Stoke aged 17, was capped 54 times for England and made 710 Football League appearances for Stoke and Blackpool.

Knighted in 1965, Matthews made his last Football League appearance in the same year at the record-breaking age of 50 years and five days. In his retirement, Matthews became an ambassador for football and received a FIFA Gold Merit Order in 1992.

Sir Stanley died at North Staffordshire Nuffield Hospital following a short illness, the hospital said.

A spokesman for the private hospital in Newcastle under Lyme said: "Sir Stanley Matthews died peacefully this evening after a short illness related to health problems that had first seriously affected him three years ago. "We have no further statement at this time."

It is understood Sir Stanley may have had an accident of some sort on the island of Tenerife before being flown to the Nuffield for treatment. A spokesman for Stoke City football club said the former star regularly went to Tenerife to escape the British winter. The spokesman said that he understood Sir Stanley had gone to the island in the Canaries in December last year and had been due back some time now.

Matthews made his international debut at the age of 19 and collected his last cap in 1956 when, aged 41, he mesmerised the Brazilian defence in England's 4-2 win at Wembley.

Matthews spent his 33-year league career with two unfashionable north of England clubs, Stoke City and Blackpool. But he won 54 international caps and was the first man to be named European footballer of the year. He won the affection of football fans throughout the world who marvelled at the right-winger's ability to ghost past defenders.

Matthews' rewrote many record books with his feats but his shining moment came in the 1953 FA Cup final. Twice a losing finalist with Blackpool in 1948 and 1951, Matthews stood 20 minutes away from a third defeat with his team 3-1 down to Bolton. Then his dazzling footwork carved out the last two goals of a hat-trick for Stan Mortensen, and Matthews went on to set up the winner for Bill Perry with 20 seconds left. Despite Mortensen's treble it was a game which would always be remembered as "the Matthews final".

Matthews was born in Hanley on February 1 1915, the third of four sons. He joined Stoke in 1929 at the age of 14 as an apprentice and spent his time cleaning boots and sweeping out the dressing rooms. Within five years, Matthews won his first England cap against Wales while still a teenager. And in 1937 he hit his only international hat-trick in a 5-4 win over Czechoslovakia.

At Matthews' 80th birthday celebrations, former England captain Jimmy Armfield praised his skills and sportsmanship. "You could kick him and do anything with him and he would never retaliate," said Armfield. "He was the perfect example of self-discipline. I never remember a referee speaking to him once - and he didn't speak to them either."

Matthews, known as 'the Wizard of the Dribble', was a crowd-pleaser to generations and tempted a British record crowd, 149,547, to Hampden Park in Glasgow. But he never earned more than £50 a week, plus £25-a-game bonus. Lord Wilson of Rievaulx, who was Prime Minister when Matthews was knighted, wrote in a foreword to his autobiography: "Stanley Matthews was a symbol of the country which gave football to the world, and internationally a symbol of English sportsmanship in the days when that was a quality acknowledged worldwide."

Sir Tom Finney led the tributes to Matthews tonight. England team-mate Sir Tom said: "I've so many memories of Stan and he was the greatest in my era in terms of close control.

"In those days you weren't expected to go back and tackle and his game was attacking the full-back.

"He was a humble man and he never got carried away by how well he played."

Former England manager Sir Walter Winterbottom said: "Stan was very fit and one thing he had was that he was very quick off the mark.

"Wingers in those days just stayed on the wing and Stan had that unique way of dribbling past people."

Tonight, Newcastle boss Bobby Robson, speaking at Wembley ahead of the England friendly against Argentina, said: "He was one of, easily, our greatest, greatest players.

"He would have played in today's game, he would have adapted - don't you worry about that.

"He had immense skill - great skill off the ball, a beautiful dribbler. I'm very sad at the news."

David Davies, executive director of the Football Association, described Matthews as "a legend who did not disappoint."

Speaking on his arrival at Wembley for tonight's England game, Davies said: "He was a great, great player. As a child I was thrilled when I watched him. I knew then he was a legend and I was lucky later in life to meet him and unlike some legends he did not disappoint when you met him.

"He was a great ambassador and served football all over the world long after many players have packed it in. Our country should be very proud of him and very sad tonight."

Asked if the new Wembley Stadium might include a monument in memory of Matthews, Davies said: "He will be remembered in a proper way - he was a legend worldwide."

webTitle: A horrible, crushing grief swamped the room

fields.headline: A horrible, crushing grief swamped the room
fields.standfirst: Paul Kelso, who attended the inquest into the Paddington train crash, describes the scene at Westminster council chambers
fields.trailText: For the families and friends of the 31 people killed in the Paddington train crash, the inquest, adjourned today in unique circumstances, was more than an initial step on the road to justice for those they lost on that crisp autumn morning last October.
fields.body:
For the families and friends of the 31 people killed in the Paddington train crash, the inquest, adjourned today in unique circumstances, was more than an initial step on the road to justice for those they lost on that crisp autumn morning last October.

It was clear that the inquest was part of the grieving process. Solicitor Louise Christian, who is acting for the bereaved relatives, said the hearing had been "an intensely personal and private experience for all the families".

For those gathered at Westminster council chambers, this was the first chance to hear details of their loved ones' last moments, a chance to find out exactly how they died, to lay that little piece of memory to rest.

Throughout the three-day hearing, against the background of the plodding formalities of legal process, heartbreaking details emerged of the lives lost. Systematically, under the sympathetic guidance of Westminster coroner Dr Paul Knapman, we moved through a list of the deceased projected on to a giant screen. In front of it, dominating the centre of the chamber, was a scale model of the final position of the two trains.

The inquest into each victim followed a strict routine. First a coroner's officer revealed how the victim had been identified. Only one body was identifiable without recourse to dental records or DNA testing. The grim implications of this fact - that fire and mutilation had rendered 30 bodies unrecognisable - remained unsaid but cast a shadow over all that followed.

The officer then provided brief biographical details of the deceased, sometimes reading a tribute from the victim's family. So we heard how Robert Cotton, a caretaker from Dursley in Gloucestershire and a stalwart of the community, had telephoned his wife 40 minutes before the crash to make sure she was awake in time for work. We heard that Fiona Grey, 33, had moved from Dumbarton in Scotland to start a new job in London just two days before the accident. And we heard how John Raisin, the oldest victim at 61, had walked from the buffet car of the Great Western train to the front carriage in order to be first through the barriers at Paddington. He had made the same journey every week for 25 years.

There were 28 other tragic tales, a carriage-load of talented, mainly young victims, killed in an accident their relatives believe could have been avoided.

On the benches where the families sat handkerchiefs were gripped tighter, lips bitten, tears shed and a horrible, crushing grief swamped the room.

Next, Detective Superintendent Patrick Bracken of British transport police gave evidence. Referring to diagrams projected on to the screen, DS Bracken revealed where each victim was believed to have been sitting at the moment of impact, and from where they had been recovered.

Finally a pathologist stepped forward and Dr Knapman asked the cause of death, which varied from multiple injuries to asphyxia. Dr Knapman's final question concerned the speed of death. Did they die instantaneously, he asked? For those families who heard the answer "yes", there is at least a little solace.

webTitle: 'I was a prodigy - the thing I've got is like Mozart'

fields.headline: 'I was a prodigy - the thing I've got is like Mozart'
fields.standfirst:
Michael Moorcock, outrageous chronicler of 60s London, is producing some of his best work yet. Nick Hasted meets him

Books Unlimited
fields.trailText: Michael Moorcock, outrageous chronicler of 60s London, is producing some of his best work yet. Nick Hasted meets him
fields.body:
Michael Moorcock's choice of residence on his brief return from Texas to London takes the visitor down an innocuous tributary of Baker Street, through iron gates and into a forgotten warren of genteel old flats where the 60-year-old writer sits waiting, a sputtering, gurgling volcano of outspoken opinion and anecdotage, a breathing history of London's cultural life. Dennis Potter? "Loathed him since the beginning of his career, glad he's dead. Made a big fuss about it too." JG Ballard? "I told Jimmy not to take that acid, he was barmy enough." Martin Amis? "Appalling self-pity." John Lydon? "Self-publicising wanker."

Moorcock's books, going on for 100 of them, have gushed out at similar velocity. There are the dozens of fantasy novels, including the Elric series which made his name; there is the prize-winning Cornelius Quartet (1966-77), whose polysexual dandy-nihilist hero Jerry Cornelius shared Moorcock's own Notting Hill home of the era, turning that quarter of London into a mythical zone for decades of bohemians. And then, there's Mother London (1988), his time-chopping tribute to his city from the Blitz to Thatcher, and his Colonel Pyat quartet, thousands of pages long, still unfinished, a digging into the Holocaust's roots. And King of the City, his new London novel, out on CD next month. And he was in Hawkwind. And played banjo for Brian Eno. "It's like grabbing Dickens by the coat-tails," fellow urban diviner Iain Sinclair reported, after trailing him last year. "English fiction's Lord of Misrule," declared Angela Carter.

"I was an infant prodigy," Moorcock breezily admits. "It's just one of those things. I was known as a smart kid from the time I could walk. Looking back, I can see why people were so nice to me. I've got teenage correspondence that goes from Woody Guthrie to Tolkien to Peake. I now realise not everyone is treated this way. I was just very confident. I'd written a social novel by the time I was 17, it was easy. The thing I've got, it's like Mozart - I can read an example of a genre, and once I've picked up what's in it, I know it. What I can do is put structures together, as easy as pie."

Moorcock's artistic proving ground was New Worlds, the science fiction magazine he edited from 1964 to 1971. He published the genre's key experimenters - JG Ballard, Brian Aldiss, M John Harrison and more. But he wasn't interested in the genre for its own sake, and sought instead "an idiom that dealt with our experience" - a response to changing times. There were fist-fights in the office over artistic principle.

"I had to be a barmy despot for it to work," he remembers, "but it stopped me growing up. It froze me. I'd always had a lot of power, since I was a child, but I didn't understand it. It was only after my second marriage collapsed that I looked back and recognised I'd been careering, going too fast. I looked after my kids at the same time, I loved them. I don't think my relationships with them suffered very much. They may have a different idea of it. But in terms of personal relationships, it was disastrous."

Once, though, things were different. "The year George Melly moved into Notting Hill, 1980, I moved out," says Moorcock, "because there were already too many pine shops. "I can do lyrical loss at the drop of a hat," says Moorcock. "It's natural to me. My childhood was in the Blitz. Then it gets built over, and you've lost a whole world. I form very loyal friendships, too, perhaps because I know I may lose them. Existentialism and entropy were in the air when I was young, as well. All my early Elrics are like fantasies by Camus." Moorcock's celebrity survived into punk, but by the time of Thatcher, the game was really up. "Thatcherism made the language of liberal humanism sound silly," he sighs. "In the 70s, if I said something, generally it got reported. With Thatcherism, I learned how rapidly the rhetoric shifts. As early as 1978, when a poet friend called Bill Butler died of an overdose, his funeral was like a Spanish Civil War veteran's. I'd never seen so many Afghan coats. The sense of being marginalised, defeated revolutionaries was very strong."

Still, when the power drained from him, Moorcock grew up at last. With his third wife Linda, he moved to Texas. He also wrote his most extraordinary work, the "memoirs" of Colonel Pyat, full of fantastic sights from adventures in the years 1900-40, narrated by a self-deceiving, Jewish anti-Semite. Byzantium Endures, The Laughter of Carthage and Jerusalem Commands (1981-92) now await a final volume. "It's just so horrible getting into his head," Moorcock explains. "It's something my wife doesn't want me to do, and I don't, because you start to become this awful character. But it's the only way. What I wanted to do was to get inside the sort of person who was my natural enemy - I'm part-Jewish. The last book is nearly finished. I know it sounds pious, but it does feel like a holy subject to me, and it's something I have to be careful with. I don't want to pick over the bones of the dead. I'm actually trying to produce a memorial." Meanwhile with his newest book, another London love song, King Michael makes it clear that he isn't stepping down yet. "All I know is," he says, "is that I was given a bit of talent. I had nothing to do with that, it's a gift. So I'll push it as far as I can."

fields.headline: Paddington crash inquest adjourned
fields.trailText: The inquest into the deaths of the 31 people killed in last year's Paddington train crash was adjourned today in unprecedented circumstances.
fields.body:
The inquest into the deaths of the 31 people killed in last year's Paddington train crash was adjourned today in unprecedented circumstances.

After hearing evidence on the third day of the inquest at Westminster council chambers, coroner Paul Knapman adjourned the hearing at the request of the lord chancellor, Lord Irvine of Lairg, pending the conclusion of a public inquiry into the accident by Lord Cullen.

Under an amendment to the access to justice act passed in January and being used for the first time, the jury was dismissed without being required to reach a verdict.

The specific purpose of the inquest was to allow the deaths of the victims to be registered, but it was felt in this case that it would be of use to the families to hear some details of their loved ones' deaths. The lord chancellor is empowered to halt such an inquest at any time.

Speaking after the adjournment Louise Christian, who heads the crash victims' solicitors group, welcomed the decision: "It has been good for families to come and hear the circumstances in which their loved ones died, and we're grateful to the coroner for allowing them that opportunity."

She added that Dr Knapman should consider resuming the inquest after the Cullen inquiry had reported: "I believe a number of my clients will want the inquest to resume, particularly if they feel... a verdict of, for example, unlawful killing would be appropriate."

It is thought unlikely the inquest will be resumed, though legislation does allow the coroner to reconvene the hearing "if he believes there is exceptional reason for doing so".

The legislation, specific to major accidents where a public inquiry is due to be convened, was introduced to stop the duplication of evidence heard by inquests and inquiries and prevent delays. A jury was called in this case only because juries are currently compulsory in rail crash inquests.

The public inquiry into the 1997 Southall rail crash did not begin taking evidence until two years after the accident. Lord Cullen will begin to hear evidence in May. A criminal investigation by British Transport Police, Operation Brodie, is also under way.

Earlier the inquest heard details of the deaths of the final six victims of the crash, which happened shortly after 8.10am on the morning of October 5 when a three-carriage Thames train bound for Bedwyn, Wilts from Paddington collided with a First Great Western travelling in the opposite direction.

The Thames train was attempting to join the main line away from London and is believed to have passed through a red signal shortly before it crossed the path of the larger locomotive.

The jury heard that the driver of the Great Western train, Brian Cooper, 52, was thrown some distance from the train and died instantly from multiple injuries. A toxicology report confirmed that he had not taken drink or drugs before the crash.

It also emerged that one of the victims may have initially survived that collision, and died trapped in the wreckage. A post mortem examination on Allan Stewart, 28, an accountant raised in New Zealand, revealed that he had endured "a period of survival" of between one and 59 minutes after the accident.

The jury also heard details of the death of Fiona Grey, 33, an IT consultant from Dumbarton. She had started a new job in London two days before the accident. Ms Grey had been sitting in the front carriage of the Great Western train next to her new boss, with whom she was lodging in Didcot, Oxfordshire.

webTitle: Straw tells police to get on with eradicating racism

fields.headline: Straw tells police to get on with eradicating racism
fields.standfirst: Read the Macpherson report (Adobe format)
fields.trailText: Home secretary Jack Straw, delivering his first annual progress report on the action plan drawn up after  the Macpherson inquiry into the Stephen Lawrence affair, warned the police today to  stop grumbling and to keep working to eradicate institutional racism.
fields.body:
Home secretary Jack Straw, delivering his first annual progress report on the action plan drawn up after the Macpherson inquiry into the Stephen Lawrence affair, warned the police today to stop grumbling and to keep working to eradicate institutional racism.

He acknowledged that the report on the police handling of the inquiry into the murder of black teenager Stephen Lawrence had made uncomfortable reading. "But there is no reason for the report to have been a trauma for the police service. It was a shock."

Some officers have suggested that rising levels of street crime could be due to police not carrying out stop-and-searches for fear of being accused of racism. The Metropolitan force was described as "institutionally racist" by the report.

Mr Straw said he believed the report had opened people's eyes to the unequal treatment some people in Britain received simply because of the colour of their skin.

It also emerged today that a third of ethnic minority staff in the home office, Mr Straw's own department, say they have suffered racial discrimination at work, although the majority believe the department is committed to equal opportunities.

Mr Straw said he believed there had been a "significant reduction" in levels of racism experienced by people at the hands of public bodies.

The action plan progress report claimed more than half the recommendations made by Sir William had been implemented. Work was under way on the remainder.

Action taken included the introduction of the new race relations act, better recording and investigation of racist incidents and racism education programmes in schools.

The report said new policies to ensure stop and search powers were used more fairly and effectively were being drawn up, police were getting better training in race awareness and the recruitment of ethnic minority police officers was being stepped up.

Two of the most controversial proposals put forward by Sir William remained under consideration.

A conclusion on whether to scrap the double jeopardy rule which blocks the prosecution of someone twice for the same crime is not expected before early next year.

Additionally, a working party is still looking at whether to change the law to allow people to be prosecuted for using racist language in private.

Mr Straw stated his commitment to independent investigation of complaints against police officers, rather than the current practice of inquiries being carried out by fellow officers.

He said: "I am under no illusions that we have a long way to go. Full delivery of the action plan can only be a start on the road to delivering a truly multicultural Britain, not just free from the scourge of racism, but where diversity becomes a cornerstone of our modern society."

Fred Broughton, chairman of the Police Federation, commented: "The service has come a long way since Macpherson but knows there is further to go, with more mountains to climb."

The crown prosecution service also published details today of the progress it has made in meeting the report's recommendations.

Almost a year after the release of the report on the Stephen Lawrence inquiry, the director of public prosecutions, David Calvert-Smith, concluded that the service had achieved a "great deal".

However, he admitted that it "still had much to do", particularly in improving communications with victims of racist crime.

Under new plans, crown prosecution staff will offer to meet victims of racially-motivated crimes to explain its decision not to prosecute or to substantially alter charges. They will also receive extra training in handling such cases sensitively.

The service adopted the Macpherson report's new definition of a racist incident and renamed its monitoring unit accordingly.

Additionally, special care will be taken to ensure that any evidence of racist motivation for a crime is referred to during the trial and any pre-trial hearings to establish correct evidence.

Defendants will not be allowed to plea-bargain (submit a guilty plea in the hope of more lenient sentencing, which saves the court time) in order to conceal any racist elements of their crime.
