webTitle: Voters rate devolution a failure, says survey

fields.headline: Voters rate devolution a failure, says survey
fields.trailText: February 23 2000: Most British voters do not think devolution has been a success, according to the first countrywide opinion poll on the new political set-up.
fields.body:
Most British voters do not think devolution has been a success, according to the first countrywide opinion poll on the new political set-up.

The ICM survey found that 91% of people in Scotland, 88% of people in Wales and 65% of people in England believed that devolution, the government's flagship policy, had achieved little or nothing since it took effect.

Despite the dismay at the realities of home rule, however, a majority of voters across Britain felt what the devolved bodies in Cardiff and Edinburgh needed was more power, not less.

The survey comes after a traumatic few months for both the Welsh assembly and the Scottish parliament with the forced resignation of Alun Michael as first secretary in Wales, and growing concerns about first minister Donald Dewar's leadership in Scotland.

The poll, conducted for the Scotsman newspaper, found that only 37% of Scots felt the parliament had been good for them; 64% believed the body had achieved a little; and 27% believed it had achieved nothing. A total of 68% wanted to see more power in Scotland.

In Wales, where the assembly has more limited powers, 48% of voters believed nothing had been achieved, 40% believed only a little had been achieved, and 62% wanted more change.

webTitle: Women take lead in Welsh cabinet posts

fields.headline: Women take lead in Welsh cabinet posts
fields.trailText: February 23 2000: The Welsh cabinet yesterday became the first executive body in the western world to boast a majority of women ministers.
fields.body:
The Welsh cabinet yesterday became the first executive body in the western world to boast a majority of women ministers.

The appointment of a fifth woman to the nine-member cabinet was hailed as a milestone in equal opportunities by the new Labour first secretary, Rhodri Morgan.

Sue Essex, 54, was awarded the post of environment secretary as part of a minor reshuffle by Mr Morgan, joining the four existing female members of his Labour cabinet.

Tony Blair's cabinet, by contrast, contains only four women out of a total of 22 members, while men outnumber their female cabinet colleagues in every other European country.

Mr Morgan said: "Wales is now the only cabinet in any democratic country in the west with a majority of women in the cabinet.

"This is a small step for the Welsh cabinet but it's a giant leap for Welsh womankind. Wales has overtaken even the Scandinavian countries which have historically had more women in their governments."

However, he was at pains to stress that Ms Essex, who was also the first female leader of Cardiff city council, had been appointed "entirely on her own merits".

The remaining four female Welsh cabinet members - agriculture and rural economy sceretary Christine Gwyther; finance secretary Edwina Hart; health and social services sceretary Jane Hutt, and education secretary Rosemary Butler - were all appointed by Mr Morgan's predecessor, Alun Michael.

The traditionally male-dominated structure of Welsh politics made Wales an unlikely frontrunner for breaking the gender barrier.

But it was the twinning campaign at last May's assembly elections, which saw two constituency parties jointly selecting a male and a female candidate from a shortlist, then allocating one to fight each seat, which resulted in women making up 40% of the assembly, with 15 of the Labour group's 28 members being female.

Ms Essex, a university lecturer in planning, described her appointment as "staggering". She added: "It's wonderful. I think from the Labour party's point of view, we've broken the traditional glass ceiling."

webTitle: Xenophobic? The PFA deserves to be heard

fields.headline: Xenophobic? The PFA deserves to be heard
fields.standfirst: Worried that Dennis Wise is in the England team again? Then perhaps the PFA has a point about limits on foreign players
fields.trailText: Worried that Dennis Wise is in the England team again? Then perhaps the PFA has a point about limits on foreign players
fields.body:
Eyebrows were raised at some of Kevin Keegan's selections for the England squad to face Argentina, notably the callups for Paul Ince and Dennis Wise. Ince has been an invisible man at Middlesbrough for much of this season, Wise has been all too visible a presence, squaring up to opponents on and off the pitch. More to the point, he is 33.

Keegan's options are shrinking drastically - Wise himself is the only English player holding down a first team place at Chelsea - so it is little wonder that the England manager should have backed a recent proposal by the Professional Footballers Association that there should be legal limits placed on the number of players from outside the European Union permitted to play here.

The Bosman case, which centred around the aborted transfer of a Belgian player to a French club, ended the limits on foreign players within the European Union. webTitle: Party comes to an end for Royal Bank

fields.headline: Party comes to an end for Royal Bank
fields.trailText: NatWest shareholders are already sitting on paper losses of £5bn since backing Royal Bank of Scotland's takeover bid a week ago.
fields.body:
NatWest shareholders are already sitting on paper losses of £5bn since backing Royal Bank of Scotland's takeover bid a week ago.

After one of the hardest-fought and narrowly won takeover contests in recent years in the City, NatWest shareholders had, only two weeks ago, been able to command more than £14 a share for their shares, or £23.5bn in total.

But yesterday, after a continued slide in Royal Bank's shares, the offer was worth just £18bn and the equivalent of around £10.80 for each NatWest share.

In fact, the sorry state of the market saw NatWest's shares close at £10.40 yesterday, below the level they were when Bank of Scotland - later to lose the contest - launched its stunning bid in September.

Royal Bank shares also slumped to fresh lows, at one stage in the day crumbling to below £7, down from levels well above £14 late last year. It is this fall in the Scottish bank's share price that is hurting the value of its bid for NatWest, whose shareholders are accepting around £4 in cash but the rest in Royal Bank shares.

While this is bad news for NatWest's shareholders, it is far from pleasant news for Royal Bank's investors, who are now holding shares languishing at their lowest levels since the hedge fund crisis of two years ago.

It is Royal Bank's shareholders who now hold the key to the deal, having to support their board's offer to NatWest at an extraordinary general meeting on Monday. While the bank can easily explain the fall as a sector-wide problem - it is fair to say that all banks are suffering - it must involve some sleepless nights for the company's directors who this week are at a management love-in in Gleneagles.

The arbitrageurs, who have distorted the share prices during the takeover battle, might also be causing some damage to Royal Bank's shares too.

The two-week gap between NatWest's shareholders support the Royal Bank bid and the Royal Bank shareholder meeting on Monday had been cited as a potential window for a rival bidder to jump in and spoil the party.

webTitle: Savills' site targets home loan seekers

fields.headline: Savills' site targets home loan seekers
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Britain's second largest mortgage broker, Savills Private Finance, is aiming to write £600m a year in loan business over the internet with the launch next month of netmortgage.co.
fields.body:
Britain's second largest mortgage broker, Savills Private Finance, is aiming to write £600m a year in loan business over the internet with the launch next month of netmortgage.co.

The separately branded website is aimed at challenging the growing charcolonline business, which produces around £35m in loan applications a month for John Charcol.

Netmortgage.co will go live next month but the main advertising thrust will not begin until May. Mark Harris, director of Savills Private Finance, said: "We see it as something that could quickly grow to equal the current size of SPF, which broked £600m in residential mortgages last year. We have taken longer to get it up and running compared to charcolonline or e-loan, but we plan to deliver something with wider choice. We aim to have around 200 different lenders with mortgage products on the site."

Charcolonline launched only three months ago but is enjoying around 1m page impressions per month. Two weeks ago Bradford & Bingley paid £100m for John Charcol, citing its net business as the principal factor behind the deal. Savills Private Finance is a subsidiary of property consultancy FPD Savill.

Research this week by eloan.com, the biggest online mortgage lender in the world, revealed that 40% of British homebuyers would be prepared to arrange their mortgage through the internet.

webTitle: Endeavour back on Earth with 'crown jewel' radar images

fields.headline: Endeavour back on Earth with 'crown jewel' radar images
fields.trailText: Space shuttle Endeavour and its six astronauts have returned from an Earth-surveying mission that promises to yield the best maps ever of the world's peaks and valleys.
fields.body:
Space shuttle Endeavour and its six astronauts have returned from an Earth-surveying mission that promises to yield the best maps ever of the world's peaks and valleys.

Glinting orange and pink from the setting sun, the shuttle was visible in the sky a full four minutes before touchdown Tuesday.

"I guess we put on a fairly nice show where folks could see us from pretty far out," commander Kevin Kregel said after emerging from Endeavour. "It was even better from inside."

Gusty wind at the runway kept the astronauts up for an extra orbit and delayed their homecoming by 1 1/2 hours. During their 11-day flight, the astronauts worked in round-the-clock shifts to keep two large radar antennas running - one in the shuttle cargo bay and one on the end of a 197-foot mast. The method is expected to produce precise 3-D maps of Earth's topography.

The radar mapped 43.5 million square miles of Earth's terrain at least twice, just 2.5 million square miles shy of Nasa's original goal. The surveyed land stretched as far north as British Columbia and as far south as Cape Horn - representing three-quarters of the world's terrain.

A faulty thruster on the end of the radar mast forced the crew to use extra shuttle fuel to steady the mast, the longest rigid structure ever deployed in space. To save fuel, the astronauts had to cut short their mapping by 13 hours.

"I thought this mission was one of the most challenging, difficult missions we ever undertook," said Nasa Administrator Daniel Goldin.

"We deployed a 200-foot boom and held the tip to inches. The radar was a few thousand pounds. The technology was incredible."

Within three hours of touchdown, technicians had unloaded the 326 digital tapes containing the radar data. After several weeks of making copies of everything, the tapes will be flown to the Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, California.

Scientists will keep the originals in humidity- and temperature-controlled chambers.

"We're really going to baby these things, obviously, because they're our crown jewels," said Michael Kobrick, the laboratory scientist in charge of the project.

Nasa and its partner, the National Imagery and Mapping Agency, expect it will take one to two years to analyse all of the tapes. The astronauts collected nearly 12 terabytes of data, enough to fill 20,600 compact discs.

The best maps will be reserved for the military. The Pentagon will use the information to improve the aim of missiles and provide better navigation for fighter pilots and ground troops.

Everyone else - archaeologists, geologists, airline pilots, emergency relief groups - will have to settle for less precise charts. But even those will be better than current ones.

Next up for Nasa is an April ferry flight by space shuttle Atlantis to the fledgling international space station.

fields.standfirst: Full table of results
fields.trailText: One year on from the Macpherson report, the Guardian is conducting a survey of the 43 forces in England and Wales to find out what progress has been made.  We have taken our questions from data Her Majesty's Inspector of Constabulary asked forces to keep, as set out in Winning the Race, and recommendations by Sir William Macpherson himself.
fields.body:
One year on from the Macpherson report, the Guardian is conducting a survey of the 43 forces in England and Wales to find out what progress has been made. We have taken our questions from data Her Majesty's Inspector of Constabulary asked forces to keep, as set out in Winning the Race, and recommendations by Sir William Macpherson himself.

1. How many ethnic minority officers do you have now? And as a percentage of the total number of officers?

2. Do your force staff appraisal procedures test individuals' attitudes towards policing a diverse community?

3 Are managers within Divisional command units encouraged to provide effective, individual support to staff from ethnic minority backgrounds?

4. Are all your staff trained in racism awareness and valuing cultural diversity? (Recommendation 49 of the Macpherson report)

fields.headline: Spielberg turns down Harry Potter
fields.trailText: Steven Spielberg has said he will not direct an adaptation of the first Harry Potter story
fields.body:
Steven Spielberg has said he will not direct an adaptation of the first Harry Potter story.

The director, who is recovering from a recent operation to remove a kidney, said, "I have every certainty that the series of Harry Potter movies will be phenomenally successful. J.K. Rowling's vision of Harry Potter is modern genius. Warner Bros and (president) Alan Horn have been more than generous in the time they've allowed me to make a decision. However, at this time, my directorial interests are taking me in another direction. Most importantly, I look forward to reading the fourth Harry Potter book this summer and taking my family to see the first movie next summer."

Spielberg's long-awaited decision now opens the floodgates to a number of directors who have expressed an interest in the project. Warner Bros would not reveal who is on its list of potential directors, but industry insiders say that Brad Silberling, Jonathan Demme, Mike Newell, Rob Reiner and Tim Robbins are all after this plum job.

Top of Spielberg's list now is Minority Report with Tom Cruise, and A.I. based on a script idea by the late Stanley Kubrick. But, although Spielberg has made it known he wishes to make two films in quick succession, the notoriously coy director would be drawn on which one would come first.

fields.headline: A new role for off-spinners
fields.trailText: England and West Indies, two Test teams that are not what they once were, have both made new appointments in the past week. West Indies hired a new coach, England a new selector. Both appointees are former off-spinners Ð Roger Harper of West Indies, and Geoff Miller of England.
fields.body:
England and West Indies, two Test teams that are not what they once were, have both made new appointments in the past week. West Indies hired a new coach, England a new selector. Both appointees are former off-spinners Ð Roger Harper of West Indies, and Geoff Miller of England.

Finger spin hasn't loomed large in West Indies' attack since the days of Lance Gibbs in the 1970s. Nor has it done much for England in the past decade or so. Once in a blue moon, Phil Tufnell wins a match; more often the spinner is just there to tie down an end. It is a truth universally acknowledged that modern Test matches are won by fast bowlers and wrist spinners.

Coaching and selecting are, of course, very different things from playing. But even in the age of career coaches like Graham Ford and John Buchanan, great value is still attached to Test experience. It does help if this is, as the pros say, in the right area.

Tim de Lisle is editor of wisden.com and Wisden Cricket Monthly

fields.headline: Key anti-racist congress axed
fields.standfirst:
Auditors' report ends official rescue of CRE event

Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: A major international conference organised by the commission for racial equality and backed by Tony Blair, which was supposed to showcase Britain's anti-racist achievements, collapsed yesterday amid official allegations of inadequate financial and management control.
fields.body:
A major international conference organised by the commission for racial equality and backed by Tony Blair, which was supposed to showcase Britain's anti-racist achievements, collapsed yesterday amid official allegations of inadequate financial and management control.

The company set up by the CRE to organise the global cultural diversity congress in Cardiff next month went into liquidation on Monday when the home office refused to bail it out with a further £1.5m after a report by government accountants raised "serious questions about the quality of the management and financial controls in GCDC 2000 Ltd".

Despite claims that the organisers had "over 1,000 pre-registered delegates", fewer than 500 tickets were sold for a congress initially planned to attract 2,000. The congress also failed to attract the sponsorship it needed, despite being such a high profile event.

The collapse of the congress, which was co-hosted by the national assembly for Wales, the CRE and the Australian multicultural foundation, is particularly embarrassing for the government as it coincides with the first anniversary of the publication of the official inquiry report into the death of the murdered black London teenager Stephen Lawrence.

The congress was to be addressed by Jack Straw, the home secretary; Alun Michael, the former first secretary of the Welsh assembly; Sir Herman Ouseley, the outgoing chairman of the CRE; and Michael Mansfield, the civil rights lawyer, as part of the government's plans to demonstrate that "Britain is a beacon to the world" when it comes to race issues.

Nelson Mandela had been invited to speak and senior government ministers from Australia, China and Canada were due to address the four-day conference originally scheduled between March 20 and 23.

Among the directors of GCDC 2000 Ltd who may now face personal liability are its chairman, Bob Purkiss, a CRE commissioner; Hugh Harris, the acting chairman of the CRE; Chris Mayant, the CRE's chief press officer; Susie Parsons, the CRE's chief executive; Maggie Semple, director of education of the New Millenium Experience Co; and Richard Stone, chairman of the Lord Ashdown charitable trust.

The home office minister, Mike O'Brien, last night said that the government had made it clear from the beginning that it could not offer substantial financial support for the conference, but that the CRE had asked for extra money on January 11. The home office called in "forensic accountants" to examine the affairs of the company. They reported the serious problems and confirmed that a further £1.5m would be needed to enable the congress to go ahead.

"Given the report's findings, it would not be justifiable to use substantial public funds to support this event," Mr O'Brien said. He said he had asked the incoming chairman of the CRE, Gurbux Singh, to hold an urgent inquiry into what went wrong.

Mr Purkiss said last night: "With hindsight, the assumption that the event could be funded through a combination of private sponsorship and delegates' fees was unrealistic.

"I can understand why the home office was not prepared to allow substantial public funding to go into GCDC 2000 Ltd once the true state of the company's affairs were apparent to us all."

The prime minister, in an endorsement of the congress, had said he was heartened by "the opportunity that this congress will provide for Britain to share our unique achievements in this area with the rest of the world."

The initiative for the Cardiff event came from Sir Herman, who decided that it would be a good idea to bring the congress to Britain after attending its last meeting in Australia three years ago.

The international panel of speakers was to include the Australian minister for immigration and multicultural affairs, the Canadian secretary of state and the Chinese minister for ethnic affairs.

webTitle: Transplant chief loses job over racism row

fields.headline: Transplant chief loses job over racism row
fields.standfirst:
Inquiry fails to reassure doctors faced with organ donation crisis

Race issues in the UK: special report
Department of health inquiry into organ donation
British Organ Donor Society
British Transplantation Society
fields.trailText: Changes to the authority which oversees organ transplants and the early retirement of its chief executive were announced by the government yesterday, at the end of an inquiry into the acceptance of a organ donation with racist conditions attached.
fields.body:
Changes to the authority which oversees organ transplants and the early retirement of its chief executive were announced by the government yesterday, at the end of an inquiry into the acceptance of a organ donation with racist conditions attached.

Last June it was revealed the family of a Sheffield man who died in hospital had stipulated his organs be given only to somebody who was white, and his kidneys and liver had been transplanted accordingly. Frank Dobson, then health secretary, denounced what had happened as apartheid in the NHS, and announced a inquiry.

Yesterday it became clear that Robina Balderson, chief executive of the UK transplant support services authority, had paid the price of the uncertainty within her organisation over how to proceed in the Sheffield case. The health minister, Lord Hunt, said that she would continue in post "for a short time before we can make the necessary arrangements".

The authority would be re-organised and renamed UK Transplant. It would have a duty to "set, deliver and monitor transplant standards", said Lord Hunt, as well as a significant role in encouraging more people to donate organs.

"Racism of any kind is appalling. The government is totally against any kind of conditions being attached to organ donation. Donated organs are a national resource, and are available to people regardless of race, religion, age or other circumstance," he said.

Two reports were published yesterday - one investigating the incident, and the other a review of the authority. The latter's modernisation, recommended by the review, is partly a response to a crisis in organ donation: numbers of donated organs are going down, while numbers waiting for transplants steadily rise.

More than 5,000 people are waiting in the UK, but in the whole of last year there were 746 donors - the lack being partly due to the drop in road accident deaths and strokes.

The Royal College of Surgeons has been calling for action, but yesterday was far from satisfied with the reforms announced, questioning whether they would be sufficient. "In particular the college regrets that the opportunity has not been taken to announce a national transplant service to ensure a co-ordinated approach _ We still have a shortage of organs and a shortage of surgeons to transplant them." It was unclear how the new authority would set, deliver and maintain transplant standards, it said in a statement, while there was no strategy for designating transplant units in hospitals or recruiting more surgeons.

The British Medical Association also did not feel the changes went far enough, saying it would like consideration of presumed consent, where everybody would be deemed willing to give their organs unless they signed to opt out.

The authority said in a statement that it "relishes the challenges" ministers had set to improve rates of organ donation, and welcomed clarification of its roles and responsi bilities. On the Sheffield donation, it said: "With the benefit of hindsight, the authority's officers would have responded differently to this incident."

The investigation of the incident, chaired by the department of health's permanent secretary, Chris Kelly, noted that Mrs Balderson considered the authority as simply the "message handling bureau", and was willing for conditions to be passed to hospitals with patients in desperate need of transplants rather than lose a donated organ. She wrote to a Unison health trade union official: "We are merely passing on an expressed view of a family member." Her view was the department should set standards.

In the view of Mr Kelly's panel: "Where the incident should have been stopped was right at the beginning ... the co-ordinator should have refused to accept the offered organs." But there was no clear guidance to anyone involved on the right way to proceed. The report noted "inadequate recognition by almost everyone concerned of their obligations under the race relations act 1976", the conditions being "unacceptable" under that legislation as well as "abhorrent".

Donated organs are a national resource, and are available to people regardless of race, religion, age or other circumstance," he said. The latter's modernisation, recommended by the review, is partly a response to a crisis in organ donation: numbers of donated organs are going down, while numbers waiting for transplants steadily rise. fields.headline: How 'whites only' offer was accepted
fields.standfirst: Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: A man was admitted to the Northern General hospital in Sheffield last July in critical condition. His name and the circumstances have not been revealed.
fields.body:
A man was admitted to the Northern General hospital in Sheffield last July in critical condition. His name and the circumstances have not been revealed.

Brain stem testing established that he was dead, and his body was put on a life support machine. The hospital's transplant co-ordinator asked the family if they would agree to his organs being used to save other lives.

The family agreed in principle, but said the dead man would have wanted his organs to go only to white people. They signed a consent form for removal of heart, kidneys, lungs, liver and pancreas, with the note: "Family consent is conditional upon recipients being white (ie, not of ethnic origin)".

The man's liver was offered to a local transplant team. The surgeon, who had a white patient likely to die in 24 hours, accepted it.

After tests, the man's heart, lungs and pancreas were rejected for transplantation. The kidneys were removed, but because there was no suitable patient locally, the co-ordinator phoned the UK transplant support services authority to offer them elsewhere. The conversation was recorded.

The co-ordinator told the duty officer: "These organs cannot go to anyone who is not white" because the family "are adamant that is what they want". The duty officer said: "You've got to respect it, I suppose."

A worried duty officer and one who took over later phoned their manager at home. "If [the co-ordinator] completely guaranteed it to [the family] that that was the stipulation, I think you have to stick by it," the manager said.

The second duty officer (duty officer B in the report) should have offered the kidney to patients on the waiting list in order of priority - according to age, time on the list, tissue type and so on. Children go to the top of the list but need a kidney that is not too large.

Duty officer B worked his way down the list, ringing hospitals, but he skipped the third and fourth priority patients - both children with Asian-sounding names. He was embarrassed to tell the surgeon, who he believed was Asian, about the stipulation. But he offered the kidney to other patients with Asian names in units he knew would turn it down because of a policy not to accept an adult kidney for a child.

Eventually, a hospital accepted the kidney for a white patient, knowing the condition attached. A white patient was found locally for the other kidney. The report said that the racist condition made no difference to which lives were saved.

webTitle: Met boosts black and Asian intake

fields.headline: Met boosts black and Asian intake
fields.standfirst: Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: A record number of black and Asian officers are now working for the Metropolitan Police following a successful recruitment drive in the wake of the damning Macpherson report last year, the force announced yesterday.There has also been a massive surge in the number of racist incidents reported to the police, the number of racist crimes solved and signs that rank and file officers are regaining their confidence to use stop and search powers.
fields.body:
A record number of black and Asian officers are now working for the Metropolitan Police following a successful recruitment drive in the wake of the damning Macpherson report last year, the force announced yesterday.There has also been a massive surge in the number of racist incidents reported to the police, the number of racist crimes solved and signs that rank and file officers are regaining their confidence to use stop and search powers.

Sir John Stevens, the commissioner, said there was strong evidence the force had changed and "was not the same Met as 12 months ago".

"It has not been easy. It has taken some longer than others to face up to their responsibilities. We are determined to go beyond this and turn the Met into a truly anti-racist police service."

Last week in an interview with the Guardian to mark the anniversary of his report into the Stephen Lawrence murder inquiry, Sir William Macpherson said the Met had to stop "whining and complaining" and get on with restructuring and reforming.

Yesterday Sir John indicated he agreed. He said he was interested in being positive, and intended to give credit where credit was due.

Although the Met is still a long way off the ten year target for ethnic recruitment set by the Home Secretary Jack Straw last April, it has managed to take on 184 extra black and Asian officers since last year, bringing the total to 1049 - about four per cent of the workforce.

The increase came despite the swingeing criticism of the Met in the aftermath of the report and a crisis in overall recruitment. Last month the Met revealed that it needed to recruit 180 officers a month to keep up to strength, but recent figures were 108, 89 and 85.

Assistant commissioner Denis O'Connor and deputy assistant commissioner John Grieve, head of the Racial and Violent Crimes Task Force, described how the number of racial incidents reported to the police had shot up by 175 per cent to 17,660 since last year. The number of racially motivated crimes has risen by 188 per cent to 15,620 and the clear up rate for race crimes has soared by 198 per cent to 3,755.

Mr Grieve said the doommongers who predicted that ethnic minority communities would not trust the police enough to report race crimes had been proved wrong. "The figures have gone through the roof. People obviously have confidence in what we are trying to do."

Sir William made 70 recommendations in his report, and 39 were aimed directly at the Met. Sir John said 25 had been implemented already and the remainder were in hand.

"We've still a long way to go to fully regain the confidence of all Londoners. But we have taken a lead in this country in encouraging advice from our communities and closer scrutiny of everything we do."

The Monitoring Group, which helps race attack victims in west London, said the rise in racial incidents was due to a post-Macpherson "backlash", targeted mainly at refugees who had just arrived in the country.

Spokesman Suresh Grover added: "Victims are galvanised by the example set by the Lawrences, but they don't expect anything by going to the police. The increase in the figures is also because police are following the definition of a racial incident as laid down by Macpherson, which provides truer recording of the actual figure."

fields.headline: House prices rise - again
fields.standfirst:
More about house prices

The full report from the Land Registry (pdf)
fields.trailText: House prices in England and Wales are rising at their fastest annual rate since 1996, with one area of West London leaping up by £1,243 a week.
fields.body:
House prices in England and Wales are rising at their fastest annual rate since 1996, with one area of West London leaping up by £1,243 a week.

Figures released by the Land Registry show that the average house price in the final quarter of 1999 was up 15.2% on the same quarter of 1998. The volume of sales increased by 19% from 206,611 in the final quarter of 1998 to 245,876 in the final quarter of 1999.

The increase across the capital was 23% over 12 months with properties in Hammersmith and Fulham increasing by one third. Surprisingly, houses in the City lost value and have come down by -5.38%.

The figures show that London is the driving force behind the current property boom and that a north south divide exists in terms of house prices and purchasing power. The average house price in London is £157,624, almost four times the value of a house in Hull.

The Land Registry survey, which looks at England and Wales, shows that large numbers of people are moving from the north to the south - a move which is having a dramatic impact on the housing market. Some areas - such as Rutland and Middlesborough - England have seen a decline in house prices.

The latest signs of a surging housing market will raise fears of further interest rate hikes from the Bank of England's Monetary Policy Committee. The MPC has already voiced some concerns that rising house prices could fuel wider inflation.

Earlier this month it raised interest rates by 0.25% to 6% and City analysts are forecasting more rises later this year. However, the property industry is not sure that rate rises will be able to take the edge off the housing market.

Housebuilder Beazer Group said rate rises could take the heat out of areas such as London and south east England, where house prices have seen the highest increases. The company's chief executive John Low said that in general, the housing market was likely to remain strong this year. "We could see moves in interest rates up to 7% without any impact on the market," he said. "The market is extremely strong and consumer confidence is high - people still want to buy houses."

There has been speculation that Chancellor Gordon Brown may take steps in next month's Budget to calm the housing market without the need for interest rate hikes. The Financial Times reports on speculation that he could raise the stamp duty on house buying to help dampen the market.

webTitle: Dobson calls for 'common sense solution' on mailshots

fields.headline: Dobson calls for 'common sense solution' on mailshots
fields.trailText: Frank Dobson today suggested that the government should not give way to the Lords on the row over whether all candidates in the London mayoral race should be entitled to a free mailshot.
fields.body:
Frank Dobson today suggested that the government should not give way to the Lords on the row over whether all candidates in the London mayoral race should be entitled to a free mailshot.

Labour's official mayoral candidate told the government and the Lords to thrash out a "common sense solution" to the row, after the Lords last night defeated the government's plans for the May 4 election.

"I do not think most Londoners would want to spend 15 million quid on a mailshot," he said.

Ministers have warned that the Lords' amendment to the Greater London assembly bill could delay the election of a mayor and members of the new Greater London assembly.

While the government claimed it could cost £15m-£30m, there is speculation that the government has so far refused to countenance the free mailshot, partly because it would offer encouragement to Ken Livingstone to stand as an independent against Mr Dobson.

The current impasse is also believed to be preventing Mr Livingstone announcing any decision on whether or not he will join the mayoral race.

Liberal Democrat hopeful Susan Kramer called it another government "slip-up" in the election and said that in the votes for both the Scottish and Welsh devolved assemblies there had been a free mailing.

"I think Londoners deserve the same treatment as anyone in Scotland," she added.

Meanwhile, gay rights campaigner Peter Tatchell resigned from the Labour party in protest at what he called the "rigging" of the London mayoral selection, which elected Frank Dobson by a narrow margin on Sunday.

In a letter to prime minister Tony Blair, Mr Tatchell, the Labour candidate for Bermondsey in a 1983 byelection, said that after 22 years as a member he could no longer be in a party which "has contempt for democracy and its own members".

He added: "The rigging of the London mayoral candidate selection is the latest, unforgivable abuse of the democratic process.

"It follows similar gerrymandering in the selection of the Labour candidates for the Scottish and Welsh elections, and your plans to pack the House of Lords with unelected, unaccountable cronies and back-scratchers."

He added: "I have stuck with the Labour party through thick and thin over the last two decades.

"I bit my lip and stayed loyal through the progressive abandonment of socialist values and policies. But your subversion of democracy is one abuse too many. Respect for democracy is non-negotiable."

fields.headline: Denzel Washington and Norman Jewison
fields.standfirst:
• Listen to Denzel Washington on his choice of roles
• Listen to Norman Jewison on political pressure and The Hurricane
• Listen to Denzel Washington on racism in Hollywood
• Listen to Denzel Washington on anger
• Listen to Norman Jewison on Robert Kennedy
fields.trailText:
• Listen to Denzel Washington on his choice of roles
• Listen to Norman Jewison on political pressure and The Hurricane
• Listen to Denzel Washington on racism in Hollywood
• Listen to Denzel Washington on anger
• Listen to Norman Jewison on Robert Kennedy
fields.body:
TP: Now both our guests tonight are familiar with London. Norman Jewison and his wife Dixie lived here for 9 years. He even worked for the BBC - poor fellow - and Denzel Washington, whilst starring in For Queen and Country came to know the East End of London pretty well and even got a London accent before Gwyneth Paltrow! (Laughter). But tonight we're discussing The Hurricane, which is the life of a black man wrongly imprisoned and it is really the tale of his struggle for freedom. At the emotional heart of this film is the relationship between Rubin Carter and Lesra Martin. And I think it's current of course, we've had one or two interesting moments recently with heavy-weight champions in London [Mike Tyson's visit] but more importantly some of you will be aware of, amongst others, the M25 3 - young black men who've been imprisoned in this country for the last 11 years for a crime which certainly I believe they did not commit.

On my right, Denzel Washington one of Hollywood's leading leading men. He and I have met before - we met in Columbus, Ohio where he gave me my very first award for television but the reason I went to Columbus, Ohio to meet him was because at the same time he gave me a lot of late night pleasure, as it were (Laughter. Denzel Washington moves his chair away from Trevor Phillips). He was starring as Dr Philip Chandler in St Elsewhere, okay!

Amongst the many things that one can say about Denzel Washington - and we all know his filmography: the Oscar for Glory, Soldier's Story, Devil in a Blue Dress, and amongst his honours, including Best Actor a few days ago at the Berlin Film Festival (Applause), he has been voted the Sexiest Man Alive (Cheering).

Norman Jewison is one of Hollywood's master story tellers. He started as an actor but is now a director who has, in a sense, specialised in bringing to us important stories, humanising them and making them available to a mass audience.

NJ: Are you going to say anything about my sexiness? (Laughter. Applause)

TP: I spoke to your wife (Laughter)... and she said she would do me serious damage if I mentioned any of that, so...

TP: Denzel, you've created a particular screen persona which could probably best be described as 'noble' and I wonder how it now feels to have become an icon who has this particular persona which comes through in all of your films: a guy who is basically moral and good... Is that part of what you hoped to do as an actor?

DW: Well, it is acting after all (Laughter). People have asked me, "Do you do films to please certain groups of people, or are you concerned with what people will think, and has that influenced your choice of films?" And the answer's "No". I just do what I feel and what I like. I don't necessarily censor or feel an obligation to have a particular moral standard - I'm willing to wallow in the mud, if necessary. It appears as if there seems to be a consistency in result, but maybe that has as much to do with the roles I choose as it does with how I play them. I do what pleases me. I honestly believe, and I've said it many times, that the universal stems from the specific and I can't walk around with a performance and ask everyone how they feel about it, but if noble is an opinion that people have I'll accept that. I've been asked many times why I don't play bad guys, or heavies, and I would do it, absolutely, in a second, just haven't been offered any so...(Laughter) if anybody has a script out there tonight I'm more than willing.

TP: You tried to buy the rights to Hurricane. What was it that attracted you to this particular story?

DW: John Ketcham, one of the producers of the film, brought the book, The Sixteenth Round, to my attention. I thoroughly enjoyed it. I just thought it was a fascinating and - in the case of this film - an incomplete book. I flew to Toronto immediately. I met with Rubin and his Canadian friends and I was expecting to meet this very angry and bitter man. I didn't. I met this sweet, little guy who will tell you to this day that he wouldn't change a thing; that everything that has happened to him has made him a better person, and made him the person that he is today.

TP: I don't know how much this is you or how much this is the character but clearly we are on Rubin Carter's side from beginning to end. But in reality Rubin Carter is a real human being and there are unattractive sides to him, which to some extent come out in the film: he is vain, he is angry and you can imagine at some point - when he shuts himself off in the prison, when he doesn't deal with people - he will come over as arrogant and unpleasant. How did you feel about that side of him? Could you get that side of him across? Or did you feel it unnecessary to deal with that?

DW: No, absolutely. In fact I could use more and that's maybe for selfish reasons. In the arc of a character, in building a character, since he ends up here somewhere (indicates high) in a lofty position then I would want to wallow down here even more in order to highlight that. One of the things that I said to Rubin when we sat down and talked for a while - after I'd figured out how much he weighed and the fact that I could run faster than he could (Laughter) - I said to him, "Maybe you got exactly what you deserved" and he said, "I did". There's a line in the film: "Hate put me in prison and love got me out". Well, I don't believe that it's just the hatred that was sent his way from different forces - police, the judicial system, whatever - I felt and I told him quite honestly that I thought it was the hatred in his own heart which put him in the position that he was in. Once I'd opened my eyes and stopped worrying about getting hit, he said "You're right". He was a mean, angry person. He was also living in a time where when you spoke about what you believed as a black man in America in the mid 60s it could cost you your life, as it did Malcolm X and many others. He was very much under the eye of the FBI and other organisations and he knew that and those forces were very powerful, but for me the journey was a personal journey. It's the story of his mental, if you will, but definitely spiritual, evolution and that's the way I attacked the role; that's what I was interested in as an actor.

TP: The story of the black athlete, particularly the boxer, who emerges from the ghetto is not an unfamiliar one. The previous example of this the Jack Johnson story. To what extent did you draw on that in thinking about how you were going to portray Rubin, because physically you changed your stance completely but actually there was there quite a lot of difference in there from how you normally are on screen?

DW: This was a different opportunity. This is a film that starts off with a left-hook and an angry man who's willing to destroy anyone who gets near him. I didn't think so much about those people: we all have it in us. We've all had some level of injustice, whether 20 years in prison, or 20 minutes sitting in your car waiting for a police officer to determine your future. Or even a few moments in an elevator with some woman clutching her purse thinking you're going to rob her ¾ regardless of celebrity, that has happened to me, nothing like what has happened to him has happened to me but I can relate. I've seen examples of it. In fact, the reason I'm in America is the result of it, so I understand that racism, I understand that's how America was founded, I understand that that history and hatred is passed down from generation to generation. I understand especially now because I'm a father of two sons and two daughters, so I use those kinds of things to fuel my own fire. And then I spent a lot of time just talking with Rubin and he walked me through his past and how those agencies and individuals affected him in his life. So I just related to the experiences I had and draw from the experiences he told me about to try and shape the character.

I mean this is like a fairy tale, this is a miracle. Can you imagine? After I decided to direct the film I spent 4 or 5 hours with Rubin, we were walking in the woods and I was amazed, "Where's the anger, where's the angst, where's the rage? God, you were locked away for 19 years for something you didn't do, your career was ruined, your family destroyed, why aren't you angry?" and he said, "Rage only consumes the vessel which contains it". And I thought that's Buddha, that's Krishnamurti, this comes from years and years and years of submerging your own ego. I mean how many people do you get to meet who are like this? That's why he's so charismatic. I wish he was here tonight because he'd just amaze you with his understanding. He's a very spiritual person.

To what extent did you do that consciously - it's very striking that in this movie Rod Steiger appears. I mean, he only appears for ten minutes but interestingly to my reading of it he plays almost exactly the same role - not the same character - but he does the same thing in the movie in that he accepts that there has been an injustice because he stands for the idea of the American Constitution and that defence of the idea of justice and the Constitution allows him to overcome his natural, ingrained prejudice. And yet I think it has to be dealt with and I've often thought if I was African-American going into a courtroom and I looked up I think my worst nightmare would be to see Rod Steiger sitting on the bench! (Laughter). So I told Rod, "I think you're going to love this role" (Laughter) He says, "Well, I'm going to have to come in and save you again, kid!"

NJ: Well, actually there was quite a group of them. I've had trouble before, listen, I made a film called The Russians are Coming and I went to Moscow and they wouldn't let me back in the United States (Laughter) so I've been through all that!

He even worked for the BBC - poor fellow - and Denzel Washington, whilst starring in For Queen and Country came to know the East End of London pretty well and even got a London accent before Gwyneth Paltrow! (Laughter). But tonight we're discussing The Hurricane, which is the life of a black man wrongly imprisoned and it is really the tale of his struggle for freedom. At the emotional heart of this film is the relationship between Rubin Carter and Lesra Martin. HOW SKIVING STARS COULD EARN THEIR LYING STRIPES

Celestine Babayaro and Nwankwo Kanu have finally returned to Chelsea and Arsenal respectively. Both went AWOL for 10 days after Nigeria's traumatic penalty-shoot out defeat in the Africans Nations Cup final and both face fat fines of up to £50,000 from their clubs unless they can come up with more convincing alibis for their absence than "my Brooklyn's got gastro-enteritis". What can they try?

"Sorry gaffer, I've caught an exotic foreign disease." Oh dear, Babayaro's sister tried that one. Chelsea's assistant manager Gwyn Williams wasn't impressed: "He [Babayaro] hasn't got malaria, that is just rubbish. All I'll say is that he is fit and well and he is back in training today."

"Excuse me boss, but there was serious civil unrest in Nigeria and it wasn't safe for me to leave the jacuzzi." Babayaro's guardian attempted something along these lines and Kanu might feel it could work for him. David Beckham must be ruing the day he moved to Hertfordshire; if he had only set up home in Moss Side he could claim something similar.

"I had extremely bad diarrhoea for 10 days and couldn't get on a plane." It might work if Kanu or Babayaro's boss was Alex Ferguson, a man who understands more than most how bowel movements affect travel arrangements.

"I developed a sudden phobia of flying and had to travel from Lagos to the Isle of Dogs on a pedalo." This could be the winner for Kanu - after all, it gets Dennis Bergkamp several breaks a season.

LIVE AND KICKING

England v Argentina and Republic of Ireland v Czech Republic. Both are being covered live at http://www.footballunlimited.co.uk. OK, they're live on Sky as well, but this is much better.

A TURN FOR THE WORSE (AGAIN)

When things aren't going well, sometimes you have to hit the very bottom before you can turn things around. Take Celtic for example. Their nadir came when they were dumped out of the Scottish Cup by Inverness Caley Thistle, but since then they have won at Dundee - yes! - closed the gap on arch-rivals Rangers to eight points - alright! - made the League Cup final - woohoo! - and several sources have reported that star striker Mark Viduka is on his way to AC Milan ... oh well, it was looking good for a while.

According to the Daily Record, Vicenzo Morabito (who describes himself as a 'super-agent' - "Is it a bung? Is it a bag of used tenners under a table in a motorway service station? No, it's Super-agent!") is a mere couple of weeks away from completing an £8m transfer on Viduka's behalf to a large club in Italy. "A club have approached me about Mark but they do not want to be in the papers until there is something more concrete," prattled the all-action businessman. Luckily, he said nothing at all about web sites, so Teamtalk was free to confirm that the Celtic hitman will be off to the rossoneri sooner than you can say 'Luther Blissett'.

However, Viduka's adviser, IMG, has denied that any transfer will take place, and suggested that our comic-book character is simply chancing his arm. "We have never done business with Morabito and we never will," insisted IMG's Claes Elefalk. A disillusioned Fiver doesn't know what to believe now - things have come to a pretty pass if you can't take a super-agent at his word.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"Unless he knows something which is completely beyond our ken, he has picked an XI who would have a hard time beating Aston Villa, let alone Argentina." - Jeff Powell of the Daily Mail on Kelvin Koogan's England side. Worried yet?

GABRIEL GABS

They've been trying to sign him for years. So now that he's 31 (in striker's years, just about to tip over the top of a very steep hill) Gabriel Batistuta has declared that he wants to sign for Manchester United. Fergie must be chuffed that his club are being treated like Middlesbrough, eh?

"I really want to play for United because they are the best club in the world right now," said the Argentinian, in no way trying to annoy the hell out of world champions Corinthians from arch-rivals Brazil. "Besides being a very cool club," he continued, missing the point completely, "it would be nice to play in the Premiership and have the experience of English life."

Sounds promising for United - and it sounds like Batigol is indeed serious. "I'm taking English lessons," he proudly smiled, pushing out his chest. Well, then, you're halfway there, Gabriel. Now all you need to do is brush up on how to invade a referee's personal body space while making all the veins on your forehead bulge out and you're in.

THE RUMOUR MILL

Liverpool are interested in AEK Athens striker Demis Nikolaidis. Gerard Houllier wants the £5m-rated Greek international on loan until the end of the season.

Rangers have reportedly signed AZ Alkmaar's Dutch right-back Fernando Ricksen for £3m. But Opta Soccer claim that Coventry will launch a £3.5m counter-bid.

Arsenal are close to signing Marseille winger Robert Pires as replacement for Barca-bound Marc Overmars.

NEWS IN BRIEF

Paul Scholes has been voted England's player of the year for 1999 by the England Members' Club.

Jorge Cadete has finally joined Bradford after passing his medical. He should debut against Aston Villa at Valley Parade on Saturday.

Dundee United's Scottish Cup quarter-final against Inverness Caledonian Thistle or Aberdeen at Tannadice will be screened live on BBC Scotland on Sunday, March 12 at 3pm. BSkyB will screen the eagerly-anticipated clash between Rangers and Hearts at Ibrox, also on March 12, from 6.05pm.

Aberdeen have abandoned plans to enter the InterToto Cup this summer.

Former chairman Tony Hale has resigned from West Bromwich Albion's board.

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: International Football (11.30pm)

Highlights of England and Argentina presented by Des Lynam. Remember him?

Sky Sports 1: You're On Sky Sports! (11.15pm, 2.15am)

McCaff sits in a studio with his mouth gaping open. Lovely coffee is sucked in, unpleasant noise is pumped out.

Sky Sports 2: World Cup Classics (5.30pm)

Scotland play Holland in the 1978 World Cu... no, you're right, it's an England v Argentina clash.

International Football - Live (7pm, 12.15am)

A saucy love-in involving England and Argentina.

Sky Sports 3: International Football - Live (7pm)

Republic of Ireland v Czech Republic. Roy Keane will have no answer to the hard-tackling Liverpool duo of Patrik Berger and Vladimir Smicer, surely.

Premiership Classics (10pm)

Tottenham hero Teddy Sheringham makes Manchester United look very stupid. Seems a while back now, doesn't it?

British Eurosport: Football (9.30pm)

Holland play Germany. Nothing to see here.

Radio 5 Live: 5 Live Football (7pm)

"You call this a 22-man brawl? I don't."

David Mellor (10pm)

You call this informed football opinion? The Fiver doesn't.

Luckily, he said nothing at all about web sites, so Teamtalk was free to confirm that the Celtic hitman will be off to the rossoneri sooner than you can say 'Luther Blissett'. However, Viduka's adviser, IMG, has denied that any transfer will take place, and suggested that our comic-book character is simply chancing his arm. "We have never done business with Morabito and we never will," insisted IMG's Claes Elefalk. A disillusioned Fiver doesn't know what to believe now - things have come to a pretty pass if you can't take a super-agent at his word. QUOTE OF THE DAY "Unless he knows something which is completely beyond our ken, he has picked an XI who would have a hard time beating Aston Villa, let alone Argentina." - Jeff Powell of the Daily Mail on Kelvin Koogan's England side. Worried yet? GABRIEL GABS They've been trying to sign him for years. So now that he's 31 (in striker's years, just about to tip over the top of a very steep hill) Gabriel Batistuta has declared that he wants to sign for Manchester United. Fergie must be chuffed that his club are being treated like Middlesbrough, eh? "I really want to play for United because they are the best club in the world right now," said the Argentinian, in no way trying to annoy the hell out of world champions Corinthians from arch-rivals Brazil. "Besides being a very cool club," he continued, missing the point completely, "it would be nice to play in the Premiership and have the experience of English life." Sounds promising for United - and it sounds like Batigol is indeed serious. "I'm taking English lessons," he proudly smiled, pushing out his chest. Well, then, you're halfway there, Gabriel. Now all you need to do is brush up on how to invade a referee's personal body space while making all the veins on your forehead bulge out and you're in. THE RUMOUR MILL Liverpool are interested in AEK Athens striker Demis Nikolaidis. Gerard Houllier wants the £5m-rated Greek international on loan until the end of the season. Rangers have reportedly signed AZ Alkmaar's Dutch right-back Fernando Ricksen for £3m. But Opta Soccer claim that Coventry will launch a £3.5m counter-bid. Arsenal are close to signing Marseille winger Robert Pires as replacement for Barca-bound Marc Overmars. NEWS IN BRIEF Paul Scholes has been voted England's player of the year for 1999 by the England Members' Club. Jorge Cadete has finally joined Bradford after passing his medical. He should debut against Aston Villa at Valley Parade on Saturday. Dundee United's Scottish Cup quarter-final against Inverness Caledonian Thistle or Aberdeen at Tannadice will be screened live on BBC Scotland on Sunday, March 12 at 3pm. BSkyB will screen the eagerly-anticipated clash between Rangers and Hearts at Ibrox, also on March 12, from 6.05pm. Aberdeen have abandoned plans to enter the InterToto Cup this summer. Former chairman Tony Hale has resigned from West Bromwich Albion's board. TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO ITV: International Football (11.30pm) Highlights of England and Argentina presented by Des Lynam. Remember him? Sky Sports 1: You're On Sky Sports! (11.15pm, 2.15am) McCaff sits in a studio with his mouth gaping open. Lovely coffee is sucked in, unpleasant noise is pumped out. Sky Sports 2: World Cup Classics (5.30pm) Scotland play Holland in the 1978 World Cu... no, you're right, it's an England v Argentina clash. International Football - Live (7pm, 12.15am) A saucy love-in involving England and Argentina. Sky Sports 3: International Football - Live (7pm) Republic of Ireland v Czech Republic. Roy Keane will have no answer to the hard-tackling Liverpool duo of Patrik Berger and Vladimir Smicer, surely. Premiership Classics (10pm) Tottenham hero Teddy Sheringham makes Manchester United look very stupid. Seems a while back now, doesn't it? British Eurosport: Football (9.30pm) Holland play Germany. Nothing to see here. Radio 5 Live: 5 Live Football (7pm) "You call this a 22-man brawl? I don't." David Mellor (10pm) You call this informed football opinion? The Fiver doesn't.

fields.headline: Rail safety
fields.trailText: Why is rail safety back on the news agenda again?
fields.body:
Why is rail safety back on the news agenda again?

Transport secretary John Prescott announced a raft of changes to the industry but was met with protest after he decided to allow Railtrack to keep its safety role. The families of those who died in the Paddington rail crash have accused him of a u-turn and going back on his promise to strip Railtrack of safety responsibilities.

What is the current system of safety regulation?

The current rail safety system was adopted in 1994 on Health and Safety Commission advice. Central to it is a 'cascade' system of safety cases prepared by railway operators, which assess the risks of their operations and arrangements for managing those risks. Railtrack and its Safety Standards Directorate plays a pivotal role countering risks by operators.

What is wrong with the current system?

The department of the environment, transport and the regions said in its report into Railtrack's safety: "We were concerned that the current arrangements did not have sufficient clarity to provide assurance about the management of safety."

How will that change?

The government has landed the rail industry with a bill of almost £2.5bn to improve safety over the next decade. This will begin with the introduction of new safety controls in rail cabs. A cheaper, less sophisticated safety system will be introduced much to the consternation of many concerned about the future safety of the industry. The more expensive ATP system will not be introduced immediately. Instead, it will be TPWS.

What is ATP?

Automatic Train Protection is a fail-safe, computerised train safety system. Many trains in Europe have it and, in the UK, Eurostar and the Heathrow to Paddington express have it. It was installed on the train involved in the Southall rail crash but was not being operated. ATP has a good safety record. It uses radio beacons to warn if a train is approaching a danger signal and will apply the brakes if the driver has missed the warning. The Hidden inquiry recommended the introduction of ATP after the Clapham rail crash of 1988 which killed 35 people. But it is vastly more expensive than TPWS and successive governments have opposed it on cost.

What is TPWS?

The Train Protection Warning stops trains travelling at up to 70mph if a driver passes a red signal. It consists of sensors on the track and trains which apply the brakes automatically. Railtrack says speed traps will operate about 200 metres before a red signal, automatically stopping trains going at up to 60mph. The aim is to make it work at speeds of up to 75mph but this is well short of the fastest speeds reached on the network. TPWS is based on the old, outdated system and it does not work on trains travelling at more than 70mph. It will be installed at up to 40% of all signals and at key junctions and has been tested on some Thameslink and Connex services in the south-east. Development plans foresee it stopping trains up to 100mph.

Who will pay for TPWS?

Railtrack, responsible for track and signals, and the 25 train operating companies will bear the cost of installing TPWS, estimated by the health and safety executive to be between £130m and £155m. The industry reckons the overall cost will be between £200m and £260m.

How will Railtrack pay for it?

The money for the new safety system will have to come from increased subsidies and higher rail fares.

Will train drivers still go through red lights?

The industry has agreed that all incidents of drivers overshooting a red light should be investigated and judged to an industry-common standard. In 1998, there were 643 such incidents, an increase of 8% on the previous 12 months. Twenty-two signals had been passed at red more than five times in the previous eight years. Mr Prescott said this was "unacceptable" and has told the train companies that any driver passing a signal at red will be subject to compulsory retraining.

Britain is facing a series of one-day rail strikes. Why?

Members of the Rail Maritime and Transport Union have been voting on whether to take action in protest at changes to guards' responsibilities which were introduced last year. Union leaders, who are expecting a result in favour of strike action, say the changes will compromise passenger. Some union officials have complained that the guards' job would be reduced to one of a "KitKat seller". The industrial action would hit most of the country's train operators and would cripple rail services throughout Britain. The RMT executive will meet to decide its next move. It will have to give seven days' notice of any walk-out.

fields.headline: 160mph wind hits flooded Mozambique
fields.standfirst: The weather: special report
fields.trailText: Tropical cyclone Eline compounded Mozambique's misery after the worst floods in decades when it hit the port of Beira with winds of up to 160mph yesterday.
fields.body:
Tropical cyclone Eline compounded Mozambique's misery after the worst floods in decades when it hit the port of Beira with winds of up to 160mph yesterday.

As heavy rains and gales lashed the centre of the country, the United Nations warned that an outbreak of dysentery and other diseases brought on by the earlier flooding could now turn into a catastrophe.

The cyclone, which ripped roofs from homes and flattened traditional mud houses, follows torrential rains which swept much of southern Africa in recent weeks, carrying away whole neighbourhoods and leaving hundreds of thousands of people homeless.

More than 100 died in the flooding in Mozambique alone, some of them children. Roads and bridges were swept away, adding to the problems of coping with Eline.

The South African military has airlifted food by helicopter to communities near the capital, Maputo, because of flooded airstrips. But it had to suspend flights yesterday because of the weather.

Families in the Limpopo valley, north of Maputo, have little food and no drinking water, compounding the threat of cholera and diarrhoea. Floods also increase the incidence of malaria and, in some areas, have dislodged landmines left from the civil war which ended nine years ago.

The UN has called for emergency aid for 300,000 people. "We are talking at this stage of basic survival needs - food, shelter, clean water, sanitation and the infrastructure," said Katarina Toll Velasquez, leader of the UN emergency team.

"Then we are looking ahead at what is the biggest fear, the outbreak of health epidemics. We have been expecting health problems, and these have already started."

Britain has donated more than £500,000 and sent a disaster management team to work with the government and aid agencies. Other European countries and the US have provided emergency equipment and food.

The Mozambican government says a further 500,000 people have been affected by the floods. It estimates the damage done by the floods alone at millions of pounds.

The cyclone, which killed seven and left thousands homeless as it swept through the north of Madagascar on Friday, is expected to move on to Zimbabwe and South Africa, which have been devastated by some of the highest rainfalls in living memory. Both countries fear that the Limpopo river, their common border, could burst its banks.

South Africa closed the border with Botswana and abandoned the area yesterday. The chief immigration officer there, Anthony Wetener, said: "We initially thought we were safe but the water is steadily rising and will soon engulf the offices. We have decided to save what we can."

Large parts of Maputo's industrial suburb have been destroyed, and the railway to the port swept away, jeopardising the fastest economic growth rate in the world.

The weather has also hit Mozambique's burgeoning tourism industry, destroying facilities on the pristine coast.

fields.headline: Only halfway there
fields.standfirst: After presciently calling for the heads of Wasim Akram and Sachin Tendulkar in an earlier column, KAMRAN ABBASI argues that both Pakistan and India still need to find the right captain
fields.trailText: Easy rests the head that wears no crown. No thoughts of bowling changes, field placings, man-management, and that awful spectre of defeat. Wasim Akram and Sachin Tendulkar are now free to do what they do best: win matches with bat and ball. Resigning is never easy - it's an admission of personal failure. Why not hang on a little longer, it must be tempting to think, it might all turn rosy? But for these two, possibly the greatest players their nations have ever produced, it would not have been a happy outcome. Captaincy was ruining their joie de vivre and blunting their potency. It was brave, and right, of them to step down. It will add to their greatness, not diminish it.
fields.body:
Easy rests the head that wears no crown. No thoughts of bowling changes, field placings, man-management, and that awful spectre of defeat. Wasim Akram and Sachin Tendulkar are now free to do what they do best: win matches with bat and ball. Resigning is never easy - it's an admission of personal failure. Why not hang on a little longer, it must be tempting to think, it might all turn rosy? But for these two, possibly the greatest players their nations have ever produced, it would not have been a happy outcome. Captaincy was ruining their joie de vivre and blunting their potency. It was brave, and right, of them to step down. It will add to their greatness, not diminish it.

"We didn't do it," say the cricket boards. "Our star captains chose to go." This is truer of Sachin than Wasim, but at least they both managed to retain their dignity. The cult of the superstar Asian cricketer is such that captaincy is part of the inheritance. But great players too rarely make good captains; far better for them to inspire their teammates with deeds rather than words.

Already Wasim is transformed: once more a giant on the field, and no longer a shackled player and befuddled captain. The same will happen to Sachin, on home wickets and with the burden of captaincy to be lifted he will once more display the sweet science of batting.

But their resignations are only half the battle. There are few viable alternatives in this crucial phase of regeneration, and Pakistan have already got it wrong. Saeed Anwar will be crushed by the captaincy rather than emboldened by it. His last spell in charge was notable for negative tactics. Imran Khan even advised him to be more aggressive this time around. On sumptuous batting tracks Saeed responded by putting Sri Lanka in to bat in all three one-day games - and lost the lot. Not quite the positive signal that was needed.

Meanwhile his form is waning. A few exquisite boundaries followed by a catch to slip is his Goweresque routine. Saeed has enough on his mind rekindling his form without having to contend with captaincy pressures.

Pakistan's one hope is Moin Khan. Tenacious and astute, Moin has a habit of responding to adversity. If the target is World Cup 2003, then Moin must quickly take the reigns. Saeed's tenure is a mistake, and it won't last long. Until a credible captain is appointed the team will be treading water. That means it's time to go for you as well, Saeedi.

India have a different problem. Sachin's resignation was bizarrely timed, leaving him two Tests against South Africa. Was he expecting to lose? Was the Indian board too spineless to appoint a successor in time for the South Africa series? Whatever the reason, Sachin's decision renders the outcome of the series irrelevant in terms of the captaincy debate. It also exposes the lack of planning in the Indian board. Once Sachin decided to resign, he should have been immediately replaced as captain. The board, it seems, feels sentimental about its favourite son. If India beat South Africa there will be immense pressure on Sachin to stay on. He should still go. All that will have been learnt is that he can win when the heat is off. And it won't be off for long.

India's options for the captaincy are more varied than Pakistan's. At least four players could put forward a compelling case. But Azharuddin has had his day, and Jadeja is too unsure of his place. That leaves Ganguly and Dravid. Ganguly held his own in Australia while Dravid shrivelled. Like Moin, he is competitive and doesn't shirk a challenge. The captaincy should go to Calcutta.

India and Pakistan are in the position England were in last summer: at the depths and sinking deeper. How much defeat can be tolerated in the rebuilding phase before winning becomes imperative? The Asian cricket boards have a myopic habit of resting on their laurels when things are going well, and opting for wholesale change when confronted by disaster. Far more constructive to adopt Australia's method of inducting new players, and tinkering with team formation from a position of strength. And, most crucially, picking the right captain.

Kamran Abbasi, born in Lahore, brought up in Rotherham, is assistant editor of the British Medical Journal. His Anglo-Asian View appears every other Wednesday on Cricket Unlimited and wisden.com. Next Wednesday Orin Gordon returns with his Anglo-Caribbean View.
