fields.headline: The bogeyman comes to breakfast
fields.standfirst: The diary of a part-time father
fields.trailText: When we are a family of three, our days begin with two grown-up people walking downstairs with their eyes shut, and one very small person reversing downstairs on all fours gurgling pleasantly and emitting unsociable odours from her thickly padded rear.
fields.body:
When we are a family of three, our days begin with two grown-up people walking downstairs with their eyes shut, and one very small person reversing downstairs on all fours gurgling pleasantly and emitting unsociable odours from her thickly padded rear.

But when we are a family of six, our days begin quite differently. One of the grown-up people, my wife Angie, stays upstairs for a while with the small, gurgling, malodorous one, who is our daughter Estelle. The other grown-up person - me - runs up and down the stairs, in and out of the kitchen, and back and forth along the hall to ensure that the three intermediate-sized people who've doubled our numbers are a) getting ready for school, and b) having a better time doing it than they have at their "other home", where their mother Dilys takes exclusive charge of morning matters. This is so that their "other dad", as Chris the Pillock is now dutifully described, can devour for his breakfast the head of the crazed crocodile, rhinoceros or grizzly bear he wrestled the previous evening then ritually slaughtered out of a fellow warrior's respect for that spirit of the wild with which desert-booted, self-made IT consultants have such a powerful affinity.

You are now probably expecting me to say: "OK, I made that last bit up." And it had crossed my mind. But, frankly, the more the three intermediate-sized people, Gloria, Jed and Billy, let slip about the regime at their "other home", the more convinced I am that nothing can be ruled out. Also, I rather like the idea that Chris hides from the bad moods and mayhem that dominate beginnings to the days. It reaffirms my sometimes faltering faith that no matter how much Dilys tries to make things otherwise, Chris can never replicate the bond between Gloria, Jed, Billy and me, a bond that becomes so apparent first thing on weekdays as I scrabble about in my housecoat and fluffy slippers with a roll-up hanging from my bottom lip.

OK, I made that last bit up. But there's plenty to be said for sluttishness in a part-time dad when his place in the affection of his part-time kids is under threat. Empathy is the key, and my kids are the biggest sluts of all. Each has their own style. Gloria really works at hers. Fast approaching 12, she's discovered glitter nail paint and hair colour in a can, both of which she applies in hallucinogenic quantities as soon as she's awake. When she descends from her toxic boudoir she looks like the Maddest Tart in Trollop City.

And do you know what? I feel so proud! Of myself, you understand, for letting her go to school looking such a fright, especially in the knowledge that her mother doesn't allow it. I know this because Gloria disclosed as much to Angie, and Angie, being a good stepmum, immediately told me. Dilys says purple hair is "not appropriate". Not appropriate! Hah! All the more reason to encourage it! At least one of us knows where true parental duty lies. On the step the other day as she prepared to leave I said to Gloria: "Remember this, big daughter: you are not only the wittiest, cleverest, coolest girl in all the world but also the most beautiful."

"Thanks Dad, er Joe."

"Er Dad, will do," I smiled.

She smiled, too.

Meanwhile, Jed and Billy had been joined at breakfast by Estelle. Wedged into her usual precarious position between her two half-brothers, she stuck a finger in her Ready Brek, then stuck it up her nose. Then stuck it in her mouth. Then forgot about the Ready Brek and stuck it up her nose again. Then in her mouth again. I placed my hands upon my hips and affected indignation.

"Oi, Stell, please don't do that. Other people might want some too."

Jed and Billy looked at me, amazed. What was that I'd said?

"What about your brothers?" I continued. "If you eat all the snot there won't be any left for their bogey butties."

"Ugh, sick!" Billy squealed, clutching at his belly and rolling off his seat on to the floor.

"Ugh, sick!" echoed Jed, doing the same, more animated than he'd been for months.

Angie had to hurry off to work. I kissed her. I squeezed her. I told her that I totally adored her. Then I bundled Jed, Billy and Estelle out of the door. As we shambled down the street, the boys chattered on in awe of my performance in the kitchen.

"Bogey butties! Our dad is so disgusting!"

Their faces glowed with love.

Sometimes, life is sweet.
fields.bodyText: When we are a family of three, our days begin with two grown-up people walking downstairs with their eyes shut, and one very small person reversing downstairs on all fours gurgling pleasantly and emitting unsociable odours from her thickly padded rear. But when we are a family of six, our days begin quite differently. One of the grown-up people, my wife Angie, stays upstairs for a while with the small, gurgling, malodorous one, who is our daughter Estelle. The other grown-up person - me - runs up and down the stairs, in and out of the kitchen, and back and forth along the hall to ensure that the three intermediate-sized people who've doubled our numbers are a) getting ready for school, and b) having a better time doing it than they have at their "other home", where their mother Dilys takes exclusive charge of morning matters. This is so that their "other dad", as Chris the Pillock is now dutifully described, can devour for his breakfast the head of the crazed crocodile, rhinoceros or grizzly bear he wrestled the previous evening then ritually slaughtered out of a fellow warrior's respect for that spirit of the wild with which desert-booted, self-made IT consultants have such a powerful affinity. You are now probably expecting me to say: "OK, I made that last bit up." And it had crossed my mind. But, frankly, the more the three intermediate-sized people, Gloria, Jed and Billy, let slip about the regime at their "other home", the more convinced I am that nothing can be ruled out. Also, I rather like the idea that Chris hides from the bad moods and mayhem that dominate beginnings to the days. It reaffirms my sometimes faltering faith that no matter how much Dilys tries to make things otherwise, Chris can never replicate the bond between Gloria, Jed, Billy and me, a bond that becomes so apparent first thing on weekdays as I scrabble about in my housecoat and fluffy slippers with a roll-up hanging from my bottom lip. OK, I made that last bit up. But there's plenty to be said for sluttishness in a part-time dad when his place in the affection of his part-time kids is under threat. Empathy is the key, and my kids are the biggest sluts of all. Each has their own style. Gloria really works at hers. Fast approaching 12, she's discovered glitter nail paint and hair colour in a can, both of which she applies in hallucinogenic quantities as soon as she's awake. When she descends from her toxic boudoir she looks like the Maddest Tart in Trollop City. And do you know what? I feel so proud! Of myself, you understand, for letting her go to school looking such a fright, especially in the knowledge that her mother doesn't allow it. I know this because Gloria disclosed as much to Angie, and Angie, being a good stepmum, immediately told me. Dilys says purple hair is "not appropriate". Not appropriate! Hah! All the more reason to encourage it! At least one of us knows where true parental duty lies. On the step the other day as she prepared to leave I said to Gloria: "Remember this, big daughter: you are not only the wittiest, cleverest, coolest girl in all the world but also the most beautiful." "Thanks Dad, er Joe." "Er Dad, will do," I smiled. She smiled, too. Meanwhile, Jed and Billy had been joined at breakfast by Estelle. Wedged into her usual precarious position between her two half-brothers, she stuck a finger in her Ready Brek, then stuck it up her nose. Then stuck it in her mouth. Then forgot about the Ready Brek and stuck it up her nose again. Then in her mouth again. I placed my hands upon my hips and affected indignation. "Oi, Stell, please don't do that. Other people might want some too." Jed and Billy looked at me, amazed. What was that I'd said? "What about your brothers?" I continued. "If you eat all the snot there won't be any left for their bogey butties." "Ugh, sick!" Billy squealed, clutching at his belly and rolling off his seat on to the floor. "Ugh, sick!" echoed Jed, doing the same, more animated than he'd been for months. Angie had to hurry off to work. I kissed her. I squeezed her. I told her that I totally adored her. Then I bundled Jed, Billy and Estelle out of the door. As we shambled down the street, the boys chattered on in awe of my performance in the kitchen. "Bogey butties! Our dad is so disgusting!" Their faces glowed with love. Sometimes, life is sweet.

fields.headline: American Mom
fields.trailText: Every child fantasises about being left behind in Hamleys after the doors close, locked in for the night with all those Barbies, model trains, ballerina costumes and Luke Skywalkers.
fields.body:
Every child fantasises about being left behind in Hamleys after the doors close, locked in for the night with all those Barbies, model trains, ballerina costumes and Luke Skywalkers.

Here in New York, the fantasy has come to life. For $17,500, your child can celebrate his or her birthday locked up after hours at FAO Schwarz, the largest toy store in the US.

The waiting list is three months, but neither the wait nor the hefty price-tag has deterred scores of New York parents desperate to throw the most talked-about birthday party in town. "The demand for our slumber party is incredible," says Elizabeth Principe, special events co-ordinator for FAO Schwarz. "We have had calls from all over the US, and recently one family flew in their son and his friends from Colorado."

The fun starts at 9pm on a Saturday night, when the birthday boy or girl and up to 14 of their friends arrive. Greeted by "counsellors" who will babysit them, the kids spend the next 12 hours roaming FAO Schwarz's three floors, playing with every toy that takes their fancy and eating as much sugary food as they can stomach.

"It is all very organised. The children are allowed to move around the store, where we have different activities and games set up for them," says Principe. "They can drive every car, try on every costume, but they are not allowed to rip open boxes."

After a midnight snack consisting of pizza and more sugar, the children are encouraged to hit their FAO Schwarz-supplied sleeping bags, but Principe says few can sleep before 3am. "They are too excited. But eventually they just crash from exhaustion."

At 8am on Sunday morning, in true New York tradition, the giddy children are served a breakfast of bagels and cream cheese, then given a $100 gift certificate to buy anything that took their fancy during the night.

Could overnight parties at Hamleys be far behind?

fields.headline: The panel
fields.standfirst: The Question: Is it ever a good idea to take your child into the office?
fields.trailText: The Question: Is it ever a good idea to take your child into the office?
fields.body:
Sue Monk Chief executive of the campaign group Parents at Work

It's not ideal for you, your child or your work, and I think most people would avoid it unless it was absolutely essential. But there are times when it makes sense: if your child is under the weather, for example, but well enough to sit quietly and read a book, taking her into the office might mean you could do at least some of the work planned for that day. Also, it can be nice for your children to see where you work, so taking them in occasionally has its benefits: my six-year-old is always asking me when she can come and see where I work. It's good that your kids can picture you when you're not around.
Verdict: Yes

Julia Drown A Labour MP and mother of a four-month-old baby

I have been told by the sergeant-at-arms not to take my son into certain areas of the Commons. I am unhappy about this. Millions of women take their children to work because they have no choice. If you need to return to work when you're breast-feeding, though, then having the baby at work is the most practical thing to do - and it's easier if there are childcare arrangements at work. I can see it's not a good idea to have babies in some parts of the Commons, but I don't think taking them into the tea rooms or voting chamber in an emergency would be a big problem.
Verdict: Sometimes

Anna Reece Head of communications, Inst of Personnel and Development

The working environment is rarely designed to accommodate children, and they can be disruptive. They take their parent's mind off their job - you can't concentrate on a task with your child there in the background - and they distract your colleagues, too. Often it's a recipe for complete disaster, as in the film Mary Poppins, where the children get taken to the bank for the day. It affects productivity all round - often people will take their children in because their childcare has fallen through, but overall they might be reducing the total output of their office that day if they do go in with children.
Verdict: No

Sharon Mears Widowed mother with an 11-year-old son

I'm bringing up my son on my own and I've got no family around me. If anything goes wrong with my childcare arrangements, I'm caught in a dilemma: do I leave the colleagues in the lurch in the magazine office where I work, with deadlines to meet, or do I go in and take my son with me? I've done it when I've had to, although of course I don't think an office is the right environment for him and he gets bored. It's a question of the lesser of two evils. The people I work with are brilliant about it, but it makes me feel guilty: I feel he's distracting other people, and that I'm not working as much as I should be.
Verdict: Yes, in extremis

Sue Nickson Head of the employment unit at lawyers Hamond Suddards

Unless they have specific provision for it, workplaces are no place for a child. Technically, you shouldn't even bring your new baby into the office to show off to your colleagues, although of course lots of people do. But it's a breach of health and safety regulations, and thus there's no insurance cover in case anything untoward happens. I can see why people are tempted to bring their children into work at half term, but it really isn't a good idea - employers should talk to their employees to find out what they need so that the question of bringing in children won't apply.
Verdict: No

fields.headline: Thread of life
fields.standfirst: Ruby was born at 26 weeks, her foot smaller than a thumbnail.  Bella Duckenfield, her aunt, kept this diary of her first two months in special care
fields.trailText: Ruby was born at 26 weeks, her foot smaller than a thumbnail. Bella Duckenfield, her aunt, kept this diary of her first two months in special care
fields.body:
January 18 1999

Ruby is far too early. Three and a half months too early, to be exact. She is known as a 26-weeker. Better survival rate than her older brother, Paul, a 23-weeker. And she's a girl. That apparently stands in her favour. Plus she is a "good" weight, 2lbs and a bit (well, every bit counts doesn't it?). Her head smaller than my fist. Her body smaller than the cat asleep on my bed.

"Congratulations" beams a Looby Lou nurse, as she bounds into the recovery room. (My sister had to have an operation, "manual placenta removal". No euphemisms on this ward). We stare in disbelief. "Congratulations?" My sister replies. "My baby's 26 weeks and in intensive care? I don't think that's anything to celebrate."

My sister and her husband should know. They've been here before. They know what the future holds for them and for Ruby. They know Paul endured 17 weeks in intensive care before he died. Seventeen weeks of relentless tests and pain, of tubes and needles and drugs and medical torture, necessary and unnecessary.

Now Ruby faces the needles that are bigger than her veins, tiny plastic tubes inserted to feed her a constant juggle of antibiotics, glucose, lipids, fluids, blood. Tubes down her throat into her lungs and tubes up her nose, probes to monitor her blood gases, heart rate and breaths. A long line pushed through her belly button, along an artery as far as her heart. All that is left free is her heel, and that only because they need to prick for blood tests every hour. (What heel? It is half my thumb nail!)

Oh Ruby, Ruby, Ruby. I'm glad your eyes aren't open yet, so you can't see what tubes are in you. But you feel it.

"Babies forget pain," the nurse says. We are not convinced.

January 19 1999

Ruby had a very unstable first night, apparently. Does that mean that they nearly lost her, once, or twice, or many times? I don't want to know the details. She is here now, and that's all the information I can process at the moment. Here with chronic lung disease, anaemia, plummeting blood pressure, unstable blood sugars. "Every day in utero made a huge difference. And don't forget she had four doses of steroids," the doctor says. How could we ever forget?

We tried so hard, Ruby, to keep you in your warm cosy house. Your mother had 3 weeks of complete bed rest, and drugs to stop labour and steroids to develop your lungs faster. Your father and I did a twice-daily organic meals-on-wheels service (you needed every bit of wholesome food you could get). We toasted the New Year in by praying we wouldn't see you for a long time. But there were other plans in the making. Out of our hands, in the end.

And Paul. You'd be three now. You knew suffering and pain all too well. If Ruby dies, then so, too, do her parents. Help her to live!

My cheeks are stained with tears. I am desperate.

January 25 1999

Ruby has survived the first week. Head scan is "normal" - 95% of bleeds on the brain occur in the first week. She came off the life support machine for a while. But her lungs collapsed and she went back on the ventilator, she was "reintubated". She has lost weight - down to 1 lb 4. Even her skin is too big for her now.

February 24 1999

Ruby has become limp and lifeless. She is being treated for septicaemia and a fungal infection of the blood which has furred up her kidneys. A cornucopia of potent drugs whizzes down the tubes into her little veins. When the drip fails, which it does practically every 24 hours, they have to find another vein. Black and blue. Scabby heel. Dried blood. Lots of pricking.

This is survival of the most basic kind. As far as I can make out, death is the only alternative to the drugs. We have to accept that for 31 of your 36 days of life, you have been on a cocktail of antibiotics. Organic food can't help you now.

February 28 1999

A scan detects fungal balls in one kidney. Then both. God knows how your organs are coping with processing all this stuff. If your foot is smaller than my thumbnail, then your heart can be no bigger than a baked bean.

But you are so beautiful, Ruby. Elongated fingers as delicate and thin as a daisy stem, perfectly sharp nails, each one the tip of a grain of rice. And sometimes, when I am very lucky, as I'm staring in through your plastic box, watching you sleep, dying to hold you and say it'll be all right, you stretch and wriggle, and open your mouth and yawn a 5p piece yawn, and you show off your tiny sliver of a pink tongue. And you are perfect. In that moment everything is all right. You are a normal baby doing normal baby things. The plastic becomes invisible and I see so clearly the chiselled lines on your palm as you open and squeeze your fingers tight.

But soon it begins again. Ping ping ping ping ping. I look at your monitor. Your traces are no longer regular patterned blips but a child's scribble across the page. "Come on, Ruby; come on, darling. Breathe. Pick up your heartbeat. Please. We don't like you looking so blue."

The nurse starts to tickle, pinch, prod, rub, shake you. Wake up. Wake up. Bradycardia. Apnoenia. Destaturations. Bag and mask over your face, pumping your lungs, forcing air into your body. Apparently you "forget" to breathe. You've got a lot to concentrate on.

Cruelly, your parents can do so little to help you. It's out of their hands now. You are in at least 30 pairs of different hands. Hands that keep you alive, administer drugs; hands that give you pain. Hands that caress and stroke you, too, even when they have to do horrible things.

It breaks my heart to see you on your own in your lonely box, inside staring out. Do you see us outside, looking, smiling, worrying? Do you hear above the hissing of the tubes up your nose that help you breathe and give you oxygen? Do you hear mummy singing those heart-wrenching songs to you. I hear them. I hear the love, and the pain, and the thwarted joy of seeing her new-born daughter. And the fear of the unknown and the known. Of the uncertain future. I hear it all in those songs. I cry for you both.

She was robbed of carrying you to term, robbed of holding you in her arms when you were born, of you nuzzling at her breast. How cruel. Yet you and she, and your father, somehow manage to carry on, to get through one hour, one day at a time. Somehow survive on a thread of life. It never will be normal now. It will be one day at a time from now on and for always. Constantly readjusting to unpredictable problems and unknown developmental obstacles, just as it is now.

Ruby, you are dearly loved and I hope you survive and grow up to have a happy, fulfilling life. But I can't guarantee it. That, too, is out of our hands now.

 Ruby spent four and a half months in special care. She is now 13 months old and is doing well.

fields.headline: Playing safe on the farm
fields.standfirst: Farms are wholesome places where rosy-cheeked children breath in fresh air and cuddle sheep - right? Wrong, according to the E coli expert who said this week that under fives should stay away.  Lucy Atkins  weighs up the risks
fields.trailText: Farms are wholesome places where rosy-cheeked children breath in fresh air and cuddle sheep - right? Wrong, according to the E coli expert who said this week that under fives should stay away. Lucy Atkins weighs up the risks
fields.body:
Last year Austrian researchers showed that children who had regular contact with farm animals were less likely to develop allergies, probably because exposure to dirt strengthened their immune systems. Parents around the country breathed a collective sigh of relief: so our grannies were right, after all, when they said things like "outdoors dirt is good dirt". We began whisking our children round open farms in droves. Then the awful story of Tom Dowling hit the headlines. Tom, now aged six, caught E coli from an infant school visit to a farm near St Albans in 1997. He survived, but he's unable to move his limbs and can only communicate by blinking. Farm dirt, it seems, might not be so healthy after all.

This is certainly the conclusion reached by professor Hugh Pennington. This week he said on BBC1's Countryfile programme that he would "go to the extreme of saying that perhaps it is unwise to take a five- or under-five-year-old on a farm visit because we have had such complications in the very small number of kids who've been infected". Pennington should know what he's talking about. He's a leading expert on the E coli 0157 bug and headed the inquiry into the Lanarkshire E coli outbreak in 1996-7, which killed 21 people.

So, am I risking my one-year-old daughter's life by letting her pet the goats? John Newton-Jones, chairman of the National Association of Farms for Schools, says I'm not, "providing the farm is properly managed and your child is carefully supervised". Fear of infection from farms should be put in perspective, he says. "There are risks of infection wherever we take our children, whether it's to a farm, the countryside, the beach or a public park. A massive range of animals and birds, including seagulls, can carry the E coli bug". Luckily, the key to avoiding it is simple: hygiene.

As long as they wash their hands thoroughly, under running water after touching the animals, and as long as the farm is run to basic safety and hygiene standards, the risks to your children of catching E coli on a farm will be minuscule.

This is because E coli is transmitted through the mouth. A spokesperson for the Public Health Laboratory Service (PHLS) explains how it works: "E coli 0157 is a particular strain of the bug that tends to cause the food poisoning outbreaks. It is transmitted by the 'faecal-oral route' and is often carried by animals." Crudely speaking, then, it goes like this: my little one strokes the goat. The goat happens to have a tiny (maybe even invisible) bit of goat poo on its fur. She then sucks her fingers, thus consuming the goat poo particle. In most cases, no harm will be done at all. But if the goat happens to be infected with the E coli bug, as some goats are, then she could become seriously ill and even die. If, though, I wash her hands carefully before she sucks them, the bug will never get into her system.

This all sounds straightforward. But Pennington's E coli warning somehow lingers. Most of us think of farmyards as wholesome places where our red-cheeked children will breathe fresh air and cuddle sheep. We don't think of them as places where they could catch a virulent killer bug.

In an average year, according to PHLS, there'll be 1,000 cases of E coli in England and Wales. Last year, 24 of those were because of farm visits (there was none in 1998). webTitle: Leeds chemists devise the 3D chip that grows

fields.headline: Leeds chemists devise the 3D chip that grows
fields.trailText: A team of British chemists has unveiled an ambitious plan to revolutionise the world computer chip market and take on industry leaders such as Intel and Arm Holdings.
fields.body:
A team of British chemists has unveiled an ambitious plan to revolutionise the world computer chip market and take on industry leaders such as Intel and Arm Holdings.

The researchers at Leeds university believe they can "grow" a 3D computer chip using molecules which assemble themselves into molecular wires. They claim the development would allow chips to be stacked on top of each other for the first time, making them much more powerful than their silicon equivalents.

Engineers can only squeeze a finite number of circuitry on chips and have so far been un able to find away of stacking them because the necessary wires are too small to join up different components.

The Leeds scientists believe that they can encourage connections to "grow" from one chip to another.

Professor Richard Bushby said he was confident electrically conductive molecules could be encouraged to grow between chips in much the same way as neural networks grow in the human brain.

With the aid of colleagues, he has patented a new type of conductive liquid crystals. However, chip industry leaders will not be panicking: the 3D chips are unlikely to reach the market before 2010.

fields.headline: Wrongs and rights
fields.standfirst: During 20 years in and out  of jail, Mark Leech had  become 'an animal'. He tells  Grania  Langdon-Down why he  now devotes his time to  helping ex-offenders
fields.trailText: During 20 years in and out of jail, Mark Leech had become 'an animal'. He tells Grania Langdon-Down why he now devotes his time to helping ex-offenders.
fields.body:
A sense of risk, of a vol-atile mix of vulnerability and assertiveness, surrounds Mark Leech, the first chief executive of Unlock, the national organisation for ex-offenders. He is now a £30,000-a-year champion of prison rights, highly regarded by senior prison officials and inmates and is an award-winning writer. But the nightmares of his past still have their claws buried deep.

It is six years since he walked out of prison for the last time after a 20-year jail career punctuated by assaults, riots, rooftop protests and long periods in solitary.

Had someone questioned why, at the age of 12, he changed from an able student who loved his school to a truant who flunked his work, he might never have started on the track that led from approved school to his tag as a "thoroughly offensive, dangerous and disruptive man."

As an eight year old, he was sent to a local authority boarding school after his mother died and his father became an alcoholic. For the next three years, he says a schoolmaster abused him but he put up with it because, for the first time, he felt loved, embraced rather than pushed away. And then one night he found the man with another boy.

"From that moment on - and I mean from that second on - walking into that room and finding it, and recognising what it was, my life changed completely. All the illusions, the relationship that I thought I'd created, just fell down around my ears completely. And I swore that nobody in authority was ever going to do that to me again," Leech wrote recently in Going Straight (Waterside Press), Angela Devlin and Bob Turney's book on people who have made a success of life after prison.

Wrapped in his anger, he stole, robbed and defrauded his way in and out of prison. Brutalised by some staff, he gave as good as he got. But gradually he learned to take his battles with authority to the courts, rather than the rooftop, reading law with London University. Life isn't easy for barrack-room lawyers, but Leech successfully sued the prison authorities more than 40 times from the county courts to the House of Lords.

But it was only when he was sent to Grendon Underwood, the country's only therapeutic prison, in 1989, that anyone asked: 'Why are you so angry?'

"I had become an animal. I had taken hostages, covered the governor of Dartmoor in excreta and either they nutted me off (to a secure mental unit) or sent me to Grendon, which had earned a reputation for turning the most difficult prisoners round.

"For the first time, I talked about what had happened when I was a kid and I was given time to step back and realise I had other options," explains Leech, who while inside wrote radio plays, his autobiography A Product of the System and the first edition of The Prisons Handbook, now regarded as the definitive guide to the penal system.

Now 42, he lives with his partner, Steve, and their two labradors in Manchester. He co-founded Unlock in 1998 with Turney, an ex-con turned probation officer, and actor Stephen Fry, who spent time on remand in custody after a teenage spree with stolen credit cards.

"We are a grab-you-by-the-throat organisation. We don't suffer fools gladly, among ex-offenders or anybody else. What is cast iron is that crime is not an option," says Leech.

Unlock has now become a limited company with charitable status, through funding from trusts including the Wates Foundation and the Tudor Trust. There are eight members of staff, all ex-offenders, and Leech is seeking volunteers to help in their Kent and Manchester offices. Eventually, they hope to have offices all over the country and drop-in centres at every major court.

One of their first tasks is preparing a discharge pack for prisoners. They have also won a contract with the Prison Service to monitor two pre-release courses to produce a blueprint for an accredited course that can be rolled out nationally. And they hope to monitor post-release hostels to ensure they are offering ex-offenders proper support.

Leech is campaigning for a change in the current rules whereby prisoners are given a discharge grant equivalent to one week's income support when they cannot start claiming benefits for two weeks.

"When they fail, people just shrug their shoulders and send them back to jail," he says. "But for want of proper policy, you end up with more victims of crime."

Another project is to persuade the government to amend the rehabilitation of offenders act 1974 to allow reformed criminals to be able to put their convictions behind them after set periods.

For Leech, his huge achievements over the last few years have not come without pain. He has had counselling to help keep his anger in check, to accept people can have a different view.

He accepts the more sceptical may think he is aiming too high and that another of Unlock's aims - to end the hostility between inmates and prison officers - is unrealistic. "I am idealistic," he admits "but I have a passion for this work. I have been locked up in body belts, in strip cells, in solitary. I have seen how destructive that can be.

"It's what drives me, the desire to help reduce crime, to give something back to society. I am not doing it as a penance. There is nothing I can do to help my victims now. But I can try to help prevent the next victim."

 For Unlock, phone 01634-247350 or email Mark.leech@markleechassociates.co.uk

fields.headline: Radio daze
fields.standfirst: Leslie Jerman on how a rowing boat, a bike  and a saint made a microphone man of him
fields.trailText: Leslie Jerman on how a rowing boat, a bike and a saint made a microphone man of him.
fields.body:
How, in our competitive society, does ambition begin? I don't know the answer,but for as long as I can remember I have wanted to broadcast.

Initially, getting on the air was a problem. My first stint on radio involved rowing a boat across the lake behind the Mohne Dam in Germany, scene of that epic raid in 1943 when the RAF breached the dam with bouncing bombs.

I was an office boy turned young reporter. We were visiting RAF stations in Germany, long after the "dambusting", when a BBC correspondent asked if I would like to see the repaired dam. We were driven there by a young pilot and, once at the dam, we hired a rowing boat. I had to row while the BBC man interviewed the pilot on tape.

Some weeks later I turned on the radio to hear a programme called Eye Witness. Suddenly, the Mohne interview began - punctuated by squeaks and splashes.

That was just the start. Persistence was to be the key especially when BBC producer Charles Chilton took over In Town Tonight, the programme in which people with a story were interviewed. My suggestions - a woman who sold leeches, a man trying to produce purple eggs and someone who ran a society for non-smokers all appeared; more followed and I received a fee for each.

Then there was my short talk on London. I wrote about the Cato Street Conspiracy and was called to a Bond Street studio in London. I read my script twice but my voice wasn't suitable. Would I mind if somebody else read my script?

Never give up. Having seen Normandy and the north of France during the war, I wanted to see more, hence my plan to cycle from London to Nice and Cannes. I wrote to the BBC asking if they cared to see a script. No, they wouldn't. But some days later Woman's Hour did.

It was a gruelling summer. I saw where the airship RIOI had crashed at Beauvais, and was disappointed later to see that Chteauneuf du Pape wasn't new at all. On and on I pedalled. Nice was nice.

I came back by train having buckled a wheel and my script wa returned because it didn't say enough about the people, but then I hadn't had much time to chat during 1,500 miles of pedalling.

But one episode I do recall. Halfway down France, a British woman tourist asked me the way. She spoke in halting French, so I replied in French, adding: "You will find it very easily, madam". She looked shaken and said: "You speak very good English!"

Convinced my voice wasn't right for radio, I began to lose heart. Until the phone rang one day. Would I do a talk about "barmy days" for BBC Radio Scotland?

That night I sorted through a cubic yard of clippings, pamphlets and books and found a cutting I had written long before. I knew then I was home and dry.

Next morning at Broadcasting House I began to talk about Mother's Day and how it had been invented by an American salesman. Ratified by Congress, it was followed by Father's Day (when the goods were a bit cheaper).

I also mentioned St George, who was not English but lived in Turkey. A former Pope had said of him that his good deeds were known only to heaven. I said he sounded like someone fit to stand in the dock at the Old Bailey.

His day, April 23, is also celebrated as Shakespeare's birthday. But nobody knows when Shakespeare was born, though he did die on April 23.

I reached for my newspaper clipping. "I will give American salesmen a gift," I said. "There are some 17 million gardens in this country and the patron saint of gardening is the little-known St Phocas. I think you pronounce it like that."

The anchorman in Glasgow said: "Oh, I hope so!" Over the landline, I said: "Let there be no mistake. P-H-O-C-A-S. He lived in Turkey, and was impeached as a Christian by the Romans and put to death. His day is July 23. That is when he should be remembered."

By now in full flight, I said: "We could have St Phocas packets of seeds, St Phocas garden tools, St Phocas gift tokens..."

The anchorman said: "I think that's enough about St Phocas."

My broadcast ended, but it was a new beginning. The producer came on with his verdict: "Adjectivally marvellous!" They put it on to Pick of the Week and I got another cheque.

Within a week the producer called again and asked if I would do a regular programme, a What the Papers Say on radio. I have done it now for four years.

fields.headline: Where the money goes
fields.standfirst: The biggest survey ever of British social  services for young people aims to replace  guesswork and hunches with the hard  facts of management accounting, writes  Robin Forrester
fields.trailText: The biggest survey ever of British social services for young people aims to replace guesswork and hunches with the hard facts of management accounting, writes Robin Forrester.
fields.body:
Social services spend £2.5bn a year on children and families, yet we have little idea where it goes. Until recently, there was little incentive to delve deeper, but now the biggest ever survey of services - the Children In Need Centre (Cinc) - is under way.

Of course, we do know how many children were in care through the year and something about them - for example age, gender, legal status and length of time in care. The information we have on child protection registers is similar. We know how many social workers, unqualified staff, children's homes and family centres the money buys. But our accounting systems were designed to show probity, with little management information deduced from them.

This will surprise readers in commerce and industry, even the professions, where costing activity is routine all the year round, both for billing purposes and management information. However, there was previously little impetus for costing some non-chargeable services in the public sector. Published work has been limited to academic projects.

But questions remain unanswered. Do we do any good? What needs do we meet? What about all those children supported through social services who are not in care or not in the child protection system? How can we measure the effectiveness of policy changes? How much do the different local authorities differ in their approaches? What are the costs of it all and how are they made up?

Cinc began three years ago to try to answer these questions. Independent experimental work in two districts of Cheshire county council had dug at the foundations. Quite separately, theoretical work was starting at the department of health. This built on research by Martin Knapp and the Personal Social Services Research Unit. Jo Williams, Cheshire director and now president of the Association of Directors of Social Services, joined up these strands and also drew in Tameside and Staffordshire social services.

The idea was to produce counting and costing tools that would help local authorities and government without feeling like just another set of official forms.

This was at the tail-end of the Conservative administration. It continued after the change of government, driven by the need to demonstrate where the money was going. It was essential to show competence and accountability to the treasury. At the time, similar work throughout Whitehall evolved into the new comprehensive spending review. When funding bids were being made by the department of health for what became the Quality Protects initiative it was felt reasonable to ask: "If child protection registers and children in care registers are falling, why do you need all this money?"

A costing model was developed to fill this gap. It was piloted in the three local authorities in March 1998. The result was a proven method that fitted on just one floppy disk. Further joint development work was tested in a national pilot in December 1998, involving a dozen local authorities. Although this pilot was supposed to road-test the method and its database, many new developments were made afterwards so that Cinc is now a new pilot.

Some time ago, administration and practice changed little over time, but the modernisation agenda of the past decade has brought an increasing pace of change. Social work is now to be measured more closely by business criteria as well as caring ones. The business aspect is testing some local authorities to their limits while others take it in their stride. The exercise will cost £3m-£4m: what is different about it and what will we get for our money?

A novel element is a week's census of all activity counted child by child. All children's workers and centres throughout the country are completing a week's time record sheet. Information managers will be assembling data such as the child's type of need, date of birth, whether in care and type of care, or on the child protection register, and postcode. One optional extra will be the gathering of information about the needs of children with disabilities. Accountants will use a standard format for unit costs.

All the data will be inputted into a central database. This will produce an account of a week's costs good enough to be used as a pattern for a year's activity. The information will be used anonynously both locally and by the department of health.

It will focus on the enormous number of children supported through social services work and indicate a wide variation in practice across the country. Initial estimates based on the pilot projects suggest that the number of children helped in a year could be more than 250,000 in Cheshire alone.

Regardless of the inconsistencies of method between local authorities, there will be the opportunity for benchmarking in much more detail. Why is authority A spending 40% of its resources on preventive work when authority B is spending 60%? Why is authority C, regarded as more successful than authority D, spending x% less per client? Local politicians will be interested to see the grouping of needs and resources by postcode and by ward. Cats will be let out of bags. Pragmatic cross-party cooperation will be tested by evidence of the spending patterns and needs analyses that emerge. Analysis by ethnicity will use the 2001 census categories. Such a massive amount of information in such a politically sensitive area is bound to have some controversial results.

The department of health will be in a stronger, better informed position in putting social services' case to the treasury. However, as the holder of yet more national data, it will also put it in a stronger position vis-à-vis local authorities.

The work of following up this month's census will last at least until the end of May, when the results will be passed to the department of health.

Local authority information systems and accounting processes will have to be significantly adjusted to cope with this new annual requirement. There is much more work to do before we can consistently link information about outcomes for children to the delivery of better services.

 Robin Forrester is service development and review manager with Cheshire social services.

fields.headline: The inspectors call
fields.standfirst: David Walker on the task facing an army of 'best value' watchdogs
fields.trailText: David Walker on the task facing an army of 'best value' watchdogs.
fields.body:
The Audit Commission today publishes marching orders for its new 300-strong army of inspectors, who will fan out across England and Wales to establish whether local authorities, police forces and fire brigades are offering best value.

The inspectors, who will swing into action on April 1 at a cost of around £60m a year, are to be the watchdogs in Labour's compact with local government. In return for abolishing compulsory competitive tendering of services, councils are required to review repeatedly what they are doing on the public's behalf. If the inspectors don't like it, they will call in the Whitehall artillery.

Wendy Thompson, the commission's director of inspections, runs this new branch which will vet council and health service books and will check whether they deliver value for money. A highly-regarded former chief executive of the London borough of Newham who before that led Community Service Volunteers, Canadian-born Thompson wants to be "one of us", assuring councils her presence guarantees knowledge and perhaps some sympathy for councils. She is not going to be another Chris Woodhead - although she would not be so undiplomatic as to use such language since the commission works closely with Ofsted.

Best value is to be a tougher regime for improving services. From April to June, the commission's auditors will be checking that all 479 councils, plus waste authorities and similar bodies, are signed up and have produced the required plans and reviews and have made sure the public know about them. Then the inspectors will be looking for results. A score of councils have been piloting the new scheme for the past couple of years, so it will not be an entirely fresh start. But there is a huge amount of new procedure for the town and county halls to learn.

Thompson's inspectors will spend between up to 10 days in each council over a five-year cycle. They will be in close touch with education inspectors, the department of health's social services inspectors, fire and HM inspectors of constabulary. But she is keen to emphasise the ways in which best value inspection will be different. "We won't," she says, "be limited to departments."

She will want to see how councils join up their work - for example, by taking all they do for children as a theme rather than looking at social services and education separately.

Councillors as well as officials are very much part of the picture. The pilots have shown how "greedy" they are for an external perspective on their local authority, says Thompson. "The onus is on the local authority to improve things after we have inspected, and we do have the ultimate power to refer a council to the relevant secretary of state."

A key word for her is "place". Councils are much more than just agglomerations of teachers, social workers, sports centre managers, planners and so on. Best value inspections want to get at how well councils articulate and serve the interests of people living in particular places, all different in history and political culture. She talks of subjecting all the measurements of Best Value to "reality checks". As she says: "It is no good our saying that because the indicators show there has been a general improvement, that's enough; we want to go out and ask people at the bus queue how they feel about the service." That will get written up and presented to the council as a challenge. If you have not improved how people feel about you, are you making progress?

But for all that, she has some powerful sticks in her armoury. All councils will be expected to show quantitative improvement in meeting targets for service delivery. Government ministers are not going to stop breathing down the neck of commission controller Andrew Foster, demanding that he screw ever tighter the various ratchets to extract better performance from councils.

Thompson, for all her feeling for former council colleagues, is now an agent of intervention. Her track record suggests she is likely to be effective - except that her presence at the commission may suggest that those who can, get to inspect; those who can't, get inspected.

fields.headline: Ways and means
fields.standfirst: How can services - private, voluntary and public - be made  more responsive to users? The Guardian and the Institute for  Public Policy Research launch awards for outstanding public  involvement in decision making. Matthew Taylor and  Malcolm Dean report
fields.trailText: How can services - private, voluntary and public - be made more responsive to users? The Guardian and the Institute for Public Policy Research launch awards for outstanding public involvement in decision making. Matthew Taylor and Malcolm Dean report.
fields.body:
When was the last time you were asked your opinion on something that mattered to you? General elections? They're only every four or five years. Local and European elections? Most people can't be bothered. Opinion polls or focus groups? You're more likely to read about one than take part.

While much has been said about social exclusion, little attention has been given to the growing phenomenon of the politically excluded - those people who feel they are not represented in our political institutions and who lack the capacity or willingness to make their views heard. It is a condition particularly prevalent among the young, the poor and certain ethnic minority groups. And it is a condition whose effects go wider than its immediate victims. We all get less good government from a system dominated by the three Ms - middle aged, middle class, men.

Like poverty, political exclusion is a particular affront to progressives. One of the big arguments between the left and right is about the relative merits of democracy and markets as systems for allocating social goods. While markets are dynamic, creative and appear to offer new choices every day, democracy is creaking, discredited and leaves many people feeling they have no choice. As they say: "It doesn't matter who you vote for, the politicians always win."

Something must be done. If the tribulations in Edinburgh, Cardiff and London teach us anything, it is surely that building new institutions is not sufficient to create a new political culture. Fundamentally, we have to recognise that traditional representative democracy must be enhanced by new ways of involving the public in decision making.

Some change is already underway. A commitment to public involvement has been made a key part of Labour's modernising government agenda. The government has argued that to achieve their long-term policy objectives - such as improving local services and tackling social exclusion and crime - it is necessary to involve the public.

Yet evidence suggests that government departments are carrying out public involvement exercises without developing a coherent cross-departmental approach. There are few opportunities for sharing or learning from best practice, or for pooling experience and expertise across central and local government.

We need to develop more coordinated methods - from opinion polls to citizens' juries - of involving the public in decision making, not as alternatives but as complementary to the traditional process. Elected representatives are there to make the difficult decisions. They have experience, access to the necessary expertise and, once elected, should have the legitimacy to govern. But the space on the ballot paper is all. You can place a cross, but you can't write: "I like my local school, but my mother's lost her home help and I'm worried about street crime." Politicians need to be listening and to be showing that they are.

This principle is not exclusive to politics. As a nation, we have a poor track record in engaging the general public in the process of change. Too often public involvement is mistaken for mere customer care - a market driven exercise used to refine a particular product or service. Increasingly, private sector bodies are making decisions in the public domain and are recognising the need to involve the public in a more meaningful way. As the government puts more emphasis on the engagement of the voluntary sector in service provision and regeneration, questions are being asked about whether this sector is any less guilty of high-handedness than the public alternative.

Exercises in public involvement are vulnerable to three main criticisms:

 The attempt at consultation is little more than an exercise in legitimising a decision already made.

 Those engaged are not truly representative of the public, often because they are the peculiar kind of people who enjoy attending public meetings;

 There remains a powerful imbalance of information between the agency consulting the citizens consulted, and the public.

The main reason for these failings is that inclusive, meaningful public involvement is expensive, time consuming and challenging for those who undertake it. Those bodies which are really involving local communities in excellent and groundbreaking ways should be publicly lauded. There is a lot of good work going on, but the danger is that public involvement mechanisms could continue to grow in quantity yet decrease in quality, and consultation fatigue could easily set in among members of the public. Put simply, bad public involvement can often be worse than none at all.

The Institute for Public Policy Research, a centre-left think tank, and the Guardian are together launching the Public Involvement Awards. Our premise is that high quality public involvement often goes unrecognised and that best practice is not always spread.

These annual awards will publicise and celebrate the impact of successful public involvement. They will reward organisations that have put time and effort into undertaking meaningful consultation, but can also demonstrate that their policies or processes were significantly improved as a result.

Any public, private or voluntary sector organisation that has shown a commitment to this principle is encouraged to take part in this award. Similarly, if you are an individual who has been consulted as part of the process of change, tell us about your experience - good or bad. Real choice is more than just being asked your choice from a set of pre-determined outcomes, more than about determining your own answers; it should empower you to change the questions.

At its worst, public involvement is window dressing that will increase public cynicism. At its best, it could be a key plank in tackling political exclusion and improving the goods and services we receive. The Guardian/IPPR awards will aim for the best.

Cases proven

Regulating the internet

To discover what a cross section of society thinks about internet regulation, the Independent Television Commission set up a citizens' forum, with 200 people recruited from a large mail-out in Birmingham. They represented all ages and walks of life: some used the internet daily, while others had never even touched a computer. For a day and a half the members of the forum debated the subject - helped by fact sheets, presentations and a panel of four diverse experts. Their opinions were assessed by monitoring these discussions and administering questionnaires before and after the forum.

 lnternet Regulation: The Way Forward? is available on www.itc.org.uk or price £5 from the ITC at 33 Foley Street, London Wl P 7LB

Redeveloping the South Bank
A major redevelopment of the South Bank site in London (stretching between Waterloo Bridge and County Hall) is currently being planned.

The South Bank Centre (SBC) is currently running a massive and innovative consultation programme to involve all those with a stake in the site in the redevelopment, from visitors to residents to artists and performers. Working with Opinion Leader Research hundreds of people have become involved in projects, including:

 A series of citizens' workshops with audiences, visitors, local residents and employees to establish the non-technical criteria for success of the redevelopment of the South Bank, and

 Consultation discussions with current and potential national and international performing and visual artists, architects, educa tionalists and curators and people with disabilities.

Karsten Witt, chief executive of SBC, says: "The scale of our public consultation at this stage in an arts-led urban regeneration project is unprecedented in the UK. I am convinced that by continuing to actively encourage informed public involvement at every stage of the re-development we will be able to create a wonderful South Bank for everyone."

Youth Parliament
In the east London borough of Tower Hamlets, a youth parliament was established in 1996 as a platform for young people to voice their views and opinions on local issues.

Many of the members of the parliament come from the Bangladeshi community in the borough - which is one of the poorest in Britain.

Recently, the youth parliament held discussions on how New Deal money should be spent in their local area, and representatives then presented ideas to the New Deal Board - the body that decides the allocation of funds for this programme.

The parliament is also represented on the Single Regeneration Budget local area board, the body which decides how funds for regeneration activities should be distributed.

 Matthew Taylor is director of the Institute for Public Policy Research. The Guardian/IPPR public involvement awards are supported by ASDA. Malcolm Dean is Society Editor.

fields.headline: Winning ways
fields.standfirst: Malcolm Dean on the pioneer projects in  community health that are picking up awards
fields.trailText: Malcolm Dean on the pioneer projects in community health that are picking up awards.
fields.body:
How do you deliver sexual health messages to teenagers, who are already saturated with sex education by the media? A pioneer project in Hampshire, which recruited young people for the task, has reached people most other projects never get to. Moreover, the feedback from young people suggests media messages are not enough. Aldershot's Peer Training Project was one of 10 charitable groups, which were winners in this year's SmithKline Beecham's community health awards - worth £25,000 each - announced last week.

Based on a Dutch model, the Hampshire project recruits and trains young people, aged 14-16, to get across safe health and drugs messages in youth clubs and schools. It is achieved through a combination of roadshows, networking, and merely being in school or youth clubs where they can provide informed answers to the questions from their peers.

The first peer training group, Dots (Drugs on the Streets) involved 12 young people, who toured youth projects with drama presentations on drugs misuse, workshops, an information booklet and a range of T-shirts carrying harm minimisation messages.

This group then became mentors and trainers of a second group of young people who created Shag (Sexual Health Awareness Group). This group's roadshow included quizzes, role-plays plus workshops on safe sex, sexually transmitted diseases, the nature of relationships and challenging homophobic attitudes. Working packs for each type of contraceptive were designed to demystify the methods. A third group Dig (Drugs in General) produced yet another roadshow, while the initial peer trainers have now moved into part-time youth work.

This year's awards demonstrated the breadth of support provided by community groups. Some won awards for the way they had helped empower disadvantaged groups of people. Others won for the new services they had developed. fields.headline: Eco soundings
fields.trailText: The Queen's silt | Colombian storm
fields.body:
The ministry of agriculture, English Nature, the Environment Agency and even the Queen's harbour master have all approved Gosport marina's plan to pump out 21,000 tons of silt and dump it into Portsmouth harbour. Shame that no one bothered to contact, let alone warn, the several hundred local oyster fishers or the Southern Fisheries district committee, who only discovered what was going on last week by chance. "What are you doing?" asked Mr Gathergood, an oysterman who just happened to see men setting up the pipes. When he found out, he was appalled. The oyster beds are less than a mile away, no one (least of all Maff) seems to know exactly where the silt will be carried, and the several hundred people who depend on the £1.2m a year export industry are rightly worried. It seems the whole project is an experiment about to be perpetrated on other ports and that Maff has blundered. But will it stop the work, due to start this week?

Colombian national police didn't consult the U'wa tribe last week when they sent in the storm troops to remove several hundred people blocking a road leading to the site where Oxy Petroleum intends to drill its first well in a new field. Soldiers and anti-riot police used tear gas, bull- dozers and riot sticks to charge the blockade, forcing the U'wa to jump into the fast-flowing Cubujón river. Three children died and there is now a general strike in the region.

ICI certainly didn't consult the residents of Weston, near Runcorn, when they dumped thousands of tons of toxic waste in an old quarry next to a housing estate. The old dump has been leaking dangerous HCBD gas, 22 houses have so far been found to be contaminated, ICI has had to offer to buy most of the houses in the village and the community is in turmoil. None more so than the unlucky resident of Cheshyres Lane in Weston, who, it seems, had his house measured for the gas recently and has now been told it is poisoning him with more than three times the recommended daily dose of HCBD. But he's only been living there for four years, so that's probably all right then.

And no one warned Heather Preen about swimming in Cornwall. She picked up an E.coli 0157 infection and, at the recent inquest into her death, all three medical and scientific experts agreed that sewage was a possible source. The coroner decided it was death by misadventure because, possibly, she could have been infected by dog faeces on the beach. But the coroner's recommendations were important. He said that UV sewage treatment should be installed - and SWW, having denied resolutely before the inquest that sewage could have been the cause of death, seems to have accepted this.

The dreadful pollution of the River Somes in Romania is just one result of the unseemly gold and mineral rush in that country. Witness Roæia Montana, site of one of a handful of ancient Roman gold mines in the Apuseni mountains. Here, a Canadian-led company wants to opencast mine for gold, but the proposed mine would obliterate half the village and the Roman remains. Villagers have even been asked to sell land and agree to the demolition of homes and churches. Roæia Montana is desperately poor. The inhabitants are torn between accepting the offer and saving their village. Local archaeologist and museum director Horia Ciugudean believes Roæia Montana should be a European Heritage site. This view is supported by English, French and German experts.

Here's some genuine consultation, and let no one say that they were not warned. If you fancy living in a state of the art eco-house, with photovoltaic electricity, wind turbine, composting and rainwater-flushing loos and no gas, water or electricity bills, there's one in Leicester up for grabs. The only snag is that all the rooms, except the bedroom, must be shared with up to 20,000 visitors a year. Still interested? Write asap to Environ, Western Park, Hinckley Road, Leicester LE3 6HX.

fields.headline: Exit pass
fields.standfirst: Learning Labs offer a  passport to a fresh  start. Simon Bowers  looks at the way the  new scheme works
fields.trailText: Learning Labs offer a passport to a fresh start. Simon Bowers looks at the way the new scheme works.
fields.body:
Prisoners about to leave jails in Teesside have been given passports to help smooth their passage back into society. The scheme, developed through the government's new "learning labs" programme, will help those completing their sentences to resume their lives and gain access to a range of public services.

Under the initiative, front-line staff from benefit, housing, employment and other agencies have worked together to develop a holistic approach to the needs of prisoners preparing for release.

The passport scheme was launched last week at Kirklevington Grange prison, near Middlesbrough, by cabinet enforcer Mo Mowlam. "This is a fantastic example of joined-up government," she said. "From where I sit in Westminster, these ideas just wouldn't have occurred to me. It really shows the potential for everybody at the front line of service provision to get involved and change things for the better."

Drawing on this potential, the learning lab think-tank produced a pocket-sized maroon passport which is now issued to every prisoner and recognised by local job centres, housing associations and benefit offices across Teesside.

Prisoners are also given help filling out a set of forms, recognised by public service agencies, which they can use to negotiate the maze of red tape awaiting them on release. It is the first step in reclaiming their identity outside prison.

John Harrison, a researcher at Sunderland university, has interviewed more than 100 inmates and former prisoners at Kirklevington and Durham prisons. He said those who have served a custodial sentence are most likely to return to crime within the first four weeks of release, so by helping former prisoners establish themselves during this crucial period re-offending rates should fall.

"Many of these people have been jailed for long periods and, because public services are changing all the time, they really don't know where to start in terms of arranging housing benefits and finding a job," he said.

Overwhelmed by the unfamiliar procedures, requests for personal documents they do not possess, and mountains of forms to fill out, the process of establish ing links with service agencies can be long and frustrating. Many former prisoners also face delays before benefits can be processed and housing arranged. In the meantime, the return to crime is a constant temptation.

Nick Harrison, a prison officer at Kirklevington for 11 years, was the first to see that the release process could be made much smoother given a little inter-agency flexibility and co-ordination. Impressed by his ideas, the cabinet office asked him to set up a lab in co-operation with local services.

The resulting prisoners' passport scheme is being piloted in five prisons across Teesside with the co-operation of public agencies working together to tailor their services to the needs of individual prisoners.

Having spoken to prisoners and the learning lab team, Mowlam was bursting with enthusiasm for inter-agency co-operation. "How can you get a job when you haven't even got a P45?" she asked. "How can you get housing without a job or a job without housing? It's Catch-22."

The Teesside project is one of five established around the country to tackle problems as diverse as tobacco smuggling or social service provision for pensioners in Torquay.

In each case the problem solving approach is the same. A committee of front line service providers work together to develop innovative solutions beyond the mind-set of central government planning.

A problem common to all the learning labs is that while many of the solutions offered involve inter-agency co-operation, there is no inter-agency budget to implement them. "It is too early to give that commitment," said Mowlam. "The prisoners and staff need to buy into the idea and make it work. Then we can find a budget and spread the scheme to other prisons."

But without a ring-fenced budget it is hard to see how these projects can achieve their potential. The Teesside project, for example, has been trying to raise a budget to place a benefits officer in prisons one day a week, but the cabinet office will not provide the funds. Mowlam has promised to discuss the matter with the treasury.

fields.headline: Flights of fancy
fields.standfirst: From an eerie screech to a joyful song, birds have carved an  indelible mark on our psyche. Guardian country diarist  Mark Cocker aims to garner fascinating fact and fiction
fields.trailText: From an eerie screech to a joyful song, birds have carved an indelible mark on our psyche. Guardian country diarist Mark Cocker aims to garner fascinating fact and fiction.
fields.body:
It was a male that called first, a long wavering hoot which lingered in the air like a question mark, begging some kind of response. Back instantly came an answer, an intense, high-pitched "kee-wick" that cut through the darkness like a blade. It was a classic duet by a male and female tawny owl, a love conversation that Shakespeare rendered in a mnemonic known to every school child: "Tu-whit, tu-woo".

I interpret the sound in the way the bard himself described it on this occasion, as "a merry note". Owls are among the first to breed of our resident birds and their vocalisations are correspondingly early in the season. Owl song in February is a hopeful, reassuring sign that their mothering woods are just beginning to return to life.

But owls haven't always been interpreted so positively. Histor ically, they were much more associated with death and disaster. Shakespeare's plays are littered with this kind of reference. At the moment of Duncan's murder, Lady Macbeth says:

Hark! Peace!
It was the owl that shriek'd,
the fatal bellman,
Which gives the stern'st good-night.

To have an owl calling about your house was usually read as an ominous portent for those within. There is a wonderful tragi-comic story from the 19th century of a landowner moved to find his gardener and two sons, dressed in black and clearly mourning for a wife and mother who had recently fallen ill. But, no, the gardener revealed to his master, the woman wasn't actually dead yet. However, an owl had landed near the cottage and hooted repeatedly. Being an experienced countryman, the gardener knew how to read the signs and was preparing his family for the worst.

We might scoff now at this rustic superstition, but the notions touched even the most distinguished intellectuals. John Ruskin once admitted: "I have found the owl's cry always prophetic of mischief to me."

In a sense, Ruskin, the superstitious gardener and I all have one thing in common: we have taken the owl's call to be something more than a simple sound. This is a role birds have played probably since the dawn of human consciousness.

Virtually the entire British avifauna has been taken as an omen of some kind. A solitary magpie was a sign of mischief and a single raven of something even more sinister. Lapwings and thrushes heralded the arrival of spring. Swallows nesting on the farm were a lucky charm, while the bittern's boom was a doom-laden sound. Geese on an autumn northerly marked the onset of winter. Fieldfares overhead suggested bad weather and waxwings, those strange Scandinavian wanderers with their ridiculous crests like conical hats, were virtual proof of a big freeze to come.

All this old bird lore is an indication of their central role in folk culture, but it is perhaps a decline from the days when birds held real power over the human imagination. During the classical period, the Greek and Roman states maintained a body of priests whose specific task was to read bird signs. Augury involved interpreting future events from the way birds were calling or whether they flocked from the left or the right. The augur's pronouncements could shape major state policies, such as whether to go to war.

Making the sparrow's chirp a matter of life and death sounds both absurd and fantastically remote from our own society. But it isn't really too distant from the current situation. The present government recently announced the establishment of a number of indices to monitor changes in the quality of life; bird populations were selected as the key environmental yardstick. Making birds a measure of the good life is our equivalent of Rome's state augury. It indicates the bird's continuing dual role as an inhabitant of the real world and as a symbol that helps shape our internal sense of life.

The importance of birds as fellow companions in the British landscape is beyond dispute. The Royal Society for the Protection of Birds now has over 1m members - more than all the political parties put together. At the last count, in its monumental publication, The New Atlas of Breeding Birds in Britain and Ireland, the British Trust for Ornithology and its army of devoted volunteers calculated that these islands hold 148,684,606 nesting birds, give or take the odd error and omission. We know the figures in detail because British birds have probably been more intensively studied than any other community of wild animals on the planet. And the reason we monitor them so incessantly is because we care. Perhaps as a way of compensating for our alienation from the natural world, the British have fallen in love with their birds.

Now Richard Mabey and I are setting out to chart this ancient relationship in a new book entitled Birds Britannica. It follows the same format as Mabey's successful companion volume, Flora Britannica, and looks at all the birds on the British and Irish lists. The aim is to capture what remains of the old bird lore, such as the owl's dark prophetic status, but also to document the legion of new stories that have sprung up since Victorian folklorists produced the last major studies. In combination, it will create the equivalent of a modern folklore, a domesday account of the part birds play in the nation's cultural life.

Every household seems to have its store of bird tales and the stories gathered to date have been by turns startling, heart-warming and funny. There are the fulmars found eating used condoms; the house sparrows nesting 640 metres underground in a Yorkshire coalmine; the swallows allowed to nest above a couple's bed, while they slept for weeks under a huge plastic sheet and were woken at 4am each day by the twittering of hungry chicks.

Another favourite is a former paratrooper's practice of breeding barn owls and releasing them back into the wild. "I live for my barn owls," he says. "I've done so much damage in my life to people, this is my way of putting something back."

Now there's a new myth in the making: the owl, not so much a symbol of death but as a means of redemption.
