fields.headline: Help and understanding
fields.standfirst: The Shipman trial left families and friends coming to terms with grief but,  as Helen Reeves writes, a team of volunteers is there to assist
fields.trailText: The Shipman trial left families and friends coming to terms with grief but, as Helen Reeves writes, a team of volunteers is there to assist.
fields.body:
The case of the Greater Manchester GP, Harold Shipman, who last month was convicted of murdering 15 of his patients, has been analysed extensively. Lawyers, psychologists, health officers and politicians have asked the usual questions: how did this happen, what are the implications and how can we prevent it?

But on this occasion, the news coverage also considered the devastating impact on the victims' family and friends, all those individuals who attended Preston crown court daily to give their evidence, or simply to watch and listen as the horrific facts slowly emerged. In the reporting of this case you may have been surprised to hear occasional reference to the charity, Victim Support. This is not the type of case that people usually associate with our work but throughout this long trial, quietly and behind the scenes, a large network of staff and volunteers provided support, comfort and information to the bereaved, whether or not they were at the trial.

These volunteers came from Manchester and Lancashire, or from some of the 16,000 people who currently work in local Victim Support schemes and witnesses services. All these volunteers were selected and trained to deal with the special aspects of grief and pain that is caused by violent crime.

They have supported people through other tragedies and have a practical knowledge of the work of the police and the courts. They understand what is required of a witness and, through their supervisors, they were able to provide a range of special facilities, such as a quiet place to wait to give evidence or help with practical matters such as claiming expenses. For those who did not have to give evidence, but who felt they needed to be present at the trial, we were able to gain access to the newly-negotiated funds to pay for the repeated long journeys to and from the court.

The witness service, run by Victim Support, already operates in every crown court building and is poised for rapid expansion into every criminal court. The government is supporting its expansion into magistrates' and youth courts, and the armed forces want it to be present in the courts martial.

This new interest stems from a growing recognition that victims and witnesses are entitled to human rights, many of which have been denied them for too long. It has also become clear that well-prepared and supported witnesses are generally better able to give evidence in the stressful and unfamiliar surroundings of the courtroom.

At Victim Support, we are delighted that more attention is, at last, being given to the special needs of some of the most vulnerable members of society who, all too often, become the targets of criminal predators. Last year alone, we supported more than 12,000 children and young people who were called to give evidence in court. This number will increase dramatically over the next two years as the service expands.

Cases involving other vulnerable individuals, including those with learning difficulties or physical and mental health problems, are now more likely to reach the courts as the extra protection and support provided by the youth justice and criminal evidence act comes into effect. In the past, many of these cases would have been abandoned because of the perceived difficulties for these witnesses to give evidence. Victim Support is already planning for this welcome and overdue reform. Of course, to do this more volunteers will be needed, more training will be required, and we will need to work in even closer liaison with the other expert groups in the community.

We recognise that certain types of crime, such as sexual or racial violence as well as crimes per-petrated against vulnerable individ uals, are far less likely to proceed through the criminal justice system, or even to be reported to the police. These individuals are supported by Victim Support's network of community schemes.

Last year, for example, Victim Support schemes offered a specialist service to more than 18,000 victims of rape and other sexual crimes and the long-term nature of this work means that we continue to help people long after a court case has ended. People's feelings don't end with a court case, even though the publicity usually does.

But if this work is so essential why do volunteers provide it? The most important reason is that volunteers, with the right level of professional training and support, do it exceptionally well. Our volunteers are local people who offer their time free of charge and thus act as representatives of the commnity in which the crime has occurred and demonstrate the concern of that community through the support they offer.

Volunteering provides a rare opportunity to make a positive difference and to begin to deal with the effects of crime. The terrible crimes committed by Shipman have devastated a community. It needs a community response to begin to heal these wounds.

 Dame Helen Reeves is chief executive of Victim Support

fields.headline: Off cuts
fields.trailText: Laurie Taylor
fields.body:
Over the years, I've participated in several broadcast discussions about marital breakdown and divorce. There has been one constant factor: after each programme there will be half-a-dozen irate letters on my desk complaining that it was all very well for the participants to talk about their own wishes but why was so little attention paid to the victims of any familial breakdown - the children?

My reaction to these letters has always been ambivalent. There is no doubt something self-serving about the manner in which some divorcees with children justify their chosen living arrangements, but isn't there also something unsatisfactory about constantly casting the child as a potential victim of such arrangements?

It was, after all, the need to get away from the image of the child as victim which led the authors of the 1987 report of the inquiry into child abuse in Cleveland to insist that "the child is a person and not an object of concern". But although this sentiment has frequently been quoted, the vulnerable child remains a stock image in awareness campaigns about childhood deprivation and abuse.

Carol Smart, the director of the Centre for Research on Family, Kinship and Childhood at Leeds university, has recently tried to remedy this situation. Together with co-researcher Bren Neale, she set out to discover what 52 children of divorced parents thought about children having a voice in the resolution of family problems. They were not quizzed about their own feelings and emotions - a standard approach to the assumed "victim" - but were given ethical vignettes involving other children of divorced parents and were asked what advice they would offer.

The results nicely confirmed the value of treating a child as a person. All but the youngest thought it important that children should have a say in post-divorce arrangements. They were particularly hostile to parents who wanted to involve them in their own conflicts and to recruit them as allies. They wanted parents to behave civilly and believed that matters would not be helped by the intervention of outside agencies.

These are not surprising findings but they do suggest that having such conversations with children outside the family context is something which should become a routine part of planning post-divorce arrangements. As one 15 year old told the researchers: "He should get a say in it, he shouldn't be left out. I mean, it's his life as well."

 Laurie Taylor talks to Carol Smart about children's views on post-divorce parenting on Radio 4's Thinking Allowed at 4 pm today.

fields.headline: Greet expectations
fields.standfirst: Lynne Wallis meets the men and women giving bouncers a good name
fields.trailText: Lynne Wallis meets the men and women giving bouncers a good name.
fields.body:
The nasty, threatening image isn't easy to erase. "It isn't so long ago that landlords looking to protect licensed premises would put the thickest, ugliest thug they could find into a blazer and stick him on the door," says Andrew Nicholls, security, safety and licensing manager for Bass Leisure Retail. Thankfully, no more.

The British Institute of Innkeeping (BII), the voluntary membership body for landlords of licensed premises, is administering its first approved training course for bouncers - or door operatives, as they prefer to call them. The BII's qualifications manager, Kathy Smith, explains: "We realised that too many doormen were dealing drugs or using violence too readily, and there's no place for that sort of behaviour any more. We wanted to develop some proper training to teach door operatives social skills and customer care."

The door supervisors' national certificate is increasingly becoming a requirement for doormen and women, who must register with their local authority prior to working the door. The course involves three days' study in a classroom, followed by a 45-minute examination. Backed by police, magistrates and the security industry, it is regarded by local authorities as the qualification for doormen and women.

Andrew Nicholls ran the first accredited class at one of Bass's new American-style Dave and Buster's leisure complexes in Bristol. The £12m site, which comprises a bar and restaurant, gaming area, snooker tables, conference centre and a golf simulator, has seven "captains of service" on the door at any one time to ensure only the right sort of people are "invited in" - and once in, that they are well looked after and well behaved.

Nicholls's eight men and three women students, whose ages ranged from early 20s to late 40s, were told: "You are the first person customers see. If they are greeted by your back, chatting to your mates, they will be turned off. You only get one chance to make a first impression, so make it a good one."

Nicholls says: "Their job is as much about helping customers as anything else, but they don't put up with behaviour that will upset our customers either."

Whereas old-style bouncers might have a knuckleduster in their pocket, the captains have notebooks in case they have to write down details of an incident for police purposes, and wear pull-off "throttle safe" ties in case they are grabbed by aggressive customers.

On their own dress code, Nicholls says: "No white socks - especially with black shoes and grey trousers. That looks terrible." They are even given handy hints on uniform care, including how to remove lipstick, blood and coffee from their jackets.

On body language, Nicholls says: "Sticking the chest out, standing feet apart with hands clasped in front is definitely a no-no. Open and approachable is what we are aiming for. Folded arms means you're disinterested, and no frowning or eye rolling. And no swearing. Ever.

"You might have had 45 minutes of abuse from a drunken young lad who has been asked to leave for mine-sweeping (pinching people's drinks) but as soon as you say 'Piss off, sonny', you can bet your life a customer will overhear you. That isn't the sort of image we want. And trouble attracts trouble."

Nicholls says women are good on the door for diffusing difficult situations, but five out of his eight male students are extremely beefy.

Mike Isaacson, 50, a big, gentle man known as Tiny, has been in security for 12 years, working holiday camps, supermarkets and pubs. He says: "If I get an aggressive drunk, I befriend him because I've got to get him off the premises. The phrase we use is 'talk 'em and walk 'em'. That way you're minimising the risk."

Although Dave and Buster's is out of town, just off the M4, it still attracts crime. While we are talking, a young female student's car is being trashed outside the complex. She reacts badly and leaves the course just after lunch, weeping. Bass have only banned six people from entry since the complex opened a year ago, but this doesn't account for crimes in the car park.

Rob Poppe, a 28-year-old rugby playing ex-Para, who works the door in between studying geography at Bristol university, asks: "Where does our duty of care end? If I see five lads beating up someone in the car park, do I interfere?" Dragging the victim inside the club's doors for protection was deemed the best option.

Mike Greenhill was a residential social worker before he became a doorman at Bass's Hollywood Bowl in Taunton, Devon, five years ago. "The main problem in Taunton is there isn't enough for young people to do and our main requirement is to keep the noise down," he says. But he wouldn't go back to his old job. "Working the door can be tough but at least in this job I'm dealing with kids who know the difference between right and wrong."

fields.headline: Cover stories
fields.trailText: A Huddersfield football fan named his baby after the club's top striker, Marcus Stewart, two weeks before the player was transferred to First Division promotion rivals Ipswich.
fields.body:
Kissing cousins: Researchers at Chester Zoo say that a study of chimpanzees shows that they kiss and make up after a row.

High drama: Emergency staff at a hospital in Hampstead, London, treated a man for inhaling fumes from his socks, which had caught light while drying in front of the fire.

Slagged off: Developers of a prestigious housing estate on former colliery land in Tankersley, South Yorkshire, have been told by the parish council that they cannot use names such as Mulberry Grove and Willow Court because they are too pretentious.

Bloody inept: A burglar who broke into a house in Southam, Warwickshire, took only a plaster from the first aid kit after cutting himself on broken glass on the way in.

Nuptial mess: A bride who had to travel to her wedding in a neighbour's car and then to the reception by tram has won £250 compensation from the Manchester taxi firm that failed to send the car she had booked for her big day.

Inched out: The opening of a new hospital in Chepstow, Monmouthshire, has been delayed because the doors were four inches too narrow for emergency beds.

Pitter-pattern: A man who put non-drying paint on the garden wall of his home in Newcastle upon Tyne to deter burglars was embarrassed when a cat climbed over the wall and then walked across a neighbour's £15,000 sports car.

Video nasty: Firefighters were called to free an 18-month-old Liverpool child who got his hand stuck while trying to take a Fireman Sam tape out of the video recorder.

'Ello, 'ello: A former police station converted into a home in Melton, Suffolk, has been named Evening Hall.

'Ello, 'ello again: A new slip road that passes by a police operations complex near Sheffield airport has appeared on an Ordnance Survey map as Letsby Avenue.

Plum job: The owners of a Japanese restaurant in Hove, Sussex, who set up a mail order website have received a request from a couple in the US who want 2kg of pickled koume plums to serve in Martinis.

Danger signs: Romantics have been asked by the local council to stop putting up makeshift love messages on a busy roundabout at Kidlington, Oxfordshire, in case they cause an accident.

Spelling disaster: Posters promoting literacy at primary schools in Devon have had to be reprinted, at a cost of £7,000, because they contained spelling mistakes.

Name of the game: A Huddersfield football fan named his baby after the club's top striker, Marcus Stewart, two weeks before the player was transferred to First Division promotion rivals Ipswich.

webTitle: BNFL hit by second false data discovery

fields.headline: BNFL hit by second false data discovery
fields.trailText: A German nuclear company was "surprised and angry" yesterday to discover that documents accompanying fuel supplied by British Nuclear Fuels more than three years ago had been falsified. Officials at the company will decide today whether to shut down a nuclear plant the size of Sizewell B.
fields.byline: John Hooper in Berlin and Paul Brown
fields.body:
A German nuclear company was "surprised and angry" yesterday to discover that documents accompanying fuel supplied by British Nuclear Fuels more than three years ago had been falsified. Officials at the company will decide today whether to shut down a nuclear plant the size of Sizewell B.

Sources at BNFL admitted last night the questionable fuel - up to 4,000 pellets of reprocessed mixed oxide - had been inside the German reactor since 1996.

This is another severe blow for the UK company, which has already lost its biggest customer in Japan by supplying fuel with falsified documents. Germany is its other main potential market.

This second example of falsified data is a separate incident and underlines the lax management at the plant, which was heavily criticised by the nuclear installations inspectorate in three reports last Friday.

A spokeswoman for the German company, Preussen Elektra, which runs the power station at Unterweser near the Dutch border, said: "BNFL had always assured us that there was no indication of falsified safety documents. We are utterly astonished."

A decision on whether to shut down the plant for checks will be made at a meeting in Hanover of representatives of the national and regional environment ministries, a federal environment ministry spokesman said in Berlin.

The Unterweser plant, a boiling water reactor, generates up to 1,255 megawatts of electricity. Shutting it down during one of the coldest months of the year would cause widespread disruption to power supplies in Germany.

But the discovery that questionable fuel has been in a German reactor for more than three years is of itself an immense embarrassment both to BNFL and the German nuclear industry.

BNFL said yesterday that workers at the mixed oxide plant had measured the batch of pellets as required and were sure they were safe and to specification, but the computer had crashed and the data had been lost. Rather than do the work again, they falsified the data, copying from a previous batch. The fuel was then made into rods, delivered to the German company and placed in the reactor.

BNFL said this was an isolated example. The Japanese falsification had happened much later, when workers had routinely falsified papers rather than laboriously check samples by hand.

Whatever the circumstances, the discovery that BNFL had also sent false papers on plutonium fuel pellets to Germany poses a further clear threat to its commercial relationship. It must set back further the company's prospects for partial privatisation.

BNFL has to justify the commercial prospects for its new £300m mixed oxide plant to the government before it can get a licence to run it - a task which looks virtually impossible since there are no customers.

The revelation comes at a supremely awkward moment for the German power utilities. Gerhard Schröder's coalition government, which includes the Greens, is committed to a phased withdrawal from nuclear energy.

The environment minister, Jürgen Trittin, a Green, on Monday called on the electricity companies to consider whether they should continue their relationship with a trading partner "which has shown itself to be unreliable".

BNFL has now been given two months by the nuclear installations inspectorate to come up with management plans to improve safety or face having some of its operations shut down.

It must set back further the company's prospects for partial privatisation. BNFL has to justify the commercial prospects for its new £300m mixed oxide plant to the government before it can get a licence to run it - a task which looks virtually impossible since there are no customers. The revelation comes at a supremely awkward moment for the German power utilities. Gerhard Schröder's coalition government, which includes the Greens, is committed to a phased withdrawal from nuclear energy. The environment minister, Jürgen Trittin, a Green, on Monday called on the electricity companies to consider whether they should continue their relationship with a trading partner "which has shown itself to be unreliable". BNFL has now been given two months by the nuclear installations inspectorate to come up with management plans to improve safety or face having some of its operations shut down.

webTitle: Women take lead in Welsh cabinet posts

fields.headline: Women take lead in Welsh cabinet posts
fields.standfirst: Devolution in Wales: special report
fields.trailText: The Welsh cabinet yesterday became the first executive body in the western world to boast a majority of women ministers.
fields.body:
The Welsh cabinet yesterday became the first executive body in the western world to boast a majority of women ministers.

The appointment of a fifth woman to the nine-member cabinet was hailed as a milestone in equal opportunities by the new Labour first secretary, Rhodri Morgan.

Sue Essex, 54, was awarded the post of environment secretary as part of a minor reshuffle by Mr Morgan, joining the four existing female members of his Labour cabinet.

Tony Blair's cabinet, by contrast, contains only four women out of a total of 22 members, while men outnumber their female cabinet colleagues in every other European country.

Mr Morgan said: "Wales is now the only cabinet in any democratic country in the west with a majority of women in the cabinet.

"This is a small step for the Welsh cabinet but it's a giant leap for Welsh womankind. Wales has overtaken even the Scandinavian countries which have historically had more women in their governments."

However, he was at pains to stress that Ms Essex, who was also the first female leader of Cardiff city council, had been appointed "entirely on her own merits".

The remaining four female Welsh cabinet members - agriculture and rural economy sceretary Christine Gwyther; finance secretary Edwina Hart; health and social services sceretary Jane Hutt, and education secretary Rosemary Butler - were all appointed by Mr Morgan's predecessor, Alun Michael.

The traditionally male-dominated structure of Welsh politics made Wales an unlikely frontrunner for breaking the gender barrier.

But it was the twinning campaign at last May's assembly elections, which saw two constituency parties jointly selecting a male and a female candidate from a shortlist, then allocating one to fight each seat, which resulted in women making up 40% of the assembly, with 15 of the Labour group's 28 members being female.

Ms Essex, a university lecturer in planning, described her appointment as "staggering". She added: "It's wonderful. I think from the Labour party's point of view, we've broken the traditional glass ceiling."

fields.headline: The wanderer returns
fields.standfirst: A biography of Graeme Wright
fields.trailText: Graeme Wright is unique in the history of Wisden editors. Eight years after handing the editorial reigns of the cricket bible to Matthew Engel, he is returning to the edit the best-selling Almanack for one year only - the 138th imprint, Wisden 2001 - during Matthew's unprecedented sabbatical.
fields.body:
Graeme Wright is unique in the history of Wisden editors. Eight years after handing the editorial reigns of the cricket bible to Matthew Engel, he is returning to the edit the best-selling Almanack for one year only - the 138th imprint, Wisden 2001 - during Matthew's unprecedented sabbatical.

A vigorous critic of the shortcomings he saw in cricket's standards on and off the field, Graeme was editor from 1987 to 1992, editions 124 to 129. He had been assistant editor for the previous eight years and to two editors, John Woodcock and Norman Preston. Since standing down, Graeme has sat on the John Wisden management board.

Wright is fulsome in his praise for the way Engel has taken Wisden forward, commending the gentle, evolutionary revolution since 1992. "Wisden is an extraordinary institution," he says. "To be its editor is a rare privilege and I feel doubly privileged in having this opportunity to do the job a second time."

Now aged 57, Wright was born, raised and educated in Wellington, New Zealand. Driven by traditional antipodean wanderlust, he came to Britain in 1968 and has lived in London ever since, working in a variety of editorial and publishing posts. From 1974 onwards, he's been a freelance editor and writer.

Like many of his countrymen, Graeme spent his winters playing rugby and his summers playing cricket. Once a medium-quick bowler (his slinging action is said to be vaguely reminiscent of Jeff Thomson's) and a useful batsman, he now finds his life-long interest in cricket sustained by its psychological and technical sides, the game's mental as well as physical aspects.

In 1993, he wrote Betrayal, one of the most incisive analyses ever of the parlous state of English cricket, which was received to almost universal acclaim (except at Lord's). "English cricket went seriously off-key during my time editing Wisden," he notes, "and it hasn't become any better since." Betrayal was described by cricket and music writer Tim de Lisle as "a 12-inch remix of Graeme's Wisden editor's notes".

Graeme currently writes for the Independent on Sunday and has just finished his first novel - an analysis of England under Thatcher, with the renovation of his house as a metaphor. "It's like Betrayal, with sex in place of the cricket".

webTitle: From cricket correspondent to cricket moderniser

fields.headline: From cricket correspondent to cricket moderniser
fields.standfirst: A biography of Matthew Engel
fields.trailText: Matthew Engel has edited Wisden Cricketers' Almanack since 1992. The year 2000 edition, the 137th continuous imprint which will be published on April 6, is his eighth as editor and the seventh under the ownership of Sir Paul Getty. Following publication, Matthew is taking the unprecedented step of standing aside as editor for a year. During his sabbatical, the cricket "bible" will be edited by his immediate predecessor, Graeme Wright.
fields.body:
Matthew Engel has edited Wisden Cricketers' Almanack since 1992. The year 2000 edition, the 137th continuous imprint which will be published on April 6, is his eighth as editor and the seventh under the ownership of Sir Paul Getty. Following publication, Matthew is taking the unprecedented step of standing aside as editor for a year. During his sabbatical, the cricket "bible" will be edited by his immediate predecessor, Graeme Wright.

Engel is also a columnist on The Guardian, where he has written on almost everything since 1979. He has covered three General Elections, Princess Diana's funeral, the fall of the Berlin Wall, the Gulf War, and about 70 different sports from cricket to underwater hockey. He now writes a weekly column for the paper - Engel on Tuesday - which has recently covered subjects as diverse as Welsh politics, corporate helplines and chicken soup.

Matthew Engel took a politics degree at Manchester University and worked on the Northampton Chronicle and Echo and at Reuters before joining The Guardian. He spent five years as cricket correspondent and won two sportswriter of the year awards.

His appointment to edit Wisden - a surprise at the time - was announced by Graeme Wright at the Wisden dinner on the night before the 1992 General Election. In his acceptance speech, Matthew declared that it was the first result of the polls: "Wisden Central, a safe Conservative seat, gained by the Monster Raving Loony Party".

He also pledged to uphold Wisden's independence, integrity and accuracy, and has since won widespread praise for his policy of slowly modernising the book without compromising its reputation. A volume with over 1,500 pages - regarded by some as a dusty book of statistics and solemn comment - is now valued by its aficionados not only for its factual reliability but also for its emphasis on cricket's humour, oddities and quirkiness.

Matthew lives with his wife Hilary, their seven year-old son Laurie (a promising batsman against his father's bowling), and one-year-old daughter Victoria in rural Herefordshire, together with a collection of cats, a terrier, ducks (none with golden plumage) and chickens. These are mostly named after cricketers, male and female. His books include a history of tabloid newspapers, Tickle the Public (1996), described in Press Gazette as a book of "wry, wise, wicked wit". He lists his recreation in Who's Who as whingeing.

webTitle: Denzel Washington and Norman Jewison - part two

fields.headline: Denzel Washington and Norman Jewison - part two
fields.standfirst:
• Listen to Denzel Washington on his choice of roles
• Listen to Norman Jewison on political pressure and The Hurricane
• Listen to Denzel Washington on racism in Hollywood
• Listen to Denzel Washington on anger
• Listen to Norman Jewison on Robert Kennedy
fields.trailText: Part two of the Denzel Washington and Norman Jewison interview at BFI Southbank
fields.body:
Question 1: What are Rubin Carter's opinions of the movie?

NJ: I was very nervous, naturally, to show it to Rubin because he may be 62 years old but, man, could he throw a punch! (Laughter). It was an emotional moment for him to have to sit there and look at his life. There was a silence when the film finished - it was three hours long with a lot of scenes in it that aren't in the film now - and he got up and he turned and I was watching - and he's blind in one eye, he lost an eye while he was in prison - and there was a pause and then I could see he was crying and then he threw his arms around me and said, "You did a good job, brother". I think he's pleased (Laughter) I don't think he's really upset and he always said to me, "I didn't know that I was that good-looking" (Laughter).

TP: How did he react to you Denzel?

DW: I wasn't there so it was different for me. I actually heard about it from other people, because I was afraid to call him (Laughter) 'cause he had said to me when we were sitting around and talking before shooting, "If you don't get this right Denzel I'm a-gonna come and see yer" (Laughter). I said to him then, "If I didn't think this was bigger than you and I then I'd be worried about that". But I do think it's bigger than him and I so I wasn't worried about it and he was quite pleased.

Question 2: What scenes got cut?

NJ: I get nervous when a picture goes beyond two hours. Most of my films are not that long. Outside Fiddler on the Roof I don't think I've ever done a picture 2 hours and 25 minutes. I took out a scene where the Canadians are arguing between themselves about whether they should go down to New Jersey. They did have reservations; it did take a long period of time. I took out a scene where the police harassed them in the little apartment they were living in - which happened, which was true. I took out a wonderful scene between Vicellous and Denzel when he looks at the wall and Denzel describes how Rubin sat in prison and looked at the wall and could see a pinpoint of light and he concentrated on that light and he said, "If you keep looking at it, you can see through it and I can see flowers of the most beautiful kind and I can smell their odours and it gets bigger and I can see children and I..." And poor Lesra's looking at the wall and he can't... and I liked it because it gave you an insight into the fact that he was talking about freedom, he could see his freedom, even though he never left his cell and that's what why he retreated, I think, into so many spiritual journeys, whether it was with Gandhi or Dr King, or Malcolm or Krishnamurti. I kind of wish I'd left the scene in, the trouble is the picture was getting so long I was afraid people were going to go to sleep.

Question 3: Your film deals with racism and corruption in the judiciary and the police. Was it difficult to get the film made?

NJ: David Picker tried to get this film made 8 - 10 years ago and couldn't get the money to make it, couldn't get the support. I don't think it's the kind of film that the studios are looking for these days (Laughter). We're in a period where content isn't very important (Laughter and applause). No, it was an independent film company, but I don't think there were any political pressures. There's a lot of political pressure now that we've made it. There's one guy in the Newark Ledger who's such a racist I think he wants to try Rubin again - after the Supreme Court has ruled on it! (Laughter) You can't believe the talk shows, you cannot believe it. There's people calling in from New Jersey saying, "I wasn't in the picture, it's not right" (Laughter).

TP: It's remarkable any time you make a film about race, it's never the people's town, they were never there!

Question 4: Which of your roles has given you the most personal satisfaction?

DW: Probably the first one ocause my rent was due! (Laughter). I'm asked this a lot and usually answer in a very clichèd way, "My next film is my favourite". I really enjoy the process, I learn a lot and I've gotten a lot from all of them. Working on Cry Freedom was wonderful in that I got to go to Africa for the first time and that was an amazing thing. But in terms of the role itself I don't have a favourite.

Question 5: What's the difference between Norman Jewison and Spike Lee when you're working on a film about racial prejudice?

DW: Different film making styles. I get along with both filmmakers and I can't even answer that question and if I could, I wouldn't.

TP: You have said that it was quite different working on The Soldier's Story which had an all-black cast than on films which didn't have an all-black cast. Can you say a little bit about that?

DW: Did I say that?! When I did A Soldier's Story with Norman I was very young and green and thought I knew everything - now I know I know everything! - it was a very different time in my life and career but just in terms of styles there are two entirely different approaches they have to making films and I've made three films with Spike and I've made two with Norman and would love to make it three. I will continue to work with both of them. I love working with both of them.

Question 6: Is Hollywood still racist towards actors?

DW: I always say racism doesn't start at the California border, or the border of Hollywood, racism is a factor in US, if not in the world. It's also a factor, obviously, in Hollywood. Where I think the most work needs to be done is behind the camera, not in front of it. One of the things we've seen in the 80s with the Spike Lees and the Robert Townsends and other filmmakers is that if you go for it and take the time and put in the effort to write your own material and absolutely refuse to be denied the right to make your film it is difficult whatever colour you are. But I think that's where the future lies. I think that if there can be considered racism it's to do with the lack of opportunities for writers and producers and the people behind the camera. That being said, it's very difficult for women of any colour in Hollywood. The men get older and the women get younger somehow and I think the bottom of the totem pole is African-American women, or women of colour. I think they get the least opportunities in Hollywood and they have the toughest road ahead of them. I've been very blessed. I've made 26 films in 20 years and haven't been unemployed for 20 years. I'm an exception to the rule but I still think we've got a long way to go. The NAACP has been very active in Los Angeles and they've been putting a lot of pressure on the studios to hire more people and I think that's good 'cause I know the minute they stop doing that then there'll be less and less people of colour in those positions. I think we've made some inroads when you look at the way Hattie McDaniel had to perform and the way African-Americans can perform now we've come a long way.

Question 7: After shooting finished did you have any anger towards white people?

DW: At the end of the film?! (Laughter). One good thing about acting in film is that it's good therapy. It's a process to have an effect on the audience. If you did then in some ways I've done my job, but I get a lot of my emotions and anger in the work itself and I've been around the block. As Malcolm X used to say, it's one thing to be angry, it's another thing to know - just to be angry and out of control won't do you any good, if you have an enemy then learn and know your enemy, don't just be mad at him or her. My career for a long time has been about the business of doing something about the anger that I felt and through the roles that I play and it's no coincidence that playing some of the roles that I play is for a particular reason, for a particular effect - like Malcolm X and The Hurricane. I'm not afraid to upset people. But I am not as upset because I understand what I'm up against.

Question 8: Tell us your experience on working on The Heat of the Night

NJ: I knew it was going to be a controversial film, an important film simply because of the times. This was probably before you were born -1966 we were shooting. I think timing has a great deal to do with films. There's a wonderful story about timing. I was skiing in Sun Valley at Christmas, just before shooting In the Heat of the Night, and I met Bobby Kennedy - our kids both broke legs in a ski race and I met him in the hospital and he asked me what I did and I told him a little bit about the story, about a black detective who works in Philadelphia and he gets stuck in a Mississippi town and the red-neck sheriff and the circumstances and the racism. And he said, "This is a very important film, Norman. Timing is everything in life, in art, in politics." And so we had spent New Year's Eve together then he sent me research on young people in the Southern United States at that time, and he stayed in touch, he really was sincere about it. I didn't think too much of it but when the film was finished it won the New York Critics' award and I went to New York to get the award and who was giving out the awards? The senator of New York, Robert Kennedy. As I went up to get the award he says, "See, I told you that timing was everything!"

Question 9: Was the decision to shoot the boxing scenes in black and white homage to Raging Bull?

NJ: As much as I'd like to say I was paying homage to Martin Scorsese I really wasn't. The reason I shot it in black and white was that I had a long discussion with Roger Deakins, the British cameraman who shot this film who I think is quite brilliant, probably as good a cameraman as I've ever worked with in my life. Scorsese's film is brilliantly done, but it's very stylised like they built the ring in certain ways, there's a lot of steam and slow motion and so on and I wanted a very terse almost semi-journalistic, very real, believable boxing scenes which meant that Denzel would have to go into training for God knows how long (Laughter) and box two hours a day for six months. He lost over 40 pounds, he was unbelievable, what he did personally. Because you're all alone, the director can't help you. You're going to be there all alone. A pair of shorts and that's it. You can't use stand-ins, you can't do anything. It has to be very carefully choreographed so that no one gets hurt. The only reference we had was black and white television, we had the old Monday night fights, the Gillette fights, "It's Monday night, the fight!" But the reason that they were in black and white was because there was no colour television so here we were looking at all these black and white [shows] and I said, "You know if we could just recreate that..." I think that's where it started and then we realized that if we did that the audience would feel maybe that it was going to be a docu-drama, that there was something very real happening because it was period, it was 1966, and then if I went to colour right in the middle of it I could jump the audience from 1966 into the 80s and they would understand that. I think it really helped the film stylistically.

Question 10: If you could choose one person to meet from history who would it be?

DW: That carpenter from Galilee (Laughter)

NJ: I'd like to have dinner with his dad (Laughter)

Question 11: Does artistic power ever scare you?

NJ: I don't think people read as much anymore and I think films have become important. I used to think when I was young that I could change the world, that my films were going to have a great effect on people. I found out that it's still a movie, that there's still that suspension of belief. I worry that people will misinterpret what I'm trying to say. That's what I worry about the most and if I worry about it too much then the film will become simplistic and filled with perhaps with too overt a message, so I try to find stories that I would think that everyone would find interesting, and just a good entertaining story, and then if I can find a story that has a raison d'etre behind it that I feel is important then that's the best for me. But I do think films should be what you pull out of them. They should mean a lot of different things to a lot of different people, perhaps. I don't know, it's hard.

DW: I'd probably be a bit more frightened by not using whatever abilities I'd been given. I'd be more frightened by procrastination and laziness and I agree with Norman in that it is just a movie, on the other hand I receive thousands of letters a year and I see the impact that it has on people. But it's just using what you've been given to say what you feel you want to say.

TP: You said earlier about the universal stemming from the specific and the comparison may be too simple but interestingly someone made the parallel with In the Heat of the Night and this movie. I saw In the Heat of the Night as a kid and the thing that struck me as a young black person watching it was both identification with Sidney Poitier, but the fact that Poitier was able to universalise a story which would mean something to me as a black person but maybe in other circumstances would mean to people who were not black and I get the sense from what people have told me about Hurricane that Denzel Washington has done the same thing in this movie. To what extent is this particular actor important in your being able to universalise a story about racial injustice in a way that a wide audience, besides a black audience, can accept it and identify with it?

NJ: Both actors are so intelligent and extremely sensitive and seem to be able to give the camera an interpretation beyond the script, beyond the lines that are there and I think Denzel is comfortable with himself as a person and therefore he knows who he is. People are comfortable with him, they like someone who is... Mmm, boy, this is hard. (Laughter).

DW: I wonder what Spike would say... ! (Laughter)

TP: I wonder to what extent you consciously feel this because you're now clearly amongst serious actors or actors with serious roles, the leading African-American, and the leading marquee name amongst African-American actors in this genre. This ability and the possibility of being able to universalise these stories is important to you and the choice of roles that you make.

DW: It goes back to the universal stemming from the specific. I don't concern myself with that. I cannot if I am a cup maker [picks up glass] I'm interested in making the best cup that I possibly can. My effort goes into that cup, not what people think about it. Now that may sound selfish but that's the only way I can operate. I can't walk around the room and ask each person their opinion of it - definitely not while I'm making it. And once it's done [slams glass down and looks at it], whatever they think, but I really don't care.

NJ: You see how sure he is! (Laughter)

DW: One of my favourite books was Lust for Life and Van Gogh was out there and burning up in the sun and I dug that, nobody was out there and nobody bought any of his paintings and now look at him. (Laughter) People buy mine but I relate to that. I don't know - and I don't want to say I don't care ocause I do - but I don't know what people are going to think and I don't do it for what I think they're going to think. I do it for what I think and what I feel and hopefully they'll buy that cup.

NJ: I think he's an artist - he doesn't need anyone's approval.

I kind of wish I'd left the scene in, the trouble is the picture was getting so long I was afraid people were going to go to sleep. Question 3: Your film deals with racism and corruption in the judiciary and the police. Was it difficult to get the film made? NJ: David Picker tried to get this film made 8 - 10 years ago and couldn't get the money to make it, couldn't get the support. I don't think it's the kind of film that the studios are looking for these days (Laughter). We're in a period where content isn't very important (Laughter and applause). No, it was an independent film company, but I don't think there were any political pressures. There's a lot of political pressure now that we've made it. There's one guy in the Newark Ledger who's such a racist I think he wants to try Rubin again - after the Supreme Court has ruled on it! (Laughter) You can't believe the talk shows, you cannot believe it. There's people calling in from New Jersey saying, "I wasn't in the picture, it's not right" (Laughter). TP: It's remarkable any time you make a film about race, it's never the people's town, they were never there! Question 4: Which of your roles has given you the most personal satisfaction? DW: Probably the first one ocause my rent was due! (Laughter). I'm asked this a lot and usually answer in a very clichèd way, "My next film is my favourite". I really enjoy the process, I learn a lot and I've gotten a lot from all of them. Working on Cry Freedom was wonderful in that I got to go to Africa for the first time and that was an amazing thing. But in terms of the role itself I don't have a favourite. Question 5: What's the difference between Norman Jewison and Spike Lee when you're working on a film about racial prejudice? DW: Different film making styles. I get along with both filmmakers and I can't even answer that question and if I could, I wouldn't. TP: You have said that it was quite different working on The Soldier's Story which had an all-black cast than on films which didn't have an all-black cast. Can you say a little bit about that? DW: Did I say that?! When I did A Soldier's Story with Norman I was very young and green and thought I knew everything - now I know I know everything! - it was a very different time in my life and career but just in terms of styles there are two entirely different approaches they have to making films and I've made three films with Spike and I've made two with Norman and would love to make it three. I will continue to work with both of them. I love working with both of them. Question 6: Is Hollywood still racist towards actors? DW: I always say racism doesn't start at the California border, or the border of Hollywood, racism is a factor in US, if not in the world. It's also a factor, obviously, in Hollywood. Where I think the most work needs to be done is behind the camera, not in front of it. One of the things we've seen in the 80s with the Spike Lees and the Robert Townsends and other filmmakers is that if you go for it and take the time and put in the effort to write your own material and absolutely refuse to be denied the right to make your film it is difficult whatever colour you are. But I think that's where the future lies. I think that if there can be considered racism it's to do with the lack of opportunities for writers and producers and the people behind the camera. That being said, it's very difficult for women of any colour in Hollywood. The men get older and the women get younger somehow and I think the bottom of the totem pole is African-American women, or women of colour. I think they get the least opportunities in Hollywood and they have the toughest road ahead of them. I've been very blessed. I've made 26 films in 20 years and haven't been unemployed for 20 years. I'm an exception to the rule but I still think we've got a long way to go. The NAACP has been very active in Los Angeles and they've been putting a lot of pressure on the studios to hire more people and I think that's good 'cause I know the minute they stop doing that then there'll be less and less people of colour in those positions. I think we've made some inroads when you look at the way Hattie McDaniel had to perform and the way African-Americans can perform now we've come a long way. Question 7: After shooting finished did you have any anger towards white people? DW: At the end of the film?! (Laughter). One good thing about acting in film is that it's good therapy. It's a process to have an effect on the audience. If you did then in some ways I've done my job, but I get a lot of my emotions and anger in the work itself and I've been around the block. As Malcolm X used to say, it's one thing to be angry, it's another thing to know - just to be angry and out of control won't do you any good, if you have an enemy then learn and know your enemy, don't just be mad at him or her. My career for a long time has been about the business of doing something about the anger that I felt and through the roles that I play and it's no coincidence that playing some of the roles that I play is for a particular reason, for a particular effect - like Malcolm X and The Hurricane. I'm not afraid to upset people. But I am not as upset because I understand what I'm up against. Question 8: Tell us your experience on working on The Heat of the Night NJ: I knew it was going to be a controversial film, an important film simply because of the times. This was probably before you were born -1966 we were shooting. I think timing has a great deal to do with films. There's a wonderful story about timing. I was skiing in Sun Valley at Christmas, just before shooting In the Heat of the Night, and I met Bobby Kennedy - our kids both broke legs in a ski race and I met him in the hospital and he asked me what I did and I told him a little bit about the story, about a black detective who works in Philadelphia and he gets stuck in a Mississippi town and the red-neck sheriff and the circumstances and the racism. And he said, "This is a very important film, Norman. Timing is everything in life, in art, in politics." And so we had spent New Year's Eve together then he sent me research on young people in the Southern United States at that time, and he stayed in touch, he really was sincere about it. I didn't think too much of it but when the film was finished it won the New York Critics' award and I went to New York to get the award and who was giving out the awards? The senator of New York, Robert Kennedy. As I went up to get the award he says, "See, I told you that timing was everything!" Question 9: Was the decision to shoot the boxing scenes in black and white homage to Raging Bull? NJ: As much as I'd like to say I was paying homage to Martin Scorsese I really wasn't. The reason I shot it in black and white was that I had a long discussion with Roger Deakins, the British cameraman who shot this film who I think is quite brilliant, probably as good a cameraman as I've ever worked with in my life. Scorsese's film is brilliantly done, but it's very stylised like they built the ring in certain ways, there's a lot of steam and slow motion and so on and I wanted a very terse almost semi-journalistic, very real, believable boxing scenes which meant that Denzel would have to go into training for God knows how long (Laughter) and box two hours a day for six months. He lost over 40 pounds, he was unbelievable, what he did personally. Because you're all alone, the director can't help you. You're going to be there all alone. A pair of shorts and that's it. You can't use stand-ins, you can't do anything. It has to be very carefully choreographed so that no one gets hurt. The only reference we had was black and white television, we had the old Monday night fights, the Gillette fights, "It's Monday night, the fight!" But the reason that they were in black and white was because there was no colour television so here we were looking at all these black and white [shows] and I said, "You know if we could just recreate that..." I think that's where it started and then we realized that if we did that the audience would feel maybe that it was going to be a docu-drama, that there was something very real happening because it was period, it was 1966, and then if I went to colour right in the middle of it I could jump the audience from 1966 into the 80s and they would understand that. I think it really helped the film stylistically. Question 10: If you could choose one person to meet from history who would it be? DW: That carpenter from Galilee (Laughter) NJ: I'd like to have dinner with his dad (Laughter) Question 11: Does artistic power ever scare you? NJ: I don't think people read as much anymore and I think films have become important. I used to think when I was young that I could change the world, that my films were going to have a great effect on people. I found out that it's still a movie, that there's still that suspension of belief. I worry that people will misinterpret what I'm trying to say. That's what I worry about the most and if I worry about it too much then the film will become simplistic and filled with perhaps with too overt a message, so I try to find stories that I would think that everyone would find interesting, and just a good entertaining story, and then if I can find a story that has a raison d'etre behind it that I feel is important then that's the best for me. But I do think films should be what you pull out of them. They should mean a lot of different things to a lot of different people, perhaps. I don't know, it's hard. DW: I'd probably be a bit more frightened by not using whatever abilities I'd been given. I'd be more frightened by procrastination and laziness and I agree with Norman in that it is just a movie, on the other hand I receive thousands of letters a year and I see the impact that it has on people. But it's just using what you've been given to say what you feel you want to say. TP: You said earlier about the universal stemming from the specific and the comparison may be too simple but interestingly someone made the parallel with In the Heat of the Night and this movie. I saw In the Heat of the Night as a kid and the thing that struck me as a young black person watching it was both identification with Sidney Poitier, but the fact that Poitier was able to universalise a story which would mean something to me as a black person but maybe in other circumstances would mean to people who were not black and I get the sense from what people have told me about Hurricane that Denzel Washington has done the same thing in this movie. To what extent is this particular actor important in your being able to universalise a story about racial injustice in a way that a wide audience, besides a black audience, can accept it and identify with it? NJ: Both actors are so intelligent and extremely sensitive and seem to be able to give the camera an interpretation beyond the script, beyond the lines that are there and I think Denzel is comfortable with himself as a person and therefore he knows who he is. People are comfortable with him, they like someone who is... Mmm, boy, this is hard. (Laughter). DW: I wonder what Spike would say... ! (Laughter) TP: I wonder to what extent you consciously feel this because you're now clearly amongst serious actors or actors with serious roles, the leading African-American, and the leading marquee name amongst African-American actors in this genre. This ability and the possibility of being able to universalise these stories is important to you and the choice of roles that you make. DW: It goes back to the universal stemming from the specific. I don't concern myself with that. I cannot if I am a cup maker [picks up glass] I'm interested in making the best cup that I possibly can. My effort goes into that cup, not what people think about it. Now that may sound selfish but that's the only way I can operate. I can't walk around the room and ask each person their opinion of it - definitely not while I'm making it. And once it's done [slams glass down and looks at it], whatever they think, but I really don't care. NJ: You see how sure he is! (Laughter) DW: One of my favourite books was Lust for Life and Van Gogh was out there and burning up in the sun and I dug that, nobody was out there and nobody bought any of his paintings and now look at him. (Laughter) People buy mine but I relate to that. I don't know - and I don't want to say I don't care ocause I do - but I don't know what people are going to think and I don't do it for what I think they're going to think. I do it for what I think and what I feel and hopefully they'll buy that cup. NJ: I think he's an artist - he doesn't need anyone's approval.

webTitle: Prudential to sell stake in Egg internet bank

fields.headline: Prudential to sell stake in Egg internet bank
fields.trailText: Prudential, Britain's biggest life insurance group, today announced plans to cash in on the success of its pioneering internet bank, Egg, by selling part of it to the public. The sale of a minority stake is expected to raise between £1.5bn and £4bn.
fields.body:
Prudential, Britain's biggest life insurance group, today announced plans to cash in on the success of its pioneering internet bank, Egg, by selling part of it to the public. The sale of a minority stake is expected to raise between £1.5bn and £4bn.

Jonathan Bloomer, Prudential's chief executive designate, said the group had not yet decided how much of Egg to float, but the London stock exchange typically regarded a "minority" stake as something between 15% and 25%.

He said the exact value would be determined at flotation both by Egg's progress and the state of the market.

The launch of Egg in 1998 started a trend in internet banking in Britain. Egg has signed up 800,000 customers by offering attractive interest rates. It had deposit funds of £7.6bn at the end of 1999, and the number of customers is expected to top 1m next month. Prudential said customers who had signed up with Egg before midnight on February 22 were expected to be eligible to participate in the initial public offering.

Egg's success has prompted other banks to jump on the internet bandwagon. Recent research predicts that the number of people in Europe who are banking online will quadruple to 21m by 2004.

Abbey National and Halifax unveiled stand-alone online banks last week, some of which may also be floated. This competition could cause problems for Egg, and shares in the Pru have fallen in the past few weeks. News of the planned float came as Prudential reported a 10% drop in annual operating profits for 1999 to £776m.

Egg and Prudential banking made a loss of £150m last year, compared with £77m in 1998. Prudential said it expected Egg to break even in the latter part of 2001, adding that investment in the concern would be similar to the £150m spent in 1999.

Mr Bloomer ruled out a large-scale merger such as that announced this week by the insurance companies CGU and Norwich Union. However, he said Prudential would look to make acquisitions in Europe to enable it to compete with the likes of Allianz, Axa, Aegon and Generali, as well as the merged CGNU.

Mr Bloomer takes over from Sir Peter Davis as chief executive next month. Sir Peter, who is credited with having transformed Prudential during his tenure, is moving to Sainsbury's, the retail group.

Egg.com

The Prudential

fields.headline: Not the Bruges speech
fields.standfirst: Derek Brown on what we can expect from Tony Blair's European speech in Ghent this afternoon
fields.trailText: 1pm: Derek Brown on what we can expect from Tony Blair's European speech in Ghent this afternoon
fields.body:
Tony Blair is today performing a little dance on the tightrope of euro-policy. He will tell an invited audience in Ghent that postwar Britain has played too little a part in the shaping of European institutions, and that its future lies unequivocally within the European Union.

He will deliberately compare his enthusiasm for the Euro-project, with the negative approach of the previous Conservative government.

That is all very welcome, but what exactly does it mean? The Dear Leader's spinners tell us that he will offer nothing new on British membership of the common currency. Nor, apparently, will he commit himself to what kind of Europe he is so happy about.

Instead, he will perform a delicate pirouette around the ghost of Margaret Thatcher who, in the dying days of her prime ministership, delivered a lecture in Bruges about the dangers of "a European super-state exercising a new dominance from Brussels".

That infamous speech led to the formation of the rampantly anti-European Bruges group of Tories. It tainted our relations with our neighbours for the best part of a decade, and paralysed Britain as a force in the community.

This, according to the carefully leaked advance of Blair's speech, is how he will respond, 12 years on: "My disagreement with Mrs Thatcher's speech in Bruges is not that its criticisms were all unjustified, it's that the response to the criticisms was that Britain should withdraw into its shell and opt out."

Cutting through the thickets of double negatives, it seems the prime minister is saying - maybe - that he, too, is against the concept of the super-state. Fair enough. In that, he belongs to an overwhelming majority of Europeans.

It's also refreshing that he is prepared, however tentatively, to knock on the head the bizarre notion that Britain can somehow go it alone.

What is disappointing, even disturbing, about Blair's mealy-mouthed circumlocution is that it - in the words of the old song - eliminates the negative without accentuating the positive. New Labour, just like Old Conservative, is mesmerised by perceived public antipathy to the whole European enterprise. Ministers dare not raise the level of debate above the dreary recital of statistics about jobs and trade, and reassurances about the defence of national interests.

That's not good enough; not big enough. If we are indeed content to be in Europe, we must begin to think of ourselves as Europeans, and abandon the wretched and irrelevant attitude of Them and Us.

Being Europeans doesn't diminish our Britishness, or Scottishness, or Yorkshireness, or Islingtonianism. We can carry on governing ourselves at every level from parish council to Westminster. For that matter, we can go on playing our part in Nato, the UN and the Commonwealth.

The European Union does not belong to us - we belong to it. It will grow and develop as we want it to, and as our elected leaders decide.

Therein lies a paradox, for the main challenge facing us is how to break the national governments' stranglehold on real power, exercised through the council of ministers. Far from being an incipient super-state, the other institutions of the union are starved of influence, let alone power.

By coincidence, the commission in Brussels is today discussing a bold communitywide commitment to full employment by 2010. The plan is likely to provoke squeals of alarm at next month's summit in Portugal, among national leaders terrified of losing control of economic policymaking.

No doubt the commission blueprint will be savaged by the Europhobes as a sinister new assault on that ridiculous concept, our sovereignty.

But if Europe is to mean anything, there must be European policies. And if Britain is to pull its weight in forming those policies, our leaders really must stop mouthing theological guff about our role, while looking over their shoulders at the opinion polls.

Related documentaries
Economic and Monetary Union: special report
New Labour in power: special report

webTitle: Exotica from the edge of Europe

fields.headline: Exotica from the edge of Europe
fields.standfirst: Jonathan Romney on Portuguese cinema
fields.trailText: Jonathan Romney on Portuguese cinema
fields.body:
This happens at me at every film festival I attend. I tell someone there's this Portuguese film they really need to see; believe me, I get the strangest looks. And even stranger ones once they've seen the film. To be fair, I'd be doing Portuguese cinema a disservice if I tried to portray it as simply bizarre and arcane. It could be, after all, that the Portugal in my head is a completely partial one, based entirely on those few auteur films that get on to the international festival circuit, that once in a blue moon get distributed in Britain, and that occasionally inspire film-makers elsewhere (among them Alain Tanner, Wim Wenders and Time Regained director Raul Ruiz).

Various things may contribute to giving Portuguese cinema its peculiar flavour: its geographic position on the edge of Europe; the folk memory of a crumbled colonial past and the experience of dictatorship this century; a distinctively literary mindset among many film-makers, and the shadow of its modern national poet, the gloom-merchant Fernando Pessoa. Perhaps there's also a sense that, if the outside world couldn't care less, then there's nothing to lose - hence a profusion of strange, severe hot-house blooms.

In fact, some of Portugal's slim national output remains unknown outside the country - its latest box-office hits include a pop-movie vehicle for a TV presenter - and many Portuguese critics are said to be sceptical about the country's artier exports. You can judge the wider picture from a rare package of new Portuguese film that comes to Britain this week under the title Sea Changes.

It opens with the national auteur par excellence - the nonagenarian Manoel de Oliveira (pictured), who made his first film in 1931. His recent autobiographical miniature, Journey to the Beginning of the World, was the very model of what they call an "autumnal masterpiece". His latest film, The Letter, is a rewrite of the 17th- century novel La Princesse de Clèves: in this version, a young aristocrat (Chiara Mastroianni) falls for a Portuguese rock singer - one Pedro Abrunhosa, who plays himself. The ultimate drift of it is just this side of unfathomable, but there's no mistaking the mastery.

Another great individual is Joao Cesar Monteiro, who stars in his own films as his alter ego Joao de Deus. An emaciated, goatish presence, Monteiro is a truly anarchic confrontationalist, with a staggering talent for visual comedy. He can also be a long-winded bore and unsavoury lech; take him as you find him, as they say. The season doesn't feature his best film God's Comedy, about a philosopher- pervert in charge of an ice-cream parlour, but it does have the crazily uncompromising The Hips of JW - a chunk of Strindberg crossed with a plot about an expedition to find John Wayne waggling his hips at the North Pole. It's a staggeringly self-indulgent film, but everyone ought to see Monteiro in action at least once.

The season also represents the reality factor in Portuguese cinema: notably Teresa Vilaverde's punchy, rather Loach-ish Os Mutantes, about young Lisbon delinquents; Mal, an enigmatic tale of urban lost souls; and one genuine overlooked masterpiece - Ossos (Bones) by Pedro Costa. "Bressonian" is a term that's bandied around a lot, but Ossos lives up to it - a very stark picture of impoverished Lisbon shanty youth. Costa lets his emaciated cast stare us out in close-up, or places them in disturbing street scenes - one of them, apparently set up as a v*rit* candid camera routine, has a character hang around a bustling square, trying to palm off his baby on passers by.

Ossos is an example of a national cinema that's accomplished and hard-edged, but that's never going to take over the world, and will probably never even be subject to the same fashionable art-house rediscovery that Iran and Denmark are currently experiencing. Given the European rush to cosmopolitanism in film, there's something strangely old-fashioned in Portuguese film-makers' seriousness and their commitment to a small canvas. There's also a waywardness, a continuing sense that discoveries are always possible. Portugal may be artistically and geographically on the margins, but it may prove to be central in keeping the European art- cinema tradition alive.

 Sea Changes opens at London's Cine Lumiere tomorrow, then tours. Details: 0181-748 0884.

Costa lets his emaciated cast stare us out in close-up, or places them in disturbing street scenes - one of them, apparently set up as a v*rit* candid camera routine, has a character hang around a bustling square, trying to palm off his baby on passers by. Ossos is an example of a national cinema that's accomplished and hard-edged, but that's never going to take over the world, and will probably never even be subject to the same fashionable art-house rediscovery that Iran and Denmark are currently experiencing. Given the European rush to cosmopolitanism in film, there's something strangely old-fashioned in Portuguese film-makers' seriousness and their commitment to a small canvas. There's also a waywardness, a continuing sense that discoveries are always possible. Portugal may be artistically and geographically on the margins, but it may prove to be central in keeping the European art- cinema tradition alive.  Sea Changes opens at London's Cine Lumiere tomorrow, then tours. webTitle: Wisden editor takes back seat as predecessor returns for 2001 edition

fields.headline: Wisden editor takes back seat as predecessor returns for 2001 edition
fields.trailText: The new editor of Wisden Cricketers' Almanack is to be the old editor. New Zealander Graeme Wright, who edited cricket's most famous reference book from 1987 to 1992, is to take charge of the 138th edition: Wisden 2001.
fields.body:
The new editor of Wisden Cricketers' Almanack is to be the old editor. New Zealander Graeme Wright, who edited cricket's most famous reference book from 1987 to 1992, is to take charge of the 138th edition: Wisden 2001.

He replaces Matthew Engel, editor since 1993, who is to take a sabbatical. Engel has just finished editing Wisden 2000, the 1600-page millennium edition, to be published on Thursday April 6. It is the eighth Almanack he has edited, a score surpassed by only three of the 13 editors since Wisden was founded in 1864. Graeme Wright, deputy editor for seven years before his six years in the chair, is the first editor to make a comeback.

Engel said: "It's been a great honour to edit Wisden, and a wonderful challenge. But it's become very wearing, partly because of the growing workload and partly because of having to cope with and explain the continuing failures of English cricket. I think everyone needs a break, including the readers. I hope to be back. In the meantime I'm delighted that Graeme has agreed to have another crack."

"I'm delighted to be coming back to edit next year's edition of Wisden," said Wright. "This is an extraordinary institution. To be editor is a rare privilege and I feel doubly honoured in having this opportunity to do the job for a second time."

Engel will become editor-in-chief of Wisden, overseeing the editorial strategy for all the company's outlets, including Wisden Cricket Monthly, recently named Special Interest Magazine of the Year, and the website wisden.com, both of which continue to be edited by Tim de Lisle. Engel will also continue as a columnist on The Guardian.

The millennium edition of Wisden Cricketers' Almanack, by far the largest ever, will include a special section reviewing the past 100 years including the Wisden choice of Five Cricketers of the Century. These have been chosen by 100 experts, most of them Test players themselves, from all round the cricket world. Each copy of the 2000 Almanack, whether hardback or soft cover, is accompanied by a free paperback book, A Century of Wisden.

The Almanack has a recommended price of £29.99 but readers can save £5 by ordering the book through Wisden Cricket Monthly (March issue on sale now, click here for contents).
