fields.headline: A great feat of ballot-rigging
fields.standfirst: Francis Wheen on: A fantastical election result for Frank Dobson | Blair's jobs for the boys
fields.trailText: John Major likes to joke that even if he stood unopposed in an election, he'd still come second. Frank Dobson has an equally rare but more useful talent. When he stands in a contested election and wins a mere 25,000 votes against 80,000 for his main rival, wily old Dobbo is still declared the winner.
fields.body:
John Major likes to joke that even if he stood unopposed in an election, he'd still come second. Frank Dobson has an equally rare but more useful talent. When he stands in a contested election and wins a mere 25,000 votes against 80,000 for his main rival, wily old Dobbo is still declared the winner.

"Stop whining," John Prescott instructs those of us who have the temerity to raise an eyebrow at this extraordinary feat of ballot-rigging, which would make the late Mayor Daley sigh with admiration. But who are the noisiest whiners? Frank Dobson was belly-aching even after his victory, grumpily assuring us yet again that he was wholeheartedly opposed to Tony Blair's "electoral college" (which is not so much a college as one of those grand-sounding but bogus universities that will sell you a degree certificate for $10). What he wanted, he said, was the verdict of Labour members, as delivered through one member, one vote.

Though he affects to be unaware of it, that verdict was duly delivered; and he lost. It's just as well he doesn't have to face himself in the shaving mirror every morning: if he means what he says, how can Dobson pretend that he is the legitimate Labour candidate?

I put this point to the home office minister Barbara Roche on a Radio 5 phone-in sometime after midnight on Sunday. "Good question," she replied. In my experience, politicians use this compliment only when they have no intention of answering the question, and so it proved.

"Ken Livingstone's campaign," Roche hissed indignantly, "attracted people who are not friends of the Labour party - including some Conservatives!" Has Roche already forgotten that this was precisely how she, Tony and the rest of their unlovely gang came to power in 1997? In other circumstances, and with a different set of dramatis personae, Ken's pluralistic appeal would be hailed by Blairites as a vindication of the Dear Leader's "big tent" strategy.

And what of the selection process? Although Dobbo himself can't defend it, Roche is willing to have a go. "The electoral college isn't a new thing... We used this electoral college for the election of Tony Blair and John Prescott."

Not true, of course. When Tony Blair first made this claim last year, he was swiftly reminded that there were no block votes in the college which elected him, since John Smith had pushed through a rule change forcing unions to ballot their members. And yet automatons such as Roche still repeat it, hoping that mere repetition will make it true.

In this, as in everything, they are simply following their leader. Political power does strange things to the brain: by the time Margaret Thatcher was evicted from Downing Street, she was as nutty as a pecan pie; within weeks of his resignation, Harold Wilson announced that he was a big, fat spider in the corner of the room, and ordered two BBC journalists to go and kick a blind man in the Charing Cross Road; the late Sir William Armstrong, Ted Heath's omnipotent cabinet secretary, was effectively running the country in 1973 while labouring under the delusion that he was a poached egg.

The only difference in Tony Blair's case is how quickly the derangement has set in. The first sound of bats flapping in his belfry was heard even before the election, in December 1996, when he told Des O'Connor that as a 14-year-old he had run away to Newcastle airport and boarded a plane for the Bahamas: "I snuck onto the plane, and we were literally about to take off when the stewardess came up to me..." Quite how he managed this without a boarding card or passport was not explained. It certainly came as a surprise to his father ("The Bahamas? Who said that? Tony? Never"), and an even greater surprise to staff at the airport, who pointed out that there has never been a flight from Newcastle to the Bahamas.

A couple of years later, he told an interviewer that his "teenage hero" was the footballer Jackie Milburn, whom he would watch from the seats behind the goal at St James's Park. In fact, Milburn played his last game for Newcastle United when Blair was just four years old, and there were no seats behind the goal at the time.

Harmless enough, you may think: many of us romanticise or reinvent our childhoods. Even Blair's friend Robert Harris - a writer of fiction, fittingly enough - admits that the PM has a penchant for "reinterpreting reality... retailoring himself and his history to suit the moment".

But Tony's more recent fantasies go beyond boyish daydreams. On Question Time last summer, he informed the audience that he had voted for Mike Foster's anti-hunting bill, which had then been blocked by the wicked old hereditary peers. As I pointed out at the time, Blair did not vote for Foster's bill and it never reached the House of Lords - not because of the hereditaries, but because Blair's own government refused to give it parliamentary time. Nevertheless, he has repeated this self-serving nonsense several times since.

Does Blair know that he's telling falsehoods? Or does he genuinely think that whatever he says must be correct? Mendacious politicians are common enough, and easily dealt with. Sincere fantasists, who can persuade their disciples to believe six impossible things before breakfast, are a more dangerous breed. Some become the leaders of chiliastic cults; others become fascists. Now we appear to have one as prime minister.

In July 1995, on the 50th anniversary of the election of the Attlee government, Tony Blair gave a speech to the Fabian Society describing the damage done by the block vote. "The party lost contact with the electorate, and in the name of internal party democracy gave away its ultimate source of accountability: the people at large. That is why the change to one member, one vote and the changes in the organisation of party conference are so important." Five years on, the man who once promised "a politics of trust" has no trust whatever in his own members, which is why he finds himself maintaining that gerrymandered ballots are the noblest and most modern form of democracy.

It would be comforting to think that he is lying. The more likely - and more alarming - possibility is that he means it.

Gilbert, Sullivan and Falconer

The Home Counties are usually thought to be the last redoubt of Gilbert and Sullivan fans, but in Essex last weekend I couldn't find a cinema that was showing Mike Leigh's new film about the duo, Topsy-Turvy. I had to travel to the heart of London's polenta belt, to the Screen on Islington Green, to catch this magnificent movie.

Can Leigh achieve the impossible and make G&S acceptable in liberal and lefty circles? I do hope so. My own enthusiasm for the Savoy Operas has long been a social embarrassment - shared only with Paul Foot, who can sometimes be heard singing choruses from Trial By Jury as he investigates another miscarriage of justice. (Sorry, Paul: your secret had to come out sooner or later.)

During the Thatcherite privatisations of the 80s, I was often reminded of the nightmare song from Iolanthe: "The shares are a penny and ever so many/Are taken by Rothschild and Baring/But just as a few are allotted to you/You awake with a shudder, despairing." Private Willis's ruminations on political control freaks have lost none of their resonance, and the rise of "Tony's cronies" will come as no surprise to fans of HMS Pinafore, where Sir Joseph Porter describes how he exploited patronage and preferment to become Ruler of the Queen's Navee.

Porter was modelled on the newsagent WH Smith, who was appointed by Disraeli as First Lord of the Admiralty in 1877 even though he had never been to sea. "You would naturally think," WS Gilbert observed, in a summary of Pinafore written for children, "that a person who commanded the entire British Navy would be the most accomplished sailor who could be found, but that is not the way in which such things are managed in England."

Indeed. If you wonder how Tony Blair's childhood chum Lord Falconer has suddenly become Lord High Everything Else in the government, with no discernible qualification or mandate for the job, wonder no more. Sir Joseph Porter KCB is alive and well, and running the Millennium Dome.

webTitle: For sale: John Motson's sheepskin coat

fields.headline: For sale: John Motson's sheepskin coat
fields.trailText: Here's a chance to buy some rather good football memorabilia and do a good turn for charidee while you're at it.
fields.body:
Here's a chance to buy some rather good football memorabilia and do a good turn for charidee while you're at it.

There's some massive fundraising auction or other going on in aid of Children's Promise. Apparently, you can bid "for a number of highly sought-after items donated by top personalities from the worlds of entertainment and sport". But, of course, all you'll want to know about is the footy stuff. So here goes:

John Motson's sheepskin coat, worn at League, FA Cup and International games throughout the UK over the last 7 years. Even his coat has a statistic;

A Liverpool FC shirt signed by the entire squad with a signature translation sheet;

A football signed by Everton FC. Looks as though their writing is clearer - there's no translation sheet with this one.

If you want any of this stuff, give the Children's Promise Press Office a ring on 0171 808 8274 before Monday 28th February. They'll send you a form which will be sent to you via fax or email and must be completed and returned by 6pm on Monday 6th March.

And there's no point contacting Football Unlimited or the Guardian about any of this - we can do nowt about it.

More about Children's Promise

Children's Promise is the appeal which asks everyone to give up the value of an hour's pay to help children facing poverty, neglect, illness and abuse. All the money raised will be divided equally between seven charities working with children. The charities are: Barnardo's, BBC Children in Need, ChildLine, The Children's Society, Comic Relief, NCH Action for Children and the NSPCC. The money will be used to fund new projects and services which would not have been possible without this appeal. Marks & Spencer has made Children's Promise possible by covering the costs of the appeal to ensure that every penny received goes to charity.

The Prime Minister, Tony Blair, launched the appeal in 1998. Since then, the Queen has become Patron of Children's Promise and scores of celebrities have pledged their support including Sir Cliff Richard, The Spice Girls, Joanna Lumley, Ian Wright and Gary Lineker.

To date, around 5,500 companies and other organisations have signed up to the appeal, giving 9 million British employees - that's nearly 40% of the workforce - the opportunity to donate tax-free.

fields.headline: Tatchell quits Labour over 'rigged' poll
fields.trailText: Gay rights campaigner Peter Tatchell has resigned from the Labour party in protest at the what he calls the "rigging" of the London mayoral selection.
fields.body:
Gay rights campaigner Peter Tatchell has resigned from the Labour party in protest at the what he calls the "rigging" of the London mayoral selection.

In a letter to prime minister Tony Blair, the former Labour candidate for Bermondsey said that after 22 years as a member he could no longer be in a party which "has contempt for democracy and its own members".

He added: "The rigging of the London mayoral candidate selection is the latest, unforgivable abuse of the democratic process.

"It follows similar gerrymandering in the selection of the Labour candidates for the Scottish and Welsh elections, and your plans to pack the House of Lords with unelected, unaccountable cronies and back-scratchers."

He added: "I have stuck with the Labour party through thick and thin over the last two decades.

"I bit my lip and stayed loyal through the progressive abandonment of socialist values and policies. But your subversion of democracy is one abuse too many. Respect for democracy is non-negotiable."

webTitle: Soap's imitation of Ofsted life is 'pure coincidence'

fields.headline: Soap's imitation of Ofsted life is 'pure coincidence'
fields.trailText: It has not been the easiest of weeks for Chris Woodhead, the government's chief inspector of schools. First there was news of a Glynebourne opera that would feature a relationship not dissimilar to his alleged dalliance with a student. Now comes the news that a teacher in the Channel 4 soap Hollyoaks - who also happens to be called Chris Woodhead - has been sacked after having an affair with a pupil.
fields.body:
It has not been the easiest of weeks for Chris Woodhead, the government's chief inspector of schools.

First there was news of a Glynebourne opera that would feature a relationship not dissimilar to his alleged dalliance with a student.

Now comes the news that a teacher in the Channel 4 soap Hollyoaks - who also happens to be called Chris Woodhead - has been sacked after having an affair with a pupil. It comes days after the Ofsted chief warned that pop culture was corrupting young people.

Mr Woodhead, 55, resisted pressure to go last year for telling student teachers that relationships between teachers and pupils could be "educative". He maintains his affair nearly 30 years ago with Amanda Johnston, now a teacher herself, began after she left his A-level class, although his ex-wife has disputed this.

But even his enemies, who if the polls are to be believed, includes most of the teaching profession, must be feeling sorry for him now. Mersey Television, which makes Hollyoaks, denied yesterday that there was any artistic conspiracy against Mr Woodhead.

"There are differences. [The character] is a woman, and she is actually called Christine, although she is sometimes called Chris," she said

"As far as the rest, it is pure coincidence. I know what you are thinking, but this is entirely fictitious."

Unlike Mr Woodhead, the character was dismissed on Monday night after a disciplinary hearing found she had lied about her fling.

Mr Woodhead's spokesman said: "I'm not going to make a comment. There is no point. It just goes on and on."

webTitle: Sexy styles win a place in the sun

fields.headline: Sexy styles win a place in the sun
fields.trailText: For more than 40 years, the Missoni label has been synonymous with zigzag patterns presented in bright colours. Cosy woollen scarves have long been a staple.
fields.body:
For more than 40 years, the Missoni label has been synonymous with zigzag patterns presented in bright colours. Cosy woollen scarves have long been a staple.

But since Angela Missoni took over the design of the collection from her parents, Rosita and Ottavio, three years ago, she has been moving the company in a younger, sexier direction - and yesterday's show proved to be her most seductive yet.

The trademark prints were there, but the folk-hippy ambience was gone: in its place came zebra and tiger stripes in camel and red silk; one-shoulder silk blouses with gold and honey brown diagonal stripes, tied at the side handkerchief-style; and slinky, glittering shirt-dresses and separates in a maze of coloured stripes and patterns. For evening, pattern was pared down to a barely-there dogtooth of gold on a cream halter-top and trousers, accessorised with a diamante-chained bag and glamorously bouffant hair.

With ladylike chic the new buzz phrase, Maxmara's taupe chiffon blouses with navy pencil skirts and pearl necklaces are suddenly the cutting edge of fashion.

And with perfectly pleated blouses, leather-trimmed boxy jackets, chiffon-edged dresses and glittering navy-and-gold dogtooth eveningwear, this is a label that well deserves its spell in the sunshine.

Meanwhile, another designer proved himself in step with Milan's newest themes. Alessandro dell'Acqua's offering was one of the sexiest takes yet on the 1920s and 1940s influences already seen at Prada, Antonio Berardi and Lawrence Steele.

The models had an air of Josephine Baker exoticism with deep side-parted chignons, fur jackets shrugged over their shoulders and outsize silk lilies worn at their throats. Black lace dresses were worn over silk slips in burgundy, a key colour for next season, while the black net skirts and blouses were strewn with crystals.

fields.headline: Bush down but not out
fields.standfirst: What the US papers are saying
fields.trailText:
An epic struggle
The Republican contest has become an epic struggle between two candidates with vastly different appeal to strikingly different audiences, and so far neither has been able to gain a clear advantage. As he did tonight, Bush will argue that he is the clear choice of Republicans to be the party's nominee. But McCain has begun to argue that, on the basis of his clear appeal to non-Republicans, he is more electable in a general election.
Dan Balz, Washington Post
fields.body:
An epic struggle
The Republican contest has become an epic struggle between two candidates with vastly different appeal to strikingly different audiences, and so far neither has been able to gain a clear advantage. As he did tonight, Bush will argue that he is the clear choice of Republicans to be the party's nominee. But McCain has begun to argue that, on the basis of his clear appeal to non-Republicans, he is more electable in a general election. Dan Balz, Washington Post

Both need what the other has
Bush and McCain each needs what the other has, but the presence of the other guy is making it impossible for either man to expand his electorate. Bush has to appeal to independents, especially if he's looking toward November, but McCain is in his way.

And McCain desperately needs Republicans - needs them right now, in fact, as the party heads into a series of primaries in which only registered Republicans can select delegates to the convention. His best argument is that he is more electable than Bush, but the Texas governor is sure to continue making the seductive argument that McCain is the choice not of true believers, but of interlopers.
John Podhoretz, New York Post

Bush not yet beaten
Because he has more money, more prominent backers and two powerful geographic bases - Florida, where his brother Jeb is governor, and his own state of Texas - Mr Bush must still be counted the man to beat. He also demonstrated again today his ability to beat Mr McCain handily among Republicans, and in many of the primaries ahead they are the only ones who get to vote.

On the other hand, Mr McCain can now entertain legitimate hopes of rekindling the widespread enthusiasm he generated in the campaign's early weeks.
RW Apple Jr, New York Times

Bush still winning a Republican majority
The exit poll results showed why Bush, though knocked down by the defeats, can hardly be counted out. Even though the overall tenor of the electorate was considerably more moderate in Michigan than in South Carolina, McCain made extraordinarily little progress in denting Bush's hold on rank-and-file Republicans. While McCain attracted almost exactly the same percentage of Democrats as he did in South Carolina and slightly improved his showing among independents, Bush almost precisely replicated his dominance among Republicans. In South Carolina, Bush won 69% of Republican votes; in Michigan, he won just about two-thirds, including substantial majorities among both GOP conservatives and moderates.
Ronald Brownstein, LA Times

Primaries are a new kind of politics
In the old politics, the field of candidates was winnowed by voters. This time it was narrowed by fund-raisers. In the old politics, the independents and party defectors who ordinarily hold the balance of power in American elections made their voices heard in November. This time they are bellowing in February.

As a result, the entire architecture of presidential politics has been altered. A process that once was in the firm control of party bosses was loosened in the 1970s and 1980s, as the proliferation of primaries transformed the nomination fight from a private selection to a public audition.

The election of 2000 has taken that trend of ''openness'' and extended it, drawing in huge numbers of independents and Democrats and thus reshaping the system into a form that would be unrecognisable to Dwight Eisenhower, Richard Nixon, and even the elder George Bush, the pillars of the old style of Republican politics.
David Shribman, Boston Globe

webTitle: Dirty tricks backfire on Mexican censor

fields.headline: Dirty tricks backfire on Mexican censor
fields.trailText: Herod's Law is the first film in Mexican history to mount an explicit attack on the party that has ruled the country for 70 years. Attempts have been made by the government to suppress the film, change its ending or delay its release until after the presidential election in July. But its manoeuvres have backfired, and few Mexicans can remember a film more eagerly anticipated
fields.byline: Jo Tuckman and Duncan Campbell in Mexico City
fields.body:
"Why don't they want you to see it?" asks the advertisement. The tens of thousands of Mexicans who crammed into cinemas last weekend did not have to wait long for an answer. Herod's Law is the first film in Mexican history to mount an explicit attack on the party that has ruled the country for 70 years.

Attempts have been made by the government to suppress the film, change its ending or delay its release until after the presidential election in July. But its manoeuvres have backfired, and few Mexicans can remember a film more eagerly anticipated.

Herod's Law was written and directed by the Mexican film-maker, Luis Estrada, 37. Last month it shared the prize for best Latin American film at the Sundance festival in Utah.

It tells the story of Juan Vargas, a bumbling but basically honest party functionary from the PRI (the Institutional Revolutionary party) who is appointed mayor of a dusty backwater village in the 40s. After making a few attempts to do his civic duty, he becomes even more corrupt than his predecessors, fleecing the peasants, sleeping with prostitutes, shooting his opponents and rising inexorably to high office.

"The film is a reflection on whether we are condemned to repeat history as we have in the last 70 years," said Estrada. "The people, the faces, the discourse can change but essentially nothing has changed."

The film, whose title comes from an expression that translates roughly as "you're screwed" - was completed last year on a £875,000 budget, 60% of it from the government's film board. But when other government departments and PRI leaders saw the finished film, alarm grew at the unprecedented portrayal of corruption within the party.

First, the film mysteriously disappeared from a film festival in Acapulco last November and was only reinstated after an outcry. Estrada was then asked by the film board to change the ending so that Vargas no longer achieves high office. He refused, saying that events in the film were no exaggeration of reality.

The film board then attempted to buy out Estrada and thus take over control of the film. He declined. He was then asked by the board to delay screenings until after July 2, election day, and again he refused. In a further twist, two out-of-focus copies of the film were released without Estrada's knowledge and house full signs were placed outside the two half-empty cinemas where they were showing.

"In this country, the reality is much stronger than anything you are going to see in a film," said Estrada, who has now bought out the film board. "The film is a key political moment we are living in right now and it can work as a mirror of the past but it is ridiculous to think that anyone will change the way they think or suddenly discover that in Mexico there is corruption and impunity because they saw it in a film."

The audience in the Cinemex theatre in the Loreto district of Mexico City relished the portrayal of the PRI on opening night last weekend.

The corrupt priest, who charges his flock for their sins, provoked chuckles. There was laughter, too, when Vargas appears in the final scene as an elected deputy, the equivalent of an MP, and there was applause when the film ended.

fields.headline: Hurricane raises a storm
fields.trailText: A former boxing champion is suing Universal Pictures for deformation of character. Fighter Joey Giardello has filed a lawsuit against the distributors of The Hurricane claiming the film wrongly portrays him as an incompetent fighter.
fields.body:
A former boxing champion is suing Universal Pictures for deformation of character. Fighter Joey Giardello has filed a lawsuit against the distributors of The Hurricane claiming the film wrongly portrays him as an incompetent fighter.

In the Oscar-nominated film, Rubin "Hurricane" Carter, played by Denzel Washington, resoundly defeats Giardello during a 1964 middleweight title bout, but is denied the title by a panel of racist judges.

Giardello says he won the fight fairly and squarely and that director Norman Jewison's dramatic licence has damaged his reputation as a fighter. He's demanding multi-million dollar damages as a result.

webTitle: 'I was a prodigy - the thing I've got is like Mozart'

fields.headline: 'I was a prodigy - the thing I've got is like Mozart'
fields.standfirst: Michael Moorcock, outrageous chronicler of 60s London, is producing some of his best work yet. Nick Hasted meets him
fields.trailText: Michael Moorcock, outrageous chronicler of 60s London, is producing some of his best work yet. Nick Hasted meets him
fields.body:
Michael Moorcock's choice of residence on his brief return from Texas to London takes the visitor down an innocuous tributary of Baker Street, through iron gates and into a forgotten warren of genteel old flats where the 60-year-old writer sits waiting, a sputtering, gurgling volcano of outspoken opinion and anecdotage, a breathing history of London's cultural life.

Dennis Potter? "Loathed him since the beginning of his career, glad he's dead. Made a big fuss about it too." JG Ballard? "I told Jimmy not to take that acid, he was barmy enough." Martin Amis? "Appalling self-pity." John Lydon? "Self-publicising wanker."

Moorcock's books, going on for 100 of them, have gushed out at similar velocity. There are the dozens of fantasy novels, including the Elric series which made his name; there is the prize-winning Cornelius Quartet (1966-77), whose polysexual dandy-nihilist hero Jerry Cornelius shared Moorcock's own Notting Hill home of the era, turning that quarter of London into a mythical zone for decades of bohemians. And then, there's Mother London (1988), his time-chopping tribute to his city from the Blitz to Thatcher, and his Colonel Pyat quartet, thousands of pages long, still unfinished, a digging into the Holocaust's roots. And King of the City, his new London novel, out on CD next month. And he was in Hawkwind. And played banjo for Brian Eno. "It's like grabbing Dickens by the coat-tails," fellow urban diviner Iain Sinclair reported, after trailing him last year. "English fiction's Lord of Misrule," declared Angela Carter.

"I was an infant prodigy," Moorcock breezily admits. "It's just one of those things. I was known as a smart kid from the time I could walk. Looking back, I can see why people were so nice to me. I've got teenage correspondence that goes from Woody Guthrie to Tolkien to Peake. I now realise not everyone is treated this way. I was just very confident. I'd written a social novel by the time I was 17, it was easy. The thing I've got, it's like Mozart - I can read an example of a genre, and once I've picked up what's in it, I know it. What I can do is put structures together, as easy as pie."

Moorcock's artistic proving ground was New Worlds, the science fiction magazine he edited from 1964 to 1971. He published the genre's key experimenters - JG Ballard, Brian Aldiss, M John Harrison and more. But he wasn't interested in the genre for its own sake, and sought instead "an idiom that dealt with our experience" - a response to changing times. There were fist-fights in the office over artistic principle.

"I had to be a barmy despot for it to work," he remembers, "but it stopped me growing up. It froze me. I'd always had a lot of power, since I was a child, but I didn't understand it. It was only after my second marriage collapsed that I looked back and recognised I'd been careering, going too fast. I looked after my kids at the same time, I loved them. I don't think my relationships with them suffered very much. They may have a different idea of it. But in terms of personal relationships, it was disastrous."

Iain Sinclair took Moorcock back to his Notting Hill home of those days recently. It's been subjected to total gentrification, of course, defined now by Julia Roberts, not Jerry Cornelius. Once, though, things were different. "The year George Melly moved into Notting Hill, 1980, I moved out," says Moorcock, "because there were already too many pine shops. But when I arrived in 1957, there were police raids every night. It was the area of Peter Rackman, who I knew and liked, and think got a very bad rap."

By the mid-60s though, Moorcock could feel his city lighting up bit by bit, not least Notting Hill. The nascent pop industry settled in nearby Ladbroke Grove, there were "at least three famous rock groups on every block". The first Cornelius book, The Final Programme (1966), was mocking yet heartfelt in celebrating the times. "I was central," says Moorcock. "All the hippies loved the fantasy books, they never read anything else. Everybody who was really famous really liked me. I flung myself into the counter-culture, because I'm a hedonist, and I loved the drugs. I loved everything. When you're in a car with women who are genuinely feeling great and sexy, and you've got nowhere else to go and nothing else to do, and you're stoned out of your brain, and you're famous and everybody recognises you - it can't get much better."

But he knew it couldn't last. The latter parts of the Cornelius Quartet see Jerry broken, brought down by a mood of aching, nostalgic loss. "I can do lyrical loss at the drop of a hat," says Moorcock. "It's natural to me. My childhood was in the Blitz. And what happens is, you have no past, in a peculiar way, because all your early memories are of ruins - huge concrete blocks, little byways, bits of rosemary and willow herb that were yours. Then it gets built over, and you've lost a whole world. I form very loyal friendships, too, perhaps because I know I may lose them. Existentialism and entropy were in the air when I was young, as well. All my early Elrics are like fantasies by Camus."

Moorcock's celebrity survived into punk, but by the time of Thatcher, the game was really up. "Thatcherism made the language of liberal humanism sound silly," he sighs. "In the 70s, if I said something, generally it got reported. With Thatcherism, I learned how rapidly the rhetoric shifts. As early as 1978, when a poet friend called Bill Butler died of an overdose, his funeral was like a Spanish Civil War veteran's. I'd never seen so many Afghan coats. The sense of being marginalised, defeated revolutionaries was very strong." Still, when the power drained from him, Moorcock grew up at last. With his third wife Linda, he moved to Texas. He also wrote his most extraordinary work, the "memoirs" of Colonel Pyat, full of fantastic sights from adventures in the years 1900-40, narrated by a self-deceiving, Jewish anti-Semite. Byzantium Endures, The Laughter of Carthage and Jerusalem Commands (1981-92) now await a final volume.

"It's just so horrible getting into his head," Moorcock explains. "It's something my wife doesn't want me to do, and I don't, because you start to become this awful character. But it's the only way. What I wanted to do was to get inside the sort of person who was my natural enemy - I'm part-Jewish. The last book is nearly finished. I know it sounds pious, but it does feel like a holy subject to me, and it's something I have to be careful with. I don't want to pick over the bones of the dead. I'm actually trying to produce a memorial." Meanwhile with his newest book, another London love song, King Michael makes it clear that he isn't stepping down yet. "All I know is," he says, "is that I was given a bit of talent. I had nothing to do with that, it's a gift. So I'll push it as far as I can."

 The CD of Michael Moorcock's King of the City and Mother London is out on March 3. King of the City is published by Scribner in May.

"I can do lyrical loss at the drop of a hat," says Moorcock. "It's natural to me. My childhood was in the Blitz. And what happens is, you have no past, in a peculiar way, because all your early memories are of ruins - huge concrete blocks, little byways, bits of rosemary and willow herb that were yours. Then it gets built over, and you've lost a whole world. I form very loyal friendships, too, perhaps because I know I may lose them. Existentialism and entropy were in the air when I was young, as well. All my early Elrics are like fantasies by Camus." Moorcock's celebrity survived into punk, but by the time of Thatcher, the game was really up. "Thatcherism made the language of liberal humanism sound silly," he sighs. "In the 70s, if I said something, generally it got reported. With Thatcherism, I learned how rapidly the rhetoric shifts. As early as 1978, when a poet friend called Bill Butler died of an overdose, his funeral was like a Spanish Civil War veteran's. I'd never seen so many Afghan coats. The sense of being marginalised, defeated revolutionaries was very strong." Still, when the power drained from him, Moorcock grew up at last. With his third wife Linda, he moved to Texas. He also wrote his most extraordinary work, the "memoirs" of Colonel Pyat, full of fantastic sights from adventures in the years 1900-40, narrated by a self-deceiving, Jewish anti-Semite. I know it sounds pious, but it does feel like a holy subject to me, and it's something I have to be careful with. I don't want to pick over the bones of the dead. I'm actually trying to produce a memorial." Meanwhile with his newest book, another London love song, King Michael makes it clear that he isn't stepping down yet. So I'll push it as far as I can."  The CD of Michael Moorcock's King of the City and Mother London is out on March 3. King of the City is published by Scribner in May.

fields.headline: Final one-dayer abandoned
fields.trailText: Heavy rain has caused the fourth one-day international between Zimbabwe and England at Harare to be abandoned without a ball bowled. It means England win the series 3-0, so avenging their whitewash here three years ago. England can now return home after a tour that has lasted almost four months. Zimbabwe are England's next opponents as well, arriving in this country in May for two Tests and a triangular tournament also involving the West Indies.

fields.headline: Railtrack reprieved
fields.standfirst:
A safe way to travel, but not safe enough

Paddington train crash: special report

More about transport
fields.trailText: The safety of Britain's railways in the aftermath of last October's Paddington disaster, which killed 31 people, is too important to be left to party politics.
fields.body:
The safety of Britain's railways in the aftermath of last October's Paddington disaster, which killed 31 people, is too important to be left to party politics.

Whether John Prescott's statement yesterday amounts to a U-turn on his post-Paddington statement that Railtrack would lose its primary role as enforcer of railway safety is a question of minor significance. What matters is that we get as safe a system as the country can reasonably afford. It always was, and will be, the case that Railtrack is responsible for operational day-to-day safety and also that the independent health and safety commission (HSE) sits at the top, overseeing the safety of Railtrack and numerous other organisations.

The important thing is what happens in between these two bodies and, above all, how much of the nation's resources is to be devoted to rail safety, as opposed to other priorities like roads or the health service. These are not easy decisions, but they are best taken at a distance from traumatic events like the Paddington crash.

Yesterday's recommendation that Railtrack should set up a subsidiary company to deal with the safety of track and signalling with an "independent" chairman will not do much to reassure passengers reading about the crashes of recent years or the imperfect way that some maintenance gangs have gone about their business since privatisation. Railtrack's overall responsibility for regulating the safety of the train operators is being transferred to the HSE, but it is still to retain its operational responsibility for the safe performance of train companies using its tracks.

Anything more radical would have involved a wholesale rewriting of the 1974 health and safety act and would have prejudged Lord Cullen's separate inquiry into the safety and management culture of the railways, which may yet call for a separate rail safety regulator. One of the public's main worries has been that the privatised Railtrack's drive for profits would compromise its safety responsibilities. But the review found "no evidence that commercial interests outweighed safety considerations".

Yet still Paddington happened. Why? The easy answer is decades of underinvestment, since if the automatic train protection system (ATP) which is now starting to be installed had been operating at Paddington, the accident would probably have been prevented. A pan-European version of ATP was endorsed by yesterday's review as the best long term way forward. In the short term, the existing train protection and warning system (TPWS) can be tailored to address the areas of high risk.

However, it is still not clear who - Railtrack or the government - will fund the the £2.5bn needed for full implementation of ATP, nor how the investment would measure up against other uses of the same money. It is reckoned that the £3m of investment needed to save one life on the railways could save five to 10 people on the roads, up to 100 in the health service, and up to 40,000 in the third world.

It is a fact of life that the frightening nature of serious rail crashes thrusts the issue into the national headlines in a way that the much more numerous deaths on the roads and elsewhere, spread apart in time and by geography, do not. There has not even been the beginning of a national debate on this sensitive subject. At the same time, statistics still show that nothwithstanding the very occasional horrific accident, rail is a relatively safe way of travelling. None of this will give any satisfaction to the victims and relatives of the Paddington tragedy, but judicious investment can at least give some tentative hope for the future.

webTitle: Protests as Railtrack keeps safety role

fields.headline: Protests as Railtrack keeps safety role
fields.standfirst:
Cost of new safety systems for trains put at £2.5bn over the next 10 years in proposals following the Paddington rail crash
Paddington train crash: special report
fields.trailText: The government last night landed the rail industry with a bill of almost £2.5bn to improve safety in three stages after the Paddington rail crash.
fields.body:
The government last night landed the rail industry with a bill of almost £2.5bn to improve safety in three stages after the Paddington rail crash.

The figure, which will have to come from increased subsidies and higher rail fares, emerged after the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, announced changes amid a hail of protest against his decision to allow Railtrack to keep its safety role.

The families of those bereaved in the Paddington crash accused Mr Prescott of a u-turn and going back on promises he made to strip Railtrack of its safety resposibilities.

The £2.5bn total suggested by Sir David Davies, president of the Royal Academy of Engineering, as the price for in stalling the most modern safety equipment in a driver's cab, will be achieved over the next 10 years.

The families of the Paddington victims were not impressed with the government's tactics, or that ministers had seen fit to release three sensitive post-Paddington reports during the week of the inquest into the tragedy.

The first, by Sir David, calls for the introduction of new safety controls in train cabs.

Diana Macaulay, whose 26-year-old son was killed in the crash, said allowing Railtrack to be responsible for safety was "like putting Peter Rabbit in charge of a lettuce patch".

Paddington survivor David Taylor, said that the government's decision to allow Railtrack to keep its safety role in a subidiary company was "an insult" to the memory of the people who had died. He said that a second internal report by the department of transport on whether safety should be removed from Railtrack was "a complete u-turn" and demonstrated that Mr Prescott was full of "hot air".

A third report by the health and safety executive absolves Railtrack from making commercial gain from safety, but says that much of its safety programmes should be improved.

Both Mr Prescott and the transport minister, Lord Mac donald, pointed out that Railtrack would be losing one of its functions, the responsibility for deciding whether train companies were safe to operate.

Mr Prescott suggested that setting up a subsidiary company to handle safety at Railtrack was only a holding operation because of legislative restrictions. Like the transport select committee, he is in favour of an independent transport safety authority and will be passing on this view to Lord Cullen, who will be heading the public inquiry into the Paddington crash later this year. One of Lord Cullen's tasks will be to report on rail safety generally.

Mr Prescott declared: "I would not be wise to pre-empt the Cullen inquiry. I am caught here. Do I do nothing? I have had to make a judgment, a judgment that was not made by the previous legislation."

He told the Commons: "As operators of the rail network, Railtrack must carry ultimate responsibility for operating their network safely." He argued that the changes would "improve accountability and public confidence in the safety of the railways".

But the Liberal Democrats spokesman, Michael Moore, called the plan for a Railtrack subsidiary "half-baked".

Bernard Jenkin, Conservative transport spokesman, said that the government had been panicked into making decisions immediately after Paddington due to the public outcry. It was now repenting at leisure.

Industry sources admitted that Railtrack's subsidiary would mean very little change to Railtrack's safety regime. Almost the same people would be working together, and it was a matter of changing round the chairs.

Sir David's report to Mr Prescott called for the introduction of a cheaper and less sophisticated train safety system as the best short-term solution for the railways.

His conclusion means that the more costly automatic train protection system recommended more than 10 years ago, after the Clapham rail crash, is still not seen as the best immediate remedy for trains passing signals at danger.

The report said that the rail industry should plan, as a first stage, to fit the cheaper train protection and warning system, with the second stage upgrading of the system. Sir David said that TPWS would prevent 70% of accidents by 2004, and that ATP, the third stage, would take at least 10 years to install to provide the ame safety level. Sir David said that TPWS would cost £250m, of which Railtrack had committed £200m and the 25 train companies £50m. He had added a further £80m for the more sophisticated development of the system.

But Sir David said that the cost of installing ATP worked out at around £2bn. It had already been planned for the west coast and east coast main lines, but it would take years for the programme to be completed.

Mr Prescott's department made it clear later that the money would have to come from the industry. It admitted that it could only be raised from subidies or higher fares to passengers.

Sir David said: "Nothing is completely safe. Even the combination of an experienced driver backed up by a well developed proven ATP system can still fail and lead to a very serious accident."

The basic TPWS system will stop a train travelling at up to 70mph towards a red light. Sir David's more sophisticated version will stop trains up to 100mph, and could be fitted by 2003.

TPWS could have prevented the Thames train going through a signal at red at Paddington. ATP was fitted to the Great Western train coming in the other direction, but could not have prevented the crash.

fields.headline: Bush's double trouble
fields.trailText: 8.30am: The Republican presidential nomination race exploded into a connoisseur's classic last night, when John McCain did the Michigan-Arizona double over George W. Bush, taking the rollercoaster contest into new realms of excitement and improbability. For political junkies, this is simply as good as it gets.
fields.body:
The Republican presidential nomination race exploded into a connoisseur's classic last night, when John McCain did the Michigan-Arizona double over George W. Bush, taking the rollercoaster contest into new realms of excitement and improbability. For political junkies, this is simply as good as it gets.

First there was Bush's win in Iowa. Then McCain duffed Bush in New Hampshire. Then Bush got up off the floor and thumped McCain in South Carolina. Now McCain defies the pundits and does the old one-two over Bush.

Can the 2000 Republican race deliver any more surprises? After this, how can you doubt it? Last night, with Arizona first. It's less than two months since a local poll improbably suggested that McCain was in danger of losing yesterday's primary in his own back yard. Arizona governor Jane Dee Hull came out for Bush.

So did an interesting coalition of local Republicans who feel neglected and perplexed by McCain's rogue political odyssey in Washington. The local papers were writing editorials saying that America hadn't yet rumbled the John McCain that Arizonans had come to know. It seemed far fetched, but there was a very definite possibility that a rampant Bush might inflict a humiliating home state upset on McCain. In the event, last night, McCain sailed home by 60% to Bush's 36%. In truth, even McCain isn't cavalier enough to neglect his base. After his coup in New Hampshire just three weeks ago, Arizona suddenly looked safe again for McCain. But the history of the fantasy of a Bush win in Arizona had one serious lesson. Underestimate McCain at your peril.

That's less likely now, because of Michigan, but it is surprising how many commentators still dismiss the McCain campaign as a one - now three - state wonder.

The real story last night was in Michigan. If McCain had lost in Michigan then he might easily have quit the race, or have scaled down his campaign to such a degree that he no longer posed a credible threat to Bush. As things turned out, McCain won by 50% to 44%, just enough for him to be able to rebut the claim that if Alan Keyes had dropped out it would have been Bush's race.

Even more important, the win makes it possible to suspect that McCain may end up as the next president of the United States, a possibility made even more credible by yesterday's opinion poll showing that McCain would beat Al Gore in a general election match-up by 24 points, while Bush would beat Gore by only five.

For that to be even a possibility, however, McCain must first go on to win the Republican nomination. Michigan makes that both more likely and less.

More likely because McCain has proved his support is not ephemeral, and because his wins last night suddenly have lots of previously sceptical people focusing on the possibility. The Bush camp should be alarmed at how many people are saying that support for the Texas governor is very wide, but very shallow.

Mixing metaphors, there is a feeling that the Bush bubble could burst rather quickly now. This week, the wily New York Republican congressman Peter King switched allegiance from Bush to McCain. Others could follow. If New York is moving McCain's way, then Bush needs to worry. But McCain still faces a huge task. Super Tuesday - sixteen states have primaries or caucuses on March 7 - is less than two weeks away. To convert a six-point win in Michigan into the impression of irresistibility in all of those 16 states is unrealistic. McCain doesn't have either the organisation or, for the time being, the funds to compete with Bush in what, from today, is a two week general election campaign.

Resources aren't everything, of course. Ask Steve Fores. But Bush got there first, he is dug in, and he is a grudge fighter.

The big talking point on the US airwaves last night was McCain's audacity in being able to capture a Michigan Republican primary in which only a minority of the voters were Republicans. McCain won yesterday because he mobilised independents, as he did in New Hampshire, and because he mobilised some Democrats too, some of whom were determined to give Governor John Engler, Bush's Michigan campaign chairman, a bloody nose.

There is no doubt that this issue will be the controversy of the day, because many Republicans, to say nothing of Bush, believe it is unfair that their party primary should be determined by unbelievers. McCain is increasingly being cast as the Democrats' wooden horse in the Republican camp. The charge may be false, but it is simple and plausible, and likely to be widely believed.

The fact remains, however, that we are now in a different type of nomination contest. Not only are the days of the one-off individual state-by-state primaries at an end, with the March 7 mini-general election taking their place. In addition, we are now moving into a phase in which non-Republicans are much less of factor than they were in New Hampshire or Michigan. Many of the March 7 primaries are "closed" to non-Republicans - a fact which strengthens Bush. In the most important one of them all - in California - only the votes of registered Republicans will count and the Republican winner statewide takes all the delegates, a huge Bush advantage.

Right on cue, McCain began speaking last night in a much more conservative way than he has done so far. In his interesting and significant victory speech, while extoling America's supposed new "McCain majority", McCain began presenting himself as a "conservative reformer". This will play well with the indignant party mainstream, which is incensed that non-Republicans can shape the party's primary selection process so successfully.

But will it be enough? McCain may talk conservative, but there are simply too many people out there who think he's much more elusive, perhaps even more liberal, than that. That's exactly why some people vote for him, of course, but McCain has two weeks to find a way of persuading more conservatives to trust him more than Michigan conservatives did.

If he fails, then McCain is likely to enter the list of great presidential Might-Have-Beens sooner than he intended.

fields.headline: Britain needs Europe, says Blair
fields.trailText: Britain's economic prosperity depends on the country's full participation in the European Union, the prime minister insisted today.
fields.body:
Britain's economic prosperity depends on the country's full participation in the European Union, the prime minister insisted today.

Tony Blair warned three million jobs depended directly on EU membership and said a large part of British trade was connected with Europe.

In a speech at Ghent city hall in Belgium, Mr Blair said that Britain could survive outside the EU - "but it would be a poorer, weaker Britain".

"We could probably get access to the single market, as Norway and Switzerland do. But the price would be applying Europe's laws without having the chance to shape them," he said.

Europe should legislate to remove the barriers to pan-European e-commerce and build the framework for future prosperity, the prime minister said.

fields.headline: 'To withdraw is not patriotic'
fields.standfirst: Tony Blair's Ghent speech
fields.trailText: Full text: Tony Blair's Ghent speech
fields.body:
At a time when the European Union is embarking on radical expansion and internal reform, I would like to take a moment to put the challenges facing Europe in context.

My starting point is this: the European Union has been one of the outstanding political achievements of the twentieth century.

NATO kept the peace. But it was the European Union and its predecessors, jumpstarted by the enlightened self-interest of the Marshall Plan, that led to the political and economic reconstruction of Europe.

The project that began with the European Coal and Steel Community had one over-arching objective: to end the feud between France and Germany that had been at the heart of one European and two world wars in less than a century.

The project has succeeded brilliantly. It has turned the age-old rivalry between France and Germany into friendship and partnership, so much so that France and Germany have been the driving force behind the European project for 50 years.

But the European Union has done more than that, much more.

It has provided a Framework for law and institutions which respects the rights of Europe's democracies, large and small: which allows competition but prevents dominance.

It has provided the framework for Europe's prosperity, not just free trade in Europe, but a single market and, increasingly, a single economy.

And it has provided a clear path forward for countries emerging from political dictatorship and centrally planned economics.

It was the European Union more than any other institution that helped Greece, Spain and Portugal turn their back on dictatorship.

Not by force of arms, but by force of example.

It was the European Union and with it the vision of a prosperous, democratic, European Germany that helped bring down the Berlin Wall, so setting off the chain reaction that ended the Cold War.

And it is the hope and promise of European Union membership that is now driving political and economic reform across eastern Europe and the Balkans, from Latvia to Bulgaria, from Poland to Croatia.

That is strengthening the hand of those who believe in democracy and free enterprise, against those who would exploit the fear of change to play the card of nationalism and protectionism.

The European Union is on the threshold of achieving the dreams of its founders. Of reuniting the continent in peace, democracy and prosperity.

But Britain could have played and can play a larger part in it.

Britain in Europe

Britains relations with Europe have too often been ambivalent or indifferent, Indeed, I believe Britain's hesitation over Europe was one of my country's greatest miscalculations of the post-War years.

We opted out of the European Coal and Steel Community. We opted out of the European Economic Community. We opted out of the Social Chapter. And we played little part in the debate over the single currency. When we finally decided to join many of these institutions, we found unsurprisingly that they did not reflect British interests or British experience as much as we would have wished.

Yet, as our history shows, Britains place has always been at the centre of Europe. England was a European power long before it became an imperial one. No King of England if not King of France, as Shakespeare's Henry V rather bluntly put it.

Even in the days of Empire, Britain was first and foremost a European power, preserving the balance in Europe, opposing those who sought to dominate Europe.

Belgian history can attest to that.

Waterloo, Ypres, the Battle of the Bulge.

British servicemen died to set Europe free. Yet since the second world war, Britain has too often been an observer in Europes development, not a player.

With the creation of the European Union, for the first time in our history, we were content to stand aside from a major development on the continent.

Nearly 60% of British trade is with the rest of the European Union. Over three million British jobs and billions of pounds of investment in Britain depend on Europe. Europe's s global trade interests arc Britains trade interests.

Of course, Britain could survive outside the European Union. But it would be a poorer, weaker Britain. We could probably get access to the Single Market, as Norway and Switzerland do. But the price would be applying Europes laws without having the chance to shape them.

That is why I am determined that Britain should play its full part in Europe - for the same reason that Belgium or France play their full part in Europe: because that is what is best for my country.

A few miles from here, in Bruges, another British Prime Minister made a speech. From it stemmed the isolationist and hostile view of the European Union. My disagreement with Mrs Thatcher's speech in Bruges is not that its criticisms were all unjustified. Some were justified. Some indeed were and are shared by others in the European Union. My disagreement is that the response to those criticisms was for Britain to withdraw into its shell, to opt-out. To see at least in terms of presentation the European Union as Britain vs Europe.

The result was not that Europe stopped moving, but that Britain stopped shaping the form and direction of that movement. The very lesson that the development of the Single Market taught us where Britain was heavily engaged was abandoned. The idea of Britain vs Europe also infected the debate in Britain and encouraged the perception that Europe was something done to Britain, over which we had little say.

And as we lost influence in Europe, it did not help us in America. Britain has close ties with America. They will remain close, no more so than under this Government. But America wants Britain to be a strong ally in a strong Europe. The stronger we are in Europe, the stronger our American relationship.

I hold to my view that Britain's destiny is to be a leading partner in Europe. It is right for Britain, and it is right for Europe. It is a central ambition for the New Labour Government.

The change in our relations in Europe since May 1997 has been fundamental. Britain has fully participated in every new initiative: economic reform; defence and foreign policy; institutional change and enlargement; immigration and crime. To each we have made a substantive and clear contribution. Without it, the nature of the changes would have becn very different.

And we have not found ourselves alone in arguing the case for reform. Others, like the new government in Belgium. are arguing the case with us.

At this crucial juncture, where reforms of an absolutely momentous nature are being debated and decided, Britains place must be at the centre of them. To withdraw from them is not patriotic; it is an abdication of our true national interest. Other countries playing a leading role in Europe do not see the European Union as an alternative to the nation state; indeed, they see it as a way of enhancing their national interests. At a time when countries are coming together ASEAN in Asia, MERCOSUR in Latin America, NAFTA in North America - Eurosceptic isolationism means marginalisation.

If people tell you that the argument for Europe has been lost in Britain, they are wrong. Of course our position is made more difficult by our media. One part has abandoned all sense of objectivity and is essentially hostile to the European Union. The other part is supine in the face of that hostility.

Take the example of last years financial negotiations at Berlin. Europe is always at its most hard-headed when it comes to paying for it. But by making our case persuasively, we protected Britains rebate and got a very good deal on structural funds. Yet that got a fraction of the media attention that attended the failure by France to lift the ban on British beef, even though the financial consequences for Britain were more far-reaching.

Another example is Vodafone-Mannesman. For weeks, our media had been telling us that this was the test of reform, and that Europe would flunk it. That politicians, rather than shareholders, would decide. When the deal went through, the British media barely commented on its enormous implications.

In fact, reform is already happening in Europe. In Germany, the government has announced plans to reform capital gains tax, opening the way for the radical restructuring of German industry. 40% of French shares are now owned by people who arent French. Italy is reforming its labour markets. Belgium, the Netherlands and Scandinavia are setting the pace in Europe on welfare reform.

That is why I will carry on pressing for a more mature and sensible attitude. So that we in Britain dont blow every dispute with the European Union or with another member state into a crisis, and get a bit of balance into our debate.

We are committed to Europe. and to reform in Europe. I am determined that Britain will play its full part in the reforms necessary for the European Union to move to the next stage of its development.

So what are the main areas for reform?

Lisbon

At the Lisbon summit next month, Europe will be dealing with a dilemma confronting us all: economic reform. How do we reap the benefits of globalisation while preserving our values and strengthening our societies?

The choice facing Europe here is not between status quo or reform. The choice facing Europe is between uncontrolled change forced by the markets, or a process of economic reform that delivers both economic dynamism and social justice.

Globalisation and the competitive effects of the Euro make reform inevitable.

As for our own position on the Euro, it is clear. Despite whatever you read or hear, it will remain exactly where it is. In principle, we are in favour of joining a successful single currency. In practice, we have to get the economic conditions right The final say is with the people in a referendum. Meanwhile, we are making the necessary preparations in the manner we have set out.

We are all, however, in the midst of a wider economic transformation. A revolution in technology. An explosion in international capital. The wind of economic change has never blown through our economies with such force.

Every government in Europe is having to respond.

Here in Belgium, the government of Guy Verhofstadt is leading the way in strengthening Europes social model by modernising it. Active welfare measures that recognise that work is the best way out of poverty. Cutting non-wage labour costs. The Rosetta plan to tackle youth unemployment. Flexible and decentralised wage bargaining. More labour market mobility.

But some things can only be done effectively at the European level.

If Europe is to compete on equal terms with America in the new economy, were going to have to create a whole new single market.

E-businesses are not like traditional businesses. They start small, use knowledge and intellectual property as their raw materials, operate internationally, and grow exponentially.

If Europe is to give them the same benefits that America offers, we need to extend the single market to the internet, to innovation, telecoms, and venture capital. Europe cant legislate for technology entrepreneurs. But we can surely get out of their way.

That is the main challenge for the Lisbon summit: how to make Europe the best place in the world to do business in the new high-tech knowledge economy.

But the Lisbon agenda rightly goes wider. It is about promoting economic dynamism and social justice. About recognising that getting people back to work is the best way of alleviating poverty and strengthening societies.

I also hope that Lisbon will mark a turning point in Europe's approach to economic and social policy at the European level. Legislation to push through liberalisation, enforced by strong independent institutions. Benchmarking and peer review to make best practice the norm in areas where member states have the sole or main responsibility, such as social and employment policy.

Today, Guy Verhofstadt and I have announced a joint proposal for Lisbon on modernising European social policy so that it makes work pay.

Wc want to put full employment back at the heart of Europe's social agenda. This requires a cross-cutting, joined up approach to policy-making. A stable macro-economic framework; market liberalisation; welfare reform.

Europe needs to be able to respond rapidly to technical, economic and social change and compete globally. To have flexible and fair working arrangements which encourage individual choice and overcome disincentives to work. To recognise the key role of education, skills and life-long learning.

A Europe of full employment also calls for the modernisation of European social policy. Changing social and economic conditions means that we need a new concept of the welfare state if we are to continue to deliver the services people need.

In Belgium and Britain we are now pursuing active welfare policies. Reforming our welfare systems so they become springboards for employment rather than simply safety nets.

And finally, Belgium and Britain will be advocating a new focus on small businesses as the main generator of jobs in modern economies.

Wider reform

But while economic reform is vitally important, it is not enough by itself.

Europe's post-war political leadership built the European Union on the basis of widespread popular support. But as the EU has matured and taken on more powers, and as the external and internal threats have subsided, the people of Europe have rightly come to expect more of a say in how it is run.

The world is changing. The Cold War is over, but we face new threats in the Balkans. from international crime, from global poverty and instability, from the consequences of mass migration.

Europe is responding to these new realities.

In 1998, Britain and France took the initiative to strengthen Europe's common defences in a way that also strengthens NATO. EU Member States are now looking at ways of enhancing their military capabilities against headline goals.

NATO will always remain the cornerstone of European defence. Both of our countries know only too well the importance of the transatlantic alliance for maintaining peace in Europe. But Europe needs to take on more responsibility and share more of the burden within NATO. And Europe needs to be able to act when the Alliance as a whole is not engaged.

Last year, led by the Finnish Presidency, the European Union also agreed changes to tighten co-operation between our judicial, law-enforcement and immigration authorities. Cross-border problems such as international crime, illegal immigration and asylum abuse require cross-border solutions.

As the new Belgium Government is doing, we must take decisive steps to deal with these problems by combining an overhaul of our immigration services with the reform of asylum and immigration law.

The dangers of inaction are clear. When reasonable and tolerant people fail to deal with the genuine concerns raised by these issues, then unreasonable and intolerant people will take their place.

Bogus or fraudulent asylum claims are the enemy of the genuine asylum seeker and these issues must be tackled at the national and European level.

The European Union is also reforming institutionally in the wake of the Commission's resignation last year and in preparation for enlargement.

I have always maintained the view that an efficient, strong and independent Commission working in the service of the whole Union is a basic requirement of successful European development. That is why the Commission reform process led by Neil Kinnock is so important, and why Britain strongly supports the changes underway.

Enlargement is also driving institutional reform. We began an intergovernmental conference earlier this month to look at how we can streamline the Commission, and reform voting in the Council to fit an enlarged European Union.

But enlargement raises wider questions. In due course, we will need to consider in what circumstances the flexibility outlined at Amersterdam should operate. To consider how we balance the desire to move forward with the desire not to create a two-tier Europe. I am confident common sense can find a way through.

And what of democratic legitimacy?

How do you prevent an enlarged Union further diluting the link between voters and decision-makers in Europe?

The tension here is between pushing forward the development of Europes institutions; and recognising that most of our citizens identify first and foremost with their national governments and national parliaments.

This is not the place for a detailed analysis. I would just make two points. The first is that there is a case for examining how we bring a greater understanding and cooperation between national and European institutions, in particular national and European parliaments. Secondly, we need a concerted drive on subsidiarity. As Romano Prodi said in his speech to the European Parliament last week:

Europe's citizens are disenchanted and anxious. They have lost faith in the European institutions. They are losing patience with our slow rate of progress in tackling unemployment. The prospect of enlargement divides public opinion between hope and fear hope for stability and progress, fear of a Europe without identity or frontiers.

As he said, the answer lies in focusing on what really needs to be done at the EU level and what should be done by the member states or civil society. Together we need to create a new, more democratic form of partnership between the European, national and regional levels in Europe.

Conclusion

So, to conclude:

The British on the whole are too pragmatic to believe in visions.

But this is, I suppose, my vision of Europe.

Free, fair and open. A community of values.

Delivering on the potential of a single market every bit as wide and as deep as Americas to generate jobs, prosperity, opportunity.

Strengthening Europe's societies and promoting social justice by once again putting full employment at the heart of our common agenda.

A beacon of democracy and free enterprise in the world. An international force for stability, for promoting European interests and European values.

A Europe that is truly the servant of the people, never their master. Strength based on strong democracy. Acting effectively in the interests of all the people of Europe, and accountable to them.

But Europe needs to take on more responsibility and share more of the burden within NATO. And Europe needs to be able to act when the Alliance as a whole is not engaged. Last year, led by the Finnish Presidency, the European Union also agreed changes to tighten co-operation between our judicial, law-enforcement and immigration authorities. Cross-border problems such as international crime, illegal immigration and asylum abuse require cross-border solutions. As the new Belgium Government is doing, we must take decisive steps to deal with these problems by combining an overhaul of our immigration services with the reform of asylum and immigration law. The dangers of inaction are clear. When reasonable and tolerant people fail to deal with the genuine concerns raised by these issues, then unreasonable and intolerant people will take their place. Bogus or fraudulent asylum claims are the enemy of the genuine asylum seeker and these issues must be tackled at the national and European level. The European Union is also reforming institutionally in the wake of the Commission's resignation last year and in preparation for enlargement. I have always maintained the view that an efficient, strong and independent Commission working in the service of the whole Union is a basic requirement of successful European development. That is why the Commission reform process led by Neil Kinnock is so important, and why Britain strongly supports the changes underway. Enlargement is also driving institutional reform. We began an intergovernmental conference earlier this month to look at how we can streamline the Commission, and reform voting in the Council to fit an enlarged European Union. But enlargement raises wider questions. In due course, we will need to consider in what circumstances the flexibility outlined at Amersterdam should operate. To consider how we balance the desire to move forward with the desire not to create a two-tier Europe. I am confident common sense can find a way through. And what of democratic legitimacy? How do you prevent an enlarged Union further diluting the link between voters and decision-makers in Europe? The tension here is between pushing forward the development of Europes institutions; and recognising that most of our citizens identify first and foremost with their national governments and national parliaments. This is not the place for a detailed analysis. I would just make two points. The first is that there is a case for examining how we bring a greater understanding and cooperation between national and European institutions, in particular national and European parliaments. Secondly, we need a concerted drive on subsidiarity. As Romano Prodi said in his speech to the European Parliament last week: Europe's citizens are disenchanted and anxious. They have lost faith in the European institutions. They are losing patience with our slow rate of progress in tackling unemployment. The prospect of enlargement divides public opinion between hope and fear hope for stability and progress, fear of a Europe without identity or frontiers. As he said, the answer lies in focusing on what really needs to be done at the EU level and what should be done by the member states or civil society. Together we need to create a new, more democratic form of partnership between the European, national and regional levels in Europe. Conclusion So, to conclude: The British on the whole are too pragmatic to believe in visions. But this is, I suppose, my vision of Europe. Free, fair and open. A community of values. Delivering on the potential of a single market every bit as wide and as deep as Americas to generate jobs, prosperity, opportunity. Strengthening Europe's societies and promoting social justice by once again putting full employment at the heart of our common agenda. A beacon of democracy and free enterprise in the world. An international force for stability, for promoting European interests and European values. A Europe that is truly the servant of the people, never their master. Strength based on strong democracy. Acting effectively in the interests of all the people of Europe, and accountable to them.

fields.headline: Moving through the Masters maze
fields.trailText: It can be very difficult for ELT practitioners to make sense of the variety of titles being given to Masters courses at British universities and colleges. Only a full description of the degree will suffice if you are serious about enrolling, but you will still need a good grasp of the terminology before you get even that far.
fields.body:
It can be very difficult for ELT practitioners to make sense of the variety of titles being given to Masters courses at British universities and colleges. Only a full description of the degree will suffice if you are serious about enrolling, but you will still need a good grasp of the terminology before you get even that far.

First there is MA TESOL (Teaching English to Speakers of Other Languages), which many courses have adopted to replace EFL/ESL (English as a Foreign/Second Language). TESOL covers learners in countries where English is rarely encountered, as well as learners who need to become near-native speakers, because they are living in a society where English is the dominant language, or else in a society where English plays a key role.

Variations of TESOL, such as ELT (English Language Teaching), LT (Language Teaching) and ET (English Teaching) may sometimes also cover teaching English as a mother tongue (this will need to be clarified). In some cases a university may offer two titles, to distinguish them.

Another common Masters degree title is "applied linguistics". This does not necessarily imply that the studies are more theoretical, ie, less classroom- and methodology-oriented, than others. It may be simply that the degree had its origin in a department that was required to use the term. The course description will reveal whether the term means that the degree is for speech therapists, drama teachers, philologists etc, as well as for EFL/ESL teachers. However, if a university has both MA Applied Linguistics and MA Applied Linguistics (TESOL), the latter is clearly the one focused on EFL/ESL.

The title M Ed (Master in Education) almost certainly means simply that the staff work in an education faculty. A similar reason lies behind a distinction between an MA and an MSc, so that MSc English may in fact not have any science content in it.

Where one university offers several degrees, all of which seem to address issues related to ELT, it is most likely that all these courses will have common elements and will be different only in one or two modules and/or the dissertation topic. It is also useful to ask what degree title will actually appear on the final certificate. This may be different from the name of the course you study.

Finally, two new areas of Masters-level study are emerging. One is culture studies that link English to its cultural roots either in Britain or abroad. The other, "global English", examines how different varieties of English are in use across the world, and helps teachers to decide what the needs of their learners are.

Course acronyms

CAL: Computers and Learning.
CALL: Computers and Language Learning.
EAP: English for Academic Purposes, ie, for higher studies.
ESP: English for Special Purposes normally includes some general courses, but also English for business, science, academic purposes etc.
ICT: Information and Communications Technology. Focus on technology is becoming popular, and this degree will include considerations of CALL and the internet, as well as general ESOL matters.
SLA: Second Language Acquisition, ie, the theories of how people learn a new language.
TLEL: Teaching and Learning English and Literacy, which would focus on English for academic purposes, and general literacy studies.
TT or TET: Teacher training, or Teacher Education and Training. This would be a module preparing you to become a trainer yourself.

 Anita Pincas is an MA course director at the Institute of Education, University of London, England
