webTitle: Start teaching them young but keep it fun

fields.headline: Start teaching them young but keep it fun
fields.standfirst: Izabella Hearn has advice for parents who want to introduce nursery-age children to English at home
fields.trailText: We all want to give our children as many life skills as possible. It is estimated that there are 1.5bn speakers of English in the world today, and that this number is growing. Our children are part of that future - so how can we help them succeed?
fields.body:
We all want to give our children as many life skills as possible. It is estimated that there are 1.5bn speakers of English in the world today, and that this number is growing. Our children are part of that future - so how can we help them succeed?

All children are born with a tremendous desire to learn, to discover, to explore and experiment. Tony Buzan, leading British psychologist, rightly comments that "a child picks up a language much better than a doctor of philosophy, and is a master of it by the age of three or four". It is remarkable (and enviable) how quickly a child can progress from communicating by using a string of baby sounds to being able to handle complex grammatical structures.

The acquisition of language, according to the linguist Noam Chomsky, can be compared to the development of walking. Just as a child will naturally learn to walk if given the right nourishment and freedom of movement, so he will acquire language if exposed to the right environment. As parents there is a lot we can do to enrich that environment and stimulate our children's natural curiosity, so they become confident and enthusiastic learners.

More and more non-native English speakers want to encourage their children to reach a good level of English. However, language is very closely linked with identity, so it is important to take steps to avoid confusion. Wear a funny hat. Put on a special shawl. Do something obviously different to your appearance to let your child know that English is different and that English is fun. Set aside a cosy corner of your home where English activities will take place. You can quickly and simply create a more exciting atmosphere by throwing a colourful blanket over an armchair that your child can associate with "English time".

Alternatively, choose an outside spot where your child feels safe, warm and secure. I have a large, tatty, friendly-looking basket, overflowing with games, toys and books, which I pull out for these occasions.

Children learn in different ways, and will respond most effectively to activities where all the senses are involved. A song or a chant that is accompanied by pictures and actions will be enjoyed and remembered, however complex the structure. There is a wealth of nursery rhymes to choose from, as well as a large number of "TEFL" songs that have become popular in the last decade. "Hokey Cokey" and "Head, Shoulders, Knees and Toes" are top favourites. In both of these the children sing and participate with actions - quite strenuous for the adult, but exhilarating and energising for the child.

Songs and chants play an important role in language development at various levels. The child enjoys new structures and vocabulary in a relaxed way, and also practises intonation and pronunciation, while becoming familiar with the rhythm of English. I have often found that even in fluent adult speakers the "music" of the language is somehow stilted, and the strong stress patterns of the mother tongue come through.

Also, when we sing or chant together, we all breathe in time and often feel a sense of unity with the people around us, which is very positive for learning. This contributes to rapport - a very important ingredient in teaching.

Young children get bored and fidgety quite quickly, so keep the activities short and varied. At the same time there is a security in establishing a familiar routine as long it isn't too rigid. The secret is to create a balance, and to do this, notice and respond to the child's needs and reactions.

A quick game of Simon Says (where the child only obeys commands such as "jump" and "run" if they are preceded by the words "Simon says") sets the scene in a light-hearted and active way. "Simon" can then be extended as an English character to introduce new material.

Puppets can provide a whole world of experience that can be transferred to language learning, and they can be simple and enjoyable to make. The shape of a person or animal cut out of card stuck on a drinking straw or stick is sufficient for endless role-play games. Make up short dialogues based on your child's experiences, and have a lot of fun practising them, using different voices.

Art activities such as making puppets, decorations for festivals, and invitations to parties can all become part of your child's English experience. Most exercises have far more value if there is a genuine reason for doing them, so make the most of special occasions such as birthdays and holidays, by helping your child to make an English card for a friend or relative that will be appreciated.

There is also a wide range of published materials available that you and your child can enjoy. All you need is a picture dictionary to play memory games, bingo and guessing games. Videos and CD Roms can be both useful and entertaining, as support material though not as an exclusive teaching tool. Many of them now come complete with activity books with colouring and matching exercises for the pre-reader.

Books that have accompanying cassettes with songs and stories are excellent - but look for ones that are really clear. Flashcards can be used as labels for vocabulary that you are teaching, as well as for games such as Pelmanism (finding pairs of cards), and board games can be adapted.

Finally, remember that valuing and developing the mother tongue is a sure way of helping your child become successful in a second language. Children who have a rich experience in their first language and are encouraged to enjoy books are often those who do best, as they are able to transfer the necessary skills.

Children all have a huge learning potential that needs to be fuelled and not neglected. Pioneers in child development, such as Glen Doman, have inspired many parents to provide their children with the stimuli they need to flourish. Above all, we should try to foster the curiosity that our children have when they are tiny and when, as Doman says, "they believe that learning is the greatest game of all".

Recommended material

A variety of picture dictionaries, flashcards, song books with cassettes and CD Roms are available from Pearson Education. The BBC also has a good range of CD Roms as well as a new course, Ozmo, which comes complete with video, tapes and books.

 Izabella Hearn teaches at King's College Madrid, Spain. She is also an author of ELT books for children

webTitle: Know your own children before sending them away to learn

fields.headline: Know your own children before sending them away to learn
fields.trailText: Just as more English is being taught in primary schools worldwide, so there are a growing number of language schools in English-speaking countries that are offering courses for younger learners. In Britain most young learners' courses are open to 10- or 11-year-olds and upwards, with a few that cater for children as young as seven. But what is a sensible age to start sending children abroad to study, especially when even adult learners find the experience of travelling to a strange country and encountering people who speak an incomprehensible language challenging?
fields.body:
Just as more English is being taught in primary schools worldwide, so there are a growing number of language schools in English-speaking countries that are offering courses for younger learners. In Britain most young learners' courses are open to 10- or 11-year-olds and upwards, with a few that cater for children as young as seven. But what is a sensible age to start sending children abroad to study, especially when even adult learners find the experience of travelling to a strange country and encountering people who speak an incomprehensible language challenging?

The answer lies in the character and temperament of each child. Children's levels of independence vary considerably, and as Ann Alexander, who runs Alexander's International School - one of Britain's longest established young learners centres - explains, parents need to have a good awareness of their child's maturity and readiness to undertake a study trip.

"A lot depends on how a child has been brought up. If they have been exposed to new things and have already started to learn independence, then they are likely to prosper," says Alexander, but she adds, "you never know how they are going to react until they get here."

Another important but simple guide that Alexander suggests to parents is to be led by a child's own enthusiasm to learn. If your child loves learning English, then they are likely to enjoy a study trip, but if the motivation comes more from the parents, then children can easily resent being sent away for extra study and could be put off English for life.

The best approach, says Alexander, is for parents to set an example to their children. If they speak and use English at home and take an active interest in the culture of an English-speaking country, their children are more likely to feel comfortable experiencing that country for themselves. That is also why children who have already travelled abroad with their parents are usually more prepared for a study trip on their own.

She also advises parents to view a young child's study trip as the first stage in a long-term process of getting to know both the language and culture. Although she claims that her courses for 11-year-olds will get children "speaking in English" within four weeks, in order to continue to make progress they will need the support and encouragement of their parents when they return home, and for some years to come.

In Britain schools that are part of the British Council's English In Britain Accreditation Scheme, have had their young learners courses inspected for the quality and standard of both their teaching and welfare provision. But it is still vital for parents to gather as much information about individual schools and courses before making a decision about where their children will study.

One determining factor should be teacher training. There is no requirement for English In Britain accredited schools to employ teachers with specific training in teaching young learners, even though it is widely recognised that specialist skills are needed to teach children. Parents should ask about teachers' qualifications and choose only schools that have a policy of employing teachers with specific ELT young learner training or general primary-level teaching qualifications.

Another area to scrutinise is welfare. In Britain laws covering the care and supervision of children require schools to meet high standards of safety and security for young learners. The Association of Recognised English Language Services (ARELS) also recommends that its members carry out checks with social services and the police on families hosting young learners.

Yet the demands of caring for young learners mean that all staff need to be well managed and committed, and one indication of this is a willingness by the school to provide detailed descriptions of all aspects of care and teaching. Parents should also ask about the age, experience and length of service of staff.

If parents are given vague information or insufficient detail by a school, then they should look elsewhere, says Tony Thompson, director of English Language And Cultural Organisation, another centre specialising in young learners in Britain. "Parents should check that schools will provide everything the child will need," he says, "from meeting each child at the airport and taking them to their host families, to how many excursions a week are scheduled and whether entrance tickets are included in the course fee. It should be a total package, so that all the child needs is pocket money."

Thompson also offers a choice of accommodation, both special residential centres for young learners and specially selected host families. Each suits different types of children, he says, but he also stresses that parents need to supply in advance detailed information about their child's special needs, allergies or preferences.

For any child, a study trip abroad will be an adventure, and it is the experience of encountering so much that is new and learning to cope that is as valuable as the English they will learn. Above all, children should have a pleasurable experience.

fields.headline: Serving up choice language chunks
fields.standfirst: Learners need never be short of a phrase, says David Wilson
fields.trailText: Many higher-level business English learners can use basic grammar more or less accurately but lack vocabulary. In particular they lack sufficient knowledge of prefabricated "chunks" of English. These are set phrases like "I'll get back to you", and collocations like "submit a report", that constitute such a large part of a native speaker's repertoire.
fields.body:
Many higher-level business English learners can use basic grammar more or less accurately but lack vocabulary. In particular they lack sufficient knowledge of prefabricated "chunks" of English. These are set phrases like "I'll get back to you", and collocations like "submit a report", that constitute such a large part of a native speaker's repertoire.

When using English for meetings, presentations, phone calls, social conversation or business reports, learners are dissatisfied because they feel their English is inaccurate. They frequently fall back on translating literally from their mother tongue to produce language that is unidiomatic and at worst incomprehensible.

My approach to is to focus initially on the English language routines they will need to complete a task successfully at work. Before designing a course I ask myself and my students these questions:

1 What work-related tasks do my students need to perform in English (eg, giving instructions/briefings, dealing with customer complaints)?

2 What kind of discourse is characteristic of such tasks (eg, telephone or face-to-face conversation, short monologues, written documents)?

3 What lexical chunks occur naturally in such discourse (eg, "I'd like to make a start this morning", "Are you with me so far?", "You have my sincere apologies for this")?

To take the example of a learner who needs to give instructions to junior colleagues at work. I obtain a sample of spoken discourse by making short two-to-three-minute recordings of a native speaker (a colleague, friend, or myself) acting out a realistic scenario giving instructions at work. For written tasks I work on chunking the language of the students' own business documents that they bring with them to the course.

Before the lesson I select examples from the recordings or written documents. I aim to provide learners with language chunks that they are likely to use frequently. In class I write down any errors they make in using lexical phrases, and add to a feedback sheet the more idiomatic language chunk equivalents.

When I teach basic grammatical structures remedially, I re-present them to learners as "set expressions". So, "I've always been interested in . . ." can be taught remedially without the repetitive analysis of its consituent parts. With this approach it is amazing how quickly even the most grammar-allergic students abandon such interference errors as "I'm all times interested . . .".

This approach works best if students spend time away from the classroom reflecting on the new language chunks they have encountered. I recommend that they practise repeating them and play acting scenarios in which they can be used. Students like to practise chunks learned from written discourse by using them in their own writing.

Students need to continue to practise new chunks of language systematically after their course. So I make sure they have them documented in a readily accessible format. In addition to giving them written checklists of language chunks, I provide my one-to-one students with an audio cassette with new items. I provide a pause between each chunk so that learners can repeat it to themselves.

The final stage is to provide simulated activities where they can transfer the chunks they have learned to job-related tasks. And it's better if ideas for scenarios come from the students themselves. They know more about their jobs than I do.

 David Wilson is a senior instructor at Specialist Language Services in York, England

fields.headline: New tools for new texts
fields.standfirst:
Christopher Tribble explains how software that dissects corpus texts opens up new possibilities for creating materials.
See the associated activities
fields.trailText: For most teachers even the best text books will never meet all their needs. Good teachers will always want to supplement the course book with other materials. They use such materials to extend what their students can do - to stimulate discussion, to enrich vocabulary, to increase understanding of how language works. But teachers are usually short of time, and it takes time to find the right texts and the right examples.
fields.body:
For most teachers even the best text books will never meet all their needs. Good teachers will always want to supplement the course book with other materials. They use such materials to extend what their students can do - to stimulate discussion, to enrich vocabulary, to increase understanding of how language works. But teachers are usually short of time, and it takes time to find the right texts and the right examples.

So imagine a situation in which you want to prepare supplementary materials to help your students extend the ways in which they give examples: they know about "for example", but you want to encourage them to start using alternative structures like: superordinate plus "such as" plus further examples.

How long would it take you to prepare an activity similar to the one linked to below (Activity 1: such as) - half an hour, two hours? With the right resources, it took me less than five minutes. If you want to do the same, you will be one of a growing number of teachers who are using corpus resources to inform and extend their teaching. To start using corpora in your classroom you need three basic resources. The first is a collection of electronically held texts, otherwise known as a corpus, and one way to create this is by using the email edition of the Guardian Weekly (Tap into the Guardian Weekly's mine of email words, November 18). The second is a reasonably powerful computer, and the third is the right kind of software.

All Guardian Weekly subscribers who access the email edition have the first two of these resources, but readers will probably not have the other piece of software: a program called a concordancer. Concordancers offer the best means for investigating a collection of texts and creating practical language learning activities. Two reasonably priced and readily available programs are now on the market for around $80 (MonConc Pro from Athelstan Press, and Wordsmith Tools from Oxford University Press), so that problem is easily solved. A concordancer offers at least two distinct tools for looking at a corpus of texts. The first lets you make lists of all the words in the texts you are studying. This is invaluable as it immediately lets you see the most frequent and the least frequent words in your text collection. The second tool lets you display in context any word or phrase you might be interested. We have already seen how "such as" could be investigated. As another example, consider a group of business English students at upper-intermediate level who have been having problems with the difference between "cost" and "price". With a collection of Guardian Weekly email texts on my computer it was simple to prepare two different supplementary tasks to help them. In the first the students were given a print-out of 100 concordance lines containing the two words in question, and were asked to develop their own rules about cost and price.

They came up with a good general rule that you can control a price (prices are decisions) but a cost is often outside your control. They then applied this rule to decide which verb would be more appropriate in a number of contexts (see Activity 2).

On a matter of design, you will notice how Activity 1 uses the default layout for a concordance printout (often called "KWIC" - Key Word In Context), and this second one uses a conventional sentence layout. Each has its advantages, but traditional sentence concordances can be a good starting point for students as they are a little less intimidating. And the result? A group of students with a much clearer idea of how these two words work.

These examples offer only a very brief introduction to the potential of corpora in language teaching - what concordance specialist Tim Johns at Birmingham university in Britain calls Data-Driven Learning. If you are interested in finding out more, and have access to the internet, you may also want to visit the British National Corpus site to find out about other text resources or Mike Barlow's Corpus Home Page. For teachers who are not on the Net, the Newsletter of the IATEFL Computer Special Interest Group has a number of articles which relate to the uses of corpora and ELT.

For more information

Athelstan Press
Oxford University Press
Tim Johns's home page has many useful examples of concordance exercises
British National Corpus
Mike Barlow
IATEFL

 Dr Christopher Tribble is a freelance consultant in applied Linguistics. He is author (with Glyn Jones) of Concordances In The Classroom, published by Athelstan Press

webTitle: One in five office workers lost in the jargon jungle

fields.headline: One in five office workers lost in the jargon jungle
fields.trailText: One in five office workers in Britain no longer understands what his or her colleagues are talking about, according to a survey released last week.
fields.body:
One in five office workers in Britain no longer understands what his or her colleagues are talking about, according to a survey released last week.

At meetings they are left floundering by management jargon and specialised electronic babble - by phrases such as "low-hanging fruit", "blue-sky ideas", "win-win situations" and "gap analysis".

If they dare ask, they discover that "getting into bed with" now means "to be more familiar with someone on a strictly professional level".

But most do not ask, for the survey indicates that more than a third of speakers use these buzzword phrases "deliberately, to show they are in control and therefore more credible".

The study, by the secretarial recruitment firm Office Angels, covered 1,000 office staff. It found that 65% had to cope with jargon derived from corporate gurus, American slang and the internet. Forty per cent found the phrases irritating and distracting at meetings, while 10% dismissed speakers who used them most often as "pretentious and untrustworthy".

Babblespeak is reportedly most common in creative sectors such as advertising, but has infiltrated financial institutions. The survey found that it was particularly common in southeast England, where 40% of staff used it compared with 25% in the north; and 30% said they used it to liven up meetings.

Paul Jacobs, a director of Office Angels, said the survey showed that corporate buzzwords were rife in the workplace. Jargon "can help to bring people and teams together in an almost tribal way as companies and sectors develop their own jargon. Or it can be used to exclude and confuse others as well as mask inexperience and lack of expertise."

Buzzwords and babble

Helicopter view: Summary
Talk offline: Discuss it after the meeting
Heavy site: Website getting many hits
Drool-proof: Technical advice for idiots
Blue-sky ideas: Ambitious proposals
Get into bed with: Be more familiar on a professional level
Face time: Non-electronic discussion
Capture: Gather more information
Orderly roll-out: Very slow phasing-in of a technological process
Strategic fit: A perfect match
Low-hanging fruit: Easy target

webTitle: Taking the ELT conference to the teacher

fields.headline: Taking the ELT conference to the teacher
fields.trailText: If you are thinking of attending an ELT conference in your country or region, but are wondering whether you can spare the time or money, you may find that you can attend as a "virtual" conference-goer via the Web and get some, if not all, of the benefits.
fields.body:
If you are thinking of attending an ELT conference in your country or region, but are wondering whether you can spare the time or money, you may find that you can attend as a "virtual" conference-goer via the Web and get some, if not all, of the benefits.

Organisers of ELT conferences are increasingly harnessing internet tools, such as discussion lists, audio and video, to share information as it is generated in the conference hall. In 1998, for example, the British Council set up an innovative "ESP anti-conference" (contributions were invited from practising teachers rather than visiting experts). It was held in Switzerland over a weekend, and by the Sunday night visitors to the virtual conference site could read and hear highlights, and navigate between discussion and seminars very much as physical participants had done.

As anyone attending an ELT conference will be aware, the most important aspects are often not the presentations but the informal discussions afterwards. The Swiss conference provided a virtual forum for this kind of discussion via the British Council's English language teaching discussion list ELTECS-L.

In March last year BBC English Production worked to reflect the spread of topics at the annual IATEFL conference on the Web, while Gary Motteram of IATEFL ran a discussion list that drew on the views of many people who had not been at the conference.

The rise of the virtual conference gives organisations the chance to offer new services to members who are not able to attend. The 1999 British Council Oxford literature conference took as its theme the teaching of modern literature. Practical hints for teachers were then conveyed in a BBC radio series, Novel Ways, and a website helping teachers to introduce books is being prepared by BBC English Production and the British Council.

At last year's annual TESOL convention a limited group (limited by speed of a registration rather than location) of virtual conference-goers was able to take part in an intensive online discussion alongside actual conference-goers. IATEFL is holding a similar, purely virtual pre-conference event in March.

Does all this mean the end of the physical conference? I doubt it. We are social creatures, and developing genuine rapport and trust usually requires face-to-face meeting. However, conferences will evolve: the emphasis will shift from the few days of the actual conference to a longer period of discussion and reflection.

Virtual conferences past and future:

British Council ESP Anti-conference
The British Council ELT Contacts Scheme
IATEFL (The International Association of Teachers of English as a Foreign Language)
IATEFL 1999 Virtual Conference
TESOL (Teachers of English to Speakers of Other Languages)

 Hamish Norbrook is manager of Online Projects at BBC English Production

webTitle: Poetry reaches the parts that prose can't

fields.headline: Poetry reaches the parts that prose can't
fields.standfirst: Alan C McLean unleashes the power of verse in the English language classroom
fields.trailText: Poetry in the ELT classroom. Is it a turn-on or a no-no? Even in Britain, introducing poetry into the English classroom can be a tricky business. There can be resistance to subject-matter and odd language. Then there is the idea that poetry is somehow "soppy". In the ELT classroom, however, there are additional problems -some cultural, some linguistic - that have to be reckoned with.
fields.body:
Poetry in the ELT classroom. Is it a turn-on or a no-no? Even in Britain, introducing poetry into the English classroom can be a tricky business. There can be resistance to subject-matter and odd language. Then there is the idea that poetry is somehow "soppy". In the ELT classroom, however, there are additional problems -some cultural, some linguistic - that have to be reckoned with.

Given these difficulties, is poetry worth the effort? What can a good poem offer the language learner that a good newspaper article or authentic dialogue can't?

The answer has to do with things such as richness of meaning, diversity and ambiguity. In ELT textbooks students are usually presented with oral and written texts whose meaning can be fairly confidently ascertained: these texts have a meaning and you, the learner, can discover it. Poetry is different. The reader is a much more active participant in working out the meaning - or rather the range of meanings - of the text. The reader brings his or her own experience to the poem. The idea that the meaning of a text can vary according to the person reading it will be a new and refreshing one for many students.

A well-chosen poem encourages teachers to ask questions such as, "What do you think this means?" When students realise that "I'm not sure" is an acceptable answer to such questions, a whole new way of thinking about meaning is opened up.

So using poems in class encourages a diversity of views and a healthy debate about meaning. What else? Well, good poems deal with issues and concerns that are important to students - growing up, love and loss, the animal world and our relationship to it, perhaps even (sadly) war and peace.

The key phrase here is "well-chosen". You've got to find poems that are at the right level for your students, both linguistically and in terms of content. This isn't easy. On the other hand, there's no point in feeding students an unrelieved diet of whimsy.

There are poems written specifically for children, many of them witty and original, and good for a quick laugh. But if you stick to poems that are a kind of extended joke, you're selling poetry short: it can offer so much more than that. On the other hand, of course, a premature introduction to classic or difficult poems can turn students off poetry for life.

I've recently been making a selection of poems to go with an intermediate coursebook designed for Arab world learners. I had a number of criteria in mind when making my choice. First, they had to be worthwhile poems - not necessarily classics, but well-written and with some kind of point to them. I wanted poems that could stimulate thought and discussion. They should also complement some of the themes treated in the course itself.

Linguistically the poems couldn't be too difficult. So no Wallace Stevens or John Donne or Gerard Manley Hopkins. I stuck mainly to poems written in the last century: getting ELT students to cope with "thou" and "hath" seemed unnecessarily cruel. Bearing in mind the cultural background of the course's target audience, topics such as sexual love and religion were out.

I also wanted the poems to be varied in terms of authorship - male and female poets, American and Commonwealth poets, as well as those from the British Isles. A pretty tall order, you may think. In introducing this poem, you could ask students to imagine they were living in a foreign country. What kind of food from home would they miss? Is there a special dish that would particularly remind them of home? When students read the poem, you could ask them to say where the poet is now. Is London her home? What food reminds her of home? Who cooks that food? You could also focus on the title of the poem. What do students associate with the word "beacon"? Do a quick brainstorming session. Expect to get words such as bright, light, warmth, illumination. How does the food in her bag act like a beacon? It's a beacon "against the cold": is she only talking about the weather here? And so on.

Another criterion that may be applied to poems you choose for the classroom use is the extent to which they inspire students to produce creative writing of their own. Some poems makes us see a familiar object with fresh eyes, and could encourage students to write in a similar way. I've found an excellent poem about a blind boy describing colours in terms of senses other than sight. Asking students questions such as, "What does red smell like, taste like, sound like?" can produce some startlingly original responses even from students whose grasp of English is quite limited.

It is often surprising how students who have struggled through coursebook material can be sparked into producing works of originality and freshness by reading a poem that strikes a chord with them.

Poetry, then, need not be daunting or frightening. Instead it can release springs of creativity that more conventional ELT texts are incapable of doing. It can, to adapt Grace Nichols's image, be like a beacon of light in the ELT classroom.

Like A Beacon

In London
every now and then
I get this craving
for my mother's food
I leave art galleries
in search of plantains
saltfish / sweet potatoes

I need this link

I need this touch
of home
swinging my bag
like a beacon
against the cold

webTitle: UK extends hand of welcome to students

fields.headline: UK extends hand of welcome to students
fields.standfirst: Donald MacLeod on the new 'warmer' brand image created for UK education
fields.trailText: Donald MacLeod on the new 'warmer' brand image created for UK education
fields.body:
Overseas students will have the chance to stay on and work in Britain after finishing their degrees. This offer is part of the Government's new campaign to shed Britain's unfriendly image and attract more foreign students, announced by the Education Minister, Baroness Blackstone, in London earlier this month.

Speaking at the launch of UK Education - a brand image to market universities, colleges and independent schools abroad - she said the Government was reassessing the whole work permit system to back up its worldwide drive to attract more students.

The campaign follows research for the British Council which found that the positive image of quality and tradition had a negative side: British people were seen as being "as cold as their climate". At a practical level there were complaints about the lack of scholarships compared with North America, criticism of student welfare and accommodation, and difficulties with part-time working during the course and work after it finished. Inadequate investment in facilities was seen as a sign of complacency.

Lady Blackstone said the Government took these matters seriously. Entry and visa procedures were being streamlined. New arrangements were operating in New Delhi and were being extended to Islamabad and Beijing. Immigration officials would now normally give students permission to stay for the full duration of the course rather than six months when they arrived. Overseas students would not have to seek permission to work part-time during terms or full-time in the holidays. Spouses and dependants would also be able to work in Britain.

Students would be allowed to stay until the end of October after their course and would be permitted to work for up to two years in a job related to their degree to gain experience - working in video production following a media studies course, for instance.

"We are sharpening our response to the needs of international students. Changes have been introduced to improve our welcome and the affordability of UK study," Lady Blackstone told the launch at King's College London.

An $8m marketing campaign to help recruit 50,000 extra higher education students and 25,000 more into further education colleges by 2005 will be based on the new brand. Lady Blackstone stressed that welcoming more international students would not mean British students being excluded.

In marketing-speak the "brand footprint" of UK Education is supposed to represent "a dynamic tradition, the new world class, being the best I can be". It is to be "responsive, welcoming, alive with possibilities". The Brand Report for the British Council says the brand footprint currently involves quality and confidence but is also set in its ways.

Australian education is seen as accessible, relaxed and matey - the image purveyed by Crocodile Dundee and television soaps. The United States is seen as forward-thinking and the land of opportunity. For young people, Hollywood strongly influences their view of the British - "lovably eccentric but also pompous stuffed shirts who are complacent within their rigid class system".

Prime Minister Tony Blair's vision of Britain as a modern-minded country with a more positive attitude to Europe provides an "unmissable opportunity" to redress these negative images, argues the report.

The UK Education campaign is a response to aggressive marketing by Australia, particularly in Asia. A one-stop shop in Singapore, for instance, provides information on applications, visas, accommodation, counselling on study options and pre-departure orientation. It also reflects the success of Scottish universities and colleges combining to market themselves abroad. However, the Association of Recognised English Language Services (ARELS), which markets British private English language schools globally, is cautious about the benefits of UK Education to its members.

ARELS spokeswoman Oksana Higglesden said: "The $8m will help in general PR terms, and it may help those schools with close links with universities and that offer specialised pre-sessional courses, but overall it is not enough. We wish to see the initiative extended in support of ELT if we are to combat the competition."

webTitle: English could become Japan's official second language

fields.headline: English could become Japan's official second language
fields.trailText: In response to the heightened sense of crisis, almost panic, over Japan's lack of facility with English in the internet age, Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi released a report last month on Japan's goals for the 21st century that proposed making English the country's official second language.
fields.body:
In response to the heightened sense of crisis, almost panic, over Japan's lack of facility with English in the internet age, Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi released a report last month on Japan's goals for the 21st century that proposed making English the country's official second language.

"Achieving world-class excellence demands that all Japanese acquire a working knowledge of English," the report said. It called for reorganising English classes according to level of achievement, not grade, improving teacher training, and contracting language schools to teach English.

Mr Obuchi's announcement was quickly followed by the formation of a panel of experts to devise measures to improve methods of teaching English by the Ministry of Education. The ministry already plans to increase the number of native English-speaking teaching assistants from 5,800 to at least 10,000, and to triple the number of language teachers it sends on three-week seminars overseas.

Opponents of the proposal say it will be impossible for all Japanese to have a working level of English.

"English as a second language? It's absurd," said Masaharu Okamoto, an English teacher at Hibiya Senior High School, one of Tokyo's top public schools. "During the nuclear accident [last September], I read that villagers were told they must go to the tasuku forsu [task force] and I thought, 'Who can understand that?' We have Japanese phrases with the same meaning. Our society is based on the Japanese language, and everyone should understand Japanese." He says what is needed is diversity in the education system, so that Japanese who need to speak English are able to learn it.

However, Yoshio Terasawa, former head of Nomura Securities International in New York and author of a book called Lack Of English Ability Is Destroying The Nation, believes that the vague nature of the Japanese language allows obfuscation. By learning English, Japan's leaders will be forced to say what they think, he says.

fields.headline: Spot the difference
fields.standfirst:
Far right Austrian politician Jorg Haider claims to share 'amazing similarities' with our prime minister. Blair is not amused. But how much do the two have in common? Emma Brockes finds out

The Austrian far right in power: special report
fields.trailText: Far right Austrian politician Jorg Haider claims to share 'amazing similarities' with our prime minister. Blair is not amused. But how much do the two have in common? Emma Brockes finds out
fields.body:
Appearance

Jorg Haider: Some years before embarking on his bid for the Freedom Party leadership, Jörg Haider had his teeth fixed and you can see the impact the dental industry has had on his style. Haider is a man who favours outdoor photo opportunities involving mountain scenery, where he can strike a fresh and minty pose. He was once photographed jogging through the streets of New York during a -17C cold snap. At 50, he enjoys the good looks of a model who works mainly for Littlewoods' catalogue but is confident that a call from Versace is just around the corner. He favours the leisure wear Hugo Boss and Armani's smart/casual range.

Tony Blair: The prime minister has almost certainly not had his teeth fixed. After the general election, Germaine Greer memorably identified the 46-year-old's most remarkable feature to be his "chaotic dentistry", but in all other respects, he can match Haider's mail-order athleticism. Blair is a man who favours outdoor photo opportunities involving Tuscan scenery before which he can strike a tanned and relaxed pose. He favours the understated chic of Paul Smith.

Style

JH: Haider has a creepy way of referring to himself in the third person: for example, "if Blair is not extreme, then nor is Haider", which may be an indication of his titanic ego, a glitch in his English, or a symptom of some deeper estrangement. He has a weakness for attempting yoof-speak when addressing the common people, and likes to boast that 35% of voters under 30 voted for his party in last year's general election. "If you accompany him to an election meeting, he will speak more dialect and his language will be a little rougher," says Professor Melanie Sully of the Diplomatic Academy in Vienna.

TB: He may not have run marathons, but he has proved himself handy with a tennis racket and, in the honeymoon period after the election, was filmed bouncing a football on his head, quiff whipping in the breeze. He looks his age, but Cherie's pregnancy has rejuvenated his image whilst delivering a powerful message to would-be aggressors about the state of his virility. He has a weakness for attempting Estuary English when addressing the common people or Des O'Connor.

On family values

JH: "For the FPO, the family is the most important anchor in the community, where children are prepared for life and learn to differentiate between right and wrong." Haider has two grown daughters and a wife, Claudia, thought to be more liberal in outlook than her husband.

TB: "Strong families cherished by a strong community: that is our national moral purpose." Blair has three school-age children and a wife, Cherie, thought to be more liberal in outlook than her husband.

On law and order

JH: "The FPO and Labour support law and order," Haider asserts, "since those who adhere to the fundamental principles of our society deserve our protection."

TB: Last August, the Government proposed giving Whitehall access to all personal bank accounts, confidential medical records and individual tax files to ease the crackdown on fraud. Civil liberties groups immediately labelled it "Big Brother Britain", but they had missed the point. "The exchange of information poses no threat to the law-abiding citizen," said a senior government source, sinisterly.

Ideology

JH: Haider has floated to the top of Austrian politics because, he says, he is "free of ideological ballast". He identifies with Blair in this, claiming that they stand shoulder to shoulder for "equal opportunity, fairness, responsibility and trust". He is sceptical of old right/left definitions, preferring to hack out a new, third way through the jungle of tired old ideologues. It is a passage so radically unshackled to the past that Haider has made the ambitious claim to be working in a society "without taboos".

Even more remarkably, he has realised his boast. In 1991, Haider broke the ultimate political taboo by identifying with Hitler. "The Third Reich had a sound employment policy," he said before venturing that Waffen SS veterans were men of "good character". His thoughts on the taboos of child abuse, bestiality and spitting at old ladies are yet to be recorded.

TB: "Let the courage of past generations, their devotion to duty and their loyalty to family and friends inspire us," wrote Tony Blair in his first official address over the internet, skilfully combining scorn for the past with the sentimentality of a wartime poster campaign. He is also tired of slavish political definitions and would like everyone to, you know, lighten up or perhaps even get real. "It is time to move beyond the social indifference of right and left, libertarian nonsense masquerading as freedom," he has said. This bid for freedom has had the unfortunate effect of winning him comparison to some of the great despots of the 20th century. "In the last few months alone, I've been compared to Hitler, Mussolini and Milosevic," Blair admitted recently.

On welfare

JH: Haider doesn't mince words when it comes to benefit scroungers, saying there should be "no taxpayers' money for criminals or wasted money on social welfare." Moreover, the unemployed should not be "encouraged to be inactive through state assistance", but rather to override their lazy instincts and enter the job market. "Without freedom there can be no social security," says Haider, "and without social security there can be no freedom." It is safe to assume that, in this context, work brings freedom.

TB: "Welfare reform goes to the heart of what Labour stands for," said Blair after the election. "It is the issue on which our government will be judged." Since then, widows benefits have been cut, £300m has been knocked off the cost of lone parent aid and the New Deal threat to withdraw benefits from those refusing jobs and training has been extended to the over-25s. Last May, 67 Labour MPs revolted during the vote for Blair's Welfare Reform Bill, which proposed to cut incapacity benefit for new claimants and restrict entitlement to those who had not paid sufficient National Insurance contributions. But in the spirit of tolerance for which his government will indeed be remembered, the cuts applied only to those who were "80% disabled or less".

On Europe

JH: Haider calls himself a European and claims to have a "positive attitude towards Europe", which includes tightening the laws on immigration and maintaining a healthy scepticism towards foreigners. These policies have had the all too rare effect of provoking a reaction from Arnold Schwarzenegger, who as an immigrant to the US says he felt "hurt" by Haider's anti-foreigner remarks.

TB: The home office handling of victims fresh off the hijacked Afghan Boeing 727 took more cues from the Sun's "chancers trying to gate crash our shores" headline than was admirable, civil rights observers have said. Last year, the government's immigration and asylum bill advocated stricter border controls, tougher sanctions against illegal residents and greater use of deportation. Afghan asylum-seekers were interviewed without legal representation (a perfectly legal practice) and Jack Straw voiced the hope that "as many as possible would be removed from Britain". Wait until Arnold Schwarzenegger gets a hold of this one.

But in the spirit of tolerance for which his government will indeed be remembered, the cuts applied only to those who were "80% disabled or less". On Europe JH: Haider calls himself a European and claims to have a "positive attitude towards Europe", which includes tightening the laws on immigration and maintaining a healthy scepticism towards foreigners. These policies have had the all too rare effect of provoking a reaction from Arnold Schwarzenegger, who as an immigrant to the US says he felt "hurt" by Haider's anti-foreigner remarks. TB: The home office handling of victims fresh off the hijacked Afghan Boeing 727 took more cues from the Sun's "chancers trying to gate crash our shores" headline than was admirable, civil rights observers have said. Last year, the government's immigration and asylum bill advocated stricter border controls, tougher sanctions against illegal residents and greater use of deportation. Afghan asylum-seekers were interviewed without legal representation (a perfectly legal practice) and Jack Straw voiced the hope that "as many as possible would be removed from Britain". Wait until Arnold Schwarzenegger gets a hold of this one.

webTitle: ETA car bomb kills Socialist politician

fields.headline: ETA car bomb kills Socialist politician
fields.standfirst: Violence in Spain: special report
fields.trailText: The Basque separatist group ETA stepped up its terror campaign yesterday, killing a Socialist politician and his bodyguard in a car bomb attack near the seat of the Basque regional government.
fields.body:
The Basque separatist group ETA stepped up its terror campaign yesterday, killing a Socialist politician and his bodyguard in a car bomb attack near the seat of the Basque regional government.

Fernando Buesa, the Socialist party spokesman in the Basque parliament, was walking past the car with his bodyguard, a member of the regional police force, when a massive explosion sent his body flying 30m (100ft).

Attempts to resuscitate them were broadcast live on Spanish state television by a camera crew that had been covering a press conference given by the Basque regional president in his office nearby.

The attack took place near Buesa's home in the university campus area of Vitoria, the Basque capital. Students raced out onto the playing fields where the victims' bodies lay, to gape in horror at the scene.

"The windows of the classroom shook," said one. "We knew they'd let off a bomb."

Buesa, who was married with three children, was known to have been on ETA's hitlist. His death came one month after an army colonel was killed in Madrid by a car bomb detonated by remote control. A similar method is thought to have been used in yesterday's attack.

Earlier, Spain's interior minister, Jaime Mayor Oreja, had warned that ETA would almost certainly strike again before the general election on March 12.

Politicians from all parties, led by the centre-right prime minister, Jose Maria Aznar, cancelled campaign events in a gesture of respect and mourning.

The two car-bombings, the first successful terrorist attacks since June 1998, followed a prolonged ceasefire which ended last November after direct talks between the government and ETA failed to agree any terms for securing a lasting peace.

Mr Aznar had authorised a meeting with the separatists but ruled out any concessions. Basques were free to pursue their aim of a separate state through institutions set up under Spain's constitution that made the country one of the most devolved in Europe.

But his position angered the Basque Nationalist party (PNV), which had persuaded the guerrillas to declare a ceasefire. It promised to work with them to achieve the formal recognition of Basque's right to self-determination.

The Basque regional president, Juan Jose Ibarretxe, a member of the PNV, was under pressure yesterday to cease cooperation in the regional parliament with ETA's political wing, Herri Batasuna.

A total of 772 people have died as a result of ETA violence since the group began its terror campaign in 1968.

Public revulsion at ETA's tactics has grown, and yesterday's attack was expected to provoke demonstrations throughout Spain similar to those which followed last month's bombing.

The choice of victim may have been meant as a warning to the PNV, which had been inching closer to the Socialist party.

fields.headline: Master of the beautiful game
fields.standfirst:
Profile Bruno Bonnell can stand up dinner guest Ronaldo - and get away with it
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Bruno Bonnell is one of the few people to have stood up Brazilian soccer maestro Ronaldo for dinner. Arrogance? Well, the Frenchman commands the $1.1bn computer games empire Infogrames and he is a very busy man.
fields.body:
Bruno Bonnell is one of the few people to have stood up Brazilian soccer maestro Ronaldo for dinner. Arrogance? Well, the Frenchman commands the $1.1bn computer games empire Infogrames and he is a very busy man.

Caught out at a question about the skipped dinner, the chairman and chief executive mumbles an excuse about keeping another engagement at the Majestic Hotel in Cannes, rather than any power play on his part.

Infogrames designed and is selling Ronaldo v Football, one of the hottest soccer games on the market. Though ineffective when France beat Brazil in 1998 to become world champions, the Brazilian is the big draw in Cannes where Bonnell is overseeing his company's part in one of the largest computer game and software exhibitions in Europe.

Bonnell, sometimes described as France's answer to Richard Branson, is giving back-to-back interviews to sell the Infogrames story.

"We will take the necessary steps to become one of the big players in the industry," he says. "We will charm the US market. We will show them a company with a great product and commitment rather than just being another European export."

The company was born in 1983 when Bonnell and schoolfriend Christophe Sapet had a product that taught people about basic computer programming.

It has since swollen through acquisition, organic growth and a listing on the French bourse, to rank among the world's five biggest independent computer games publishers and distributors.

It boasts more than 1,000 game titles, 100m users, and sales this year expected to hit $400m. Games include Alone in the Dark, V-Rally and Mission Impossible, as well as the hot item featuring Ronaldo and the Brazilian soccer team; it also has the licence to produce titles with Looney Tunes characters.

Even with such an impressive stock market value, Infogrames is battling with other independent games distributors, including Eidos and America's Electronic Arts, to grow even bigger. There has been perennial speculation of consolidation in the industry and Bonnell has previously hinted at a merger with Eidos, his UK-based closest rival which has the well-built Lara Croft as its best selling game.

Only last year Britain boasted the largest interactive entertainment market in Europe, worth £1.4bn, beating both Germany and France.

Asked about consolidation, Bonnell says: "I'm not a prey. We have to look to take the lead on our competitors."

Infogrames has access to more than $500m for further acquisitions but he is coy about future deals. "Eidos is a very respectable company but our development lies towards the US and Japan."

The UK he describes as a "very interesting and erratic market" where games not accepted by players are scrapped.

To achieve critical mass, Infogrames last year snapped up a majority stake in American publisher and distributor GT Interactive Software for $135m and in the process gained an important Nasdaq listing. The company also bumped up its sales target after the acquisition to $1bn by 2001. A healthy target but one that suggests growth by consolidation, say analysts.

Bonnell wants Infogrames to be on every platform and already its games are on Sega, Sony and Nintendo, as well as mobile phones, personal computers, the internet, interactive television, handheld games and palmtops. It also has a games channel with Canal Plus.

Last week, a deal with BSkyB's interactive television service Open was announced to provide games sites for subscribers surfing the internet through their TVs.

The French group has also invested $200m to establish a subsidiary, Infogrames.com, that will hold all its online assets. Bonnell estimates 20% of the company's sales will come from online users by 2002.

Investors have not always wanted to chase technology stocks nor to join the boards of computer game companies. So Bonnell and Sapet still own a third of Infogrames.

"It wasn't seen as a serious business," says Bonnell. "Being a board member then of a games company was not something honourable. Now they all want to tell their kids about it."

webTitle: Psion plays for supremacy on all platforms

fields.headline: Psion plays for supremacy on all platforms
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
psion
fields.trailText: Psion, the British maker of handheld computers, took its battle for supremacy in the mobile computing arena to new heights yesterday when it signed up multinationals including IBM and Nokia to develop a standard that will allow the transfer and synchronisation of information across all platforms.
fields.body:
Psion, the British maker of handheld computers, took its battle for supremacy in the mobile computing arena to new heights yesterday when it signed up multinationals including IBM and Nokia to develop a standard that will allow the transfer and synchronisation of information across all platforms.

However the group, known as SyncML, has been snubbed by software group Microsoft. The rejection could seriously damage the ambitions of SyncML, analysts said, because Windows - the mostly commonly used PC operating system that receives and sends data - would have to be a part of the synchronisation chain.

"The reason Microsoft is so successful is because it's got a closed system," said one analyst. "By having an open standard it allows any Tom, Dick or Harry to come into your marketplace - and that affects the bottom line."

Microsoft's decision was not unexpected given its rivalry with Psion in the handheld market, in which the two companies are promoting different operating systems.

SyncML's planned system would allow the automatic updating of information from mobile phones to PCs or palmtop computers.

Psion's shares rose 175p to £50.53 on the announcement. But analysts said it would have no effect on Psion's bottom line. "What it does show is that Psion has got a seat at the table," said one analyst. "Psion is important enough to sit down in the same room as IBM and Nokia."

SyncML's other partners include Motorola, Palm, Lotus, and Starfish Software.

Noel Poore, head of software and technology at Psion, said more co-operative agreements would be announced shortly. He said the founding partners of SyncML had invested about a £1m to develop the system, which could be operational by the year's end.

"We feel that synchronisation technology will further us as a mobile internet-oriented company," Mr Poore said.

"Hence we feel a standardisation initiative is very worthwhile investing in and positioning ourselves as leaders in this field, and not be just another 'me too'."

Synchronisation is expected to be targeted at the corporate market, with businesses able to access information such as customer details, email, calendars and "to do" lists which would be up to date regardless of where the data is stored.

Mr Poore agreed a standard system would lead to greater competition. "It's a classic example of 'co-opetition'," he said. "We believe standards at this level are something that benefits everybody and substantially expands the total availability for the market place for those types of products. It's better than fighting one another over propriety time and time again."

Other open standards have developed, such as wireless application protocol or WAP which permits internet access from mobile phones. WAP has created a flurry of excitement about potential sales of a new generation of mobiles.

SyncML is not Psion's first development venture. It has a stake in Symbian along with Ericsson, Matsushita, Motorola and Nokia which licenses, develops and supports software for mobile phones. The group has also been lobbying for open standards across wireless technology.

 Shares in support services group Capita surged almost 20% yesterday as it announced a link with Microsoft to develop an e-business solutions package for British schools.

The stock leapt 208p to £13.55 after a solid set of results and another deal with Oracle and eLoyalty to develop a platform for customer relationship management services for local governments.

Capita reported a 25% leap in annual pre-tax profit to £32.2m on turnover of £327m, an increase of some 38% on the previous year.

webTitle: Driver thrown from cab, inquest told

fields.headline: Driver thrown from cab, inquest told
fields.standfirst: Paddington train crash: special report
fields.trailText: The driver of one of the trains involved in the Ladbroke Grove crash was thrown from his cab by the impact, and his body was recovered yards away alongside tangled wreckage, a Westminster inquest was told yesterday.
fields.body:
The driver of one of the trains involved in the Ladbroke Grove crash was thrown from his cab by the impact, and his body was recovered yards away alongside tangled wreckage, a Westminster inquest was told yesterday.

Michael Hodder was driving a three-carriage Thames scheduled service from Paddington to Bedwyn. Shortly after 8.10am it collided with a First Great Western train from Cheltenham to Paddington travelling in the opposite direction.

The Thames train was attempting to join the main line away from London, which meant crossing the path of the intercity service. The Thames train is believed to have passed through a red signal.

On the second day of the inquest into the deaths of 31 people in the crash on October 5 last year, the jury heard that a detailed pathology report revealed that Mr Hodder, 31, had not used alcohol or drugs before the crash.

Mr Hodder, who was married with two children and lived in Reading, died instantly. The driver of the Great Western train, Brian Cooper, was also killed.

The jury heard that many of those killed had to be identified by dental records, or in some cases DNA testing. In some cases, there was a considerable delay in recovering bodies from the scene, two miles outside Paddington station, and transferring them to a temporary mortuary.

The body of Martin King, 41, a company director travelling in the second coach of the Thames train, was not taken to the mortuary until 21 hours after it was discovered.

Questioned by solicitors acting for Mr King's family, Detective Chief Inspector Guy Ferguson said that rescue teams "were under considerable pressure", and that specialist cutting equipment had been required to extract bodies from the carriage.

The body of Antonio Lacovara, 24, was recovered between two coaches of the Great Western Train. Asked why Mr Lacovara had remained in the carriage for so long, Mr Ferguson said it had been difficult to extract the bodies as many were dismembered. It had been imperative to remove them and associated belongings to assist police in identifying the victims.

Later Robin Kellow, whose daughter, Elaine, 24, was thrown from the rear coach of the Thames train and crushed by another carriage, attacked Railtrack for what he described as a "negligent" track layout at Ladbroke Grove. Ms Kellow was the only person in the rear coach of the Thames train to die.

"I and all the bereaved want something positive and lasting to come from this slaughter, but our history of these events holds out little hope," he said.

As he continued his attack, the coroner, Paul Knapman, asked that he confine his comments to his daughter. A police investigation into the accident is continuing, and a public inquiry chaired by Lord Cullen is expected to begin hearing evidence next month.

The inquest resumes today.

webTitle: 82 civilians feared dead in Chechen massacre

fields.headline: 82 civilians feared dead in Chechen massacre
fields.standfirst: Crisis in Chechnya: special report
fields.trailText: A human rights organisation claimed yesterday that Russian troops summarily executed at least 62 people earlier this month in the worst massacre of civilians to date in the Chechen war.
fields.body:
A human rights organisation claimed yesterday that Russian troops summarily executed at least 62 people earlier this month in the worst massacre of civilians to date in the Chechen war.

Survivors have described how around 100 soldiers systematically robbed and shot civilians on the southern outskirts of Chechnya's capital, Grozny, in a two-day rampage which began on February 5.

Troops - most of them said to have been mercenaries - are alleged to have raped civilians, thrown grenades into basements where people were hiding, and executed anyone who tried to resist the looting. Many of the troops are thought to have been drunk.

On February 9, soldiers returned to the district of Aldi and threatened to punish any survivor who spoke of the massacre, according to researchers from Human Rights Watch who reconstructed the episode from the testimony of refugees who fled Grozny.

Russia's spokesman on the conflict was not available for comment last night, but officials have consistently denied that troops have taken part in atrocities against civilians.

"This is the single worst massacre of civilians that we have documented so far," said Malcolm Hawkes, a Human Rights Watch representative in Moscow.

Researchers have compiled a list of 62 names of people - mainly elderly men and women - they believe were killed during the attack, but say the final figure could be as high as 82. This is the second major allegation of large-scale brutality by the advancing Russian army to have emerged in recent weeks.

Earlier this month, Human Rights Watch focused on another part of Grozny, the Staropromyslovski district, where they claimed as many as 41 civilians had been killed by Russian soldiers in the space of several weeks.

"It is particularly galling to learn that while the Russians were denying that the killings in the Staropromyslovski region took place, an even worse massacre was occurring," Mr Hawkes said.

The Aldi attack took place as Russia seized the besieged Chechen capital, after a brutal bombing campaign which continued for several days after Chechen guerrillas abandoned their hold over the area.

One Aldi survivor told the New York Times of the time when the bombing stopped: "The troops started mopping up. We thought they would just check everyone's passports, but it was a cleansing of everything alive. They killed cattle, dogs, people - children and old people."

As soldiers swept through the streets demanding money and valuables, Akhmed Abulkhonov, 75, from Mesayev Street, tried to fend them off with a payment of 300 roubles (£6.50), according to one survivor interviewed by Human Rights Watch. The soldiers rejected this as a derisory payment, so he went back to his home and returned with $100.

"You have dollars and you only wanted to give us roubles," the woman quoted a soldier as saying. She said the troops then beat Mr Abulkhonov, shot him, set his cattle shed alight, and finally roped his daughter Lucia to an armoured personnel carrier and drove off with her.

Neighbours later buried Mr Abulkhonov in a front yard, along with other local victims of the massacre.

With access to Grozny severely restricted, there was no way of independently verifying the figures or the testimony of the refugees interviewed in camps in the neighbouring region of Ingushetia.

In an attempt to respond to escalating claims of severe human rights abuses in Chechnya, the acting president, Vladimir Putin, last week appointed a senior official, Vladimir Kalamanov, to look into the allegations of atrocities.

Mr Kalamanov yesterday promised to mount a thorough investigation into all recent claims, adding: "If the authorities abused their position, they must be punished."

But he stressed that he would not only be seeking to protect Chechnya's civilians. "We must also protect the rights of soldiers and officials. I can't refuse my protection to the representatives of the federal authorities."

There was some scepticism about what he would achieve. "At this date we are still unaware of any concrete measures that the Russian authorities have taken to prevent such abuses happening, or to bring the perpetrators of these war crimes to justice," Mr Hawkes said.

Russian officials preferred yesterday to focus on their own claims that Chechen guerrillas were planning terrorist attacks throughout Russia today to mark the 56th anniversary of the start of the mass deportation of Chechens under Stalin, who accused the entire nation of collaborating with the Germans.

Thousands died when about 650,000 Chechens were deported to central Asia and Siberia in rail cattle cars. The date is observed in Chechnya as a day of mourning. Rebel spokesmen have denied that Chechen fighters have any intention of marking the anniversary with attacks.

The Aldi attack took place as Russia seized the besieged Chechen capital, after a brutal bombing campaign which continued for several days after Chechen guerrillas abandoned their hold over the area. One Aldi survivor told the New York Times of the time when the bombing stopped: "The troops started mopping up. We thought they would just check everyone's passports, but it was a cleansing of everything alive. They killed cattle, dogs, people - children and old people." As soldiers swept through the streets demanding money and valuables, Akhmed Abulkhonov, 75, from Mesayev Street, tried to fend them off with a payment of 300 roubles (£6.50), according to one survivor interviewed by Human Rights Watch. The soldiers rejected this as a derisory payment, so he went back to his home and returned with $100. "You have dollars and you only wanted to give us roubles," the woman quoted a soldier as saying. She said the troops then beat Mr Abulkhonov, shot him, set his cattle shed alight, and finally roped his daughter Lucia to an armoured personnel carrier and drove off with her. Neighbours later buried Mr Abulkhonov in a front yard, along with other local victims of the massacre. With access to Grozny severely restricted, there was no way of independently verifying the figures or the testimony of the refugees interviewed in camps in the neighbouring region of Ingushetia. In an attempt to respond to escalating claims of severe human rights abuses in Chechnya, the acting president, Vladimir Putin, last week appointed a senior official, Vladimir Kalamanov, to look into the allegations of atrocities. Mr Kalamanov yesterday promised to mount a thorough investigation into all recent claims, adding: "If the authorities abused their position, they must be punished." But he stressed that he would not only be seeking to protect Chechnya's civilians. "We must also protect the rights of soldiers and officials. I can't refuse my protection to the representatives of the federal authorities." There was some scepticism about what he would achieve. "At this date we are still unaware of any concrete measures that the Russian authorities have taken to prevent such abuses happening, or to bring the perpetrators of these war crimes to justice," Mr Hawkes said. Russian officials preferred yesterday to focus on their own claims that Chechen guerrillas were planning terrorist attacks throughout Russia today to mark the 56th anniversary of the start of the mass deportation of Chechens under Stalin, who accused the entire nation of collaborating with the Germans. Thousands died when about 650,000 Chechens were deported to central Asia and Siberia in rail cattle cars. The date is observed in Chechnya as a day of mourning. Rebel spokesmen have denied that Chechen fighters have any intention of marking the anniversary with attacks.

webTitle: Main points of the three reports

fields.headline: Main points of the three reports
fields.standfirst: Paddington train crash: special report
fields.trailText: The department of transport's internal report:
fields.body:
The department of transport's internal report:

 Railtrack to set up subsidiary company Railway Safety Limited with its own board and chief executive whose pay will not be linked to Railtrack's success. New company to look after signalling and track.

 The health and safety executive will take over responsibility for safety for the 25 train companies.

Sir David Davies's report into train safety systems:

 Continue installing the train protection warning system - TPWS - on trains. System automatically stops trains passing signals at danger but is effective only below speeds of 70mph.

 Also recommends eventual installation of more expensive - around £2bn - automatic traIn protection system - controlled by a system of trackside sensors linked to computer in the cab. This will take at least 10 years to complete across the rail system.

Health and safety executive report:

 Found no evidence that commercial interests outweighed safety conditions at Railtrack.

 Railtrack safety management needs to improve techniques on accident investigation.

 Found absence of a proper policy to investigate the 25 train operating companies.

 Found safety records incomplete, and Railtrack's regional zones did not know what was expected of them.

fields.headline: Yesterday, bad day
fields.standfirst: Life in parliament: special report
fields.trailText: Good day
fields.body:
Good day

Sir Edward Heath. He celebrates 50 years in the House of Commons today and gave an interview to the Press Association in which he warned the Conservatives could only win the next election if they regain their previous pro-European supporters.

Saving of the day

Each call to the NHS Direct telephone hotline costs the department of health about £8, junior health minister Gisela Stuart said in a Commons written reply. However, that compared favourably with the £10.55 cost of going to a GP and the £42 price of one visit to an accident and emergency ward.

Rehearsal of day

A first glimpse of what could become the typical 21st century election count. Gone are the rows of counting staff at long tables and party officials scanning piles of ballot papers. Instead, votes are fed into machines which can scan them into a computer at a rate of more than 100 a minute. The rehearsal took place at Hammersmith and Fulham town hall, ahead of the May 4 count for the London mayor and assembly.

Today

Commons on half term mini-break. Lords will debate second reading of the deafblind persons bill.
