fields.headline: Rage against the machine
fields.standfirst: Two rebels, one on each side of the Atlantic, are challenging the rigid hierarchy of their political partiesThe US elections: special report The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Two rebels, one on each side of the Atlantic, are challenging the rigid hierarchy of their political parties.
fields.body:
They are the men against the machine. One is a decorated Vietnam vet with a lightning temper, the other a newt-fancier with a talent for the one-liner. One talks proudly of his PoW past as a guest in the Hanoi Hilton - "a hotel where they didn't leave a mint on the pillow" - another brags of his time as the red bogeyman of Conservative nightmares. One is fresh from last night's expected victory in Arizona and up-to-the-wire clash in Michigan, the other mulls his options in Brent East. One is John McCain, the other is Ken Livingstone - and they are playing a remarkably similar game. Both are on a quest which, if they succeed, could change the way politics is done forever.

Presidential candidate McCain is mounting a double challenge: both his message and his method are rebellions against the system. The Republican's signature theme is the corruption of American politics, thanks to the corporate givers and the "special interests" - the lobbies who offer hefty donations in return for friendly decisions from Washington. He says his target is this "iron triangle" of lobbyists, cash and legislation. That's why he has spent 14 years in the senate pushing for campaign finance reform: until that's fixed, says McCain, the whole system is broken. With the candour that has become his trademark, the former Navy flyer talks like a real-life Bulworth - Warren Beatty's fantasy politician who shocks America by suddenly telling the truth. He asks audiences why they don't have a decent health care system. "Because the Democrats take money from the trial lawyers and we take money from the insurance companies," explains McCain, happily lambasting his own party. Until all the politicians wean themselves off the milk of corporate cash, he says, America's biggest problems will remain unsolved.

The form of the campaign reflects its content. John McCain is the insurgent daring to take on the entire Republican establishment, lined up behind George W Bush: the countless governors, mayors and party bigs who are determined to see that Prince George gets his birthright. Bush has the money, a colossal $70m of it, as well as grass roots organisation on loan from party bosses in almost every one of the 50 states. Michigan was a classic case. The Republican governor there, John Engler, behaved like an old-time machine pol calling in the favours. So when a Michigan law firm was asked to turn over its offices this weekend - allowing Bush volunteers to use it for tele phone canvassing - they knew better than to say no to the man who runs the state. One Detroit suburb loyal to Engler had 560 people working in shifts on 300 phones to get out the Bush vote: McCain, by contrast, had 25 volunteers making calls from home.

Ken Livingstone must know that a similar disadvantage awaits him. If he seeks the London mayoralty as an independent, he will be a lone soldier fighting not one but three party machines - with Labour, the Lib Dems and the Tories all training their organisational fire on him. He will be the one playing to the packed houses, the one gaining the loudest applause on the hustings. But he will lack the boring nuts and bolts which make up a political machine - and which get results.

For this is one of the paradoxes of politics: you can be the most exciting and inspiring candidate on the stump and still lose. In the US, Gary Hart set pulses racing in 1984, but lost the Democratic race to the machine man Walter Mondale. Pat Buchanan catalysed a revolt of "peasants with pitchforks" in 1996, but the Republican nomination still went to the charismatically-deprived creature of the establishment, Bob Dole. Ross Perot caught a national mood in 1992 but he was squeezed out, partly by his own self-destructive behaviour, but chiefly by the organisational might of the two main parties. In Britain we know what happens when new groups try to break out of the box. Incredibly, the last new party to become a permanent feature of the British political landscape is Labour, which celebrates its 100th birthday at the weekend. The Social Democrats created huge momentum in the early 1980s, a genuine buzz of excitement, but still they failed - beaten back by Labour at its most demoralised. Even on its knees, Labour still enjoyed the advantage that matters: the machine.

Both the Livingstone and McCain revolts are throwing down a challenge: does it always have to be this way? There is certainly an appetite for change. After all, a huge chunk of both men's appeal is their underdog status: vote for them and it's one in the eye for the big boys. There is a rebellious streak in both British and American culture, and these candidates know how to tap it. "I'm just like Luke Skywalker trying to get out of the Death Star," cries the Star Wars fan who would be president. "Everybody's against me. Governor Engler, Governor Bush, all the governors, all the senators. They're shooting at me from everywhere!" Less dramatically, Ken never misses a chance to boast that "I'm my own man".

Can independents like them ever win? Not under the old rules. But the new politics of the 21st century offers a gleam of hope. When McCain whipped Bush by 19 points in New Hampshire he raised $2m in instant cash - via the internet. Friends of Livingstone admit an indie campaign would have to rely less on door-knocking than on radio phone-ins and TV appearances. In both the London mayor's race and the Republican primaries, new technology and new media suggest a way the candidates can defy the juggernaut.

In Britain, this change need not be confined to Ken. If he wins, independents will try to follow his lead by seeking mayors' jobs (if they happen) in Liverpool, Birmingham or Manchester. The constraining embrace of the party - which values uniformity above all - would be cast aside, replaced by a variety pack of candidacies, each one tailored to the specific constituency it sought to win. The old party system would be broken. Disagreements would no longer have to be contained within the fractious coalitions that are the Labour and Tory parties. Instead what are now mere internal factions could break out and run on their own - confident that their lack of a machine would not spell disaster.

All that's a long way off. For the moment, the smart, if cautious money says Bush will win the Republican nod and Livingstone will struggle to fulfil his dream. But something will have to give eventually. Bush will have to accommodate the sentiment McCain has voiced; political parties in Britain will have to change. Labour will either have to accept that its "brand" means different things in different parts of Britain - that Scottish Labour differs from Welsh Labour which differs again from London Labour - or it will see more breakaways across the country. Thanks to devolution, the days of the monolithic party with a single message are fading. If the new rebels succeed, winning without a machine, then they will be over for good.

webTitle: Signals passed at danger as Prescott hurtles on

fields.headline: Signals passed at danger as Prescott hurtles on
fields.standfirst: Life in parliament: special report
fields.trailText: Last October the government decided to blame Railtrack for the Paddington crash. Yesterday John Prescott announced that the new custodian of our fragile lives would be, er, Railtrack.
fields.body:
Last October the government decided to blame Railtrack for the Paddington crash. Its executives, we were led to believe, were as guilty as if they had personally assassinated every passenger in the front first-class carriage. The company was to be stripped of its responsibility for rail safety.

Yesterday John Prescott announced that the new custodian of our fragile lives would be, er, Railtrack.

It's as if Bluebeard had been appointed head of Relate, or Vlad the Impaler selected to run the NHS blood bank.

That is an oversimplification, of course. Safety will be the responsibility of a Railtrack subsidiary, run independently of the company's core interests, which involve cramming station forecourts with shops while the actual railways fall to bits. After all, someone on a train isn't spending cash at H Samuel or Paperchase, and is thus a waste of Railtrack's precious resources.

The new safety company will have separate finances, and it won't be run by a Railtrack director. In the deputy prime minister's resonant words yesterday, "the new company will be tasked with a more comprehensive audit regime", which I take to mean that Vlad can run the blood bank, provided he isn't caught drinking the stock.

As so often, it was Gwynneth Dunwoody, the formidable chairman of the transport committee, a woman whose scowl could stop a runaway train, who put her finger on it. Since Paddington, she said, "not one Railtrack executive, apart from the man in charge of public relations, has been required to resign. That is a cause for astonishment".

It might astonish her, but not New Labour. Their culture insists that there is no problem which cannot be solved through public relations, no success which is not the outcome of spinning. The crash was a PR disaster; therefore the answer is to sack the PR man.

Much of Mr Prescott's statement to MPs yesterday concerned "signals passed at danger", or SPAD in the jargon. Apparently these incidents have fallen to hardly more than one a day, for which we are supposed to be grateful.

But a Prescott speech consists almost entirely of signals passed at danger. As ever we hurtle onwards, like that old film clip showing the London to Brighton journey in four minutes. Words crash from side to side of the track: "legislaylative changes"; "rest-spective"; "the new safety regulor"; "civilation", which has something to do with civilian aviation.

Now and again we hit a set of points, and the train judders and shakes. "Railtrack should not be stripped of its own responsibility for which it is responsible."

Replying to Mrs Dunwoody, he declared: "The argument is to go with which and I don't think that TWPS is necessarily the best possible safety."

Alarmed MPs stared out of the window as red lights flashed past: "All the responsibilities of the group safety, not the safety of the Railtrack, they will have responsibility in this matter, and they will be producing each year their finances and they will be supported, ring-fenced so the report today reduces the confusion."

Or, "I'm sure you will have received these recommendations and recommendations of judgments given to me which the house can take judgments which are valid".

The wonderful thing is that in today's Hansard Mr Prescott's words will make perfect sense. Those Hansard writers could decipher the Rosetta stone in their spare time.

Once again, Archie Norman, the Tory environment shadow, left the reply to his understrapper, Bernard Jenkin. Mr Jenkin's brief is transport, but normally the top man faces the top man. Mr Norman cannot go on bottling out like this.

webTitle: You don't have to be black to be in an ethnic minority

fields.headline: You don't have to be black to be in an ethnic minority
fields.trailText: Messrs Younge, Sivanandan, Johnson and Clifford and Ms Kolawole and Ms Lindsay all gratuitously use the term black to describe all people from ethnic minorities including the millions of people who are of mixed race (Pride and prejudice, February 21).
fields.body:
Messrs Younge, Sivanandan, Johnson and Clifford and Ms Kolawole and Ms Lindsay all gratuitously use the term black to describe all people from ethnic minorities including the millions of people who are of mixed race (Pride and prejudice, February 21).

The margin notes used in the report clearly demonstrate the significant differences in the plight of people of different backgrounds with unemployment rates varying from 8% for Indians to 21% for Bangladeshis and Pakistanis, yet most of your contributors fail to acknowledge the existence of anyone with an Asian origin. This is despite the fact that there are more people of Asian origin in the UK than people of Afro-Caribbean origin and that only one of the seven people included in the identity parade insets described himself as black.
John Rogers
London

 In response to Boris Johnson's piece (Am I guilty of prejudice? We all are, February 21), there is a difference between prejudice and institutional racism and Mr Johnson failed to draw this distinction. I am a young black woman. I have not been racially assaulted. I have not been stopped by the police. But, I have been advised by my university's careers service to put my nationality on my CV, due to the fact that prospective employers will assume from my non-English name that I will require a work permit and immediately discard my application.

Mr Johnson is wrong. The existing legal framework has not minimised the problem. The struggle against racism, institutional or otherwise, lies way beyond "tolerance" and "good manners"
Octavia Goredama
University of Leicester

 Boris Johnson repeated that canard about Ali G being a racist character. If Nation (the black newspaper) can recognise Cohen's comic creation for what it is, a send up of white middle-class youth's infatuation with all things gangsta, and their brainless aping of the worst aspects of the image of blacks in the media, surely the Guardian can accept this?

Much like the accusations of sexism levelled at Mark Lamarr (for taking the piss out of someone who gets her arse out in soft-porn lads mags to become famous then decides that she wants respectability and credibility so nobody's allowed to mention it anymore) this criticism is misguided, short-sighted and misdirected. You are attacking those who attack, however obliquely, what you should be attacking: namely the institutional racism of the mainstream media that allows black people only to be portrayed as violent misogynist drug-dealing scum or dead victims of the brand of racism that even the Daily (hate) Mail can't condone, and the narcissism of certain "meeja whores" who show little talent and less clothing but still demand to be treated as something other than the over-paid figures of ridicule/titilation that they so obviously are.
Tom Paternoster
London

fields.headline: Converted to preaching
fields.trailText:
The article on Dr Carey (February 22) might have inspired more confidence if the writer had shown an awareness of the existence of the word "sermon". We should not then have had the Archbishop preaching a "lecture" at Essex university or delivering an Easter "speech" from the pulpit of Canterbury cathedral.
John Turner
Enfield,Middx

fields.headline: The making of Jinnah
fields.trailText: As someone whose family played a significant part in the creation of the state of Pakistan and continues to serve the country to this day, I find risible the accusation that I am part of an "Indian lobby" (Letters, February 19).
fields.body:
As someone whose family played a significant part in the creation of the state of Pakistan and continues to serve the country to this day, I find risible the accusation that I am part of an "Indian lobby" (Letters, February 19). I am a Pakistani and proud of it. I am sure the present Pakistani government, which has committed itself to deal severely with the endemic corruption in the political and financial life of the country, is able to distinguish between "Indian lobbies" (whatever that might mean) and financial malpractise.

As the director, producer and co-writer of Jinnah, I believe my film is an emblematic record of the creation of Pakistan and of the life of its founding father. I invite the government of Pakistan to investigate the business of entitlement and accountability concerning the making of the film, through its accountability bureau. There are questions to be answered.

The fact that Farrukh Dhondy, Shashi Kapoor and Indira Varma, a writer and two actors of Indian origin, participated in Jinnah refutes the "Indian lobby" allegation. On the contrary, it demonstrates that there are leading Indian artists who are willing to play a role in the making of a film which is hardly a piece of subversive Indian propaganda. Surely this collaboration is something to be applauded rather than vilified by scurrilous and chauvinistic innuendoes. This is paranoia masquerading as patriotism.
Jamil Delhavi
Producer and director of Jinnah

 Akbar Ahmed (Letters, February 19) refers to 70,000 civilians killed in Kashmir. During the mid 1980s, when I lived in Bangladesh, the memory of the struggle for liberation from Pakistan was still fresh in the minds of all the people I met. Hardly a family was unscathed by the events of March 25, 1971 and thereafter.

On that day, after the election victory of the Bengali-based Awami League, the Pakistan army seized power and began a highly organised slaughter of those it believed to be in the leadership of the independence movement. Thousands of teachers, student leaders, journalists and political activists were murdered. In this massacre and the following war of liberation, as many as a million citizens of what was to become the nation of Bangladesh died.

At that time Prof Ahmed was a civil servant in the Pakistani administration in Dhaka, the capital of what was then East Pakistan. Would he tell us, in view of his concern over the fate of the people of Kashmir, what exactly did he do?
Terry Fitzpatrick
London

fields.headline: Plenty of advice for Ken
fields.trailText: There is a fourth option for Ken Livingstone (Leader, February 22): to let his name go forward as an independent candidate, issue a simple policy statement and then refuse to campaign any further.
fields.body:
There is a fourth option for Ken Livingstone (Leader, February 22): to let his name go forward as an independent candidate, issue a simple policy statement and then refuse to campaign any further. That way he can claim to have respected the popular will of Londoners and yet not be accused of splitting Labour by, as you suggest, triggering a secession of pro-Ken activists. Democracy and the moral high-ground, what could be better?

Is there any need for Livingstone to actively campaign? It seems clear that the bedrock support is rounded in a perception of his pro-London attitude rather than in any detailed policy; and, since a Livingstone candidacy can be expected to generate a negative campaign from the Labour candidate, it may suit him better to stay out of the mud-slinging. It is not as if he needs the hustings to get his face known.

And there is a precedent which he may wish to consider. In 1865 the liberal philosopher John Stuart Mill was elected MP for Westminster, having refused to canvass or spend money on a campaign. True, Mill did attend some public meetings, where he declined to answer questions on his religious opinions; Livingstone could similarly decline to answer questions on his opinions about the Labour party.

A "liberal" tag may seem odd when attached to Ken Livingstone; but in this case at least, it may do him no harm.
Dr Kevin Francis
Deptartment of government University of Strathclyde

 So there are plans to replace Frank Dobson with Mo Mowlam at the last minute (Secret plan to ditch Dobson, February 22). I hope Mo will not agree to this. Ken Livingstone's support is based not on the unpopularity of Frank but on the fact that Londoners respect Ken for standing up for what he believes is good for London and Londoners, and his defiance of party apparatchiks.

Mo would go the same way as Frank. The only way to prevent any further disasters is to introduce one member one vote - and for Frank now to stand down in favour of Ken.
Andrea Woelke
London andrea.woelke@eggconnect.net

 I seem to remember that Frank Dobson said that he was definitely staying on as health secretary and was not going to run as mayor. At least if Ken breaks his word and stands as an independent, it will be because he wants to, and not because someone told him to.
Colin Tollervey
Weymouth colin@stonesculpture.co.uk

 You report one leftwing MP as saying "Ken's support comes from white Stalinists over 50". I am a leftwing socialist and a supporter of Ken Livingstone.

I am also 42 and a Roman Catholic priest and Franciscan friar. Should Ken run as an independent, I will not have a moment's hesitation in voting for him - even though I am hardly a white Stalinist over 50.
Fr Seamus Mulholl
London semulholland@yahoo.com

 If Ken Livingstone does stand against the Labour candidate for mayor, the first thing that will happen is his expulsion from the Labour party. He will then be under pressure to resign his parliamentary seat and fight a byelection as a non-Labour candidate.

The next thing to happen will be that he will join the pantheon of Labour defectors, including Oswald Mosley, Dick Taverne, Dave Nellist, Arthur Scargill and Ramsay MacDonald, who thought they were bigger than the Labour party - but weren't.
Paul Richards
London

fields.headline: Mind the parent gap
fields.trailText: Claims from the government's Women's Unit that sexual discrimination is costing unskilled women employees up to £m over a working lifetime warrant serious challenge (Equal pay laws must be enforced, say campaigners, February 22).
fields.body:
Claims from the government's Women's Unit that sexual discrimination is costing unskilled women employees up to £m over a working lifetime warrant serious challenge (Equal pay laws must be enforced, say campaigners, February 22).

The so-called "parent gap" identified in the report is based on the assumption that a "typical" woman has two children when she is aged 23 and 26, takes nine years out of the labour market and then works part-time for a further 28 years. This implies that parental responsibilities prevent the women from working full-time even when her children are aged 34 and 37. On the other side of the comparison, the figures assume that comparable men are able to work full-time up to normal retirement age. Yet we know that the group with the highest rates of involuntary unemployment is men aged over 50.

Perhaps most misleading is that differences in earnings between men and women as a whole indicate that equal pay legislation is not working. Legislation offers women easily enforced and powerful remedies if they are paid a different rate for the same job. It also offers remedies if women are paid less for work of equal value, although this is more difficult to prove. It is not discrimination in pay rates per se that accounts for the differences in men and women's earnings but that women are concentrated in lower paid jobs.
Stephen Brooks
London

stephen.brooks@clara.co.uk

fields.headline: Adoption's no easy option
fields.standfirst: Politicians must not pretend otherwise
fields.trailText: The prime minister is going to take charge of a radical overhaul of our adoption laws. The Tories go further; they would require all children in residential care to be given an adoption plan. Both major parties say we need to end the anti-adoption culture of social workers. Who could complain about that?
fields.body:
The prime minister is going to take charge of a radical overhaul of our adoption laws. The Tories go further; they would require all children in residential care to be given an adoption plan. Both major parties say we need to end the anti-adoption culture of social workers. Who could complain about that?

Well, everybody interested in rational policy-making, for a start. True, there is a lot wrong with our adoption laws. They have remained unchanged for 25 years. There is now an inherent contradiction in the law, with adoption procedures still not recognising the emphasis in the 1989 children act on children's interests being paramount.

That is one reason for the delays in the process: courts paying undue regard to the refusal of birth parents to give consent. But there are many more obstacles -such as the £13,000 fee which a local council has to pay when a neighbouring authority assesses and finds a suitable adoptive family for a child in its care.

Many cash-strapped social service departments jib at that. We are also still waiting for the right to paid leave for adoption and more generous adoption allowances. But none of this spurred last week's fervent political activity. All these faults have been known for years. The Tories introduced an inadequate bill and then withdrew it; Labour promised reform in opposition but have been silent since. The action was prompted by the scandal in the North Wales homes. But the number of children placed in such homes has shrunk to a small minority - 14,000 out of 56,000 - since most of that abuse occurred.

Placing more children in foster or adoptive families was a sensible step, but calls for even more careful monitoring, not less; children are more vulnerable to abuse when there is a lack of independent visitors. The Tory adoption plan is absurd. Many of the children in residential homes have been adopted once and gone back after a breakdown. Neither major party is recognising the enormous challenge involved in the adoption of these traumatised children. These are not babies. The average age is 10 and 40% are between 10 and 15 with complicated ties to their birth families. No wonder 20% of adoptions end in a breakdown. We have to put right the uneven use of adoption, cut unacceptable delays, and improve the support for adoptive parents. But both major parties need also to show a greater awareness of the harsh realities facing social workers.

fields.headline: Reputations
fields.trailText: While accepting that all lists are arbitrary and meaningless, the positioning of Woodrow Wilson as No 6 of the most effective US presidents cannot go without comment (White House winners and losers, February 22).
fields.body:
While accepting that all lists are arbitrary and meaningless, the positioning of Woodrow Wilson as No 6 of the most effective US presidents cannot go without comment (White House winners and losers, February 22).

He might have been academic and responsible for leading the US into the first world war, but he also introduced segregation into the federal bureaucracy, illegally intervened in Mexico in 1914 and did nothing while his attorney general, A Mitchell Palmer, ran riot through the US constitution in the red scare of 1919. Surely Wilson should be moved to No 40, just above James Buchanan, a man who truly deserves his position.
Thomas J Lyons
London

fields.headline: No need for genuflection
fields.standfirst:
Reconciliation is called for, not parity
Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The top brass are said to be in a cold fury. The generals do not like the rumours that the British army might be asked to take part in a "ceremony of reconciliation" with the IRA, whereby each side would hand over a symbolic clutch of weapons.
fields.body:
The top brass are said to be in a cold fury. The generals do not like the rumours that the British army might be asked to take part in a "ceremony of reconciliation" with the IRA, whereby each side would hand over a symbolic clutch of weapons.

Some, according to yesterday's Times, are even threatening resignation. They say the army cannot countenance any event which establishes a moral equivalence between themselves and the terrorists. And put like that, one can hardly blame them. They are right to see a world of difference between a legal army and an illegal campaign of terror.

But none of those who advocate a day of reconciliation - including this newspaper, which was first to revive the suggestion at the start of this month - ever said otherwise. Perhaps some clarification is required. First, this is not a provo scheme. It surfaced first in the Hillsborough agreement between Tony Blair and his Irish counterpart, Bertie Ahern, sealed last Easter on the anniversary of the Good Friday agreement. It triggered no rejectionist outcry then: rather it was seen as a good idea which might break the deadlock on decommissioning. It lay dormant until it was revived this month.

The fact that the IRA sees some merit in it - perhaps as a face-saving way to make disarmament palatable to hardliners - should not automatically disqualify it. On the contrary, if people are genuinely keen to see a handover of guns, they would surely seize on this as part of the choreography which might help achieve that outcome. Second, nobody has suggested anything so tacky as a "ceremony" where British and IRA bullets would be thrown on to the pyre. Instead there is talk of a carefully programmed sequence of events: an announcement of a reduction in troop numbers, if the security assessment warrants it, followed by a move by the IRA. If that could represent a way out of the current impasse, all those committed to peace should surely at least discuss it.

fields.headline: Lebanon exit by year end
fields.trailText: Israeli troops will almost certainly leave south Lebanon by the end of the year, the army's chief of operations said yesterday, and they will be ready to do so even if there is no peace agreement with Syria.
fields.body:
Israeli troops will almost certainly leave south Lebanon by the end of the year, the army's chief of operations said yesterday, and they will be ready to do so even if there is no peace agreement with Syria.

"The real question is: if and when we get an order to change our positions, will we be ready to do it? The answer is 'yes'," Major General Giora Eiland said in Tel Aviv.

"If in a few months we realise that there is no hope of agreement between Israel and Syria then we will decide what to do," he said.

The admission comes amid relentless speculation about whether Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, will be able to reach a peace agreement with Syria and Lebanon in time to redeem his election pledge to bring troops home by July 7.

Some 70% of Israelis support withdrawal from Lebanon, according to some opinion polls. The intensification of fighting in Lebanon earlier this month - which saw the deaths of seven soldiers in Hizbullah missile attacks - has added to pressure on Mr Barak to withdraw from 18 years of an unwinnable war, and led to fresh bouts of soul-searching about "Israel's Vietnam".

Earlier yesterday, a senior military spokesman also spoke about arriving at "a formula" by which Israeli troops could pull out of the self-declared security zone in south Lebanon in the absence of a full-scale agreement.

While Gen Eiland refused to say directly that the army had a contingency plan, there have been signals in recent days that the establishment is considering its options should it fail to revive the talks suspended with Syria last month, or to come to an understanding with Lebanon. "We have some decisions, but I can't say there is a plan," he said.

The risks of a unilateral withdrawal are high. In recent days, Israeli analysts have outlined scenarios in which the army would be compelled by public opinion to respond with force to any attack on northern villages by Hizbullah guerrillas in south Lebanon.

On Monday, however, the prime minister warned US Jewish leaders that an Israeli withdrawal from the security zone in the absence of an agreement might not bring a cessation of hostilities with the Hizbullah militias there.

The military spokesman yesterday said Israel's bombing of Lebanese power stations during the upsurge in fighting was a show of strength in advance of the planned withdrawal.

"We believe we have built a better situation for the next couple of weeks or months, hopefully until the day when we have an agreement or other formula to go out of Lebanon," the spokesman said.

webTitle: Historic actors' club told to quit its London home

fields.headline: Historic actors' club told to quit its London home
fields.trailText: The world's oldest acting club has been told to leave its London home after losing a legal battle against an eviction order.
fields.body:
The world's oldest acting club has been told to leave its London home after losing a legal battle against an eviction order.

The Green Room, which was founded in 1876 and includes among its 2,500 members Prince Edward, Andrew Lloyd-Webber and Richard Attenborough, has 28 days to leave its premises in Adam Street, after a county court judge ruled in favour of the club's landlord.

The private members' club for actors, writers and directors had claimed that it had a protected tenancy, which allowed it to occupy the basement floor of the four storey terraced building for as long as it wished. In a hearing at central London county court last month, the club claimed it had an "exclusive occupation" agreement for the premises it has occupied since 1955, whereby it paid its landlord, Adam House, a yearly rent of £10,000.

But the court backed the landlord, who said that the lease had run out in 1996 and that the club should have vacated the premises by March last year.

Derek Lamden, the Green Room's secretary, said the club would seek a new base in central London. "There's no way this club will collapse."

In a hearing at central London county court last month, the club claimed it had an "exclusive occupation" agreement for the premises it has occupied since 1955, whereby it paid its landlord, Adam House, a yearly rent of £10,000. But the court backed the landlord, who said that the lease had run out in 1996 and that the club should have vacated the premises by March last year. Derek Lamden, the Green Room's secretary, said the club would seek a new base in central London. "There's no way this club will collapse."

webTitle: Republican knives out in do-or-die campaign

fields.headline: Republican knives out in do-or-die campaign
fields.standfirst: McCain and Bush trade insults as race for presidential nomination moves up a gear in run-up to Super Tuesday
fields.trailText: John McCain and George W Bush ripped into one another with their bitterest insults so far in the race for the Republican presidential nomination yesterday, signalling an increasingly ill-tempered contest in the run-up to the March 7 "Super Tuesday" primaries in 16 states.
fields.body:
John McCain and George W Bush ripped into one another with their bitterest insults so far in the race for the Republican presidential nomination yesterday, signalling an increasingly ill-tempered contest in the run-up to the March 7 "Super Tuesday" primaries in 16 states.

As voters went to the polls in Republican primaries in Michigan and Arizona yesterday, the two candidates traded accusations about campaign tactics in a race in which both men are increasingly relying on negative tactics, despite earlier promises to the contrary.

Mr McCain was expected to win yesterday's Republican primary in Arizona, the state for which he has been a senator since 1986, but the contest in Michigan was too close to call last night, with both sides hoping for victory.

Campaigning in Michigan, where polls showed Mr McCain to have a narrow advantage, Mr Bush conceded that the race would be close. "That's why I'm still here in the state, working hard to turn out the vote," the Texas governor told reporters.

Hundreds of miles away in Arizona, Mr McCain cast a vote for himself. He was widely expected to win comfortably, despite the opposition of Arizona governor Jane Dee Hull, who supports Mr Bush.

"It's kind of nice to be the first presidential candidate in this campaign to vote for himself," Mr McCain said in Phoenix, where he voted with his wife Cindy.

Asked whether yesterday was a "do-or-die" opportunity to regain the initiative after being beaten by Mr Bush in last Saturday's South Carolina primary, Mr McCain said: "Every thing is do or die in this campaign. That's why we're having so much fun. Every day is do or die. We're a high wire act, an insurgency campaign and we've had a great ride."

But the candidates' expressions of election day optimism failed to mask the bitterness which exists between the McCain and Bush camps over inflammatory attacks being made by their supporters in the no-holds-barred world of the automated phone-call campaign.

Mr Bush laid into Mr McCain about phone calls in which, he alleged, Mr McCain's supporters labelled the Texas governor as anti-Roman Catholic for giving a speech at the Bob Jones university in South Carolina, a notoriously sectarian college whose graduates include the Rev Ian Paisley. More than a quarter of the electorate in Michigan is Catholic.

"He's called me an anti-Catholic bigot," Mr Bush complained in Royal Oak, Michigan, yesterday. "I don't appreciate it. My campaign manager here, John Engler [Michigan governor] is a Catholic. My brother's a Catholic. My sister-in-law's a Catholic. And there's no excuse for that kind of politics."

The Bush campaign released a tape of the phone call, in which a male voice criticises Mr Bush for appearing at a venue where a past college president once labelled catholicism as "a satanic cult". The words "anti-Catholic bigot" were not heard on the tape.

Meanwhile, Mr McCain attacked Mr Bush for sanctioning phone-call messages from his supporter Pat Robertson, the rightwing evangelical Christian campaigner, in which Mr Robertson de scribed a key McCain supporter as "a vicious bigot".

Mr Robertson's taped message to Michigan voters dubbed the former Republican senator Warren Rudman, the McCain campaign national chairman, as "a vicious bigot who wrote that conservative Christians in politics are anti-abortion zealots, homophobes and would-be censors".

With the Michigan and Arizona contests now over, the race for the Republican nomination effectively ceases to be a series of individual one-state contests and becomes a nationwide campaign.

Though there are Republican primaries next Tuesday in North Dakota and Virginia, the campaign emphasis is shifting to the vital votes on March 7.

That is the day on which 16 states will hold primaries and caucuses to choose their Republican and Democratic candidates, making it easily the most important day in the 2000 campaign calendar so far.

Super Tuesday will decide 59% of the delegates to this year's Republican convention and 61% of the Democratic convention delegates.

webTitle: Gore v Bradley: it's showtime at the Apollo

fields.headline: Gore v Bradley: it's showtime at the Apollo
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: Where Ella Fitzgerald and James Brown once sought to woo the black audience through song and funk, Bill Bradley and Al Gore chose instead to lacerate each other in the service of democracy.
fields.body:
Where Ella Fitzgerald and James Brown once sought to woo the black audience through song and funk, Bill Bradley and Al Gore chose instead to lacerate each other in the service of democracy.

But showtime at the Apollo, the Harlem home of black culture, was not entirely devoid of dance steps - though not the sort that Brown, the godfather of soul, would recognise.

Mr Bradley, the former New Jersey senator who is struggling to stay in the race for the Democratic presidential nomination, alluded to the theatre's past by saying: "What you have just seen is an elaborate 'Gore' dance. It's a dance to avoid facing up to your conservative record on guns."

Vice-president Gore, wearing black cowboy-boots to perform his metaphorical steps, said: "You've made personal attack after personal attack. The problem is that these attacks don't solve any problems. They do divide us as Democrats."

Mr Bradley, with the air of a headteacher on the point of losing patience with the smug head boy, accused Mr Gore of being a closet conservative who also held a suspect record on affirmative action and abortion.

At one point he attempted to hand the vice-president a stack of his voting records as if it were homework that required further attention. Mr Gore said Mr Bradley was untrustworthy and that his healthcare plans would harm patients.

They started before a mostly black audience of about 1,000 - including celebrity supporters such as Spike Lee (Bradley) and Whoopi Goldberg (Gore) - with a spot of softball. How would they stop police brutality and contain crime at the same time? This was an easy entree to the subject of Amadou Diallo, shot 19 times by four New York policemen who are now on trial for murder.

"I think it was an outrage," said Mr Bradley, hands wide as though he were expecting to receive a basketball, as he once did for a living as a star player for the New York Knicks. "I feel it. Everybody in this room feels it. I think it was also a tragedy."

Mr Gore felt it too. "The Diallo case and the other cases are just heartbreaking," he said.

They even agreed on what to do about police attitudes to the community: stop "racial profiling" - the targeting of black people.

This was where the candidates parted. Mr Bradley, jowls working overtime, said: "I am questioning why you haven't made this happen in the last seven and a half years."

Mr Gore, executing a two-part left turn from the waist like an articulated lorry, slammed on the brakes: "You know, racial profiling practically began in New Jersey, Senator Bradley."

Most commentators gave the verdict in the bout between the two wealthy, middle-aged whites at the cradle of black working-class talent to Mr Gore.

It was no accident that the Apollo was chosen as the venue for the only Democratic debate since the New Hampshire primary on February 1. Black support was decisive when Bill Clinton won the 1992 primary in New York.

webTitle: Straw's concession on jury trial change

fields.headline: Straw's concession on jury trial change
fields.standfirst: Are your rights at risk? Find out here
fields.trailText: Jack Straw is to unveil a big concession tomorrow over his plans to abolish the right to jury trial when he reintroduces the legislation into the Commons. The climbdown comes in the face of more than 58 Labour MPs backing a call for the proposal to be shelved until a wide-ranging inquiry into the criminal justice system reports in the summer.
fields.body:
Jack Straw is to unveil a big concession tomorrow over his plans to abolish the right to jury trial when he reintroduces the legislation into the Commons. The climbdown comes in the face of more than 58 Labour MPs backing a call for the proposal to be shelved until a wide-ranging inquiry into the criminal justice system reports in the summer.

The home secretary, whose original scheme suffered a crushing defeat in the Lords last month. is to drop plans for a "test of reputation and livelihood" designed to bar persistent offenders from choosing jury trial.

Opponents claimed that this test would have introduced a "two-tier" system of justice under which a bank manager would be allowed jury trial while the homeless defendant was forced to have their case heard by magistrates.

The measure would stop about 18,000 defendants, who are charged with middle-ranking offences such as burglary and theft, each year electing for jury trial in the crown court. It is designed to save about £102m a year and speed up the system of justice.

Mr Straw hopes that the concession will draw the sting out of the backbench rebellion. Tony Blair and Mr Straw have pledged to force a showdown with the Lords once the measure has the backing of Labour's large Commons majority.

But last night Mark Fisher, the Labour MP for Stoke-on-Trent, and a leading figure in the rebellion, said the concession did not go far enough. The entire system was in need of an overhaul and he could not understand why the government could not wait until the review by Sir Robin Auld reported in the summer.

fields.headline: England's jail terms among longest
fields.trailText: The courts in England and Wales are among the toughest in western Europe, with only Portugal giving offenders longer prison sentences, according to home office figures comparing international crime rates, which were published yesterday.
fields.body:
The courts in England and Wales are among the toughest in western Europe, with only Portugal giving offenders longer prison sentences, according to home office figures comparing international crime rates, which were published yesterday.

The official statistics also show that the prison population in England and Wales on a per capita basis is once again close to the top of the western European league table with 126 inmates per 100,000 population. More people are jailed in England and Wales, as a proportion of population, than happens in Sudan, Saudi Arabia or China, and across western Europe the rate of imprisonment is exceeded only by Portugal.

But the figures also show that England and Wales has one of the lowest murder rates in western Europe, and that London is well down the homicide league table for capital cities across the continent.

The home office bulletin suggests that the ordinary citizen in England and Wales is more likely to be robbed, burgled or have their car stolen than in the US or many European countries. But the comparative data is based on 1995 figures, and since then there have been significant falls in the number of these offences in England and Wales. For example, car thefts have fallen from 513,927 in 1995 to 387,000 in 1999.

The home office said that the international comparisons based on 1998 figures collected from 29 countries showed that while crime rose by 5% across the industrialised world it fell by 1% in England and Wales.

In Scotland it rose by 3%. In Northern Ireland recorded crime rose by 28% to 76,664 offences, which in the international comparisons was second only to the 37% increase in crime recorded in South Africa that year.

After a period in the early 1990s when the prison population fell to only 42,000, Britain has regained its place near the top of the western European league table for imprisonment.

The prison population in England and Wales has risen to more than 68,000 - back near the top of the league table. In world terms, it is exceeded by the US (668 inmates per 100,000 population), Russia (690 per 100,000) and the Czech republic (215 per 100,000).

A separate study by the Council of Europe covering nine European countries confirms the more punitive approach of courts in England and Wales.

It concludes that English offenders sentenced for assault, robbery and theft are given longer prison sentences than those that similarly convicted criminals receive in Denmark, Finland, France, Germany and Sweden.

However, the National Association for the Care and Resettlement of Offenders yesterday denied there was a direct link between the rise in prison numbers in England and Wales and the fall in recorded crime.

"Between 1994 and 1998 the prison population increased in most European countries, as well as in North America, Japan, New Zealand and Australia and South Africa. Yet the crime rate fluctuated wildly in these countries. Some, such as Britain, Ireland and the United States saw a fall in recorded crime. But in most countries the crime rate and the prison population both went up," said Rob Allen, Nacro's director of research.

webTitle: Christ portrayed as naked, human and divine

fields.headline: Christ portrayed as naked, human and divine
fields.standfirst: Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: A small limestone statue of a naked man proved yesterday that it had not lost its power to move the beholder.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy,  Arts and Heritage Correspondent
fields.body:
A small limestone statue of a naked man proved yesterday that it had not lost its power to move the beholder.

"It is an extraordinary and disturbing image," said Neil MacGregor. "It represents Christ at the moment of absolute destitution, waiting to be tortured. It was made to move people to compassion, and it does."

Mr MacGregor, director of the National Gallery, was speaking at a preview of Seeing Salvation, the gallery's millennium exhibition of images of Christ.

The statue, Christ on the Cold Stone, was carved in the Netherlands 500 years ago, and is one of dozens of startling objects and images borrowed for the exhibition from museums across Europe, joining the great religious paintings in the gallery's own collection.

The statue, on loan from a museum of religious art in Utrecht, is most unusual because the Christ, portrayed slumped in exhaustion after he has carried from the cross to the place of crucifixion, is completely naked apart from the crown of thorns.

The exhibition is intended to demonstrate the artistic dilemma of trying to represent a being both human and divine, but is also intended to restore the devotional context of the works.

There are small portable objects intended to inspire personal contemplation and prayer, such as books, rosary beads and prayer rolls, including one inscribed by Prince Henry, who became Henry VII.

One of the rarest objects is the most humble, a papier-mache face of Christ, bought for pennies at a medieval fair, and the only survivor of thousands that must have hung in ordinary homes. One extremely rare medieval copy of a miraculous icon, believed for centuries to be an image given to the artist by Christ himself, has been loaned by the Queen.

There are works by Titian, Velazquez, and Bellini, as well as controversial 20th century works, displayed together for the first time, by Salvador Dali, Holman Hunt, Graham Sutherland and Stanley Spencer.

Spencer's gigantic Resurrection at Cookham, showing his friends and neighbours rising from the dead in the village churchyard, borrowed from the Tate, is the last image in the show.

Gabrieli Finaldi, co-curator of the exhibition, said: "We will be very interested to see the public reaction. People can admire them as art objects, or be moved to prayer - one does not rule out the other."

The exhibition is sponsored by the Jerusalem Trust and the Pilgrim Trust so that, unlike other special exhibitions, admission is free. It opens to the public on Saturday.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.body:
More and more go to dome
Millennium Dome attendance figures for February have already almost exceeded those for January, it was announced yesterday.

The visitor total for January 31 to February 20 was nearly 360,000, compared with 366,204 for the whole of January.

Male birth pill backed
Two-thirds of Scottish men would use a male contraceptive pill if it were available, according to a survey, published in the journal Human Reproduction.

Warren's suits a knock-out
Boxing promoter Frank Warren yesterday lifted the title of best dressed businessman in Britain, awarded by the Menswear Council. Other contenders included Sir Terence Conran and British Airways chief Bob Ayling.

Banking on consumer aid
The Consumers' Association yesterday announced plans to expand its work for customers overcharged by banks.

Its trading arm, Which? Ltd has bought Anglia Business Associates Ltd. ABA, based in Norwich, specialises in auditing bank statements for overcharging errors.

Football duo fined
Two Portsmouth footballers yesterday admitted being abusive to police after a drinking spree.

Rory Allen, 22, and Aaron Flahavan, 24, were each fined £750 and ordered to pay £55 costs at Fareham magistrates court. They were arrested in the car park of the TGI Friday restaurant in Fareham last Friday night, the court heard.

webTitle: Fishing boat 'not watertight' on fatal last trip

fields.headline: Fishing boat 'not watertight' on fatal last trip
fields.trailText: Accident investigators have discovered an open hatch on the wreck of the Solway Harvester, prompting fears the ship was not watertight when she went down with her seven crew in the Irish sea last month.
fields.body:
Accident investigators have discovered an open hatch on the wreck of the Solway Harvester, prompting fears the ship was not watertight when she went down with her seven crew in the Irish sea last month.

An interim report reveals that a fish-loading scuttle on the ship's main deck was open and did not have a safety hatch, which could have left the vessel at risk to flooding from high waves.

The investigators also discovered that the scallop dredger's life rafts were not properly attached and maintained, and four of the seven crewmen who lost their lives had not undergone basic safety training.

The Solway Harvester went down bow first in stormy waters 11 miles from the Isle of Man on January 12, but the marine accident investigation branch safety bulletin says there is no evidence of any collision with the boat.

The report's authors have urged the fishing industry to take immediate action to secure the safety of fishermen. They are asking boat owners to ensure that decks are kept watertight, and that life rafts are properly installed and maintained, and to make sure that all crew undergo mandatory basic safety training.

The MAIB recommends that in the "overriding interest of safety" the maritime and coastguard agency should take immediate action to promote and enforce better safety practices.

Skipper Craig Mills, 29, his brother Robin, 33, their cousin David, 17, and fellow crew members David Lyons, 18, Wesley Jolly, 17, John Murphy, 22, and Martin Milligan, 26, from the tiny communities which make up the Machars of Whithorn in the south-west of Scotland, all died when the Solway Harvester sank.

A spokesman for the boat's owner said he was abroad and unavailable for comment.

Chief inspector of marine accidents John Lang said in the safety bulletin: "The MAIB's initial inquiries have revealed evidence of several safety shortcomings, which give rise to serious concerns about the safety of all fishing vessels, and particularly for the crews sailing on similar scallop dredgers and other trawlers operating out of Kirkcudbright."

Hamish Morrison, chief executive of the Scottish Fishermen's Federation, said the report, although welcome, did not explain what had happened to the vessel.

The public should not be left with the impression that if the problems highlighted had been resolved the victims would still be alive. "That's not true because all the crew were found inside the vessel. Whatever happened, happened quickly and was catastrophic."

fields.headline: National roundup
fields.body:
Affair with youth 'led to axe killing'

A father beheaded his neighbour with an axe after she gave birth to his teenage son's baby, Birmingham crown court was told yesterday. Anthony Phillips, of Wolverhampton, was convinced that Lorraine Howell, 34, had corrupted his son Jamie, 17.

The electrician, aged 43, climbed over his garden fence and attacked his neighbour with an axe while her two young children were in the house.

Mrs Howell, who had separated from her husband, embarked on an affair with Jamie Phillips and gave birth to their child, Lauren, on November 17 1998. Roger Smith QC, prosecuting, said that when the deeply religious father of two heard of this he bought an axe from a hardware shop and began plotting her murder.

The affair began soon after Mrs Howell's husband, Peter, left the marital home in August 1997.

"By December 1997, sexual intercourse had occurred on two occasions.

"It did not become a regular thing and as far as Jamie can recollect he only had sex with Lorraine Howell one time after that.

"But Lorraine Howell became pregnant as a result."

Jamie later told his mother that he was the father. "She told the defendant and he was outraged."

Phillips later told police that on May 1 1999 he had seen Mrs Howell's back door was open and entered her house.

"He said Lorraine was coming down the stairs with a bundle of washing in her hands. He said he just swung the axe and it was 'like hitting a piece of rubber. I just basically took the axe and hit her with it repeatedly,' he said."

Phillips admits manslaughter, but denies murder.

The case continues.

Girl tells of avalanche rescue

A British teenager yesterday told of the moment when a wall of snow engulfed her at an Austrian ski resort.

Alice Reed, from London, who was celebrating her 17th birthday on a family skiing holiday in the Alpine resort of Tauplitz, was rescued by a ski instructor and a family friend also caught in the avalanche on Monday.

Miss Reed told ITN: "I didn't really have time to be scared, but snow was completely covering me. It was in my mouth as well, so it was hard to breathe. My left arm was free so I pushed the snow away from my head and found I was stuck."

The friend, David Wallace, added: "I was trapped to my midriff. The ski instructor, who was further down the slope, managed to get herself out, got me out, and then we dug Alice out." She was taken to hospital for treatment to minor leg injuries.

Police from nearby Bad Mitterndorf said the party was lucky to survive. The guide, Maria Huber, 23, told reporters: "The snow was all around me up to my shoulders, but because I could see to orientate myself I was able to get free. I was able to dig them out. We were lucky that one of us was free and could see the others."

Police in Bad Mitterndorf are hunting two snowboarders who they believe started the avalanche by skiing off-piste. Elsewhere, avalanches in ski resorts left six dead - three women in Bolzano, Italy, and another three people in Davos in Switzerland.

Grade buys Pinewood for £62m

Pinewood studios in Buckinghamshire saw the end of an era yesterday as its founder and owner, Rank Group, sold the complex to investors led by the former head of Channel 4, Michael Grade.

Pinewood, built in the 1930s, was sold for £62m - more than the £50m originally expected. Rank no longer sees Britain's biggest film studio as a core business. On Monday, the company sold its Odeon cinemas chain for £280m.

The move will take Mr Grade back to the heart of the British entertainment world after his three-year stint as chief executive of First Leisure.

Mr Grade, speaking from Australia, said: "People love to film at Pinewood, especially Americans. We want to keep attracting the Hollywood blockbusters but also see more British films, TV programmes and adverts made there."

The British film industry was set for huge expansion as government initiatives such as tax breaks and national lottery funding took effect, he said. The explosion in the number of cable and satellite television channels and internet sites would bring a further increase in the boom.

Mr Grade is receiving backing from the investment group 3i for the deal. He will run the company alongside Ivan Dunleavy, formerly chief executive of a video production company.

The most recent figures, for 1998, show Pinewood made an underlying profit of £4.4m on £13.2m of turnover.

Dan Adler, one of the directors at 3i who arranged the financing for the deal, said: "The media business is all about who you know, and after being controller of programmes at the BBC and chief executive at Channel 4, Michael Grade has a contacts book to die for."

Pinewood will continue wooing the big US movie producers such as Sony, Fox and Warner Brothers, all of which use its studios.

As well as 20 studios of various sizes, Pinewood houses dozens of businesses associated with the film industry such as lighting and production outfits. It also has large office facilities, vital for attracting the entourages of staff who work on big budget productions.

Sky centres beam the way ahead

Mobile phone masts that disfigure the landscape could one day be replaced with communications platforms floating in the sky, it was disclosed yesterday.

A team of British scientists is investigating ways of using airships, balloons or small pilotless aircraft to relay phone, TV and internet signals.

The high altitude platforms would fly higher than Concorde but be much closer to the earth than orbiting satellites.

Powered by solar panels, they would offer more efficient and cheaper communications than either cellular phone or satellite systems.

Research into the platforms has been driven by the explosion in demand for services such as mobile phones, internet access and email.

They could deliver all these to both stationary and mobile users, rendering existing ways of connecting with the internet obsolete.

They would also be able to cope with large numbers of TV and video channels, and could replace current satellite or cable TV systems.

The platforms would be designed to respond to user demands. For instance, they might direct most of their capacity over city centres during the working day, but move their antennae beams out to the suburbs in the evenings.

The platforms could also prove useful where there was a sudden need for communications, as in the event of an earthquake or other disaster.

Tim Tozer, leader of the communications research group at York university, said: "This has colossal potential, and indeed may be the only way we are going to fulfil all the demands for wireless services."

The York researchers are collaborating with 10 other teams across Italy, Spain, Switzerland, Slovenia, Hungary and the UK. The work is being funded by an EU grant totalling £3m

Slip did not show Council cleared over landslide

Scarborough district council has been cleared of blame for the disaster in which one of the North Yorkshire resort's leading hotels slipped off the cliff (pictured above) one morning in June 1993.

Lord Justices Stuart-Smith, Schiemann and Tuckey yesterday allowed an appeal court challenge in London by the council against a 1998 high court ruling that it had failed in its legal duty to keep the land between the hotel and the cliff's edge safe.

The claim had been brought by Holbeck Hall Hotel Ltd and English Rose Hotels (Yorkshire) Ltd, owners of the four star hotel built in 1880.

Lord Justice Stuart-Smith said that it had not been "just and reasonable" to impose a liability on Scarborough for the damage.

The council in its appeal argued that it could not fairly be said Scarborough knew of the danger. The owners had claimed that the council, if it knew the land was unstable, owed a duty to the owners to take steps to prevent a disaster.

The judge said: "Scarborough have done nothing to create the danger which has arisen by the operation of nature." He did not consider that the high court judge who found Scarborough to blame had addressed the question of the extent of the damage that could reasonably have been foreseen.

Vegetarian 'danger of infertility'

Vegetarians were warned yesterday that their diet could cause infertility in both men and women.

Lack of meat might also create a risk of anaemia and an inability to work due to lack of vital minerals.

Margaret Rayman, director of nutritional medicine at Surrey university, said young women were most at risk because they lost iron during menstruation and could not replace it by eating just greens.

Dr Rayman said: "Iron, zinc and copper are readily found in red meat [but] are poorly represented in fruit and vegetables. A shortage of zinc can cause fertility problems particularly among men who secrete large quantities of it in the testes."

She added: "Vegetarians could optimise their uptake by drinking orange juice with a meal as it improves the body's absorption of iron."

webTitle: Effing is off, rules theatre computer

fields.headline: Effing is off, rules theatre computer
fields.trailText: It is the theatre which likes to call a spade an effing spade, which has fearlessly fought censorship for a century, and where no taboo is ever safe.
fields.body:
It is the theatre which likes to call a spade an effing spade, which has fearlessly fought censorship for a century, and where no taboo is ever safe.

But the Royal Court, which defied the lord chamberlain in the 60s, and where provoking moral outrage is almost a point of honour, has finally been brought to book - by its own computers.

Expletives are immediately deleted every time a piece of gritty, full-blooded dialogue is typed into its new system. Even furious staff emails complaining about the computer's censorious ways have lost their more colourful turns of phrase.

"It's hilarious," said literary manager Graham Whybrow. "It's just bizarre that the theatre that brought the world Shopping and Fucking, that campaigned successfully to stop the lord chamberlain's vetting of plays, and that has championed playwrights from Edward Bond to Sarah Kane should be pulled up by its own computers like this."

The Royal Court's history of profanity is long and glorious. Sir John Gielgud is believed to have uttered the first perfectly pronounced "fuck" on a British stage in its production of Veterans in 1972.

Staff realised something was amiss last week when they moved back into the theatre's Sloane Square headquarters in central London after a £26m refurbishment.

The preferences for their new Microsoft system, which automatically "corrects" swear words, and which was designed to curb abuse and harassment by email in American offices, were set centrally by the theatre's computer department. They are now hastily freeing the boundaries again.

Last night hundreds of actors, writers and celebrities turned up for the first of the theatre's two-night reopening celebrations. Royal Court legends Harold Pinter, Arnold Wesker and Michael Frayn were in the audience to see Conor McPherson's new play about an alcoholic undertaker, Dublin Carol, which features a healthy quota of expletives.

webTitle: Four jailed for turf war murder

fields.headline: Four jailed for turf war murder
fields.standfirst: London's gun violence: special report
fields.trailText: Four Jamaicans involved in a turf war between Yardie-style gangs in London were jailed for life yesterday for shooting a man after a row over a parking space at a leisure centre.
fields.body:
Four Jamaicans involved in a turf war between Yardie-style gangs in London were jailed for life yesterday for shooting a man after a row over a parking space at a leisure centre.

The attack, which led to the murder of Dion Holmes, 29, was like something from the "wild west", with shots being fired from a 12 bore pump action shotgun and pistol, the Old Bailey was told.

Richard Horwell, prosecuting, said Winston Harris, 38, Stephen Murray, 26, Jermaine Hamilton, 22, and Leonard Cole, 27, had gone to the Bridge Park leisure centre last May bent on revenge and retribution because they felt slighted by a rival posse.

They were members of a gang called the Lock City Crew which used the leisure centre, near Wembley stadium, as a meeting place and hideout for drugs and ammunition.

The shoot-out was provoked after the wife of a member of a rival gang, the Cartel Crew, drove to the centre. A security guard, who was also a member of the LCC, admonished her for poor parking and told her to try again, the court was told.

The woman flew into a rage, smashed a bottle and had to be escorted away by the police.

She returned 20 minutes later with her husband, infuriating the LCC gang members who thought it showed "a certain lack of respect to them and their territory".

Mr Horwell added: "Their hackles rose. They wanted to defend their territory and teach this impudent other group a lesson they would never forget."

The four men armed themselves with guns carried in a sports bag, the jury heard.

One of them locked the doors of the leisure centre to prevent people from leaving, but their plan to pick off their rival went wrong.

Hamilton accidentally fired his shotgun, causing panic and Harris, who has served jail terms in New York for violence, let off another shot in an effort to control the crowd.

In the mayhem Mr Holmes, of Streatham, south London, was hit. He was found lying in a pool of blood with a bullet hole through his heart and liver, the court heard. All four men, who are from north London, pleaded not guilty.

The court heard they had come here from Jamaica in the mid-1990s and were staying here illegally.

A fifth man, David Lewis, 49, from Wembley, was cleared of murder, manslaughter and a firearms offence and was freed.

Following the convictions Detective Superintendent Peter Camilletti, who led the investigation, described the Jamaicans as "very nasty armed criminals."

"When you think of the background, it takes courage to come forward and give evidence. This case has proved that you can get support from the public. We are dealing with hardened criminals who form themselves into posses and arm themselves."

Police appealed for help to track down Anthony Wray, 38, who is also wanted in connection with the shooting.

Gerry Davis, director of community development at Brent council, said he was appalled that the leisure centre had become a meeting place for gangsters. The borough has spent £100,000 to improve security since then.

"In addition, the internal CCTV system has been extended and external cameras are being installed to link to the council's central monitoring centre," he said.

webTitle: High hat Prince steps out in Trinidad

fields.headline: High hat Prince steps out in Trinidad
fields.standfirst: The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: Perhaps it was a reflection of Britain's poor eating habits that Trinidad had been expecting the Prince of Wales to be "stodgy" - according one local newspaper yesterday - but far from remaining distant and aloof, the heir to the throne has surprised locals by plunging himself into the vibrancy of Caribbean culture,  writes Matt Wells in Port of Spain .
fields.body:
Perhaps it was a reflection of Britain's poor eating habits that Trinidad had been expecting the Prince of Wales to be "stodgy" - according one local newspaper yesterday - but far from remaining distant and aloof, the heir to the throne has surprised locals by plunging himself into the vibrancy of Caribbean culture, writes Matt Wells in Port of Spain .

Since he arrived for a tour of the region on Monday night, Prince Charles has met a calypso music star, tried his hand at playing the steel drums, and marvelled at the extravagant costumes being prepared for Trinidad's annual carnival.

For Trinidadians who had been expecting a more reserved response to their traditionally gregarious character, it is an eye-opener. As he inspected preparations for Trinidad's world famous carnival yesterday, the prince was enveloped in a swirling mass of sequinned performers who gave him a brief taste of the spectacle which takes over the island every year.

Prince Charles was visiting the workshop, or "mas camp" of Peter Minshell, Trinidad's premier carnival costume designer. As he entered the hangar-like premises just outside Port of Spain, he was greeted by five performers manipulating 20ft-high puppets, girls dressed in cream and and gold Indian costumes, and other children in scarlet mini-elephant outfits.

Mr Minshell said that while the carnivals of Rio and Sydney now rival Trinidad for sheer scale, the roots of carnival culture lie firmly in the Caribbean. He had praise for London's version: "Notting Hill is the artery of carnival, but Trinidad is the heart."

webTitle: BMA document consigns Dr Finlay image to scrap heap

fields.headline: BMA document consigns Dr Finlay image to scrap heap
fields.trailText: The era of Dr Finlay, the comforting local GP who looks after his community from cradle to grave, is dead, but today's family doctors have no clear idea of what is his 21st century replacement, according to a discussion document for the profession.
fields.body:
The era of Dr Finlay, the comforting local GP who looks after his community from cradle to grave, is dead, but today's family doctors have no clear idea of what is his 21st century replacement, according to a discussion document for the profession.

More than 100 people, mostly key figures in general practice, contributed to the document, Shaping Tomorrow, written by medical journalist Chris Mihill for the British Medical Association. The paper, published yesterday, will be sent to every GP in the country, to stimulate debate ahead of a conference next month on the way ahead for general practice.

GPs are under pressure to modernise the way they work from a government that has already clashed with the BMA over introduction of measures like walk-in clinics and NHS Direct.

These initiatives appeal to patients who want rapid treatment at their convenience, but strike at the heart of the traditional doctor-patient relationship, where the GP was virtually a family friend.

GPs themselves were split on the advantages and disadvantages of such relations, the document showed.

Roy Lilley, visiting fellow at the King's Fund, offered a patient's perspective. "When I go out in the morning, my doctor's surgery is closed. When I come home at night it's closed. Saturday mornings he's only there for emergencies, and Sundays it's closed," he said.

Those who visit the doctor's surgery of the future may be more likely to see a nurse than a GP, some believed. GPs were wrong to try to hold on to everything, according to Simon Fradd, joint deputy chairman of the BMA's GPs committee.

"People talk about a loss of status and professionalism. But, in my practice, a third of the patients are seen by nurses. I am seen as the expert the nurses turn to when they need assistance," he said.

Mr Mihill wrote: "It may be that some GPs over-invest in the notion of personal doctoring, clasping it to themselves like some psychological comfort blanket, when the truth is that most patients couldn't care less as long as they are seen by a competent professional."

Stephen Thornton of the NHS executive was blunt about the changes that were needed. "The Dr Finlay model is a nonsense. It gets in the way and creates a whole series of myths. Even if it was wonderful whenever it was, it's not appropriate now," he said.

GPs had a variety of ideas of what they wanted from the future, but, said Mr Mihill yesterday: "They don't want to be curators in some historical theme park." They could see change was inevitable, even though some were happier with it than others.

According to John Chisholm, chairman of the GPs committee, the profession had to run with the ball. "I believe it makes sense to embrace and shape change rather than have it imposed," he said yesterday at the document's launch.

The full document is available on the BMA website: www.bma.org.uk.

webTitle: Climate change warms outlook for English wine

fields.headline: Climate change warms outlook for English wine
fields.standfirst: The weather: special report
fields.trailText: The south of England could soon rival France as a wine-growing region as evidence mounts that global warming is taking hold.
fields.body:
The south of England could soon rival France as a wine-growing region as evidence mounts that global warming is taking hold.

Scientists looking at the crops which will be most suitable for the British climate in the next 50 years have predicted a healthy future for vineyards.

The confident assertion follows evidence of a significant climate shift in Britain across the next century with temperatures rising and conditions for grape growing becoming more favourable.

At the moment only white wine grapes thrive in the south, but red varieties like cabernet sauvigon and merlot could soon be grown successfully, according to researchers at the environmental change institute at Oxford university. The south coast of Scotland could also be producing wine within 50 years.

A predicted temperature rise of up to two degrees centigrade, coupled with increased carbon dioxide in the atmosphere, which aids growth and sugar content, will allow bigger harvests and better grapes.

Classic red varieties of grape, which until now have mainly been grown in the warmer south of France and Italy, could become the mainstay of wine production in the south of England.

Ruth Butterfield, a research scientist at the institute, said: "With higher temperatures overall, we will get better quality wines to rival French wines. Higher temperatures mean that crops will develop more quickly and we will be able to harvest them quicker, before any rainfall."

Ian Berwick, general secretary of the UK Vineyards Association, welcomed the research and agreed that the best wine growing regions would move north with global warming.

He said: "Climate change will mean the south of France will eventually become like the Moroccan desert and they will not be able to grow grapes.

"With the best temperatures for wine growing moving north, so will the best areas. The UK, Belgium and Denmark will become [more] temperate areas."

Mr Berwick, who owns Bruisyard vineyard, north of Ipswich in Suffolk, added: "At the moment the most northern wine growing areas, like Alsace, Germany and the UK, produce white wines with a little bit of red production.

"With the climate warming increasing we will be producing reds with a little bit of white, and countries such as Sweden and Norway will produce whites."

Elizabeth Gibson, co-owner of Bearsted vineyard, near Maidstone in Kent, which won the UKVA's vintner trophy in 1999 for the best UK sparkling white wine, said: "If we can grow varieties of red grapes like cabernet sauvigon and merlot due to climate change, we would be delighted."

The research was revealed as scientists in Washington found evidence that the rate of global warming was accelerating.
