webTitle: IRA rejects arms deal linked to army pull-out

fields.headline: IRA rejects arms deal linked to army pull-out
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The IRA threw the fragile peace process in Northern Ireland into further confusion last night when it ruled out explicitly linking arms decommissioning to demilitarisation to pave the way for a solution to the intractable issue of weapons.
fields.body:
The IRA threw the fragile peace process in Northern Ireland into further confusion last night when it ruled out explicitly linking arms decommissioning to demilitarisation to pave the way for a solution to the intractable issue of weapons.

It also denied it had suggested a national day of reconciliation as representing a key element of any deal. The Irish government first forwarded the proposal, an attempt to draw a line under 30 years of conflict, in last year's ill-fated Hillsborough declaration.

A senior IRA source emphasised that its failed, last-minute initiative put to John de Chastelain's international commission on decommissioning, was no longer on offer. He underlined the IRA's decision to withdraw from engagement with General de Chastelain.

That move came after Peter Mandelson, Northern Ireland secretary, 12 days ago signalled a return to direct rule. He calculated that allowing the Ulster Unionist leader, David Trimble, to resign as first minister would effectively scupper the Good Friday agreement.

Both of the elements the IRA addressed yesterday were thought to have featured in the failed three-point plan it forwarded as Mr Mandleson was suspending the fledlging power-sharing executive.

The other aspect was the issue of a statement avowing that its war was over, and, significantly, the IRA made no comment denying that.

The IRA source, speaking on behalf of the group's leadership, refused to divulge details of its last-minute move 12 days ago. But there was no timeframe specified, and any slim chance of the May deadline for the completion of decommissioning is evaporating fast.

Ulster Unionists last night believed the IRA was playing hardball, just as the first steps to resolving the impasse are beginning to be explored after nearly a fortnight of acrimony. They think that the terror group is trying to wring as many concessions as possible.

The government is thought ready to extend the decommissioning timetable if other elements of a deal can be struck. It is also prepared to accept the catch-all definition of decommissioning as "putting arms beyond use" rather than demanding destruction.

It believes the crucial issue now is to secure a commitment from the IRA that it will decommission, and it also wants a start date.

But Ulster Unionists say they want IRA weapons destruction before agreeing to sit again in government with Sinn Fein.

Mr Mandelson also sparked ire at the weekend when he appeared to suggest that decommissioning and demilitarisation could be linked. He also sees possibilities in a day of reconciliation.

His comments enraged the unionists, both supporters and opponents of the Good Friday agreement, and some military sources. They said it wrongly suggested the army had been guilty of wrongdoing, and indicated equivalence between the army and the IRA.

The army was forced to deny a report that Lieutenant General Sir Hew Pike, its commanding officer in Northern Ireland, had threatened to quit if Mr Mandelson linked troops cuts to terrorist decommissioning. It said he remained committed to his role.

The government is increasingly keen on a day, or act, of reconciliation as a crucial area of negotiation. The IRA's comments last night, crucially, do not rule it out.

But the government says there is no question of a trade-off. The defence secretary, Geoff Hoon, said: "The government cannot and will not contemplate anything which suggests any equivalence between the security forces and terrorists."

webTitle: Sweltering Atlanta shows summer in cities will get even hotter

fields.headline: Sweltering Atlanta shows summer in cities will get even hotter
fields.standfirst: The weather: special report
fields.trailText: The long hot summer of the cities is here to stay. Nasa scientists have found that, day or night, the air over cities is invariably much hotter than over the surrounding countryside. And the heat is going to get worse.
fields.body:
The long hot summer of the cities is here to stay. Nasa scientists have found that, day or night, the air over cities is invariably much hotter than over the surrounding countryside. And the heat is going to get worse.

By 2025, almost 80% of the human race will have moved to the cities, other scientists predict. City authorities will be urged to plant trees to create cool spots, and to paint roofs white so as to reflect heat back into space.

Dale Quattrochi, of the US space agency's global hydrology and climate centre, told the American Association for the Advancement of Science in Washington yesterday that around Atlanta, Georgia, woodlands had been cut down and farmland developed at the rate of 55 acres a day for 19 years.

The growth had created a sprawling city with rooftop temperatures that sometimes reached 70C (170F), an island of heat so powerful it generated its own thunderstorms even in what should have been the cool of the night.

What was true for Atlanta was true for cities in both the developing and the developed world. "We are finding in this dome of elevated temperatures - because of pavements, buildings and asphalt that soak up the sun through the day and re-radiate it at night - we have differences between the city and surrounding areas, of 3, 6 and even 7C."

In 1997, Nasa flew an aircraft over downtown Atlanta and found the daytime air temperature was barely 27C (80F), while the surface temperature was almost 49C (120F). At night, from 2am to 4am, the air temperature was 10-13C (50-55F) but the city's surface was still 24C (75F). Using weather data services set up for the 1996 Atlanta Olympic games, researchers noted that over a nine-day summer period, there were five days when Atlanta's own heat triggered thunderstorms.

The same relentless spread of the cities into the country side had happened everywhere. In southern China, in the Pearl delta, urbanisation had increased by 319% between 1988 and 1996, according to Karen Seto, a geographer from Boston university.

"As Chinese people get richer, they want cars. Forget the bicycle, they want a car, just like Americans. So increasingly a lot of land in China is being converted to industrial and commercial uses and lastly for roads," she said. "Urbanisation is happening at an incredibly fast rate."

According to Marc Imhoff of Nasa's Goddard centre, growth of cities imposed a cost that had yet to be met. Towns were spreading over valuable agricultural land and in some areas urban sprawl had effectively lopped 20 days off food-growing capacity each year.

"Human survival depends on the ability to produce food," he said. "If the capacity of the landscape to carry out photosynthesis is substantially reduced, then the ability of the planet to support human life must also be diminished."

webTitle: How a seller's £5m profit can be halved by the hidden costs of auction houses

fields.headline: How a seller's £5m profit can be halved by the hidden costs of auction houses
fields.trailText: A principle of buying and selling at auction is that what you see is what you get. There is, however, one area where quite the opposite applies: the price.
fields.body:
A principle of buying and selling at auction is that what you see is what you get. There is, however, one area where quite the opposite applies: the price.

One thing is certain: whatever the figure when the hammer comes down, that is the price that no buyer will pay and no purchaser will receive. Indeed, so wildly do real prices diverge from hammer prices that some auction houses are thought to be considering declaring the real price to would-be bidders.

Take Monet's Beach at Trouville, which sold at Christie's in London for £4.18m in 1997, and imagine it back on sale today. The hypothetical hammer comes down at £5m. The buyer and seller beam with contentment.

Immediately, the auction house docks £500,000 for its 10% seller's commission, then charges the buyer £750,000 for the 15% "buyer's premium".

This levy, unheard of before the late 1980s, was resisted furiously when it was first imposed by the auction houses. The London art dealers, the backbone of any auction room, were incensed and took legal advice to see if the premium could be stopped in court. It could not.

The double levy is now an established feature of auctions, creating the anomaly whereby the auctioneer - while supposedly acting in the best interests of the seller - actually earns more money from the buyer. In any other trade or profession there would be mutterings about conflict of interest, and hasty consultations with lawyers. But in this matter, as in so much else, the art world is different.

On top of the buyer's premium, the purchaser pays 17.5% VAT on that £750,000, adding a further £131,250 to the bill.

Should the Monet have come in from outside the European Union for auction, and should the buyer not be intending immediately to re-export it, there will be a 5% import tax payable on the £5m, a fur ther £250,000. No such tax was payable before the early 1990s, when Britain agreed to harmonisation of various European duties.

Meanwhile, the seller, if a British taxpayer, is likely to face capital gains tax of 40% on the £4.5m left after paying the commission - a further £1.8m.

So, from a £5m hammer price, the seller will end up with £4.5m at most, and £2.7m at least. On the other side, the buyer will see the cost of a £5m bid climb to £5.88m at least, and possibly £6.13m.

The auctioneer, meanwhile, will have carved £1.25m out of the sale - a quarter of the hammer price.

fields.headline: Sotheby's takes a hammering
fields.standfirst: President and chairman quit, shares fall and credit rating of top auction house is downgraded amid criminal inquiry into price-fixing deal
fields.trailText: Sotheby's, the oldest and, until recently, the largest auction house in the world, ended one of the worst days in its 256-year history last night with the ultimate ignominy. On top of having to admit to being the subject of investigations in the United States, Europe and Australia into alleged price-fixing - and the consequent resignations of its chairman and president - the institution that has spent centuries sizing up the financial cut of a client's jib learned that its own IOUs had been downgraded.
fields.byline: Dan Atkinson  and  Michael Ellison  in New York
fields.body:
Sotheby's, the oldest and, until recently, the largest auction house in the world, ended one of the worst days in its 256-year history last night with the ultimate ignominy. On top of having to admit to being the subject of investigations in the United States, Europe and Australia into alleged price-fixing - and the consequent resignations of its chairman and president - the institution that has spent centuries sizing up the financial cut of a client's jib learned that its own IOUs had been downgraded.

Standard & Poor's, the credit-rating agency, marked it down because "Sotheby's no longer possesses the credit characteristics of an A-category rating".

For an auction house long renowned for its snootiness, this would have been the bitterest of pills. Other than, perhaps, the knowledge that arch-rival Christie's has effectively "shopped" Sotheby's to America's much-feared department of justice. Christie's entered an amnesty agreement in return for the goods on alleged price-fixing between these two giants of the auction world between 1995 and 1997.

Christie's turned federal evidence in early January, and the reverberations yesterday toppled both Diana Brooks, Sotheby's president since 1994 , and its chairman, Alfred Taubman, the effective owner of the auction house since 1983.

His departure raised the question of whether Sotheby's is now up for sale. A spokeswoman in London "couldn't speculate" on the company's future, but if the man who once saved Sotheby's from the indignity of a bid from two US felt manufacturers were to sell up, what price would his one-time pride and joy command under the hammer?

Shares fall

Mrs Brooks - until now the most powerful woman in the art world - is said to have such a head for figures that she can add up sales totals faster than Sotheby's computers. But even those with more modest number-crunching skills were able to work out the importance of the fall in the company's value yesterday.

Less than a year ago its shares were worth $47 (£29) each. They opened yesterday at $17.75 and by lunchtime in New York were down to $14.5, the direct result of the criminal investigation.

Once the idea of a criminal investigation into the auction house might have seemed as incongruous as the notion of Sotheby's and the internet (on which the house now has a major presence). But it was by email that staff at the auctioneer's new £69m New York headquarters heard the news of the resignations of Mrs Brooks and Mr Taubman. It is believed that the two were helped to make up their minds by a board meeting conducted by telephone.

"No one's rejoicing", said a New York art lawyer. "We're waiting for the other shoe to drop. At this point we don't know how seriously these disclosures will affect confidence in the market."

But Angela Westwater, a contemporary art dealer in the city's SoHo district, said: "For a lot of people to whom the art world is hype anyway, does it increase their fears and cynicism?"

Sotheby's yesterday admitted that the cost of any settlement with the justice department, added to possible fines by European and Australian regulators and bumped up further by the outcome of 36 class-action suits in the US, could present it with a bill that "could well have a material impact on Sotheby's financial condition and/or results of operations".

For a company that made £57m profit in 1998 from auction sales totalling nearly £1.2bn, that has to mean that the house is bracing itself for the worst.

The root of Sotheby's problems line in the early 1990s, when revenue started to fall as a result of the slump that followed the high-price 1980s. Both Sotheby's and Christie's raised their buyer's premium rates and, three years later Christie's brought in a sliding scale for seller's commissions of 2% to 10%, and Sotheby's followed suit. Smelling a rat, the justice department launched an "anti-trust" investigation in 1997, spurred on by the dominance of the two houses, which account for 95% of the £2.5bn global auction business.

As the inquiry proceeded, Christie's changed hands, going private in May 1998. In January this year a spokeswoman said: "Christie's is co-operating with the department of justice and has entered into an amnesty agreement".

Its new chairman is Michael Sovern, a former president of Columbia university and, in the late 1980s, the chairman of an anti-corruption commission which was run jointly by New York's city and state governments.

Sotherby's

At Sotheby's, Mrs Brooks is replaced by William Ruprecht , a senior auctioneer and managing director of the house in north and south America since 1994.

There were only two crumbs of comfort for Sotheby's last night. One is that Christie's US amnesty does not apply to the inquiries being carried out by Britain's office of fair trading (OFT), by the European commission or by the Australian authorities.

And the other is that - whatever penalty Sotheby's faces in the US - it will face none in Britain. Tough new OFT fining powers do not apply to offences committed before March 1.

Founded: 1744 by Samuel Baker with a book auction.

Reputation: The world's oldest and, until recently, largest auctioneer known in the trade by its address: New Bond Street. Once described as "businessmen pretending to be gentlemen". Bought leading US fine-art auctioneer Parke-Bernet in 1964. Is today American-based.

Ownership: Bought for £87.2m in 1983 by US shop ping-mall tycoon Alfred Taubman after hostile bid by felt manufacturers Marshall Cogan and Stephen Swid.

Recent difficulties: In 1997, an internal inquiry was launched after accusations that staff were involved in trafficking in old masters out of Italy in defiance of Italian law. The previous year, the house seemed to have been caught on the hop by faked works purporting to be examples of the Russian avant-garde.

Sales: About £1.19bn.

Christies

Founded: 1766 by James Christie, friend of the painter Joshua Reynolds. Catherine the Great an early customer.

Reputation: Once tagged "gentlemen pretending to be businessmen", but emerged as very aggressive player during the lean years of the early 1990s.

Ownership: Was quoted on stock market. In 1997, broker SG Warburg Dillon Read was trying to put together a private buyout of booming Christie's, with a consortium of six private individuals including the Bahamas-based tycoon Joseph Lewis, himself one of Christie's best clients. But the proposed deal ran aground on issues of price and complexity.

In May 1998, French businessman François Pinault bought Christie's for £721m. It is now part of a family of names including Gucci, Samsonite and Chateau Latour.

Sales: £1.35bn in 1999.

webTitle: Frostbite forces Fiennes to abandon North Pole trek

fields.headline: Frostbite forces Fiennes to abandon North Pole trek
fields.trailText: Sir Ranulph Fiennes has been forced to abandon his latest attempt to reach the North Pole after he developed severe frostbite in his left hand, expedition organisers said yesterday.
fields.body:
Sir Ranulph Fiennes has been forced to abandon his latest attempt to reach the North Pole after he developed severe frostbite in his left hand, expedition organisers said yesterday.

One of the two sledges Sir Ranulph had been pulling fell through thin ice and he developed frostbite after pulling it from the water.

He had no choice but to cancel his 520-mile solo trek across one of the harshest environments on earth where temperatures are as low as -56C. He was unable to pitch his tent because of his injuries.

Sir Ranulph said last night that he had been very close to becoming "dead mutton".

He told ITN: "Within a minute of coming out of the water my hand was completely frozen to the extent that it was useless.

"Fourteen minutes later my body core was completely cold. I managed to start the cooker using my teeth and one hand which had a little bit of feeling in it.

"It was a very, very close run thing. I had to try to get back to the land because all the time the ice was breaking."

Sir Ranulph was forced to re trace his steps to the starting point in Ward Hunt Island, and radio the UK base camp in Aberdeen for help.

Lawrence Howell, the UK base leader, said: "He is in a stable condition and is receiving specialist medical treatment in Ottawa. He seems to be responding to treatment.

"He was pulling the smaller of the two sledges, which weigh 500lb in total, when it fell through the ice. He managed to pull the sledge out of the water but in doing so lost feeling in his left hand.

"The weather conditions were poor. He had no choice but to retrace his steps."

He had hoped to become the first person to walk solo and unsupported to the North Pole and complete the trek in 80 days, hoping to raise at least £1m for cancer research.

Sir Ranulph, who formerly served in the SAS, made a solo crossing of the Antarctic in 1993.

webTitle: Pinochet fit for trial, says Belgium

fields.headline: Pinochet fit for trial, says Belgium
fields.standfirst: Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: The Belgian authorities last night disputed the findings of the medical report into General Augusto Pinochet's health, claiming the former Chilean dictator's condition is so "light" it does not make him unfit to stand trial.
fields.byline: Jamie Wilson, Ian Black in Brussels and Adela Gooch  in Madrid
fields.body:
The Belgian authorities last night disputed the findings of the medical report into General Augusto Pinochet's health, claiming the former Chilean dictator's condition is so "light" it does not make him unfit to stand trial.

In a written submission to the home secretary, Belgian judge Damien Vandermeersh requested that the general should undergo further medical tests to make a more precise assessment of his condition. He added that, at the moment, they did not agree with the interpretation of the medical report.

Spain, Belgium, Switzerland and France were given until 5pm yesterday to make representations to Jack Straw on the medical report that persuaded him to announce that he was "minded" to halt extradition proceedings against the general.

All four countries have challenged Mr Straw's decision, with the Swiss authorities saying Pinochet's health condition is no bar to his standing trial, while Spain and France have demanded the right to carry out independent medical tests.

But Belgium, which has been proudly occupying the moral high ground in the Pinochet case after obtaining a high court order forcing the disclosure of the medical report, appears to have taken the strongest line.

A spokesman for the Belgian foreign ministry said last night: "In his report, the judge says that technically the British report is very good, but they don't agree with the interpretation of the result.

"The British conclusion is that Pinochet is suffering a rather severe cognitive deterioration which makes him unable to sustain a trial. But for our judge here the deterioration is actually light, which does make him fit for trial."

Last night the home office refused to comment on the contents of the representations, saying only that Mr Straw would make his final decision as soon as possible. However, the nature of the submissions would appear to increase the chance of a further legal challenge to Mr Straw's final decision, which he is expected to announce to the Commons early next week.

The situation could be further complicated as sources close to the general have already indicated Pinochet would refuse to undergo medical tests at the behest of any of the extraditing countries.

The Swiss authorities, who have so far played no part in the court proceedings against Pinochet, have written to Mr Straw claiming international treaties did not allow Britain to refuse to extradite Pinochet because of ill health.

Baltasar Garzon, the investigating Spanish magistrate who has been the driving force behind international attempts to bring Pinochet to justice, yesterday challenged aspects of the medical report and asked to be allowed to carry out fresh medical tests.

In his submission to Mr Straw, Judge Garzon said the former dictator's state of health should be assessed by experts chosen by the Spanish judiciary.

But sources close to Judge Garzon said Spanish doctors accepted that there was no guarantee the general's health could resist a trial.

In France, judicial sources said investigating magistrate Roger Le Loire had asked for further tests in his formal submissions to the home secretary.

webTitle: Two Jags Prescott adds a Rover to his fleet

fields.headline: Two Jags Prescott adds a Rover to his fleet
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: John Prescott is to shed his hated image of "two Jags " for a new embarrassing epithet - "three limos".
fields.body:
John Prescott is to shed his hated image of "two Jags " for a new embarrassing epithet - "three limos".

The new register of member's interests disclosed yesterday that the deputy prime minister has the sole use of not two, but three cars.

It reveals that Mr Prescott has taken a free car given to the Labour party by the Rover car company for his personal use. Mr Prescott also has a tax-free, chauffeur-driven government XJ8 Jaguar and his own XJ6 Jaguar that he had before he entered government.

Labour has confirmed he still has the use of a Rover 800 every time he goes to a party event, such as the conference or when he is campaigning. The company has offered to upgrade this to a new Rover 75 as part of a deal offered to Tory and Labour to give them the latest demonstration models.

Mr Prescott's entry in the register says: "Use of car loaned to the Labour party from the Rover Group com mencing 28 April, 1995, for use by the deputy leader."

His office last night revealed that while the car had been on loan to Labour since 1995, Mr Prescott's sole use of the vehicle appeared to come into force since he got into government.

Mr Prescott needed the third car because he was not allowed - unlike the prime minister - to use government cars to attend party events, his office said. The car famously fea tured at Bournemouth last year when he and his wife, Pauline, used it to travel 250 yards from the hotel to the conference hall. Mr Prescott claimed that if he had walked along the seafront it would have ruined his wife's hair-do.

Michael Ancram, the Tory party chairman, has taken over the Conservatives' car.

Some of the other entries revealed by the register were:

William Hague, Tory leader: eight free private jet and helicopter trips paid by Tory treasurer, Michael Ashcroft, Tory donor Lord Kirkham, Sir Stanley Kalms, and tax exile Irvine Laidlaw. Also has use of Sebastian's Coe's Range Rover.

Charles Kennedy, Liberal democrat leader: spent £20,000 on his leadership campaign with donations from former British Rail chief Sir Peter Parker, lobbyist Sir Ian Wrigglesworth and former Tory MP Hugh Dykes.

Tony Banks, Labour MP. Trip to Marrakesh as guest of Chelsea footballer, Frank Leboeuf and his wife.

fields.headline: New Mirror share inquiry
fields.standfirst: More about the Mirror share deal scandal
fields.trailText: Piers Morgan, editor of the Mirror, has been investigated over alleged share dealings in a third company, it emerged last night. Mr Morgan is believed to have been quizzed over share transactions in Wiggins, a property and airports group.
fields.body:
Piers Morgan, editor of the Mirror, has been investigated over alleged share dealings in a third company, it emerged last night. Mr Morgan is believed to have been quizzed over share transactions in Wiggins, a property and airports group.

It was alleged that Mr Morgan bought shares in the company the day before they were tipped in the Mirror by the paper's now-dismissed City Slickers team.

Mr Morgan, 34, has been cleared by the paper's parent board, Trinity Mirror, of any wrongdoing over share dealings in two other companies which have been written about by the Slickers team.

The controversy surrounding Mr Morgan's share dealings began almost three weeks ago when it emerged that he had bought £20,000 worth of shares in Viglen, a hi-tech firm run by Sir Alan Sugar. He netted an almost-100% profit the next day when the shares rose after the Slickers wrote a story which said the company was moving into the internet.

At the weekend it emerged that he had stands to make up to £500,000 from an investment in recruitment business Corporate Executive Search. He bought £10,000 worth of shares in the company the day before the shares were suspended, pending a takeover announcement.

It also emerged last night that the Stock Exchange inquiry, which has been passed over to the department of trade and industry, investigated dealings by Mr Morgan in a number of companies.

Mr Morgan is understood to have bought the shares in Wiggins at the same time as the Slickers, Anil Bhoyrul and James Hipwell, in October 1998.

Shortly after buying the shares the Slickers tipped Wiggins, saying it was "undervalued" and was a potential takeover target. They also detailed plans by Wiggins to buy four regional airports and advised "get in quick".

A spokesman for Trinity Mirror refused to discuss Mr Morgan's individual share dealings but repeated that he had been cleared by the internal investigation of doing anything wrong.

The Slickers were sacked without compensation on Friday after a two-week internal inquiry. They are challenging the decision, but bounce back today with a version of their controversial column in satirical magazine Punch.

Taped recordings of conversations between Mr Morgan and his broker, Anthony Laiker, are believed to be among several boxes of evidence passed to the DTI by the Stock Exchange.

Mr Laiker lost his job with stockbroking firm Kyte Securities last week.

webTitle: GP questioned over deaths of 5 patients

fields.headline: GP questioned over deaths of 5 patients
fields.trailText: Police in Cumbria have questioned a doctor who runs a clinic for drug addicts following the deaths of five patients prescribed the heroin-substitute methadone.
fields.body:
Police in Cumbria have questioned a doctor who runs a clinic for drug addicts following the deaths of five patients prescribed the heroin-substitute methadone.

Police said yesterday that they may exhume at least two of the five bodies as they begin lengthy forensic investigations. Their inquiries are believed to centre on allegations of negligence rather than premeditated killings.

Detectives are expected to investigate amounts of methadone prescribed to users in Carlisle trying to kick their heroin habit.

The deaths, including that of 19-year-old Michael Kirkpatrick who died of a methadone overdose last May, date to the beginning of 1999.

The Medical Protection Society last night named the doctor as John Gordon, a 50-year-old GP working in a group practice close to the centre of Carlisle, a city with what police acknowledge is a serious heroin problem.

Dr Gordon, who qualified in 1974 and is from Liverpool, was described yesterday as "strict but fair" by a patient to whom he prescribes methadone.

He was arrested by Cumbria police on Monday and questioned on suspicion of manslaughter for 12 hours before being bailed until June without being charged.

He has not been suspended by North Cumbria health authority but has agreed not to work at the surgery while the investigation continues. The authority has referred the case the the General Medical Council and the NHS Tribunal.

Inquests have been held on two of the five dead men. Ian Morton, coroner for north-east Cumbria, recorded a verdict of accidental death on Mr Kirkpatrick, a heroin addict who had mistakenly taken an overdose of methadone. He described the death as "a tragic waste of a young life". Detective chief inspector Peter Kilbride, who heads the inquiry, said officers had contacted the families of the five men. "We are considering exhumation of possibly two bodies but no decision has yet been made."

fields.headline: The great manipulators
fields.standfirst: As the Lords squared up to Labour again last night, their real target was the government's arroganceNew Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: As the Lords squared up to Labour again last night, their real target was the government's arrogance
fields.body:
The moment when a government first begins to lose its grip is an absorbing area of study. Tony Blair makes no secret of his interest in it. But there is the equally well-known danger of fighting old wars rather than scanning the horizon for new sources of disaster.

Well-briefed by hindsight, received wisdom currently says that due to an unhealthy preoccupation with satisfying the tabloid-reading middle classes, this government is heading down a road all too familiar to earlier Labour administrations, the one that ends up in a disastrous alienation from its core vote. The sad saga of the selection of the Labour candidate for London mayor will be analysed largely in this light.

But maybe there is something even more insidious at work, something which could, potentially, alienate the Daily Mail voters who decide elections, rather than the party trusties who merely canvas them. The alienation of the heartlands is a serious symptom of incipient trouble, but Labour can probably win at least one if not two elections without all those surplus votes in safe Labour seats. What could threaten a prolonged spell of Labour government is the very hubris to which the Tories finally succumbed.

What, after all, finally destroyed 18 years of Conservative supremacy? The economic catastrophe which followed so swiftly on the heels of the 92 election victory and then the sustained inability to agree a line on Europe, were undoubtedly grave problems for their real supporters, the men and women who were needed in the front line of the election campaign. But the final straw, the sequence of events which compounded their failure in government and seemed to suggest a disregard for it, and which left such a bitter and enduring after-taste, was surely sleaze.

Sleaze demonstrated a complacency about power, a contempt for the responsibilities of the representative, and the arrogance of the serially re-elected. Sleaze, in the shameless figure of Neil Hamilton, became the unacceptable stamp of the Conservative party. It rippled out disastrously from that handful of voters in marginal seats who win and lose elections to the leafy prosperity of Swindon and finally even to Enfield Southgate. Labour's equivalent could be its disregard, in both the party and the government, for the conventions of democracy.

If the lunacy of the London mayoral selection had not been going on at the time, it would have been impossible to imagine there could be any repetition of the farcical election and subsequent fall of Welsh leader Alun Michael. In fact, that was just another episode in an apparently escalating disregard for the means used to achieve centrally-dictated ends.

Way back, before the mass euphoria of the May day landslide wiped out all collective memory, there was a small cloud, a kind of nagging discomfort, provoked by the way a handful of stalwarts in comfortable seats were suddenly elevated to the Lords, smoothing the notoriously unpredictable path into the Commons for talented recruits like Yvette Cooper and Ross Cranston. Was this quite right, one or two wondered, before lifting their eyes to the giddy prospect of a Labour government.

Then there was the awkwardness about the nature of the selection of candidates for the devolved Scottish and Welsh parliaments, the fortuitous exclusion of those misfitting old-timers. There was that centrally-ordered list system for the Euro elections. That was a bit of a facer. So much so, the Electoral Reform Society, alarmed by the reduction in the say of the voter in the choice of their representatives, is now setting up an all-party group to look at ways of pushing democracy up the system. And the selection of Labour's candidate for mayor was so absurd that none of its participants supported it. Yet leadership figures still go on TV to babble about the superiority of the electoral college as if it were the triumphant pinnacle of a finely-calibrated mechanism to establish the will of party supporters, instead of a shabby bit of Tammany Hall manipulated with the subtlety of a sledgehammer.

Last night there was another attempt at what looks like damaging tinkering with the underwiring of democracy. Ministerial plans to prevent candidates in the London elections from having a free mailshot (at the taxpayers' expense) were defeated by the massed ranks of opposition peers. Ministers were outraged, insisting their own breach of the etiquette of democracy (it is highly un usual to try to force through electoral arrangements against the will of the other parties) was no justification for the unelected peers ganing up on the government.

They will now have to do a deal or risk delaying the elections, due on May 4. It is a trifling matter, but it should be used as an opportunity to start to reverse the damage which has been done, if only to silence the opposition merrymaking over the idea that the government's resistance to a free post, enjoyed by candidates in all but council elections, was just one more attempt to handicap an independent Livingstone candidacy. But all the evidence of the past two years seemed to point to Labour's high command being blind to the interpretation voters might place on its actions: in this atmosphere, any charge of electoral manipulation has resonance. It needs stamping on, hard.

webTitle: Labour backer named as PM's Middle East envoy

fields.headline: Labour backer named as PM's Middle East envoy
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair was forced to admit last night that he has appointed one of Labour's most generous fundraisers, who bankrolled his office before the last election with millions of pounds, as his personal envoy to the Middle East.
fields.body:
Tony Blair was forced to admit last night that he has appointed one of Labour's most generous fundraisers, who bankrolled his office before the last election with millions of pounds, as his personal envoy to the Middle East.

Lord Levy, a multi-millionaire music impresario, paid nine visits to the region last year on behalf of the prime minister, outstripping the foreign secretary, Robin Cook.

Downing Street's disclosure of Lord Levy's role, made in a parliamentary written answer after earlier denial, was questioned by the Tories and the Liberal Democrats.

Francis Maude, shadow foreign secretary, demanded to know whether Lord Levy, who has substantial business interests in Israel, was acting as a Labour party fundraiser during his trips.

"If this proves to be the case there will be a clear conflict of interest, not to mention a strong hint of impropriety," Mr Maude said.

Norman Baker, Lib Dem MP for Lewes, who tabled the parliamentary question to the prime minister, said that Mr Blair appeared to be moving towards an American system of awarding foreign policy jobs to party backers.

"It is unacceptable to have someone acting as a minister who is not accountable to parliament," Mr Baker said.

The prime minister said last night that Lord Levy had visited eight separate middle eastern countries on his behalf, over nine trips, since April last year. In his most recent trip earlier this month, Lord Levy visited Lebanon and Syria. He has also visited Jordan, Lebanon, Eqypt, Oman, Qatar and Bahrain, while making numerous visits to Israel, where he has substantial business interests.

In a written parliamentary reply last night, the prime minister said that Lord Levy had paid his own costs, although the foreign office had provided accommodation and advice during some of the trips.

Downing Street played down speculation that Lord Levy, who ran the "blind trust" which funded Mr Blair's office in opposition, was acting as his personal envoy to the Middle East when his role was first disclosed last year. The foreign office was initially sceptical about Lord Levy, fearing that he was treading on the toes of the former Middle East minister, Geoff Hoon.

However, the foreign office is now said to be relaxed about his role.

Lord Levy, who plays tennis with the prime minister, established such stars as Alvin Stardust, Chris Rea and the group Bad Manners.

fields.headline: Direct and to the point
fields.standfirst: You'll have seen the surname somewhere before. But, as Sophie Fiennes prepares for the broadcast of her new documentary The Late Michael Clark, she's more concerned with making her own reputation as a film-maker than living off her family's. She talked to  Danny Leigh
fields.trailText: You'll have seen the surname somewhere before. But, as Sophie Fiennes prepares for the broadcast of her new documentary The Late Michael Clark, she's more concerned with making her own reputation as a film-maker than living off her family's. She talked to Danny Leigh
fields.body:
It's priceless. I'm in the local cafe with Sophie Fiennes to talk about The Late Michael Clark (BBC 2, 11.25pm), her documentary portrait of the ever-contentious dancer and choreographer, and all I'm hearing are the city boys beside us discussing share prices. She's brimming with enthusiasm - detailing her adolescent fondness for David Bowie and the way "as soon as you bring a camera into a relationship, everything changes" - but such is the volume of our neighbours, there's really only one conversation at this table, and it's about investing in sugar. How's that for art versus commerce?

Eventually, however, we get the place to ourselves. Which is fortunate, because while tonight's programme hardly threatens to bulldoze through the ratings, it does prove its director to be more than simply a celebrated family name (yes, you may be familiar with her brothers, Ralph and Joseph). A loose, non-linear account of the build-up to Clark's CURRENT/See (his return to the stage after four years of smack and inactivity), The Late... gives you everything from the rehearsals of Big Bottom - the all-bass quintet whose stentorian rumblings provide the show's soundtrack - to the star's bin-bag-clutching trip to the laundrette. And, somewhere between the relative relaxation of Clark in front of the camera - borne of having known Fiennes for eight years - and the film's Digital Video-derived sense of vérité, the results are absorbing, inventive and, more unexpectedly, entirely approachable.

"I realise my tastes probably lean towards the experimental," she admits, "but at the same time, one of the things I find most irritating in any medium is self-indulgence. And I really don't feel there's anything in there which is wilfully obscure. I mean, I know so many people who are interested in the same things as me, who are hungry for this kind of stuff, and that it's not, you know... a wank in the bath."

So far so good. Yet, despite its ease of access, her film won't just have to contend with viewers' preconceptions; it's also going to be remembered as much for what's been left out as edited in. The thorny issue of heroin, for example, comes and goes in the space of a sentence. But, she says, that's neither an oversight nor the act of a friend eager to paper over the cracks.

"Once you introduce heroin," she remarks, "I just feel it unbalances what you're actually trying to do with the work. I mean, it's so much easier to make a documentary where you spend fifteen minutes talking about someone's heroin addiction than it is to actually look at their work. That way, you have to give something of yourself."

Similarly, there's a distinct lack of talking heads and pop-psychoanalysis in evidence. Almost uniquely, Fiennes remains adamant she wants Clark - or whoever she happens to be dealing with - to be understood through their work rather than the other way around; not for her the hackneyed game of small-screen headshrinking. Rarely less than animated, she fairly bristles at the mention of more conventional documentary technique.

"You see, I think that school of thought often produces what I call illustrated radio, where you basically have a voiceover interpreting someone like Michael Clark for you, and as a viewer you're then supposed to just venerate at the shrine of their celebrity. But that's not what I wanted to do. Because once you put someone in this..."

She leans in, her fingers forming an impromptu frame.

"...what you find are all sorts of visual things which say more about you than a voiceover or journalist could ever convey. So I didn't want to make something where people sat and talked about Michael, and where Michael was forced to do that himself."

Indeed, it's striking how, while he seldom shies away from the lens, Clark seems markedly disinclined to PR himself; for a man often condemned as a self-publicist, he seems reticent about thrusting himself at the audience.

"Right," Fiennes nods, "and one thing that has led to is people saying that I'm not telling them enough about Michael, that I'm not revealing what's he's like." And does she have a problem with that?

"No, because I think by the end you have a far better insight into Michael and his work than you would with a series of experts offering their 'take' on him."

In one sense, of course, it's all about context. The snag with such an approach is that it runs the risk of fazing an audience weaned on the non-stop drama of the docusoap; what makes her film tick is its ellipses, the spaces between the big events. You wonder how she fits in alongside the Airports and Uncovereds.

"What troubles me," she remarks, "is that those programmes are basically emotional pornography, and their success pushes people like me into a really tight corner. I mean, part of it is that they imply a kind of instant celebrity, so you find people simply playing a role they've created for themselves. There isn't a great deal of naivety in subjects anymore."

She lets out a small sigh. And, instead of drawing inspiration from TV, looks instead to the purism of the Dogme 95 film-making collective for kinship. It's an admiration dating back to 1998's Lars From 1-10, her documentary sketch of Dogme nabob Lars von Trier - a choice of subject which can't help invite comparisons with Clark (both dismissed as controversialists, both notorious control freaks, both extremely media savvy....) "Oh, I can see the parallels," she confirms. "I don't know, I think maybe it's because I respect people who don't offer themselves up on a plate. I mean, I'm drawn to the kind of work they do where you really have to crawl through barbed wire on your belly."

Next up comes a feature-length documentary she's preparing on Noel Jones, "an amazing gospel preacher in LA who, it turns out, is Grace's brother". But, with her Dogme connection and her desire to "marry documentary to the language of cinema", is The Late Michael Clark simply a prelude to a career in features; what you could, if you were feeling lippy, call the big league?

"Hmm. I don't think so. I'm interested in using cinematic language, but I like being inside the story as it unfolds. And also, and I know this might sound funny coming from me, I don't really know enough about actors."

Funny she should mention that. Because, if she were to make the move into features, she's all too aware her public profile would expand with it; not the most comfortable thought for a woman who admits a faint terror at the idea of being sold as someone else's sister. That said, she's sceptical whether "there's even much mileage in that angle in career terms - I mean, all it means is that if I wore a fancy dress to a film premiere there'd be a picture of me smiling in someone's society pages."

"And I am nervous about revealing myself. I don't know, maybe it's because I'm secretive. It's probably why I'm drawn to people like Michael, because they're so brave in exposing themselves. And that fascinates me, because I'm so wary of it. I mean, if I were to make original fiction, I'd feel totally naked."

"So," she says, "at the moment, I'm quite happy to indulge in this kind of... Munchausen By Proxy."

She raises an eyebrow; then comes a broad, lopsided grin; and, finally, Sophie Fiennes bursts out laughing.

fields.headline: Go-go gorillas
fields.trailText: It should have been obvious from the subtitle - "adventures in human evolution" - that BBC2's Ape-Man was not going to be a straightforward documentary. Any lingering hopes of seriousness were soon dashed as we plunged into an unlovely mixture of The X Files and Twin Peaks, all flashy jump cuts, trippy images and a horror-movie score. fields.body:
It should have been obvious from the subtitle - "adventures in human evolution" - that BBC2's Ape-Man was not going to be a straightforward documentary. Any lingering hopes of seriousness were soon dashed as we plunged into an unlovely mixture of The X Files and Twin Peaks, all flashy jump cuts, trippy images and a horror-movie score. Somewhere along the line the decision must have been made that the subject matter of Ape-Man - prehistoric anthropology - wasn't interesting enough on its own, and would have to be tarted up in order to keep us watching. And so we saw sensible French archaeologists digging in the silted caves of Brassempouy, while the camera zoomed madly in and out of focus and the music suggested that a serial killer lurked behind the next rock. Archaeology is interesting, but it's not violently thrilling, and so the effect was just silly.

If you could ignore these trappings, and it wasn't easy, what was left was a loosely structured argument about whether or not the creatures who made the French cave paintings some 25,000 years ago were actually human. A rickety syllogism invited us to believe that they were: the cave paintings are similar to modern ones in the Kalahari; the Kalahari bushmen go into shamanistic trances; people in trances see grid patterns; there are grid patterns on the walls of French caves. Thus we concluded that the ability to go into a trance is the essence of the human spirit, ergo the cave painters were human.

This may be a travesty of some rock-solid research, but as presented in Ape-Man it seemed nothing more than guesswork and supposition. Unconvincing but crucial evidence was supplied by Dr Etzel Cardeña, a psychiatrist in Washington DC, who puts subjects into deep hypnosis and records what they describe. The fact that his patients see geometric shapes (and who doesn't when they're falling asleep?) was used to clinch the argument, and we were back in the French caves looking at - yes - geometric shapes. That was enough to plunge the editors into an orgy of flash-cuts, repeated images of hooves and faces and insane horror music, as if enlightenment had been reached. Quite who this was meant to appeal to remains a mystery.

More down to earth was The Secret World Of Year 3 (BBC2), yet another observational documentary, this time set in a primary school. There are few corners of British life where the questing camera has not yet been, so now it's the turn of the very young to step into the spotlight. Seven-year-olds Kate, Louisa, Michael and Daniel go to Oakdale Primary School near Peterborough, and they're in their last week of infants. Playground tiffs were treated with all the seriousness of high drama thanks to a sonorous voiceover by Paul McGann, but it's hard not to be won over by the children's natural charm. Pearls of wisdom fell thick and fast. "If I break the rules I might go to jail and have to eat horrible things like shepherd's pie", said one little bruiser, while a very loud girl informed her friends that "the man has to put his willy in the lady's bum" for a baby to be born.

Which (almost) brings us to the concluding part of Queer As Folk 2 (Channel 4). The pressure was on writer Russell T Davies to provide a resolution to all his story strands, and as a result the narrative fell to pieces about halfway through the episode. But that's a minor quibble; it was worth it for the audacious fantasy ending, sending Stuart and Vince off to America as gun-toting bigot-bashers. Along the way there was an orgy of wish fulfilment: Nathan standing up to his irresponsible teacher, Alexander emerging from suicidal depression as a drag queen, Stuart and Vince finally, somehow, getting their act together. The winding-up process of any ongoing drama is painful, but Davies did it with aplomb, ransacking his favourite movies (seemingly All About Eve, Thelma And Louise and possibly Back To The Future) and revelling in the fantasy and absurdity of it all.

If Queer As Folk was an American drama (and there's a danger that it might become so) it would go for dozens of series and finally run out of steam about three years after its sell-by date. As it is, we're left wanting more, which is never a bad thing. Davies, and indeed Channel 4's drama commissioners, have a lot to live up to. What other programme could ever boast among its closing credits a character called "Orange Spunk Man"?

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: I have increasing sympathy with Hilaire Belloc's judgment on scientific prediction - "Oh let us never, never doubt what no one is sure about". Tonight's Frontiers (9.0pm, Radio 4) certainly helps. Peter Evans has visited the Laser Interferometer Gravitational Wave Observatory, where researchers have built five miles of lasers to await the arrival of some elusive cosmic signals one-thousandth the diameter of a proton. They only currently exist as an Einsteinian equation. Should they ever arrive we could apparently peer into black holes - maybe.
fields.body:
I have increasing sympathy with Hilaire Belloc's judgment on scientific prediction - "Oh let us never, never doubt what no one is sure about". Tonight's Frontiers (9.0pm, Radio 4) certainly helps. Peter Evans has visited the Laser Interferometer Gravitational Wave Observatory, where researchers have built five miles of lasers to await the arrival of some elusive cosmic signals one-thousandth the diameter of a proton. They only currently exist as an Einsteinian equation. Should they ever arrive we could apparently peer into black holes - maybe.

Andy Kershaw's journey across the US, following Chuck Berry's imagined route to The Promised Land (10.0pm, Radio 2), brings him to South Carolina. He finds himself in the middle of an extraordinary electoral rumpus about flying the Confederate flag over the state Capitol. As the presidential candidates duck and weave round the issue, black Congressman John Lewis recalls how the Carolina police fractured his skull just for seeking his constitutional rights.

webTitle: Watch this: satellite, cable and digital

fields.headline: Watch this: satellite, cable and digital
fields.trailText: Raise The Red Lantern | That Riviera Touch | Down By Law | Crumb
fields.body:
Raise The Red Lantern (Zhang Yimou, 1991)

2.55am, FilmFour

The exquisite Gong Li plays a young woman who reluctantly agrees to marry a wealthy merchant in pre-communist China. She joins the first three wives in a gilded cage, an estate where the red lantern signifies the husband's flavour of the month. The intricate politics of the women's rivalry and the overpowering sense of oppression are minutely related, lavishly filmed.

That Riviera Touch (Cliff Owen, 1966)

9am, Carlton Cinema

When Eric and Ernie are sacked from their jobs at the choc factory they decide to blow Eric's savings on a tour of southern France, where they are quickly embroiled with the local gangsters - who, of course, have never encountered Englishmen Abroad quite like this. Doesn't really do justice to the telly-brilliance of Morecambe and Wise, but it's as close as they got in three big-screen attempts.

Down By Law (Jim Jarmusch, 1986)

8pm, FilmFour

Now this is serious comedy: one of Jarmusch's eloquent, funny essays on the beauty and beastliness of life. Tom Waits and John Lurie - who also provide a fine soundtrack - play hard cons slammed up in a New Orleans jail; little Italian Roberto Benigni shows them the way out and the meaning of life. Quirky, warm-hearted humour, beautifully photographed in black and white.

Crumb (Terry Zwigoff, 1995)

10pm, FilmFour

Best known for his feisty feline creation Fritz and the best-selling 70s iron-on, Keep On Truckin', Robert Crumb proved to be much more popular on the underground comic scene in San Francisco than in his high-school classroom. Taking us on an open tour through his odd upbringing - influenced by his older, mentally unstable brother Charles, but controlled by a heavy-handed father - the artist reveals how the hate he felt towards girls who never recognised his genius fuelled his masturbatory drawings. This wonderfully honest film helps us to see beyond his big-bootied, headless women and into his highly creative but troubled mind.

webTitle: Galileo passes near Jupiter's moon Io in dangerous flyby

fields.headline: Galileo passes near Jupiter's moon Io in dangerous flyby
fields.standfirst: Galileo - Journey to Jupiter: Nasa homepage
fields.trailText: Nasa's ageing Galileo spacecraft swept closer than ever before past Jupiter's volcanic moon Io yesterday, surviving the intense radiation without the computer shutdowns that marred previous encounters.
fields.body:
Nasa's ageing Galileo spacecraft swept closer than ever before past Jupiter's volcanic moon Io yesterday, surviving the intense radiation without the computer shutdowns that marred previous encounters.

The 2 1/2-ton, $1.4 billion orbiter flew within 124 miles of Io's surface at 14:32 GMT, taking images and measurements of what is believed to be the most volcanically active world in the solar system.

"It looks like it went pretty well," said Jim Erickson, Galileo's project manager at Nasa's Jet Propulsion Laboratory. "We don't see any issues, and everything seems to have been done fine. This is one of the lucky ones."

Controllers had received much of the telemetry data within two hours of the flyby, and there were no indications that the radiation in the area of Jupiter's nearest moon affected the probe. It takes 42 minutes for a signal from Galileo to reach Earth.

Scientists are hoping to see how the moon has changed since two previous Io encounters in October and November, said Duane Bindschadler, Galileo's manager for science planning and operations at Nasa's Jet Propulsion Laboratory.

"We are looking at some areas we haven't seen at this high a resolution before," he said earlier. "The other thing we're doing is targeting the particularly active volcanoes, and hoping to see active lavas on the surface."

Using a myriad of instruments, scientists aimed to measure the temperature and potentially the composition of the lava on the fiery moon, he said. The readings and images will be returned over the next several weeks.

Galileo is now on its second extended mission since completing its primary goals in 1997. Fuel for manoeuvring is running low, navigation equipment is failing and the probe has encountered twice as much radiation as it was designed to withstand.

Mission officials, acknowledging that their plucky probe will not last forever, are incrementally increasing the danger of its encounters in an effort to squeeze it for as much scientific information as possible.

Galileo, which was launched in 1989, flew within 380 miles of Io in October, revealing more than 100 volcanoes, some of which spewed 2,700-degree-Fahrenheit (1,480-degree-Celsius) lava and vented gases miles into space.

A month later, Galileo flew within 186 miles of the surface. Its camera captured lava spurting more than a mile high. Engineers again were able to restart its computer after the radiation caused another shutdown of its science instruments.

fields.headline: The Guardian/IPPR Public Involvement Awards 2000
fields.trailText: We are looking for Britain's most community focused organisations - bodies in the public, private and voluntary sectors who are consulting the public in far-reaching and innovative ways and who are prepared to let ordinary members of the public participate in the decisions made concerning them.
fields.body:
We are looking for Britain's most community focused organisations - bodies in the public, private and voluntary sectors who are consulting the public in far-reaching and innovative ways and who are prepared to let ordinary members of the public participate in the decisions made concerning them.

Whether it is asking a local community about the best way of improving where they live or involving users in planning services, we want to find bodies which listen to ordinary people and act on what they say, and which are proud of what they do and want to tell the rest of the country about it.

We will give awards to the best and most innovative public involvement in the UK. The awards will be presented by a prominent public figure and winners will receive widespread publicity in the national press. So do you know of an organisation which has:

 Recently carried out a highly successful public involvement exercise or initiated an outstanding strategy for involving the public?

 Changed a service or a strategy because the local community wanted it changed?

 Altered its structures to allow the public more of a say in the decision making processes?

 Is successfully channelling the voice of users, citizens, or disadvantaged groups into decision making?

 Has involved sections of the community who have never before been given the chance to have a say?

 Has developed an innovative approach to public involvement?

 Is successfully harnessing new technology to consult the public?

There are no fixed categories for the awards. Anybody who makes decisions in the public interest can be nominated for an award:

Public sector bodies, such as local authorities, health care trusts, central government bodies.

Private companies, such as local businesses, utility companies, financial institutions, retail bodies.

Voluntary sector organisations.

Any organisation which has successfully developed innovative approaches to public involvement.

A panel of expert judges has been appointed to adjudicate the awards. They come from a range of backgrounds, including academia, private companies, community organisations, the media, health services and trade unions. The judges have decided on a set of criteria which will be made public. They will meet in the summer to shortlist applicants and to decide on the awards.

 The Public Involvement Awards are supported by Asda

 To apply for an award or for further information contact Vicki Combe at IPPR for a nominations pack, tel: 0207 470 6127; email: v.combe@ippr.org.uk or visit the website at www.pip.org.uk Nominations are due in by May 31, 2000.

webTitle: Rush by MPs to reveal their freebies

fields.headline: Rush by MPs to reveal their freebies
fields.trailText: The Commons' new anti-sleaze atmosphere has led MPs to declare everything from large quantities of free air miles to complementary tickets for Wimbledon.
fields.body:
The Commons' new anti-sleaze atmosphere has led MPs to declare everything from large quantities of free air miles to complementary tickets for Wimbledon.

The register of interests published yesterday includes Ann Clwyd, Labour MP for Cynon Valley, and Tess Kingham, Labour MP for Gloucester, declaring 20,000 Virgin air miles given when they were stranded after their transatlantic flights were cancelled.

Others admit ringing up Roger Willoughby, the registrar who polices declarations, to make sure they would not be called before Elizabeth Filkin, the parliamentary commissioner for standards, whose investigation led to MPs recommending a month's suspension for Teresa Gorman, Tory MP for Billericay.

Tessa Jowell, the employment minister, discloses she and her husband, David Mills, had four years' tax returns done free by a chartered accountants, Chiltern. She told the Guardian: "Mr Willoughby said it was marginal, but in the present atmosphere it is much better to over declare than under declare."

John Prescott's office agonised over a free helicopter from Milton Keynes to Silverstone from the Motorsports Association. He had been invited to present the grand prix trophy in his capacity as deputy prime minister. Again, this was ruled as marginal - but he decided to register.

Other one-off declarations include Brian Donohue, Labour MP for Cunninghame South, who had his garage built courtesy of Bardon Aggregates. Stephen Pound, Labour for Ealing North, received two Harrods hampers from Mohammed al Fayed but auctioned one for charity and gave the other to pensioners.

Anything to declare?

Big names list their benefits in the register of MPs' interests

Martin Bell, Independent, Tatton.

 Fees of £1,300 and £1,500 for Mail on Sunday articles. Proceeds after tax go to constituency fund.

 Fee of £1,000 for Sunday Mirror article on BBC.

 Contract from Penguin Books for An Accidental MP, to be published autumn 2000.

 Fee of £750 for Radio 4 programme on Biafra war.

 Fee of £750 for narrating Discovery channel series. Proceeds after tax to constituency funds.

 22-27 March, 1999 to Australia to attend annual awards ceremony of Melbourne press club. Club class Quantas flight and two days hotel accommodation.

 5-8 September 1999 to Kosovo as guest of UK working group on landmines. Return flights to Pristina and three days hotel accommodation in Pristina.

Michael Ancram, Conservative, Devizes

 Director and shareholder of Portzium Ltd, family estate company in Roxburghshire

 Minority partner in Bonny Extra (Paper)Ltd Partnership, waste paper consultant.

 Use of Rover 75 car provided by Rover Group

 Tickets for Wimbledon finals, from the BBC

 Small tenanted estate and partnership in Roxburghshire.

Tony Blair, Labour, Sedgefield

 Secondment of part time assistant to Sedgefield constituency from Freedom Group of Companies plc

 Nine day overseas visit in August 1999 accompanied by family as guest of Signor Chiti, president of the Tuscan regional government.Stayed in holiday villa and made donation to a local charity.

Harriet Harman, Labour, Camberwell and Peckham

 8-11 April 1999 to Harvard university, US, for conference on gender parity and the liberal tradition.Paid by German government.

 28 June 1999 to Amsterdam, to learn about sex education. Funded by Schering Ltd, a drug company.

John Major, Conservative, Huntingdon

 Director, Mayflower Corporation plc, car industry.

 Member, European advisory board of the Carlyle Group

 Chairman of European advisory board of Emerson Electyric Company, St. Louis, Missouri

Contract with Harper Collins for autobiography

 Trips to US in February, March, April, May, September and October 1999 to give lectures

 Kuwait, March 1999, funded by National Bank of Kuwait to deliver speech.

 Bermuda, April 1999, to speak to business audience, paid by EMC Corporation.

 Spain, April 1999, to deliver speech, paid by Muncipal of Madrid and EMC Corporation.

 Geneva, May 1999, to deliver speech paid by Pepsi Co.

 November 1999 to Strasbourg to deliver speech, paid by American Express,

 January 2000, to Saudi Arabia, to deliver speech, paid by Harvard university/Jeddah Chamber of Commerce.

 Unpaid posts as president of National Asthma Campaign; patron of Child of Acheivement Awards and deputy president of Surrey county cricket club.

Peter Mandelson, Labour, Hartlepool.

 Fees from speeches and lectures between January and September 1999 paid by AEEU,TT International,TBWA, Ernst and Young, World Trade Conference.

 Loan of Imac computer by Matthew Freud.

 14-16 January 1999 to Paris for annual British-French colloque,paid by BP.

 29-31 January,1999 to Cologne, flight sponsored by Foreign Policy Centre.

 7-15 February, 1999 to Johannesburg and Cape Town. Flights paid by AEEU.

 26-27 February,1999 to Milan to speak on globalisation paid by Unstitute of Public Policy research.

 8 March, 1999 to Madrid to speak at The Economist Agenda 2000 Conference.Paid by the Economist.

 18-20 April, 1999 to Washington to speak at the Hudson Institute International Regulatory Forum. Paid by Hudson Institute.

 April 1999 to Corfu and Albania to visit Butrint Foundation.Paid by Lord Rothschild.

 23-24 May 1999 to Madrid to speak at Mexico and Europe conference paid by Euroamerica Foundation.

 28-31 May 1999 to Georgia, US for Howard Gillman Symposium. Paid by the Progressive Foundation and Firstmark Communications.

 June 1999 to Portugal, to attend Bildenmerg conference paid by organisers.

 20 June 1999 to Marbella to speak at Warburg Dillon Read conference,paid by company.

 18-26 August 1999 to Aspen, Colorado to attend Aspen Institute summer workshop.

 13-15 September 1999 to Frankfurt, on behalf of German British Forum, paid by organisers.

Michael Portillo, Conservative, Kensington and Chelsea.

 International affairs adviser to Kerry McGee Corporation, oil and chemical company, for up to £10,000 a year.

 International strategic adviser to the Probyn Group, fianncing renewable energy, at up to £15,000 a year.

fields.headline: Lords force mayoral climbdown
fields.standfirst: The weather: special report
fields.trailText: The government is preparing a climbdown over the rules on London's mayoral election after peers last night overwhelmingly backed a Tory call to allow candidates a free mailshot to voters.
fields.body:
The government is preparing a climbdown over the rules on London's mayoral election after peers last night overwhelmingly backed a Tory call to allow candidates a free mailshot to voters.

An alliance of Conservatives, Liberal Democrats and cross benchers inflicted a government defeat of 215 votes to 150, a majority of 65.

In a stormy three-hour debate, opposition peers accused ministers of refusing a freepost primarily in order to deny publicity to Ken Livingstone, the defeated Labour mayoral contender, should he run as an independent.

A mailshot, which ministers had argued would be too costly, was necessary "for the sake of democracy", peers insisted.

The Lords amendment to the Greater London assembly bill, moved by the deputy leader of the Opposition peers, Lord Mackay of Ardbrecknish, overturned the orders in the legislation governing election expenses.

Peers also last night rejected by 206 to 143, a majority of 63, a second order setting out the rules for running the elections. They defied a plea by the environment minister, Lord Whitty, not to throw out measures putting the ballot "nuts and bolts" in place. The last time secondary legislation was overturned by peers was in 1968.

Ministers will reintroduce both orders, but are expected to offer a compromise that would allow a mailshot, but on a cheaper basis than the universal one permitted for national and Euro elections.

It is likely to mean that leaflets go to each household rather than each voter, and that all the candidates' promotional material is bundled together rather than being delivered separately.

The changes will be made not to the London assembly bill but to the representation of the people bill, which reaches its report stage in the Lords next Tuesday.

Though the government has raised the prospect of the peers' defiance risking holding up the May 4 elections, in reality Downing Street would not permit a delay.

Lord Mackay said that London had 5m voters, and denying candidates a free mailshot to the voters would put Mr Liv ingstone and others at a disadvantage. The London mayoral election was equivalent to the elections for the Scottish parliament and the Welsh assembly, rather than to local elections, as ministers claimed, he told peers.

Accusing Labour of "gerrymandering" to block Mr Livingstone's candidacy, he said: "Here we are again. It's all so logical.

"You fix the Labour candidate, by fixing Livingstone, then if that's not enough, and just in case he stands, fix him again by having no free post."

Lord Goodhart, for the Liberal Democrats, insisted that the upper house had to be "not a poodle but a rottweiler" in defending democratic principles.

"We need a free post for the sake of democracy. Candidates must be able to get their mes sage over to electors," he said.

The government claimed that a full mailshot for mayoral candidates would cost £15-30m - a figure dismissed as "absurd" by Lord Goodhart.

The Lib Dems have proposed measures to reduce the cost, including delivering candidates' leaflets bundled together with polling cards.

In a clear hint at compromise, Lord Whitty told peers that, clearly, the "concerns" expressed would be returned to during Tuesday's Lords debate on the representation of the people bill. He pledged that the orders would be re-introduced at the earliest opportunity, claiming they did not in any case have any bearing on the mailshot issue and were simply about secondary legislation necessary to run an election on May 4.

A Downing Street spokesman said last night: "In exchange for them [Tory and Lib Dem peers] voting through the orders, we will look again at this [the mailshot] in the context of the representation of the people bill."

Lord Whitty said in a statement after the defeat: "The House of Lords have done a very rash thing today. They have overturned the secondary legislation necessary to run an election on May 4.

"We will consider ways of striking a sensible balance between the Opposition's concerns and our worries about uncontrolled costs and the real risk of abuse."

webTitle: Voters rate devolution a failure, says survey

fields.headline: Voters rate devolution a failure, says survey
fields.standfirst: Devolution in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Most British voters do not think devolution has been a success, according to the first countrywide opinion poll on the new political set-up.
fields.body:
Most British voters do not think devolution has been a success, according to the first countrywide opinion poll on the new political set-up.

The ICM survey found that 91% of people in Scotland, 88% of people in Wales and 65% of people in England believed that devolution, the government's flagship policy, had achieved little or nothing since it took effect.

Despite the dismay at the realities of home rule, however, a majority of voters across Britain felt what the devolved bodies in Cardiff and Edinburgh needed was more power, not less.

The survey comes after a traumatic few months for both the Welsh assembly and the Scottish parliament with the forced resignation of Alun Michael as first secretary in Wales, and growing concerns about first minister Donald Dewar's leadership in Scotland.

The poll, conducted for the Scotsman newspaper, found that only 37% of Scots felt the parliament had been good for them; 64% believed the body had achieved a little; and 27% believed it had achieved nothing. A total of 68% wanted to see more power in Scotland.

In Wales, where the assembly has more limited powers, 48% of voters believed nothing had been achieved, 40% believed only a little had been achieved, and 62% wanted more change.

fields.headline: Livingstone's awayday
fields.standfirst: Campaigner confronts hare coursersThe London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone cupped a hand to his brow and watched as a brown hare bobbed and weaved its way across the flatlands of west Lancashire pursued by two sleek greyhounds at Altcar near Ormskirk yesterday.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone cupped a hand to his brow and watched as a brown hare bobbed and weaved its way across the flatlands of west Lancashire pursued by two sleek greyhounds at Altcar near Ormskirk yesterday.

The Brent East MP said he was "having a day off" from Labour's London mayoral fight to address another of his passions, the campaign against blood sports. "I have come today to find out about coursing. We have to have a debate," he told spectators who confronted him at the Waterloo Cup event, the highlight of the hare coursing calender.

Mr Livingstone, whose private member's bill would outlaw hunting with dogs, told spectators he did not consider coursing a sport. "I don't understand the thrill in that," he said. "I didn't like the cheer that went up when that hare was killed."

A spokesman for the Countryside Alliance said: "Every year they tell us it is our last Waterloo Cup but we keep coming back. We used to get as few as 2,000 spectators here in the 1980s. There should be over 9,000 here today."
