fields.headline: Labour bid to scupper Livingstone
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: The Labour leadership last night stepped up its campaign to force Ken Livingstone out of the race for elected mayor of London when it published private correspondence showing that he made a written promise to back Frank Dobson if the ex-health secretary won the party's nomination, "however narrowly'.'
fields.body:
The Labour leadership last night stepped up its campaign to force Ken Livingstone out of the race for elected mayor of London when it published private correspondence showing that he made a written promise to back Frank Dobson if the ex-health secretary won the party's nomination, "however narrowly'.'

As the momentum continued to build behind an independent Livingstone campaign, and the government's plans to hold the election without freepost delivery were thrown out by the House of Lords, the release of the embarrassing letters demonstrated that Labour's Millbank headquarters is now convinced that the former Greater London Council leader will go it alone.

With the latest ICM poll for the Evening Standard showing that even one in three Tories would vote for Mr Livingstone as an independent, and that most Londoners reject Tony Blair's attempt to brand him an extremist, the party hierarchy is convinced that its best card is to portray the Brent East MP as a man who cannot be trusted.

In the exchange of letters between Mr Livingstone and Labour's chairman, Vernon Hince, over Christmas and the new year, Mr Livingstone wrote: "If Frank Dobson wins the vote in the electoral college, however narrowly, I will support his campaign for mayor."

Mr Hince demanded first that Mr Livingstone repudiate reports saying he would run as an independent if he won a majority among the Labour membership but lost the electoral college, as has now happened. The following day, Mr Hince changed the allegation, saying that Mr Livingstone had refused to deny that he might stand as an independent.

In his most categorical reply, the Brent East MP stated on January 7: "There are no circumstances in which I would leave the Labour party and run as an independent candidate for mayor."

Mr Hince yesterday wrote again, protesting that "last month you gave your word to me... I believed you. Now I find it is suggested that you are threatening to break your word and stand."

But Mr Livingstone's spokesman yesterday said: "Londoners don't care about exchanges of letters with Vernon Hince, they're furious about being told who to vote for. Playing the hypocrisy card will backfire. Frank Dobson said he wasn't standing for mayor and changed his mind. Nick Raynsford promised the House of Commons a one-member one-vote selection and then welcomed the electoral college."

Of 250 letters received yesterday, Mr Livingstone said that 248, along with 300 emails, had urged him to run, though he is getting conflicting advice from friends on the left over his acute dilemma.

But the defeat of the government's plans for the May 4 mayoral elections by 206 votes to 143 in the Lords last night - over its insistence that there could be no freepost for May oral candidates' election addresses - could mean that any announcement of an independent Livingstone candidacy may be delayed. His supporters say he will need to be certain that the elections are not going to be postponed.

Meanwhile, Downing Street repeatedly denied reports in yesterday's Guardian that there was a contingency plan to ditch Mr Dobson and back Mo Mowlam as the prime minister's candidate for London mayor if a Livingstone campaign were to take off.

But the official line shifted during the day. Number 10 initially dismissed the report as "drivel", then claimed that Mr Livingstone's friends were seeking to undermine Mr Dobson, but later said that it was "no secret" that Ms Mowlam, the cabinet office minister, had been interested in the job.

Ms Mowlam pointedly failed to rule out stepping in to be Labour's mayoral candidate if Mr Dobson was seen to be fatally damaged by the controversy over Labour's selection process. "Frank Dobson has my 100% backing," she said. "The selection process is over, Frank is Labour's choice."

Senior Labour sources confirmed that the option had been discussed. "Whatever discussions had taken place, we have put a stop to them," one said. Alastair Campbell, Mr Blair's official spokesman, insisted yesterday that the prime minister knew nothing of the Mowlam option.

Throughout the day, there were increasingly vocal calls for Mr Livingstone to run from across the London labour movement. Mick Shaw, London executive member of the Fire Brigades Union, said that his union might contribute funds to a Livingstone campaign, even if that meant disaffiliation from Labour. "We would be under enormous pressure to support him if he stands, after our members voted for him by 94%".

fields.headline: Lord Annan
fields.standfirst: Academic and administrator who strove to promote a philosophy of education at a crucial time for British universities
fields.trailText: Noel Annan, who has died aged 83, was a remarkable man. His qualities had a completeness that made him the spokesman of more than one generation. To his intellectual flair and imagination was added considerable experience.
fields.body:
Noel Annan, who has died aged 83, was a remarkable man. His qualities had a completeness that made him the spokesman of more than one generation. To his intellectual flair and imagination was added considerable experience. After distinguished war service he became a leading academic, a fellow of King's college, Cambridge, and a university lecturer in politics. He went on to become a university leader and administrator, as provost of King's from the early age of 40 (1956-1966); as provost of University College, London (1966-1978); and the first full-time vice-chancellor of the University of London (1978-1981). He held these responsibilities at crucial periods in the history of British universities.

He knew periods of expansion and prosperity, as he knew years of stringency and uncertainty. He sat on innumerable committees and chaired most of them. His decisiveness and affability were valuable assets, but much more than this, he was one of the few who sought both to understand and to explain what was happening. He strove to find a philosophy of education.

Annan was also a public figure. Once again he presided over councils and committees. He was a director of the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden; chairman of the board of trustees of the National Gallery; a trustee of the British Museum; and president of the London Library. There were government bodies, such as the public schools commission, and private bodies, notably the Gulbenkian foundation.

He was therefore much in the public eye. At times he attracted attention by making statements which were deliberately resonant. In 1970, for example, he forcefully expressed his opposition to the plans of the Conservative government of Edward Heath to allow public museums and galleries which had hitherto been free, to charge for admission. Why, Annan asked, should someone who worked in a shop be unable to spend some of the lunch break looking round the British Museum or the National Gallery?

The prime minister angrily claimed that this was a small matter which had got completely out of hand, and there were those who mocked - and Annan encountered many such in the course of his career - by asking how many shopgirls did Lord Annan know? But the protests succeeded. And for Annan this was not a small matter. His indignation was part of a process in which he devoutedly believed: that of civilising people.

He was an accomplished speaker. As an orator fulfilling his duties as provost of King's, when giving the Hobhouse Lecture at Bedford College (1958) or the Romanes Lecture at Oxford (1965), speaking on the television Brains Trust in the 1960s, or performing as the Dimbleby Lecturer on the BBC some years later, he was always impressive. He became a life peer in 1965, and his speeches in the Lords were always carefully prepared and listened to with respect. He often took the chair at public lectures and would frequently conclude proceedings with an anecdote that was better than any of those which the speaker had produced. This always delighted the audience and sometimes the speaker.

Noel Annan was educated at Stowe and King's College, Cambridge. He wrote the biography of Stowe's first headmaster, JF Roxburgh (published in 1965), who was also his headmaster. Annan believed that it was during the 1920s that the intelligent public began seriously to doubt whether the accepted principles of the public school were adequate and right. Roxburgh, whom Annan admired, had tried, in his own way, to deal with these demands. And at Cambridge Annan pursued these considerations.

Postwar, in the days of Attlee's 1945-51 Labour government, he thought that the university had not paid sufficient attention to what had been happening in schools and in education. He wanted Cambridge to change its attitude. He believed in grammar school boys, and as they adapted themselves to fit in to their new surroundings, they discovered that brains and originality opened doors. Annan believed that in the 1950s it was the manners of the grammar schools that came to predominate. Both public and grammar school boys came to dislike the upper class and their ways.

As provost of King's, Annan made an effort to attract boys from the maintained grammar schools. Thirty years later he noted that 54% of the entry to King's came from the comprehensive system and 15% from the few maintained grammars schools that still existed. He believed that comprehensive school students had a greater potential than their public school contemporaries.

But, of course, Annan himself belonged to the gilded elite. His own description of how he was recruited, in the war years, and became a member of MI14, a small unit of the military intelligence division of the war office, could not be bettered. It was in December 1940. "I was lunching with my father at our club, when he introduced me to a member called Carl Sherrington. He was the son of a famous Cambridge physiologist who had won the Nobel prize." As a result of this meeting, "I got a letter telling me to report to a Captain Sanderson at the war office." This captain believed that Annan was an expert on railways. He was not, but his father had been associated, some time before 1914, with the Chesapeake and Ohio railway. Hence, Annan was given an important job in operational intelligence studying the movement by rail of German forces. Then, after Germany's surrender, a chance meeting with Bill Cavendish-Bentinck (the future 9th Duke of Portland) led to Annan's appointment to the political division of the British control commission, eventually stationed in Berlin.

This is surely the old public school account of how we won the war, a story which accords with Correlli Barnett's view of the British upper class supporting each other as they muddle through. But Annan shows us in his account, Changing Enemies (1995), how the machinery became professional and worked. His book is very far from the traditional story of a man at war. It is the essential Annan. Who else would have begun with a quotation from Troilus and Cressida? Who else would be able to recall a return to Berlin in 1948, when the East Germans were beginning their blockade of the city, and to tell of how he had renewed his student acting days? The Marlowe Society were producing Webster's The White Devil and they invited Annan to play the part of Cardinal Monticelso.

Annan enjoyed Cambridge hugely. He was at the centre of social and intellectual life. He always remained a King's man. EM Forster had been given a set of rooms in King's from 1953 (to his death in 1970) and Annan constantly referred to him as "my guru". Forster sometimes thought that King's was a bit too ostentatious, and that its buildings had a tendency to say "look at me." Annan's critics would say that it was not surprising that he did not think this. They suggested that Annan was too smart and sophisticated. But if Annan defended that which was exclusive, he was sometimes only being sensible. It was absurd to accuse the Apostles, a club that existed to discuss a variety of subjects, as being the centre for homosexuals or for becoming traitors, as certain hostile critics did.

He was very active as a critic. It was during these years that he wrote two influential articles, one on Kipling's Place in the History of Ideas (Victorian Studies 1959-1960) and the other, The Intellectual Aristocracy, on the emergence of that group in England (published in Studies in Social History, a tribute to GM Trevelyan, 1955). Both have been endlessly quoted. It was during these years that he developed his views on sociology, and proposed that it be taught as an undergraduate subject in Cambridge. "Nothing marks the break with Victorian thought more decisively than modern sociology" was his dictum. He sat on innumerable committees and chaired most of them. There were government bodies, such as the public schools commission, and private bodies, notably the Gulbenkian foundation. He was therefore much in the public eye. In 1970, for example, he forcefully expressed his opposition to the plans of the Conservative government of Edward Heath to allow public museums and galleries which had hitherto been free, to charge for admission. He believed that comprehensive school students had a greater potential than their public school contemporaries. But, of course, Annan himself belonged to the gilded elite. His own description of how he was recruited, in the war years, and became a member of MI14, a small unit of the military intelligence division of the war office, could not be bettered. It was in December 1940. "I was lunching with my father at our club, when he introduced me to a member called Carl Sherrington. He was the son of a famous Cambridge physiologist who had won the Nobel prize." As a result of this meeting, "I got a letter telling me to report to a Captain Sanderson at the war office." This captain believed that Annan was an expert on railways. He was not, but his father had been associated, some time before 1914, with the Chesapeake and Ohio railway. fields.headline: Iran's MPs promise individual privacy
fields.standfirst: More about Iran
fields.trailText: Iran's newly-elected reformers yesterday demonstrated their intention to break with the past, promising to pass laws to guarantee that the state stays out of citizens' private lives and to ensure the free flow of information.
fields.body:
Iran's newly-elected reformers yesterday demonstrated their intention to break with the past, promising to pass laws to guarantee that the state stays out of citizens' private lives and to ensure the free flow of information.

The Islamic Iran Participation Front group, led by Mohammad Reza Khatami, the brother of the progressive president, Mohammad Khatami, said Iranian voters had handed it a huge responsibility in bringing them to power and defeating the conservative establishment in Friday's election.

The group's members said they hoped to be "honest brokers of the people's trust". Part of this trust was to permit social freedom hitherto denied to Iranians.

"We will try to differentiate between people's public lives and their private lives. Private citizens must be free to do the things they wish," said Rajabali Mazrouei, a newly-elected MP from Isfahan.

A ban on satellite dishes, imposed in the early 1990s under the then-president Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, is to be one of the first rules to change. Conservative clerics believe that satellite dishes will allow western decadence.

But the reformers said they would never compromise their revolutionary or religious values in order to restore rela tions with the United States.

The US has joined a host of countries in giving their approval to the outcome of the parliamentary election, a gesture which many reformers frown upon in public.

Even though the reformers may hope one day to reap the economic rewards of renewed relations, they have no plans to begin a dialogue until the US changes its stance on Iran.

"In the past the US supported one of the most repressive regimes in history, which was the Shah's regime," said President Khatami. "Now we still face hostile sanctions and allegations [of support for terrorism] against us that are unproven. There is a better tone, but no practical steps to pull down the wall of mistrust."

The reformers' statements on social freedom are unprecedented in Iran since the 1979 revolution, when the conservative clerical establishment prohibited social activity they deemed to be against Islamic principles. Iran's new generation of leaders plans to apply a more flexible interpretation of the Islamic texts.

In particular, the reformers want to guarantee press freedom and other civic rights. Over the last 20 years, they said, democratic principles enshrined in the constitution were ignored or distorted.

The interior ministry is not expected to announce the official results of the election for several more days.

fields.headline: Court blow for Microsoft
fields.standfirst: Microsoft on trial: special report
fields.trailText: The prospect of Microsoft being broken up moved a step closer yesterday as the judge in the landmark anti-trust case against the software giant founded by Bill Gates compared it with the oil monopoly run by John D Rockefeller at the turn of the century.
fields.body:
The prospect of Microsoft being broken up moved a step closer yesterday as the judge in the landmark anti-trust case against the software giant founded by Bill Gates compared it with the oil monopoly run by John D Rockefeller at the turn of the century.

Judge Thomas Jackson's invocation of Standard Oil, a monopoly which was broken up by the courts in 1912 because of anti-competitive behaviour, provided a boost to the case against Microsoft brought by the federal government and 19 US states yesterday.

Tough questions to Microsoft's leading lawyer marked a far more negative stance by the judge. He repeatedly interrupted Microsoft's counsel John Warden as the lawyer sought to defend the Seattle-based company which controls 90% of the world's computer operating systems. At one point the judge accused Mr Warden of evading his questions.

The judge's tone suggests that Microsoft will be hard pressed to stop him from finding that the company broke US anti-trust laws.

In yesterday's court hearing, which provided both sides with one last chance to put their case before the judge, the judge reserved his most biting criticism for Microsoft's argument that its copyright ownership excused its behaviour.

"I don't really understand your copyright defence," said the judge, before adding that Mr Rockefeller had "a fee-simple control over his oil and I don't see a distinction".

He interrupted Mr Warden's argument that "anti-trust laws did not trump copyright laws". The judge said: "I am not so sure of that."

The argument concerned Microsoft's bundling of its internet browser with its Windows operating system. The government has argued that by putting the two together Microsoft was forcing its way into a fledgling market by abusing its stranglehold over operating systems. The judge indicated his support for that view in his preliminary ruling in November which found that Microsoft abused its monopoly position and harmed competitors and consumers alike.

Microsoft is under heavy pressure to reach a settlement with the government in its separate talks with a mediator appointed by Judge Jackson. If no settlement is reached the judge is expected to rule on the case in the spring.

fields.headline: People power overcomes atomic power
fields.standfirst: Future of Japan's nuclear energy programme thrown into question as utility giant is forced to scrap plans for plant
fields.trailText: Japan's nuclear power industry suffered a historic defeat yesterday when one of the country's biggest utilities was forced to scrap plans for a power plant that it has been trying to build for 37 years.
fields.body:
Japan's nuclear power industry suffered a historic defeat yesterday when one of the country's biggest utilities was forced to scrap plans for a power plant that it has been trying to build for 37 years.

The stunning setback - less than six months after the country's worst nuclear accident - underlines the growing hostility to atomic energy in Japan and raises questions about the government's ambitious atomic energy programme.

The plan to construct two 1,300 megawatt reactors in Ashihama, a scenic coastal area in Mie prefecture, central Japan, has been the subject of a prolonged and bitter confrontation since 1963, when it was first proposed by Chubu Electric Power Company.

The prefecture's governor, Masayasu Kitagawa, broke the stalemate yesterday by becoming the first politician of his rank to order the abandonment of a nuclear project.

"The plan has neither the support nor the cooperation of local residents," he told an assembly of local politicians. "It should go back to the drawing board." Within hours, Chubu Electric announced that it would start looking for an alternative site.

The decision has sent shock waves through Japan's nuclear industry, as prefectural governors have tended to side with the powerful utilities which bring jobs and tax revenue, rather than residents.

Public opinion has grown more hostile, however, as a result of a series of high-profile accidents and cover-ups in recent years. In a sign of the changing climate, anti-nuclear campaigners have been elected mayors in some towns and four years ago, the community of Maki in northern Japan rejected plans for a nuclear plant in a referendum.

Mr Kitagawa said his decision was prompted by the growing concerns about nuclear safety in the wake of the uncontrolled nuclear fission at a uranium processing plant in Tokaimura last September.

One man died and more than 400 people were exposed to radiation following the accident, which occurred when plant workers mixed seven times the safe amount of uranium in a bucket. It has since emerged that they were following an illegal manual and that the plant was rarely inspected by the authorities.

"People's worries and disbelief in nuclear power reached a previously unknown intensity after the Tokaimura accident," Mr Kitagawa said.

The reputation of the industry has also been damaged by revelations that workers at British Nuclear Fuels fabricated safety data on shipments of recycled fuel sent to Japan.

The Mie governor's move comes at a sensitive time for the government, which is in the midst of a five-yearly re view of Japan's nuclear policy.

A country with almost no natural energy resources, Japan relies on atomic power to supply 30% of its electricity and it wants to increase this amount by building 20 new plants by 2010. Even before yesterday's decision - which means at the very least a delay for one of those facilities - bureaucrats were debating whether to lower the target because of the increasing hostility to nuclear power.

Parliament is also expected to begin a debate early next month on where to site a new storage site for high-level radioactive waste. In the current climate, few prefectures are likely to be willing to accept such a facility.

Anti-nuclear campaigners welcomed yesterday's decision. "After a 37-year fight by the people of this area, we have finally won a victory," said Yoichi Shibahara, a resident near Ashihama. "After this decision, it will be impossible for nuclear plants to be built against the wishes of local people anywhere in Japan."

The reputation of the industry has also been damaged by revelations that workers at British Nuclear Fuels fabricated safety data on shipments of recycled fuel sent to Japan. The Mie governor's move comes at a sensitive time for the government, which is in the midst of a five-yearly re view of Japan's nuclear policy. A country with almost no natural energy resources, Japan relies on atomic power to supply 30% of its electricity and it wants to increase this amount by building 20 new plants by 2010. Even before yesterday's decision - which means at the very least a delay for one of those facilities - bureaucrats were debating whether to lower the target because of the increasing hostility to nuclear power. Parliament is also expected to begin a debate early next month on where to site a new storage site for high-level radioactive waste. In the current climate, few prefectures are likely to be willing to accept such a facility. Anti-nuclear campaigners welcomed yesterday's decision. "After a 37-year fight by the people of this area, we have finally won a victory," said Yoichi Shibahara, a resident near Ashihama. "After this decision, it will be impossible for nuclear plants to be built against the wishes of local people anywhere in Japan."

webTitle: Nine in hospital as dumped radioactive material is uncovered in junkyard

fields.headline: Nine in hospital as dumped radioactive material is uncovered in junkyard
fields.trailText: Workers from Thailand's office of Atomic Energy for Peace remove a container of radioactive cobalt-60, discarded from an x-ray machine and found in a junkyard in Bangkok.
fields.body:
Workers from Thailand's office of Atomic Energy for Peace remove a container of radioactive cobalt-60, discarded from an x-ray machine and found in a junkyard in Bangkok.

The Thai government filed a complaint with police yesterday against Kamol Sukosol, a distributor of x-ray equipment, alleging that it mishandled radioactive materials and exposed at least nine people to dangerous levels of radiation.

They believe the cylinder containing the radioactive isotope was removed from one of three x-ray machines dumped in a parking lot. Five workers at the scrapyard who opened the cylinder were in hospital over the weekend with radiation sickness. Four waste collectors who removed the cylinder also came down with radiation sickness and were placed in intensive care on Monday.

The victims suffered sharp drops in their white blood cell counts, blisters, skin burns and hair loss.

"The company failed to handle the radioactive waste, and put people's lives at risk," said Ong-art Klampaiboon, an adviser to the country's science ministry.

webTitle: Egypt's sexist divorce laws blamed not on Islam, but on men

fields.headline: Egypt's sexist divorce laws blamed not on Islam, but on men
fields.standfirst: Women face long struggle for equal rights to leave partners
fields.trailText: After seven years of marriage and two children, Azza's husband walked out on her and exercised his Islamic right to take a second wife. He refused to pay Azza any child support until a court ordered him to, and for four years he ignored her pleas for a divorce.
fields.body:
After seven years of marriage and two children, Azza's husband walked out on her and exercised his Islamic right to take a second wife. He refused to pay Azza any child support until a court ordered him to, and for four years he ignored her pleas for a divorce.

A women's legal aid centre in the poor Cairo suburb of Boulaq was finally able to persuade a judge to grant Azza a divorce six months ago.

"I began selling things from home to survive," said Azza, 32. "He spends all his money on his other family.

"I never saw a good day with him. At one point I broke down and told my children their father had died because we never saw him."

During her divorce hearing, which took place four years after her husband had left her, the presiding judge asked what harm Azza had suffered.

"She was abandoned - and the judge kept asking what harm had been done," recalled Azza's lawyer, Seham Ali.

Ms Ali, who works at the legal aid centre, said Azza was considered lucky in that her divorce trial lasted only 18 months. Other women have struggled for years to free themselves of marriages.

Ms Ali cited the example of Itimad, 45, whose husband left her 10 years ago.

Four different divorce cases that the centre has raised for Itimad over the past three years have failed, merely because the court clerk assigned to deliver the divorce summons cannot find Itimad's husband. He may have been bribed by the husband, Ms Ali claimed.

Women's rights activists in Egypt have campaigned for years to wrest divorce from the male preserve it has been for so long.

According to the 1929 personal status law, a woman can only file for divorce in cases of physical or psychological abuse, which must be proved by the woman.

But a man could simply say "I divorce you" three times, or get a divorce by filing a paper with the marriage registrar, in which case he would not even need to inform his wife.

Supporters of that legislation claimed it was inspired by Islamic law. But women's activists noted that it also conveniently ignored rights afforded by Islam to women.

The activists lobbied to guarantee more rights for women by writing them into marriage contracts, but opposition from the religious establishment torpedoed their efforts.

Last month, under pressure from the government, the Egyptian parliament approved amendments to the personal status law which, for the first time in Egypt's history, allow women to file for divorce on grounds of incompatibility.

After all manner of social disintegration was predicted by members of the male-dominated parliament, MPs approved the changes.

Under the new law, based on an Islamic precept called khula, women who want to divorce their husbands must return their dowries and relinquish all financial claims, including alimony.

The doom-laden predictions of male politicians that the law would encourage women to leave their husbands en masse - along with cartoons in national newspapers that showed men in chains and moustachioed wives with downtrodden men at their side pushing baby buggies - reflected the deep-seated fear of women's rights in this deeply conservative country.

Opposition to the amendment also came from Afghanistan's ultra-conservative ruling Taliban movement.

A Taliban spokesman said the changes were "a blatant violation of Islam". He said: "The Islamic world should protest against this move."

But liberals have argued that the new changes do not go far enough, saying it would be difficult for poor women to return their dowries and to renounce financial rights.

Zeinab Radwan, a dean at Cairo university's college of Arabic and Islamic studies, says it is not Islam that denies women rights, but the male monopoly of its interpretation.

"It is not a law that will destroy the family, but men's behaviour," she said. "Men in this country are not used to the idea that women have rights. They're used to the fact that they have power. This law is just a beginning - but still does not guarantee a woman all her rights."

Some 1.5m divorce cases are filed each year in a population of 64m. Currently 7m people are seeking legal separation.

webTitle: Fresh dig could solve the mystery of Pompeii

fields.headline: Fresh dig could solve the mystery of Pompeii
fields.standfirst: Ticket cash to fund archaeology, if the mafia can be kept out
fields.trailText: Pompeii's decades of neglect are about to end in a flood of funds for fresh excavations that may resolve the 2,000-year-old mystery about how the victims of the volcanic explosion died.
fields.body:
Pompeii's decades of neglect are about to end in a flood of funds for fresh excavations that may resolve the 2,000-year-old mystery about how the victims of the volcanic explosion died.

Work announced yesterday will reopen swaths of the site to the public and allow digging in an unexplored 20 hectares, where bodies and buildings are believed to be smothered in pumice, undisturbed since Vesuvius erupted in AD79.

The findings may resolve the dispute over whether those who died were asphyxiated slowly by ash or poisoned instantly by a cloud of toxic gas.

Analysis of thermal shocks to 300 bodies found at the nearby village of Herculaneum suggested they were killed within seconds by a gas at a temperature of 400C.

Other theories suggest that most of the 2,000 victims were killed by inhaling the ash and pumice which piled 20ft high. A column of smoke reached 25 miles into the sky.

Historians are also keen to settle a debate over whether survivors attempted to rebuild parts of the city before leaving in despair.

Giovanna Melandri, Italy's culture minister, said archaeologists would be delighted at gaining long overdue access to the 20 hectares - almost a third of the site.

"New excavations also mean a new life for an area that has been abandoned for too many years," Ms Melandri said.

Pompeii's annual 2.3m visitors make it one of Italy's most popular attractions, but tourists and archaeologists alike have despaired at its neglect.

Stray dogs roam the ruins, unaccompanied tour groups chip mementos, wall paintings are fading, stone is crumbling and supporting braces are weakening. The area now open is half of what was available to visitors 40 years ago, said administrators.

The revamp will be funded mostly from the site's revenues, which have quadrupled to more than £8m a year since a reform two years granted Pompeii autonomy from the culture ministry, ending its contributions to Rome.

From March 15 it will be possible to make reservations and buy tickets from an internet site: www.pompeiisites.org.New £5 ticket will allow visits to three other sites around Naples.

Administrators are also encouraging corporate sponsorship and lobbying for hotels, restaurants, bars and shops. Critics claim commercialism would spawn a theme park and destroy Pompeii's quality of stillness.

Authorities are also concerned that the Camorra, the Naples-based mafia, would strive to control the new businesses.

Ms Melandri said she had signed a protocol with the interior ministry to ensure that all transactions are monitored and made transparent. "It's an essential condition," she said.

However, Amato Lamberti, of the Camorra Observatory, warned that it would be extremely difficult to block criminal infiltration.

"Racketeering is endemic. It is very difficult to find a company that does not pay bribes or respond to blackmail," he said.

Interest in the site was galvanised last month when archaeologists at the nearby site of Ercolano found skeletal remains of 48 people. The bodies included newborn babies and adults. Coins in their pockets suggested they were trying to flee, said Pietro Giovanni Guzzo, a superintendent.

Most of the 20,000 inhabitants escaped thanks to three days of warning activity by Vesuvius, but the speed and intensity of the August 24 eruption doomed those who remained.

Excavation at Pompeii began in 1748 when the Bourbon kings of Spain used the discoveries to decorate their own palaces.

Privately funded excavation at a Pompeii suburb this month exposed a covered, heated swimming pool decorated with erotic wall paintings. It will be opened in May but the Vatican has decreed it unsuitable for children.

webTitle: Tigers could roam wilds of Africa

fields.headline: Tigers could roam wilds of Africa
fields.trailText: For the first time in nearly a million years, tigers could soon be on the loose again in Africa.
fields.body:
For the first time in nearly a million years, tigers could soon be on the loose again in Africa.

They will not be the sabre-tooth variety which once stalked the continent, but if an experiment with two Bengal tiger cubs by two of South Africa's leading conservationists is successful, the big cats could be headed for a comeback.

John and David Varty plan to breed from the tigers and let the offspring loose in a sprawling park for endangered species. It will also provide a home to gorillas, chimpanzees and black rhinos.

But David, who runs Conservation Corporation Africa, says that first they have to discover the answer to the crucial question of whether tigers can survive in the wild in Africa.

"If these two cubs grow up successfully and are not damaged by an African parasite, then we will breed. If the offspring come through and are able to kill prey quite successfully then we will continue to breed and try and establish a genetic pool in Africa.

"But it is experimental. We don't know what kind of problems we might encounter," he said.

Although conventional wisdom has it that there have never been tigers in Africa, there is evidence from fossils that the sabre-tooth species was found in many parts of the continent until about a million years ago. The reason for their disappearance is unclear but palaeontologists believe it was probably caused by dramatic climatic changes opening up the savannahs.

"Tigers move around on their own. With the arrival of the grasslands, it seems they couldn't compete strength-to-strength in the terrain with the lions," David said.

The Bengal cubs were chosen because they are pure bred, whereas most tigers are not. They will initially be kept on a farm to see if they are resistant to local parasites. In time they will be allowed to roam freely through parts of a park which will encompass five forests in the foothills of the Drakensberg mountains which are being sold by the government.

David says the main motivation for the project is conservation. There are fewer than 7,000 tigers left in the world, although some say the real figure is only half that number.

Although this is the first attempt to breed tigers in Africa outside a zoo, David's brother John says there is nothing unusual about the principle.

"The Arabian oryx was returned to the wild from the Phoenix zoo, and black rhinos are being bred in Texas," he said.

fields.headline: World in brief
fields.trailText: Nato halts searches in Mitrovice
fields.body:
Nato halts searches in Mitrovice

Peacekeepers in Mitrovice yesterday suspended most weapons searches to defuse tension a day after their troops struggled to prevent riots in the divided Kosovan town.

The Nato-led peace force, K-For, announced a suspension of house-to-house weapons searches in both the Albanian and Serbian sectors of the city, but said soldiers were still searching cars and individuals.

The house-to-house checks had enraged Serbs, many of whom were thought to keep weapons in case of an attack by ethnic Albanians.

About 1,000 Albanian miners yesterday demonstrated silently near the site where peacekeepers had fired tear gas on Monday and fought with their bare hands to prevent Kosovo Albanians from storming a bridge. The Albanians - part of a 60,000-strong protest march from Kosovo's provincial capital, Pristina, - had been demanding an end to Mitrovice's division into Serb and Albanian areas.

The division has sparked violence that has left nine people dead and more than 20 wounded this month, including two French soldiers shot in gun battles.

Leaders of the city's Serb minority community north of the bridge, which divides them from ethnic Albanians, claimed that hundreds of armed troublemakers broke through K-For lines on Monday to reach the bridge. Their claims were denied by K-For.

"I think that troops did a good job yesterday in what could have been an explosive situation," said Captain Joe Butterfill, a spokesman for British forces. British troops have moved in to support French soldiers who have been controlling Mitrovice since the UN took over Kosovo. Reuters, Mitrovice

Taiwan hits back over talks threat

Taiwan yesterday issued a defiant response to China's warning that it would use military force unless the island's leaders joined talks on reunification.

The Taiwanese Mainland Affairs council criticised Beijing for failing to accept that it did not rule Taiwan.

"The Chinese communists' continued denial of the existence of the Republic of China can only bring more trouble to cross-strait relations and deepen tension," said a spokesman, Lin Chong-pin. "This will not at all help to resolve the actual issues involved."

On Monday, Beijing's state council threatened to use "drastic measures, including military force" if Taiwan dragged its heels indefinitely on reunification talks.

The Clinton administration yesterday rejected China's threatened use of force.

"We believe that peaceful dialogue and bilateral engagement between the sides is the way to move forward," said a presidential spokesman, Joe Lockhart. Agencies

Ex-minister called on to quit top job

Pressure mounted yesterday on Roland Dumas to resign as the head of France's highest judicial body, over allegations that he was involved in a kickback scheme.

Mr Dumas, 77, was ordered on Friday to stand trial after he was investigated over two years for "complicity and illegally receiving company funds" from the oil company Elf between 1989 and 1992, while foreign minister under the then Socialist president François Mitterrand.

Mr Dumas took leave of absence from the presidency of the nine-member constitutional council in March.

"The presumption of innocence must be respected but so must the dignity of the constitutional council," Philippe Bassinet, a Socialist party official, was quoted as saying yesterday. Mr Bassinet was among the few Socialists voicing what has reportedly been advised in private. Rightwing politicians have demanded the resignation of Mr Dumas. AP, Paris

Rebel leader deported

South Africa has deported Sierra Leone's former rebel leader Foday Sankoh after he spent four days in the country in breach of a United Nations travel embargo.

Mr Sankoh and members of his Revolutionary United Front (RUF) are obliged to obtain UN permission to travel under international sanctions imposed against the organisation at the height of its brutal war on the government and civilians.

Pretoria said Mr Sankoh's visa was issued "in error" by the South African embassy in Ivory Coast and insisted that he was not on an official visit. Newspapers in Sierra Leone reported that he was in South Africa to tie up a private diamond deal.

At the weekend, the UN security council issued a statement protesting at Mr Sankoh's visit. Foreign ministry spokesman Dumisani Rasheleng said the South African mission mistakenly believed the UN travel ban on Mr Sankoh was lifted after he was appointed to the government under last year's peace accord. Chris McGreal, Johannesburg

Georgia turns down Stalin kin

The central election commission in Georgia yesterday rejected an attempt by a grandson of the former Soviet dictator Josef Stalin to run for president.

Because Yevgeny Dzhugashvili was a citizen of Russia, not Georgia, he could not be a candidate in the April 9 election, according to commission spokeswoman Eka Peradze.

The incumbent president, Eduard Shevardnadze, is the frontrunner in the race.

Mr Dzhugashvili, a leftwinger who has called for the restoration of the Soviet Union, was barred from running in Georgia's parliamentary elections last autumn because he is not a citizen.

A 64-year-old retired Soviet army colonel, he heads Georgia's Popular Patriotic Union, a coalition of seven parties, including the Communists. AP, Tbilisi

Pupils skip school to party in bar

A regional education minister in South Africa who arrived at a school sports day discovered about 300 pupils had debunked to a nearby shebeen - a township bar - where they were drinking, dancing and undressing each other.

Ignatius Jacobs turned up at Ingxayizile high school north of Johannesburg after a concerned parent called his department to say things were "out of hand", according to the minister's spokesman, Lebelo Maloka.

"The minister couldn't believe what he saw. Hundreds of learners, both male and female, were drinking alcohol inside and outside the shebeen and dancing as if it was a party," he said.

Mr Jacobs lectured the pupils, who were all in uniform, on their behaviour and the need to get an education. He called for the prosecution of the bar owner for selling alcohol to minors.

The local mayor said he would see to it that the shebeen's licence was revoked. The school principal was not available for comment. Chris McGreal, Johannesburg

The incumbent president, Eduard Shevardnadze, is the frontrunner in the race. Mr Dzhugashvili, a leftwinger who has called for the restoration of the Soviet Union, was barred from running in Georgia's parliamentary elections last autumn because he is not a citizen. A 64-year-old retired Soviet army colonel, he heads Georgia's Popular Patriotic Union, a coalition of seven parties, including the Communists. AP, Tbilisi Pupils skip school to party in bar A regional education minister in South Africa who arrived at a school sports day discovered about 300 pupils had debunked to a nearby shebeen - a township bar - where they were drinking, dancing and undressing each other. Ignatius Jacobs turned up at Ingxayizile high school north of Johannesburg after a concerned parent called his department to say things were "out of hand", according to the minister's spokesman, Lebelo Maloka. "The minister couldn't believe what he saw. Hundreds of learners, both male and female, were drinking alcohol inside and outside the shebeen and dancing as if it was a party," he said. Mr Jacobs lectured the pupils, who were all in uniform, on their behaviour and the need to get an education. He called for the prosecution of the bar owner for selling alcohol to minors. The local mayor said he would see to it that the shebeen's licence was revoked. The school principal was not available for comment. Chris McGreal, Johannesburg

webTitle: Truckers rally in Washington against soaring fuel costs

fields.headline: Truckers rally in Washington against soaring fuel costs
fields.trailText: The centre of Washington was brought to a standstill yesterday when hundreds of American truckers brought their rigs to town in the largest show of protest so far against rising fuel prices.
fields.body:
The centre of Washington was brought to a standstill yesterday when hundreds of American truckers brought their rigs to town in the largest show of protest so far against rising fuel prices.

Amid growing worldwide concern about higher crude oil prices caused by lower production in the Opec oil-producing nations, more than 300 trucks assembled at dawn in New Jersey and arrived in Washington, 200 miles to the south, in a three-mile-long convoy, hooting their horns and paralysing traffic.

After parking their rigs in dozens of streets around the congress building, the Capitol, the truckers climbed the steps to demand that congress and the White House approve a 15c (10p)-a-gallon rebate scheme for commercial truckers while prices remain high, and that they cut federal excise tax on diesel.

But few congressmen were in Washington to meet the protesters yesterday since only the senate is in session this week. The House of Representatives is in recess.

"It's cheaper to park a truck than it is to drive it right now," said one protester, Douglas Sorantino. "We're not looking for handouts. We're looking for help."

"It's putting us out of business," said a Pennsylvania trucker, John Medaglia. "We make a very small profit-margin as it is. Fuel has just about doubled in price."

The principal grievance of the truckers, many of whom are independent operators, is that diesel prices have risen in the eastern states by up to 55% over the past six weeks, according to the American Trucking Association. Low stocks and prolonged cold weather leading to increased demand are being blamed for the price rises.

Crude oil is selling for around $30 (£18.75) a barrel, its highest price since the gulf war in 1991 and nearly three times the price of a barrel of crude in December 1998.

The truckers say many haulage firms may soon go out of business, creating shortages of goods and higher inflation.

Fuel prices in the US remain exceptionally low by international standards, with a gallon of regular unleaded petrol costing on average $1.36 (85p) and a gallon of diesel $1.46 (91p).

But the sensitivity of the issue in an election year cannot be overestimated. The Clinton administration moved last week to protect US consumers from spiralling domestic heating costs, releasing an extra $125m (£78m) to help poorer families.

fields.headline: Diego Simeone
fields.body:
Age: 29.

Appearance: Villain in a spaghetti western.

Do they eat spaghetti in Argentina? Don't be difficult.

Position: Midfield player.

Status: Argentinian hero, English nightmare.

Why so? He's the player whose late tackle provoked the petulant kick that got David Beckham sent off in the 1998 World Cup. They are due to meet again tonight as England play Argentina in a "friendly" at Wembley.

This chap Beckham, should I have heard of him? Oh, don't be so ridiculous.

Is there animosity between the two? For the purposes of Pass Notes, yes. The sending-off was blamed for England's agonising defeat on penalties, and Beckham spent the summer in purdah.

Wasn't he photographed there in a sarong? Perhaps you've devoted too much time to reading about the London mayoral race.

So tonight could see fireworks? Not necessarily. Diego is being very diplomatic: "If I see him before the game we will shake hands. He asked me for my shirt last season and I was happy to oblige."

Why did Beckham want his shirt? For Brooklyn? No, in the interests of international peace.

There's a bit of history between the two sides, isn't there? The past 30 years has seen a succession of ill-tempered battles. England manager Alf Ramsey branded the Argentinians "animals" during the 1966 World Cup; Diego Maradona's "hand of God" put England out in 1986; and in 1998 Argentina were again England's nemesis. Add that bloody fixture in the South Atlantic in 1982...

Stop! You're about to say something you'll regret. Thanks.

Why is Simeone singled out for criticism? As well as admitting to a spot of play-acting to get Beckham sent off, he did not endear himself to English fans by saying that their team were a bunch of second-raters who had no chance in France '98.

He was right: That's what hurt most.

Do say: "At least the clash adds spice to an otherwise boring friendly."

Don't say: "Gotcha, Diego."

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In our Portrait of the Archbishop of Canterbury, pages 4 and 5, G2, yesterday, we said that Dr Carey had "let it be known, semi-officially, that he plans to remain in office for another three years, at the personal request of the Queen". A spokesperson for the Archbishop says this is wrong and has asked us to make it clear that the Archbishop has not spoken to the Queen or to anyone else about any specific retirement date.
fields.body:
In our Portrait of the Archbishop of Canterbury, pages 4 and 5, G2, yesterday, we said that Dr Carey had "let it be known, semi-officially, that he plans to remain in office for another three years, at the personal request of the Queen". A spokesperson for the Archbishop says this is wrong and has asked us to make it clear that the Archbishop has not spoken to the Queen or to anyone else about any specific retirement date.

In a report on page 5, February 21, and again in an article on page 6, G2, yesterday, we referred to a study called Women's Incomes Over A Lifetime. In both cases we said it was based upon research conducted by the London School of Economics. The LSE did in fact edit the report but the main research was undertaken at Birkbeck College (by Hugh Davies) and at the Institute of Education (by Heather Joshi).

We placed Cliveden in Berkshire twice in Sport, February 21 (page 3 and page 7). It is in Buckinghamshire.

The quotes from John Lahr in the Saturday Profile of David Mamet (February 19) were taken from his article on Mamet in the New Yorker of November 17 1997. John Lahr is the magazine's senior drama critic.

Solomon made an embarrassing appearance as Soloman in the Corrections, February 21.

fields.headline: When love is not enough
fields.standfirst: The government wants to speed up adoption. It says too many children are languishing needlessly in care. But that is the best place for many of them, says  Meg Henderson, who bitterly regrets adopting her daughter, Louise
fields.trailText: The government wants to speed up adoption. It says too many children are languishing needlessly in care. But that is the best place for many of them, says Meg Henderson, who bitterly regrets adopting her daughter, Louise
fields.body:
In the past 24 years my husband and I have adopted three children and fostered many others. We are part of a mostly silent majority of adopters who have gradually become more vocal in an attempt to stem the number of adoptions taking place. Yes, that's right: we want fewer children to be adopted. We want the bandwagon halted in its tracks until social services get their act together and stop destroying well-meaning families.

Mass adoption in this country took off from a US initiative in the late 50s that rolled over here within a decade. You may remember the accompanying slogan: "Every child has a right to a family." No in-depth research, no thought, just an evangelical crusade that brooked no doubts. Indeed, anyone advising caution was likely to be stoned to death as a heretic; I bear the scars to this day. But Armageddon has come to pass, and the care system in the US is today in crisis, with the UK's crisis perhaps five years behind.

The whole foundation of child adoption, as opposed to baby adoption, was that tender loving care by ordinary, warm-hearted individuals would produce happy, healthy children. Appeals were made to the emotions on television and in the newspapers, with little comments such as "may be attention-seeking" or "needs a lot of reassurance" - phrases that old hands would recognise as covering a multitude of difficulties, but which meant little or nothing to the unsuspecting viewers at whom they were aimed. On television these appeals, together with footage showing appealing, needy children that touched the heart and the conscience, as they were designed to do, were fronted by celebrities who are still on my personal hit list; to this day I can't look at a Jane Asher cake without wanting to throw it at her. Social services, we were told, weren't looking for some impossible ideal, but for the average family, for people with a lot of love to give, and we all like to think we have that.

The trouble was, and still is, that it is all a lie, because the majority of children in care are so damaged that ordinary, warm-hearted individuals have no hope of coping with them.

However much it goes against the zeal, not every child is adoptable. The breakdown rate in adoption began to soar, though to this day most social services will come over all coy and vague when asked to put a figure on it, and they never tell prospective adopters that breakdowns happen. But, for the record, a major study some years ago in Strathclyde region found that breakdowns escalated from around 16% if the child was adopted aged five, to 60% if the child was adopted at nine or older. There is no reason to suspect that other areas of Britain do any better.

In that study, three years was counted as a success but, as battle-scarred old sorts like me know, adoptions can break down after longer than that. There are lots of reasons, lots of problems, from constant lying, stealing and other forms of anti-social behaviour, to the most common: the inability of the child to form emotional attachment. Children in distress either sink or swim, and the swimmers often do so by looking out for number one. Families give affection and it is taken, often with demands for even more, but it can be debilitating and draining when little comes back, and even when it does, there may be strings attached. The children become users of others, portraying an affection they don't feel to get whatever they want. It's a common scenario and even understanding it doesn't necessarily make it any easier to cope with year after year.

My family's experiences are not unique; we have not been especially unlucky. There are a lot of us out there. Anyone who is told "it's just like having your own" should sue. Our son, Euan, was a baby adoption. We then fostered two girls, Louise and Marion, aged 30 months and 18 months respectively, adopting them five years later. Louise, was, according to the case social worker, "showing early signs of disturbance... she clings to people". How we laugh when we think back, however wryly. Believing that we were reclaiming a child with the potential to become a functioning human being, we sank most of our energies into Louise over the years, taking time and emotion from ourselves and our other two children. But gradually, as we unwound Louise's problems, we discovered more than we had been told. An officer from the Scottish Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children told us that Louise had been battered at 10 months by one of mummy's boyfriends because she wouldn't call him daddy, and after that she was noticed head-banging. Recognising this as a sign of brain damage, a health visitor informed social services who made an appointment for the mother to take Louise to hospital for a check-up. When she failed to turn up for three appointments they shrugged their caring shoulders and did nothing more. Neither did they tell us, her now adoptive parents, only confirming it when we found out. And that became the pattern; as we discovered some new horror they would confirm it, but nothing more was disclosed.

Life with Louise became more hellish as she grew and we kept in touch with social services, so they knew that our family life was under great stress. We were no longer looking for progress, we were trying to contain her increasingly bizarre behaviour. Our son, Euan, walked out of the house one day and didn't come back for the longest 36 hours of our lives, worn down and depressed by the strain of life with Louise. He was doing his Highers [the Scottish equivalent of A-levels] at the time. He failed them and left school. It took him three years to enrol at college to resit Highers and A levels, which meant that he started university later than he should have.

In the meantime, Louise had been diagnosed as psychotic at 16, and we realised that what we had been living with was the characteristic long, slow decline of schizophrenia-type illnesses. When I told the placing social worker he replied: "Well, that's hardly surprising, given her family history." He then unfolded the rest of her family history, which was riddled with mental illness. He hadn't disclosed it before, he said, "because no psychiatrist would give us official diagnoses on the other family members, due to patient confidentiality". Didn't it occur to him to tell us that there were grounds to ask for these diagnoses? And when did he find out, "officially"?

We have now found out the full extent of Louise's problems: brain damage consistent with violent shaking of a child under the age of one, a form of moderate to severe autism that can follow such injuries, and, of course, a psychosis that is only partially controlled by powerful drugs with their attendant side-effects. In the circumstances, confirmation of early sexual abuse somehow paled into insignificance. The prognosis is that she will never work, marry, have children or even be allowed out without an escort, and for the rest of her life she will need 24-hour care.

It was our belief that social services owed our other two children compensation for their ruined childhoods, and that they should make some kind of settlement to ensure Louise's future care; compensating my husband and me would be impossible. Their response has been to say that they think they're legally covered, that we should have sued within three years of finding out what they knew, three years when we were desperately trying to cope with a mentally ill child. And besides, they say, total disclosure wasn't policy when we adopted the girls in 1985 - not true, but it wastes more time on pointless correspondence. I know of adoptive parents in similar circumstances who have wasted four-figure sums involving lawyers in just this kind of stalling, the local authority happy in the knowledge that as a result they will have that much less to finance a court case. Legally covered, you see; morality doesn't come into it.

It doesn't stop there. Some years ago, as special foster parents, we took two boys, George, nine and Sandy, 12, both with varying degrees of foetal alcohol syndrome, which affected them both mentally and physically. It was our job to find out if they were adoptable and, if they were, to get them into an adoptable state. We quickly discovered that social services' greatest worry, that George had "problems of gender identification", was wide of the mark; he was anatomically male, but in his mind he was female. His femininity gave him access to the company of girls, but it soon became clear that he had much deeper psychological problems when we witnessed a variety of unprovoked attacks on girls, verbal, physical and sexual.

It was when he attacked Marion that we discovered what everyone else already knew: that this tendency was well-documented. They had placed an abusing boy in a family with two girls. Given George's problems and with puberty looming, we gave our opinion that he was not adoptable and that more attention should be focused on Sandy, who might be. We were so concerned that Sandy was being sacrificed to support his brother that we offered to adopt him. And that's when social services descended, removing both boys. You can't adopt if you don't have custody of the child. One social worker justified removing both boys with the remark: "After all, blood's thicker than water." Despite protestations that the boys would be placed with a family within months, both remained in care till their late teens, and Sandy never did find out that he could have been adopted. In fact, he died not knowing. It was just a small paragraph in a newspaper - murders are not uncommon in big cities these days. Sandy, aged 21, was attacked and stabbed with a sword. When he was released from care where could he go but back to the deprived, rundown, violent inner-city area he came from? There was nowhere else. Blood is indeed thicker than water, as those who had to hose Sandy's blood off the street doubtless noticed.

As old hands at adoption know, what matters most is not how young the children are, but what has happened to them in their lives, and the family history. You only have to think of how much a child learns in its first year to have some idea of the harm that can be done in that time. Social workers often say that the level of damage is not apparent for years, which is true, and so they go on placing ticking time bombs within unsuspecting families. Being childless and wanting a family or feeling sorry for these children are bad reasons for adopting. The only people who should take them on are those with an almost professional ability and knowledge; kindly, golden-hearted, warm, loving, ordinary people risk destroying themselves and their families.

Some placements do work out well, we know about those because they are always the ones trotted out as "examples". But there is no way of knowing if you are being told the full truth, or of predicting which placements will succeed, and finding out has destroyed many marriages and families. In recent years, as adopters have become more vocal about the fall-out of that misguided bandwagon from the US, and a new generation of social workers has replaced the mindless crusaders, adoption has slowed down. Not a bad thing, when you remember the extra damage done to children whose adoptions have failed, as well as the families they have scarred.

The sad fact, one that has been scorned out of ignorance and dogma, is that there are many children who are so damaged that they can only handle institutional care. But that doesn't mean the workhouse or years of abuse - it means that we have to look at providing different kinds of institutional care to suit the children who cannot cope with life within a family and cannot be coped with. The last thing we need now is another New Labour crusade of show without substance, a simplistic vote-enhancer for Tony, saviour of little children. Generations of children have suffered enough damage, as have families conned by nonsense about "tender loving care". Soundbite solutions are not the answer.

We quickly discovered that social services' greatest worry, that George had "problems of gender identification", was wide of the mark; he was anatomically male, but in his mind he was female. His femininity gave him access to the company of girls, but it soon became clear that he had much deeper psychological problems when we witnessed a variety of unprovoked attacks on girls, verbal, physical and sexual. It was when he attacked Marion that we discovered what everyone else already knew: that this tendency was well-documented. They had placed an abusing boy in a family with two girls. Given George's problems and with puberty looming, we gave our opinion that he was not adoptable and that more attention should be focused on Sandy, who might be. We were so concerned that Sandy was being sacrificed to support his brother that we offered to adopt him. And that's when social services descended, removing both boys. You can't adopt if you don't have custody of the child. One social worker justified removing both boys with the remark: "After all, blood's thicker than water." Despite protestations that the boys would be placed with a family within months, both remained in care till their late teens, and Sandy never did find out that he could have been adopted. In fact, he died not knowing. It was just a small paragraph in a newspaper - murders are not uncommon in big cities these days. Sandy, aged 21, was attacked and stabbed with a sword. When he was released from care where could he go but back to the deprived, rundown, violent inner-city area he came from? There was nowhere else. Blood is indeed thicker than water, as those who had to hose Sandy's blood off the street doubtless noticed. As old hands at adoption know, what matters most is not how young the children are, but what has happened to them in their lives, and the family history. You only have to think of how much a child learns in its first year to have some idea of the harm that can be done in that time. Social workers often say that the level of damage is not apparent for years, which is true, and so they go on placing ticking time bombs within unsuspecting families. Being childless and wanting a family or feeling sorry for these children are bad reasons for adopting. The only people who should take them on are those with an almost professional ability and knowledge; kindly, golden-hearted, warm, loving, ordinary people risk destroying themselves and their families. Some placements do work out well, we know about those because they are always the ones trotted out as "examples". But there is no way of knowing if you are being told the full truth, or of predicting which placements will succeed, and finding out has destroyed many marriages and families. In recent years, as adopters have become more vocal about the fall-out of that misguided bandwagon from the US, and a new generation of social workers has replaced the mindless crusaders, adoption has slowed down. Not a bad thing, when you remember the extra damage done to children whose adoptions have failed, as well as the families they have scarred. The sad fact, one that has been scorned out of ignorance and dogma, is that there are many children who are so damaged that they can only handle institutional care. But that doesn't mean the workhouse or years of abuse - it means that we have to look at providing different kinds of institutional care to suit the children who cannot cope with life within a family and cannot be coped with. The last thing we need now is another New Labour crusade of show without substance, a simplistic vote-enhancer for Tony, saviour of little children. Generations of children have suffered enough damage, as have families conned by nonsense about "tender loving care". Soundbite solutions are not the answer.

fields.headline: Time to face facts, Ken
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: As Ken Livingstone ponders the question of whether or not to stand as an independent against the Labour candidate in the forthcoming mayoral elections in London, a few facts need to be borne in mind.
fields.body:
As Ken Livingstone ponders the question of whether or not to stand as an independent against the Labour candidate in the forthcoming mayoral elections in London, a few facts need to be borne in mind.

If he does decide to stand, his argument will be that he was robbed of the Labour party selection contest by a stitch-up using the block vote of the AEEU and the Co- operative Wholesale Society. This was the argument used by Ken when the result was announced on Sunday and his justification for describing the result as "tainted". It is also the argument used by Paul Foot in yesterday's Guardian and has become common currency in the debate over the mayor. Indeed the very fact an electoral college was used has become code for saying the selection was unfairly conducted.

First of all, the electoral college is not new. It has been in use in the Labour party for many years. It was not just used in Scotland and Wales. It was also used to elect Neil Kinnock, Roy Hattersley and John Smith, as well as Tony Blair and John Prescott of course. Going back even further, the electoral college was used in the 1981 titanic battle for the deputy leadership between Tony Benn and Denis Healey. Unlike Frank, Denis Healey really did win by a whisker. But Tony Benn, to his credit, never even hinted that he would consider walking away, leaving the party and running as an independent.

When the electoral college was introduced it was defended by Ken and his allies as reflecting the federal nature of the party - unions, party members and elected representatives. And indeed that is one of its strengths. But, goes the next argument, the electoral college was misused in London. Ken's supporters will say that in earlier instances all unions who took part balloted their members.

It is true that not all unions balloted their members in London. But it is not true that this delivered the result for Frank Dobson. Where union ballots took place, in most cases the unions did not split their votes in the way the Labour members section was divided. Thus in ballot after ballot which Ken won, he was able to ratchet up 100% of each union's vote while Frank and Glenda received 0%.

A telling fact about the so-called stitch-up is that if every union had split their vote in the way that the GMB, for example, did, Frank Dobson's margin of victory would have been even higher. This remains true even if those organisations which did not ballot had done so and Ken won these ballots by a margin of four to one.

The second objection to the electoral college is that the MPs, MEPs and candidates section swung it for Frank. But does anyone really argue that the candidates who are to campaign alongside the mayor should not have a big say in who the candidate is? One reason that Tony Blair did not argue for straight one member one vote in the past for leadership contests is that he believes, as do the vast majority of MPs, that you cannot have a party leader who does not have the confidence of the PLP. The same applies in London.

It is a complete myth to say that the electoral college is either an illegitimate method of selection or that its operation delivered the selection unfairly for Frank Dobson. His margin of victory was reduced by the inclusion of MPs and MEPs and by union after union allocating 100% of their vote to Ken as long as he won more than 50% in their ballots.

So let us move on from the misplaced accusations of a stitch-up and focus on the real issue this week - will Ken run as an independent or not? To complain about a result is one thing, but to walk away and run against the party is to place yourself outside the party for ever.

It is a step I would never contemplate, nor would the vast majority of Labour's members, be they on the right or the left. The question of Ken running as an independent has been raised time and time again over the past few months and he ruled it out absolutely. He also assured the selection board: "I am happy to confirm, as I have done on so many occasions that, if Frank Dobson wins the vote in the electoral college - however narrowly - I will support his campaign for mayor."

It is time for the speculation to stop. Labour deserves better than the events of the past few days. We have a candidate now and Frank Dobson deserves better than to be undermined in this way. It is time the nonsense stopped and all of us, including Ken, backed Frank for mayor - as he promised.

 Ian McCartney is cabinet office minister

webTitle: OFT edict plays to captive audience

fields.headline: OFT edict plays to captive audience
fields.standfirst:
News Analysis Lenders are unhappy about all the regulatory cooks in the mortgage kitchen
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Anger at the growing number of regulatory cooks in the mortgage kitchen grew yesterday after the office of fair trading issued a broadside against the embattled loans industry - but failed to identify any company breaking its rules or to name any "victims".
fields.body:
Anger at the growing number of regulatory cooks in the mortgage kitchen grew yesterday after the office of fair trading issued a broadside against the embattled loans industry - but failed to identify any company breaking its rules or to name any "victims".

A strongly worded document from the OFT declared that the "unrestricted rights of banks and building societies to change interest rates are unacceptable". Does this mean no more increases in mortgage rates without OFT approval? Will banks be forced to keep savings rates more in line with the Bank of England base rate?

Not quite. The announcement amounted largely to preventing lenders from keeping interest rates unacceptably high on loans where borrowers are locked in beyond the end of a fixed-rate period. For example, someone takes a 5% fix for two years but is tied in for five years, during which time the lender pushes the rate up to 10%.

But what appears to be good news for consumers bears little scrutiny. Mortgage lock-ins or "penalty overhangs" now make up a small part of the mortgage market. Abbey National, for example, ditched its lock-in penalties two years ago. "It's not an issue for us or any of the major lenders," said a spokesman.

The OFT said it had found contracts which allowed banks to change terms "to maintain the profitability of the bank" or "in the interests of shareholders". But it was unable to supply details of which institutions have such contracts and admitted receiving no more than a handful of complaints.

Mortgage industry bosses shrugged off the announcement, but some are becoming increasingly weary about the tone and direction of mortgage regulation.

"It's a macho way of saying something fairly obvious," said Tim Sweeney, director general of the British Bankers' Association.

Adrian Coles, director general of the Building Societies' Association, said: "Regulators typically look at last year's problems rather than next year's."

At issue is the explosion in bodies that now bang the consumer drum on mortgage regulation.

The treasury, the department of trade and industry, the financial services authority, the department of the environment, transport and the regions, the mortgage code compliance board, the OFT and the consumers' association are all empowered to issue edicts over mortgage advice, products and terms. And the industry still awaits Don Cruickshank's report into competition between lenders, expected next month.

Mr Coles said: "The treasury recently had an opportunity to put it all under the FSA, but they didn't, and it's just something we have to live with."

The kindest words he could find for yesterday's OFT announcement was that it "codified" industry practices that changed two years ago.

Under the guidance, banks will not be restricted in how they set interest rates, but will have to make it clear how interest rates may vary in future.

Yesterday the OFT insisted that its new guidelines will have relevance to consumers. A spokesman said: "The guidance comes from extensive consultation with banks and building societies which all saw a draft before we released it. The number of complaints we have received is not huge because people don't necessarily know that the contracts are unfair. It's our view that there are still some stragglers out there with these terms, and the consumers' association are endorsing our guidance."

The OFT says the guidance came out of the Northern Rock case in 1997. The bank infuriated its savers after moving thousands who thought they were in a "best buy" account into lower-paying products without warning. The former building society recanted after intervention by the OFT.

"Many banks and building societies have already improved their contract terms following the action I took against Northern Rock early in 1998. Regrettably there are stragglers who have yet to strike a fair balance in the terms that allow them to change interest rates," said the director general of fair trading, John Bridgeman.

Even Northern Rock was yesterday scratching its head about the OFT's announcement.

Executive director Adam Applegarth said: "The days of potential unfairness to tied-in customers have gone. We learnt the lessons the hard way at the start of 1998 our savers and borrowers are already protected."
