webTitle: 25,000 Unilever jobs go in cull of brands

fields.headline: 25,000 Unilever jobs go in cull of brands
fields.standfirst: FitzGerald attacks City's obsession with the internet
fields.trailText: Unilever is to chop 25,000 jobs and shut 100 factories worldwide as part of a huge restructuring to improve competitiveness.
fields.body:
Unilever is to chop 25,000 jobs and shut 100 factories worldwide as part of a huge restructuring to improve competitiveness.

Most of the jobs will go in Europe and North America alongside the ditching of 1,200 of its 1,600 brands, including household names such as Pear's soap, Radion washing powder and Jif lemons .

The company will spend £3.3bn over the next five years shaking up the food and household product group but the changes could go further.

The entire bakery division is on notice to meet tough new targets or be hived off. The Elizabeth Arden cosmetic business could face a similar threat if a restructuring fails there.

Chairman Niall FitzGerald said Unilever was committed to squeezing out 6% volume growth from its 400 power brands "and a further significant expansion of margins from 11% to 15%".

He believes the shake-up will produce annual savings of £1bn but he would not give details of exactly where the job losses - one tenth of the company's total - would fall. Britain has already been at the forefront of partial restructuring so industry experts expect the food sector in Germany to be one particular victim of change.

Unilever is to concentrate on improving its supply chain by focusing on 150 key manufac turing plants. And it plans to make much greater use of the internet not only for procurement but also for building closer relationships with customers.

Around £450m of extra marketing will be put behind global brands such as Calvin Klein fragrances, Lipton Tea and Magnum Ice Cream. Local jewels such as Persil washing powder and Colmans mustard in Britain will also be pushed heavily.

The City welcomed the move, marking up the share price 6% in early trading and it ended the day up 5p at 391p. Unilever's price has sunk from a 52-week high of 699p as the Anglo-Dutch group has produced low levels of return.

Mr FitzGerald blamed the City's obsession with internet stocks for some of the decline. He said: "Our business is not based on potential or promise but on the continuing reality that each week, month and year there are more people who need nutritious food, clean homes and personal health."

But his own company's shortcomings were underlined yesterday with pre-tax profits for 1999 falling 5% to £2.9bn while sales rose only 2% to £27.6bn. But optimism about the future led to a final dividend of 8.75p, bringing a total for the year up 11% in real terms.

Margins improved and sales growth was stronger than expected in the fourth quarter with recovery in south-east Asia but continued high marketing costs in south America where Unilever is fighting a costly detergent war with arch-rival Procter & Gamble took their toll.

Unilever has also been challenged in the US ice cream business because of increased competition. But Mr FitzGerald said heavy marketing would help his company win back market share.

David Lang, analyst at Investec Henderson Crosthwaite, said Unilever was moving in the right direction having lost ground in the past. "Its a very radical move - perhaps the biggest in the company's history.

"The basic problem has been an inefficient supply chain with all attention on the brands but Unilever now seems determined to be cost-effective."

Union leaders were seeking urgent talks to find out how many jobs in the UK are threatened by the announcement.

Sir Ken Jackson, general secretary of the Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union, said he feared Britain's reluctance to join the euro had played a part in the decision.

But a spokesman for Mr FitzGerald - a euro-enthusiast like Sir Ken - denied this.

fields.headline: Soap sales slipped away
fields.trailText: There is great interest from collectors in Victorian Pears soap adverts but declining demand for the product, writes Terry Macalister . Yesterday Unilever washed its hands of Pears saying it was not one of its 400 "power" brands on which the future of the group will be built.
fields.body:
There is great interest from collectors in Victorian Pears soap adverts but declining demand for the product, writes Terry Macalister . Yesterday Unilever washed its hands of Pears saying it was not one of its 400 "power" brands on which the future of the group will be built.

It was named after Soho hairdresser Andrew Pears who patented its revolutionary transparent design around 1789. It was manufactured for much of last century at Unilever's Port Sunlight plant in Birkenhead, but for the last few years it has been available in Britain only from a factory in India. Marketing has dropped to almost zero.

In Victorian times the adverts were everywhere. Typical of their message was this one from 1897: "Every tablet of Pears Soap is kept at least 12 months before it is sold. This can be said of no other soap in the world, and good soap, like wine, improves with age."

Pears has struggled to take 3% of a British soap market worth £127m a year. By contrast one of the favoured 400 brands, Dove soap, has a 22% market share.

Other brands killed off by the Anglo-Dutch conglomerate include Radion and Harmony hair spray. Radion, most famous for its shocking orange packets, was launched barely 10 years ago but has struggled to capture more than 2% of a British detergent market worth £900m a year.

It is to be amalgamated by Unilever into its Surf brand and will continue under the banner Surf Sun Fresh. Surf has a 6% market share but this has been growing fast.

As global competition increases, Unilever says it must concentrate research and marketing spend on a small number of dominant brands. So you'll see more of Lynx, but more likely on the internet than in exquisitely hand painted poster designs.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText:
House prices rise 15%

House prices in England and Wales are rising at their fastest annual rate since 1996, according to figures published today by the Land Registry. The data shows that the average house price in the last quarter of 1999 rose 15.2% compared with the same quarter of 1998, from £83,905 to £96,687. The volume of sales increased by 19% from 206,611 in the final quarter of 1998 to 245,876 in the final quarter of 1999. Central London prices are still the fastest rising, with the average property up 23% over 12 months from £128,083 to £157,624. The lowest percentage rise came in the north, where the average property value went up just 5.24% from £58,617 to £61,689.

Iceland sets GM-free pace

All meat and meat products on the shelves of Iceland supermarkets from September will be produced from herds reared on feed that contains no genetically modified ingredients, the supermarket chain said yesterday.

Iceland sets GM-free pace

All meat and meat products on the shelves of Iceland supermarkets from September will be produced from herds reared on feed that contains no genetically modified ingredients, the supermarket chain said yesterday.

The new non-GM meat will not cost more than the ranges already stocked. webTitle: Barclays to import iShares from Canada

fields.headline: Barclays to import iShares from Canada
fields.trailText: Barclays Global Investors is expected to announce tomorrow the creation of a new type of stock market investment known as iShare.
fields.body:
Barclays Global Investors is expected to announce tomorrow the creation of a new type of stock market investment known as iShare.

The move by the fund management arm of Barclays is expected to encourage investors to put their money in "index-tracking" strategies followed by the iShares, which will be listed on the London stock exchange.

The iShares will be similar to products that BGI is already selling to investors in Canada. Officially known as "exchange-traded funds", the launch of the products in Canada late last year has already prompted BGI to plan to unveil 51 similar investments in the United States later this year.

The arrival of iShares in Britain is expected to mark a new way of investing in the stock market for both private and professional investors. The products are different to existing unit trusts and investment funds in the way they are traded and the expected lower fees paid to the investment manager, in this case BGI.

But, they are also different to these more familiar products in that they allow investors to adopt more sophisticated trading strategies because iShares can be bought "on margin", allowing investors to borrow money to pay for them.

BGI, which refused to comment yesterday, is expected to announce plans to unveil a whole range of products based on traditional indices as well as internet stocks.

By buying the iShares, investors will have almost instantaneous access to which ever stock market index is tracking rather than the delay they now experience by buying traditional unit trusts or investment trusts.

The iShares - known in Canada as iUnits - might prompt fears of greater distortion in the stock market where index-tracking funds are said to be behind the rise in demand for big stocks in the major indices.

Index tracking involves buying shares to replicate an in dex as opposed to "active" fund managers which make decisions about which stocks to buy and sell on their merits.

The success of these exchanged-traded funds in Canada was highlighted by Matt Barrett, Barclays new Irish-Canadian chief executive last week at the bank's 1999 profits presentation as a reason for the business achieved by BGI.

BGI, based in San Francisco, is already one of the world's biggest fund management groups, more than $680bn (£421.4bn) of assets for investors, most of which is in so-called index-tracking products.

While the group has apparently had some success with the exchange-traded funds in the North American market, where investors are more prevalent, Barclays has had a checkered history at launching new products in Britain. For instance, its b2 investment products launched two years ago have repeatedly been said by rivals to be an expensive mistake.

webTitle: Copycats could bet against Buffett's book

fields.headline: Copycats could bet against Buffett's book
fields.standfirst: Investment guru takes a tumble
fields.trailText: According to Wall Street's Buffettologists, the most famous investment vehicle in the United States, Berkshire Hathaway, is now trading at a slight discount to book value. In simple terms, then, the market no longer ascribes a premium to the world's foremost "value" investor.
fields.body:
According to Wall Street's Buffettologists, the most famous investment vehicle in the United States, Berkshire Hathaway, is now trading at a slight discount to book value. In simple terms, then, the market no longer ascribes a premium to the world's foremost "value" investor.

Warren Buffett has delivered compound annual returns of just under 25% during the past 35 years, and in that time a whole copycat investment and publishing industry has been built up around a man whom many consider to be the greatest investor of all time.

But his stock-picking "value" today amounts to nothing more than a sum of the parts: the stakes in Coca-Cola, Gillette, the couple of wholly owned insurance companies - among them America's biggest, General Re - and various other bits and bobs, including a small holding in British Allied Domecq.

Today, if somebody were to post a message on an internet investment bulletin board saying: "watch the sage", the chat room would assume this was a reference to the UK accountancy software group.

Its shares are up fivefold over the past year while the Omaha man's stock has almost halved. Two years ago Mr Buffett had to warn his followers that they were paying unrealistic prices for shares in Berkshire Hathaway, explaining that the unwieldy size of the fund made it increasingly difficult to maintain his past record of extraordinary returns.

At the time, the investment company's "market to book" ratio stood at four times - investors valued some $25bn of assets at over $100bn, simply because Mr Buffett was in charge of them.

Two years on Berkshire is reduced to issuing public statements refuting market rumours that the 69-year-old sage is ill and wants to retire. The market to book ratio stands at around one, give or take a few hundred million dollars.

What has gone wrong is that Mr Buffett does not understand technology stocks - and he has told everyone that he is not going to invest in something he does not understand. He said something similar 31 years ago. Declaring that the market looked a bit potty to him and not wanting to damage the storming investment record he had already achieved, Mr Buffett liquidated most of his holdings and took a four-year breather before going on a bargain-hunting binge during the violent bear market of 1973 to 1974.

Of course we now have both a raging bull market and nasty bear market - the so-called split market.

Since its mid-January high, the Dow Jones has fallen 13%, while the technology-rich Nasdaq composite index has soared 16% from its new year low. The trend in London is the same, only more pronounced, with the FTSE 100 off some 13% and the Techmark 100 up a huge 41%.

Those caught on the wrong side of investor sentiment are squealing: only yesterday Unilever chairman Niall FitzGerald was in the driest of form, explaining how his company made, rather than promised, investment returns on the back of supplying "people who need nutritious food, clean homes and personal health".

Mr Buffett could make similar claims: people need to shave, they are advised to insure themselves and they will drink cola, whatever the prevailing bandwidth in data communications. Berkshire Hathaway in its regular A form is a "chunky" stock, trading in units of $51,000 each - although there is a pocket-sized B version of the shares which costs £1,700.

If you have managed to make a mint in cyberspace a contrary side-bet on the stock-picking skills of Mr Buffett has rarely appeared so tempting.

For art's sake

Britain's permanent representatives at the European Union may be looking more than usually sheepish this week after yesterday's convulsions at Sotheby's.

These are the men and women charged with pleading with Eurocrats not to slap their droit de suite tax on Bond Street, arguing that giving artists and their descendants a cut every time a painting is sold will do little to help struggling creators and much to destroy Europe's only world class art market - London.

In the middle of these critical negotiations it emerges that Bond Street's finest - Christie's and Sotheby's - allegedly spent the mid-1990s cheerfully colluding in fixing the rates of commissions charged to sellers. Neither, of course, is British-owned these days, but they remain the flagships of the London art scene.

Adding to this unedifying spectacle is Christie's decision in January to turn state's evidence in the United States in return for an amnesty. That will not play well with the Eurocrats, if only because of French-owned Christie's lack of Euro-patriotism in not cutting such a deal first with the Brussels enforcers at present conducting their own inquiry.

One final point: in the mid-1990s there was a lot of huffing and puffing about how ruthlessly competitive Bond Street had become; now we learn the other side of the story. The lesson? On Bond Street it is quite possible to have plenty of smoke and very little fire.

fields.headline: Wimpey offers the bespoke house
fields.standfirst: Builder says factory pre-packing will cut construction time from 13 to six weeks
fields.trailText: Fancy ordering a bespoke detached home, arranging a mortgage and reaching completion within, say, six weeks? According to George Wimpey, the housebuilder, you will be able to do so soon.
fields.body:
Fancy ordering a bespoke detached home, arranging a mortgage and reaching completion within, say, six weeks? According to George Wimpey, the housebuilder, you will be able to do so soon.

Later this year on two sites in Essex, Wimpey will put up factory-made homes for Guinness Trust, a housing association, which will come with fitted carpets and can be assembled in a couple of days.

Dennis Brant, Wimpey's chief executive, sees the revo lutionary concept being rolled out into the private sector where an increasingly wealthy population is demanding detached homes designed and built to their own specification.

The houses, complete with steel frame to allow maximum loft space, will be assembled in four or five modules which will be delivered to sites where the foundations and pipes and wires have already been laid. They take 4 to 6 weeks to build in the factory compared with 13 weeks for a traditional house.

Unveiling a 33% rise in 1999 pre-tax profits to £112.8m, Mr Brant said the new concept homes could help encourage more young people into the construction industry and promote the "de-skilling and multi-skilling" under way.

A government task force led by Sir John Egan demanded 18 months ago that the industry clean up its act, condemning shoddy profits, filthy sites and downtrodden employees.

By moving the building of homes to modern, air-conditioned factories, Mr Brant said, more young people would be attracted to the industry - and discover that the old craft skills were no longer needed while flexibility reigned supreme.

Mr Brant also disclosed that a growing number of home-buyers are moving online, with Wimpey reporting 750 sales leads a month and a 300% increase in visits to its website in the past year.

The group - which wrote off £4m last September because of accounting irregularities and has seen its shares slide in recent years - said it was on course to beat its targets ahead of schedule. The shares rose 1p to 109p yesterday.

webTitle: CA to aid small firms overcharged by their banks

fields.headline: CA to aid small firms overcharged by their banks
fields.trailText: Only weeks after announcing it is to sell cars, the Consumers Association is moving into another area of business.
fields.body:
Only weeks after announcing it is to sell cars, the Consumers Association is moving into another area of business.

It has bought a company specialising in helping small firms overcharged by banks in the first of a possible range of services for some 3.5m small businesses.

The lobby group denied it was moving away from its focus on consumers, adding that they would remain its "prime focus". The CA's trading arm Which? has bought auditing company Anglia Business Associates for an undisclosed sum. It is only the second acquisition in its 43-year history.

Anglia Business Associates, based near Norwich, was founded seven years ago by American businessman Mark Radin and now employs 17 staff - most of whom are former bank managers. It specialises in auditing bank statements for overcharging errors and helping firms recover their money for a fee.

The CA said it aims to build up the service offered by the company, and added that its business was "entirely consistent with the Consumers' Association's mission".

However, some observers said the deal could send rela tions between the CA and the banking industry plunging to a new low.

Anglia Business Associates has frequently clashed with banks over its claims that customers are being overcharged to the tune of billions of pounds. It says it uncovers errors in three-quarters of the cases it examines.

The CA has already locked horns with the high street banks over issues such as un fair mortgage terms and cash machine charges, but said that "good banks have nothing to fear" as a result of this latest initiative. "We are not anti-bank," added Dave Roberts, commercial director.

Small firms are an important group of consumers, he said, and the CA may develop the service. "There are various needs the small and medium-sized enterprises sector has that we might be able to service."

fields.headline: Vanguard Medica
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: A change of name is often a ploy used by companies trying to leave behind their disappointing histories.
fields.body:
A change of name is often a ploy used by companies trying to leave behind their disappointing histories.

Cynics might suggest this is the case with Vanguard Medica, which will soon reinvent itself as Vernalis Group. The new name comes from the verb "to vernalise", a term meaning nurture or develop.

Vanguard certainly needs treatment - its recent history has been littered with delays and setbacks. In 1998, the group abandoned two psoriasis medicines and a drug for kidney failure - which was axed because patients could not stand its taste.

Then last year, Vanguard's lead product - migraine treatment frovatriptan - was held up by US regulators, which wanted more clinical trials.

The share price came close to 700p in 1997. Yesterday's closing price was 235p, up 27p, which now values the business at £77m.

Under pressure from institutional shareholders, chief executive Robert Mansfield has made big changes. He bought Cerebrus, a private company developing cancer drugs, for £9.6m in December, and began a review of the combined group's development pipeline.

The conclusions, which came out yesterday, involve shelving products for asthma, Alzheimer's disease and malaria. Instead, the company will concentrate on products tackling cancer and the central nervous system.

Vanguard is trying to get investors excited about possible treatments for obesity and Parkinson's disease. The market for both is huge. For example, 15% of Britons and a third of Americans are classified as obese. However, both are yet to begin clinical trials and they are at least five years away from commercial launch. The real story surrounds frovatriptan, which could be on sale in Europe this year and is considered an improvement on Glaxo Wellcome's drug Imigram, which has annual sales of £700m.

Vanguard is still likely to lose £20m this year but it can look forward to revenue as it finds partners.

webTitle: PwC fears bank report will focus too much on past

fields.headline: PwC fears bank report will focus too much on past
fields.trailText: Don Cruickshank's report into banking competition could damage the sector and exacerbate financial exclusion if it focuses too much on the past, a report by consultant PricewaterhouseCoopers says today.
fields.body:
Don Cruickshank's report into banking competition could damage the sector and exacerbate financial exclusion if it focuses too much on the past, a report by consultant PricewaterhouseCoopers says today.

Angus Hislop, head of UK banking at PwC, said that by scrutinising historical data from the big banks Mr Cruickshank, head of the government's banking review, might overlook new threats to bank profitability from the internet and open European markets.

PwC's anxieties have been aroused by the fact that Mr Cruickshank - who is expected to publish his report next month after more than a year of investigation - has spent months collecting back data from banks on the profitability of their products and the distribution of their customer base.

"Government fears that there is not enough competition in UK banking might have been true in the past ... Our report shows the internet posing the biggest opportunity and the biggest threat to UK retail banking," Mr Hislop said.

The PwC report, The Breaking Wave, says that by focusing on competition among banks the report could be in conflict with other government objectives on social justice, the promotion of technology and financial stability.

The report tells the banking industry to be more open about its products, particularly in terms of price. In this way, banks might set the agenda rather than have it thrust upon them by government.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.body:
Telecoms almost singlehandedly saved the FTSE from falling below the psychological 6000 barrier by close of trading. Strong demand for Vodafone and BT allowed the index to regain almost half of Monday's 1.4% loss by lunchtime as it traded up at 6126.5.

However, early strength from Wall Street quickly seeped away and by the London close the FTSE was down 66.9 at 6014.7, not far off the session low of 6002.7 just before the end of trading.

Vodafone did most to keep heads up, with heavy trading ahead of another re-weighting. The shares climbed 33.5p to 344p after announcing it had 88.91% Mannes mann share acceptances. The second tranche of Vodafone shares to fund the Mannesmann acquisition became ef fective at the close of trading yesterday and demand pushed the price up further.

BT climbed 50p to £11.01 amid rumours of a radical restructuring aimed at boosting the share price to as much as £20.

fields.headline: Ay, Carmela!
fields.standfirst: Edie Falco was just another jobbing actress. Then she got a contract with the mob and her life changed. Stuart Jeffries meets the Sopranos star as she makes her West End debut
fields.trailText: Edie Falco was just another jobbing actress. Then she got a contract with the mob and her life changed. Stuart Jeffries meets the Sopranos star as she makes her West End debut
fields.body:
The woman centre stage looks pissed off. She's trying to play this Debussy thing on the flute but she can't get it right. Then, backstage, a trumpet begins to play, not just the Prélude à l'après midi d'un faune, but a sensual, cool jazz variation on its theme. The sort of playing that can turn a girl's head. "Shit," says the flautist. She'll never be as good a musician as the side man who is even now coming centre stage, bent on wooing her.

Terry, this wannabe jazzer's moll, is a lovely paradox: a foul-mouthed ingénue with a Noo Yawk twang and a trucker's diction, who doesn't understand the heroin addiction prevalent among certain jazz musicians. She's tough but winningly vulnerable.

This is the first time we see Edie Falco in Side Man, the West End transfer of an award-winning Broadway show. Warren Leight's autobiographical play is about the trials and tribulations of male jazzers in New York, from their 50s heyday to their 80s nadir, and the women who loved them. It's dramatised from the perspective of Terry's son, here played by former TV sexpot, Jason Priestley.

Falco, who played Terry in the original off-Broadway production, knew this milieu and empathised with Leight's biography. "My father used to be in a band. Frankie Falco and his Orchestra. They used to play the Catskills. He had hundreds of obscure jazz records. My mother, too, was a creative person, an actress. So I understand the tension of an artistic household.

"I read the play and I thought 'I know this world'. What could be more beautiful than to play a different angle on that world and suss out a character's motivation? It's an incredible therapy." Perhaps by working on this play she could, just as the playwright Leight did, understand her parents and what they endured.

During Side Man we watch Terry over four decades of a difficult marriage to a man who is passionate about his art and, less frequently, about her. She's a woman forever on the fuzzy end of the lollipop, often disappointed, bitterly inhaling a cigarette with angrily crossed arms, and exhaling out razor-sharp put downs.

Falco seems to have specialised in pissed-off women who are slightly but significantly older than herself (she's 46). In The Sopranos, for instance, she plays Carmela, the wife of screwed-up mobster Tony. "I don't have a kid myself, but for me to imagine having a 17-year-old daughter in real life - that's too much!" She won the best actress award at last year's Emmys and a Golden Globe for the best performance by an actress in a dramatic television series for the part.

In the first series of this mafia comedy-drama, she had a thing going with the local priest. While Tony was out unburdening himself to his sexy shrink, Carmela was at home watching a DVD of the Remains of the Day with Father Phil, hoping that he might stop being a servant of the Lord for one evening at least.

But, at the end of the series, she turned on this clergyman who appeared to want to seduce her and eat all her Italian-American delicacies, delivering one of the best put-downs in recent TV. "I really appreciate everything you've done for me," she tells the priest, "the religious counselling, the book on Buddhism. But I think you need to look at yourself, because you have this MO where you manipulate spiritually thirsty women and I think a lot of that is tied up with food somehow as well as the sexual tension game." Father Phil, devastated by this acute character analysis, shrinks from the Sopranos' house.

In Oz, like The Sopranos a Home Box Office-produced drama that has found a niche in British TV viewers' hearts, she plays a double-shifting single mother prison guard, a role which Falco understood from her "resting" periods. It was, she recognised, "another service-type job in a polyester uniform", just like the waitressing jobs that used to tide her over when off-Broadway shows and indie films didn't pay the rent. This wasn't a career path she hankered to pursue: "You would bring a fajita to someone and they would go: 'I saw you in so and so.' Horrifying."

Falco puts down her coffee and takes a drag on her Malboro Light. She's started smoking again after three years, partly because it's easier to smoke in public in London than in New York. Which, for me, is nice, because now she looks something like the stereotype I've created in my head, all smoke-cloud sexuality and caffeinated brittleness. Annoyingly, though, she isn't a disappointed woman in real life. She doesn't even have Carmela's long nails or her penchant for liberally applied make up or pastels. She's swathed in cream to rhyme with her blonde hair, that problematic signifier of her Italian-Swedish heritage that has deprived her, she says, of Italian-American roles that have in the past gone to dark-haired actresses like Annabella Sciorra and Marisa Tomei.

Why is a woman with a finally burgeoning acting career working in London? After all, she's pining for her dog Marley, not to mention her boyfriend, actor-director John Devlin. Why come to Shaftesbury Avenue when she's the talk of US TV-land? A lot of people tried to talk her out of working in London: "My agent was like, 'if you have to'. It didn't make sense in career terms. But I have been so successful in following my heart. I have made a lot of terrible career decisions. But this is what I want to do as an actor: there are stories I want to help tell, experiences I want to have.

"I wasn't sure that the play would work here: the jokes are so specific to New York. But the previews I've done indicate to me that they get the references. What's surprised me is that the audiences are even more ebullient than the best New York crowds. I thought they would be reserved!

"As a kid in Long Island, I was like, 'don't even bother dreaming of going to London'. It was a place where theatre is revered, the home of acting, and it was so far beyond me it was untrue. So when the opportunity presented itself, there wasn't a choice for me. It was just a matter of working out my schedule so I could do it."

There is another advantage to working in London for five months. In New York, she cannot now walk to the supermarket without someone hugging her and assuming that she is Carmela Soprano. "There must be actresses who pursue the career for that end result. I'm not one of them. I love it here because nobody gives a shit who you are. Jason Priestley [the former Beverly Hills 90210 star who plays her son in Side Man] gets all the crowds here."

Why does she specialise in these bitter, frustrated women? "I don't want to be critical but you get casting directors who aren't very imaginative. When I was at college, I'd get Diane Keaton-type kooky roles because of a role I once played. Later I played a tough Brooklyn wife in my friend Nick Gomez's film Laws of Gravity and they must have thought - this is what Edie does. Now I'm apparently bitter. But they're roles, not me.

"What I like about the roles I have been playing lately is that they are substantial. As Terry I grow up on stage, go through this emotional journey. There's been a lot said about how there aren't many substantial roles for actresses and I seem to have sidestepped that problem. Part of the appeal with The Sopranos is that these are real people. True, sometimes we want to watch shows about beautiful people which have nothing to do with our lives, but a lot of the time we want to see people who suffer like us and fail like us. With The Sopranos I think you have that." Apart, to be sure, from having to shoot people and wear wires for the Feds.

This is a good time for Falco, but it wasn't always thus. In the early 90s, she seemed stuck playing bit parts for independent film directors like Hal Hartley (she was in Trust and The Unbelievable Truth) and Abel Ferrara (The Funeral and The Addiction). She played Marge Gunderson in a TV spin-off pilot for the Coen brothers' film Fargo, but perhaps because it's difficult to imagine Falco eclipsing Frances McDormand's "Minnesota nice", it remained a pilot.

What's more, Side Man didn't seem to offer a path to fame. It started as a cosy group of New York actors enjoying themselves in a play that seemed destined to remain off-Broadway. She was recruited because Marisa Tomei dropped out. They played tiny venues in upstate New York, and never dreamed of Broadway, or of basking in the glory of Tony awards or being reviewed by John Lahr in the New Yorker. These things came (playwright Leight and Frank Wood, who plays the title role, won Tonys last year), but not to Falco. She had to quit the production before it transferred to Broadway because she had been contracted to play Carmela, only returning when the production transferred to another Broadway theatre.

"It was crazy. I had to sign a six year contract just to make the pilot. Fortunately the pilot was a success so we made 13 episodes." The Sopranos became a huge hit in the US, where the second series is being broadcast to rave reviews, and a cult show here. When Falco finishes her run on the London stage she returns to Queens and New Jersey to start work on the third series. She'll also be working on a new series of Oz later this year.

"I figure that in December 2001 I might get a vacation. That at least is my fantasy. I've been working for three and a half years at a breakneck pace, which is a change from all those years where I was struggling to work at all. I guess this is payback time. Big payback time." She grins. This is not a pissed off woman at all.

 Side Man opens at the Apollo Theatre, London W1 (0171-494 5511), on Monday.

fields.headline: Poor teen, fifteen, sixteen . . .
fields.standfirst: Homelessness, unemployment and poverty among the young must be addressed before they become the parents of the next generation
fields.trailText: Disaffected, disadvantaged and jobless young people have had a good innings so far in terms of New Labour's policy initiatives. There is the New Deal to get 18 to 24-year-olds into work, Youth Offending Teams, and new help for those leaving council care. Recently, a national Youth Support Service under the brand name Connexions was announced. It is intended to "re-connect" young people and education, seen as the main avenue for including them into society.
fields.body:
Disaffected, disadvantaged and jobless young people have had a good innings so far in terms of New Labour's policy initiatives. There is the New Deal to get 18 to 24-year-olds into work, Youth Offending Teams, and new help for those leaving council care. Recently, a national Youth Support Service under the brand name Connexions was announced. It is intended to "re-connect" young people and education, seen as the main avenue for including them into society.

Now employment minister Tessa Jowell is also looking at the transition to adulthood of young people at risk as part of the 2000 comprehensive spending review. Increasingly the Blair government sees that substantially the same group of marginalised or excluded young people - roughly 10% of the age cohort - are at risk of homelessness, offending, lack of basic skills, unemployment, dependency and early pregnancy. They are on the receiving end of too many uncoordinated interventions with too few positive outcomes.

Young people in the United Kingdom get a worse start than many of their contemporaries elsewhere in Europe. As the chart shows, the UK is near the bottom of the European league in the proportion of young people leaving school with low level qualifications, the proportion of 18-year-olds still in education and the numbers of young homeless. Becoming a self-sufficient adult is harder than it was 20 years ago. Then, nearly half of school leavers went straight into jobs - now it is less than one in ten.

It is alarming, too, how homelessness, unwanted pregnancy and drug and alcohol abuse affect ever younger people. The mean age at which cannabis gets used has fallen from 15 to 12; for heroin from 17 to 15. During the past five years there has been a significant rise in the number of homeless 16 and 17-year-olds, some from local authority care, but many more from families who feel their responsibility comes to an end when the child reaches 16.

Studies of young men in prison show their association with homelessness, with local authority care, with exclusion from school, lack of skills, unemployment and drug use - also how many of them are or are about to become fathers.

The new support scheme promises a lot. Connexions will be largely delivered by existing local authority careers and youth services, also by schools' and colleges' welfare services, by probation officers, social services and voluntary organisations.

By starting to work with 13-year-olds Connexions ought to be able to bridge the trench between pre and post-16 provision. This is important, not just to be able to track problems in younger and younger age groups, but because things that happen or fail to happen at school are often strong predictors of later problems. The Safe in the Cities project identified school exclusion as a significant predictor of subsequent homelessness, though not a cause. Connexions might make young people excluded from school aware of local housing options: when they leave home it is planned, cutting the risk that they end up sleeping rough.

Connexions is meant to be a single service with a single point of contact - the "personal adviser". But these advisers cannot just sit and wait for problems. Connexions is going to have to seek out young people, using the skills of the variety of voluntary organisations trying to help young people. For homeless young people the Social Exclusion Unit recognised that organisations such as Foyers - voluntary schemes that house and encourage young people to re-engage with employment - are already doing the Connexions job and should be given the status as well.

If the government's ambitions are going to be realised attitudes will have to shift. Young people themselves are going to have to be brought into planning and maybe also delivering the service. A Carnegie Foundation study showed that young people felt services were often not open at the right hours nor offer what they wanted. Con nexions has to take their views seriously just as private companies routinely base decisions on market research.

Technology has a part in all this. As well as a medium for service delivery it could be the acid that dissolves the organisational "silos" in which many Connexions advisers may be bottled up in their disciplines and hierarchies. Shared use of the internet and email could create a virtual organisation of personal advisers developing a shared understanding of problems outside their "patch" and a shared goal of promoting young adults' learning as an overlay on their separate professional goals.

Of course money matters. The new national youth support service implies a massive shift of resources towards the 10% who have tended to receive little attention from those agencies charged with increasing educational participation. There should be efficiency gains from organisations working more effectively together, but the increased emphasis on working with the most problematic part of the cohort, with low caseloads, will require several times the £220m budget of the careers service.

A total of £500m has been talked about: this is the minimum required. While some of this will be existing money the logic of Connexions requires significant new money as well. This is where Tessa Jowell's review ought to make the treasury use a long ruler. Payback for a better youth service could take years to show. Moreover the costs of reaching and connecting could easily grow, the more successful the scheme is.

Alistair Darling, the social security secretary, has recently re-committed the government to its target of abolishing child poverty within 20 years. That depends on getting parents into work that is skilled and secure. Better service for youth now is about the skills and qualities of parents tomorrow. It is time to start investing: the performance of tomorrow's parents depend on better services for young people today.

 Carolyn Hayman is chief executive of the Foyers Federation

Con nexions has to take their views seriously just as private companies routinely base decisions on market research. Technology has a part in all this. As well as a medium for service delivery it could be the acid that dissolves the organisational "silos" in which many Connexions advisers may be bottled up in their disciplines and hierarchies. Shared use of the internet and email could create a virtual organisation of personal advisers developing a shared understanding of problems outside their "patch" and a shared goal of promoting young adults' learning as an overlay on their separate professional goals. Of course money matters. The new national youth support service implies a massive shift of resources towards the 10% who have tended to receive little attention from those agencies charged with increasing educational participation. There should be efficiency gains from organisations working more effectively together, but the increased emphasis on working with the most problematic part of the cohort, with low caseloads, will require several times the £220m budget of the careers service. A total of £500m has been talked about: this is the minimum required. While some of this will be existing money the logic of Connexions requires significant new money as well. This is where Tessa Jowell's review ought to make the treasury use a long ruler. Payback for a better youth service could take years to show. Moreover the costs of reaching and connecting could easily grow, the more successful the scheme is. Alistair Darling, the social security secretary, has recently re-committed the government to its target of abolishing child poverty within 20 years. fields.headline: A life at sea
fields.standfirst: She's been dubbed 'one of the best captains on the US east coast'. Now, after 15 years catching swordfish, Linda Greenlaw has netted a £400,000 book deal. Peter Lennon meets a nautical legend in the making
fields.trailText: She's been dubbed 'one of the best captains on the US east coast'. Now, after 15 years catching swordfish, Linda Greenlaw has netted a £400,000 book deal. Peter Lennon meets a nautical legend in the making
fields.body:
Tugboat Annie, she ain't. For one thing her girth is too modest: 5ft 3in, 130 lbs; then her range is too vast. Linda Greenlaw, still under 40, was skipper of a "longliner" fishing boat working out of Maine, US, for 15 years, regularly steaming across 1,000 miles of ocean in search of swordfish.

Thirty days at sea was about average, with an all-male crew. She is an unaffected, forthright woman, and she disposes of the obvious question of chauvinism directly. "It was never a problem. But people who ask me about it just don't believe this. They are disappointed. I have been interviewed by women who say, 'Oh, come on, you must be able to think of something.' They just don't want to take no for an answer. The relationship onboard is like what you read about firemen. Fishing is a fraternity. Maybe, being a woman, fraternity isn't the word. But accepting the masculine terms doesn't bother me."

The crucial element in her relationship with the crew seems to be that she had professional authority. "I could do any job onboard a man could do." And there is a bonus in being a woman: "Men have to keep up with or outdo a woman," she says. "It's a macho thing. If I work 18 hours a day, they will work 20."

There was another problem. Old-time fishermen regard women as Jonahs: they bring back luck. But when she started to bring home catches of 50,000lbs of swordfish, they began to call her Lucky Linda.

It was when Sebastian Junger described Greenlaw as "one of the best captains on the entire US east coast" in his bestseller The Perfect Storm that she found urgent messages on her answering machine from US publishers. The result is The Hungry Ocean, in which she takes one 30-day fishing expedition, high in catch but scuppered financially by falling markets and foul weather, to describe her relationship with the sea.

Her father is a "suit-and-tie guy", a financial executive in a large ship-building company. He thought she was going to go to law school "but after graduation I knew at 19 what I wanted to do with my life". She is also a product of a traditional, one might say antiquated, island community. She was born and brought up on Isle au Haut, Maine, 65 inhabitants; no bridge connection to the mainland seven miles away; no cinema; one store, nothing but woods and sea to fill the imagination.

By the time she was 15, she had headed for the sea, initially taking out her father's powerboat then going on a friend's trawler as a cook. When an accident left the crew a man short, she was allowed to work on deck, and rapidly became a helmsman. Pretty soon she was skipper of the Hannah Boden.

In terms of hardship and danger, life at sea has not changed. Being washed overboard is considered an easy way to go. What the fisherman fears most is the lethal longliner's hook. "Size and sharpness render hooks unforgiving when they decide to dive into and tear through flesh," she writes. "Just as fatal are the internal injuries that result from being crushed under the weight of a rogue wave."

But Greenlaw is also a modern captain, who can gut a fish and toss a Doppler with the best. The Doppler is a piece of electronics used to detect and define thermoclines - layers of water, like blankets of varying thickness, in motion. The trick is to detect the blanket most abundant in fish. "If you understand Einstein's theory of relativity," she says, "you can figure out the Doppler. I did a radar observer's course in which you study the principles of relative motion, so I ended up knowing it pretty well."

How did she become a writer? "My ability to write got me through college. Anything that had maths or science, I would steer away from. Anything that required an essay I could get through. I've had comments from professors like, 'I'm not sure you're right, but it's well written.' People ask which is harder, writing or fishing. I say they are equally difficult, but I like fishing."

Greenlaw now has a new £400,000, two-book deal, which should sweeten the labour. She says that modern technology has not detracted from the pleasure of fishing. "The electronics make it easier to navigate," she says. "But really it boils down to a baited hook. Despite all the technology and plastic deedaws, nothing will ever beat a sharp hook and fresh bait."

But behind the thrill and satisfaction of fishing, there is a human problem: loneliness and isolation. Recently, she gave up ocean-fishing and took up lobster-fishing; as her sense of isolation from normal life became more acute, she began fishing closer to shore. "There are a lot of similarities between the island I live on and a fishing boat. There is roughly the same degree of isolation. You can't pick up the phone book and look through the Yellow Pages; you have to do things for yourself." Her core problem is not a lack of loyal companions, but the need for a relationship, there not being a vast choice of men among the island's 65 inhabitants. Has she tried to build up a relationship with a person ashore?

"Several times. It becomes very desirable to have a relationship with one man, and the more time that goes by without doing this, the more desirable it becomes - and more difficult. It's a really tough question. But I am, like, truly in love with my life." That's stiff competition for anyone, I say.

"Right. But by the same token, I would like to get married, and I would like to have children. I have had some nice boyfriends. But there is something about, 'Thanks for dinner! See you in 30 days...' Most men are not that patient. Maybe also it's that you get very independent."

When Hollywood releases its version of Sebastian Junger's The Perfect Storm, now in post-production, Greenlaw's circle of acquaintances is bound to widen. She offered to play her own part but they are playing safe with a professional, Mary Elizabeth Mastrantonio, who played opposite Ed Harris in The Abyss.

Will all this wean her away from the sea? "No. All this is not a new career; in the scheme of things it's a very short segment." She finds a phrase to sum up her life on the ocean: "I like the way I feel when I am at sea."

 The Hungry Ocean, by Linda Greenlaw, is published by Sceptre, price £6.99.

fields.headline: Passion play that smoulders on
fields.standfirst:
A torrid tale of controversy and mutual revenge missions
Batistuta and co are given a licence to thrill
fields.trailText: The Americans have a better term for friendlies; they call them exhibition matches. England, with their media-driven hunger for success, may be desperate to win every game but even such prestigious opponents as Italy or France rarely share this enthusiasm when the results do not matter.
fields.body:
The Americans have a better term for friendlies; they call them exhibition matches. England, with their media-driven hunger for success, may be desperate to win every game but even such prestigious opponents as Italy or France rarely share this enthusiasm when the results do not matter.

There are, however, two exceptions. Germany want to beat the English any time, any place and Argentina, who like the Germans have bad memories of Wembley in the 1966 World Cup, will never pass up an opportunity to teach England a footballing lesson.

No doubt the brain-dead will roundly deride Argentina's anthem at Wembley tonight as well as booing their players.

After all, they might argue, England were cheated to defeat in the 1986 World Cup quarter-finals and the countries were at war four years earlier.

Yet those spectators with deeper feelings for football will feel privileged for the chance of watching the national team that gave the game Alfredo di Stefano, Omar Sivori and the Hand of God himself, Diego Maradona.

Certainly there was no ill-feeling towards the Argentine side that came to Wembley in the spring of 1951 for one of a series of Festival of Britain matches played that summer. A crowd of 100,000 watched England win 2-1 with late goals from Stan Mortensen and Jackie Milburn after the goalkeeping heroics of Rugilo had protected the lead taken by Argentina midway through the first half.

The moment when football matches between England and Argentina ceased to become generally amiable encounters came at Wembley in 1966, nine minutes before half-time in a World Cup quarter-final.

From the start Argentina had littered the field with fouls and Antonio Rattin, their tall, elegant captain, had been getting on the nerves of the small, officious German referee, Rudolf Kreitlein. Finally Kreitlein sent Rattin off for dissent, he refused to go and it was 10 minutes before order was restored.

Then Geoff Hurst's header won the game for England and ever since then there has been an undercurrent of hostility each time the teams have met. Eight years later, when Argentina returned to Wembley for a friendly, England were being managed by a caretaker, Joe Mercer, but Argentine resentment at Alf Ramsey's description of them as "animals" smouldered on.

The game was drawn 2-2, England being denied victory by a penalty in the last minute from Mario Kempes. "The second half was spoiled by a number of reckless fouls," reported the Official FA Yearbook, "mainly by the Argentinians."

Three years later, when Don Revie was in charge, England drew 1-1 with Argentina in the Boca Juniors stadium in Buenos Aires, a raucous bearpit of a ground.

Towards the end of the game Trevor Cherry tackled Daniel Bertoni from behind, whereupon the Argentine punched him in the mouth, removing two teeth. In the interests of diplomacy and self-preservation, the referee sent both players off.

What remains arguably England's best performance against Argentina came under Ron Greenwood at Wembley in a warm-up match for the 1980 European Championship in Italy. Argentina, by now the World Cup holders and including the young Maradona, were well beaten 3-1 as Kevin Keegan found his best form.

It was not until the 1986 World Cup quarter-finals that Argentina's footballers finally fell out of favour with England's fans. Early in the second half, with the game goalless, the ball ricocheted high off the boot of Steve Hodge near the England area. As Peter Shilton came out a fraction late to meet it, Maradona got there first and fisted the ball into the net.

Maradona's anxious glance towards the referee gave the game away but the goal stood and in English eyes Diego was cast as the devil incarnate from then on despite his mesmerising dribble through Bobby Robson's defence to increase Argentina's lead.

The last two meetings between England and Argentina, another Wembley friendly in 1991 and the World Cup match in St Etienne two years ago, have each seen the teams share four goals. Maybe the last encounter exhausted English Argiephobia since the bulk of the blame for the early departure of Glenn Hoddle's side from France 98 was laid at the door of David Beckham for getting himself sent off and leaving 10 men to force the penalty shoot-out that, inevitably, England lost.

It would be nice to think Wembley now remembers with greater affection the distinction and modest dignity Ossie Ardiles brought to English football during his Tottenham days or the moment in the 1981 FA Cup final replay when Ricky Villa's dribble through Manchester City's defence took the trophy to White Hart Lane and gave the old competition one of its greatest moments.

Either way, those who barrack Argentina tonight will surely envy the talents at the disposal of their coach, Marcelo Bielsa, compared to those at present available to Keegan.

fields.headline: Keegan takes a Wise gamble
fields.standfirst:
Chelsea's much sent-off captain lines up with Heskey against Argentina
Firebrand has chance to light up midfield
fields.trailText: Dennis Wise will tonight represent Kevin Keegan's latest attempt to solve the eternal England problem of not being able to put more than two passes together without giving the ball away.
fields.body:
Where ignorance is bliss, 'tis jolly to be wise - Dennis Wise, that is, who will tonight represent Kevin Keegan's latest attempt to solve the eternal England problem of not being able to put more than two passes together without giving the ball away.

The 33-year-old Chelsea captain has been sent off 11 times in his career and six times in the past 18 months. Even now he faces another misconduct charge from the Football Association after a fight in the Stamford Bridge tunnel after the game between Chelsea and Wimbledon 11 days ago.

Nevertheless Keegan has convinced himself that Wise's bad disciplinary record should not prevent him being given a chance against Argentina to show that, alongside David Beckham and Paul Scholes, he can pass, tackle and organise well enough to be worthy of consideration for the European Championship squad.

"Dennis Wise's consistency for Chelsea has been tremendous," Keegan insisted yesterday. "A lot of things surrounding him have overtaken his performances on the field but he deserves an opportunity and what better game than this for him to answer his critics?

"I can't defend his disciplinary record but, as far as I'm concerned, this will be a fresh start for him. I think I can trust him, or I wouldn't play him. He is an aggressive player, a winner, and he does care. You can see that. He's also got courage, although sometimes, as he would probably be the first to admit, he has overstepped the mark."

For Wise's growing army of critics this will smack of calling up John McVicar when someone has lost the keys to the local bank. Yet in pure footballing terms there is certain logic in preferring a ball-player who can tackle a bit, like Wise, to Paul Ince, a ball-winner with a limited range of passes.

At the same time the choice of Wise in his testimonial season is a reminder of how desperately short of top-class creative talent Keegan is. Wise's international career has experienced false starts under Graham Taylor and Terry Venables.

This evening Wise and Beckham will take it in turns to hold in midfield while Scholes moves forward to support Alan Shearer and his latest partner, Emile Heskey. As a husky 22-year-old with useful pace Heskey is worth a try and Liverpool rate him highly enough to want to sign him from Leicester. But as a striking combination England are unlikely to see football's answer to Torvill and Dean.

Yesterday Shearer overdid the praise slightly when he declared that Heskey was "probably a bit like Batistuta in a way; he hasn't scored as many goals but is in a similar mould". Tonight, should Gabriel Batistuta be in the mood, the extravagance of that statement may become apparent.

Another danger for Keegan tonight is that an exercise designed to enhance the shape and make-up of the side that faces Portugal in Eindhoven on June 12 in England's opening match of Euro 2000 will founder on a lack of understanding between players who have appeared together only fleetingly at this level if at all.

The Wise who binds together the movements of Chelsea's multi-national team will do well to adapt quickly in a side thrown together and asked to find a pattern capable of taking on a number of accomplished players in one of the world's most settled teams.

Seven of the side Argentina are set to field played against England 19 months ago when Glenn Hoddle's team went out of the World Cup on penalties after the dismissal of Beckham had offset the startling impact of Michael Owen. Ariel Ortega, Juan Veron, Diego Simeone and Javier Zanetti will not freeze in apprehension each time Wise gains possession.

Argentina have yet to beat England at Wembley. Much, from England's point of view, will depend on Keegan's back three establishing an early rapport with the midfield that will not allow the opposition to make infiltrating runs to set up chances for Batistuta and Claudio Lopez.

Shearer's resurgence of scoring form at Newcastle under Bobby Robson and his renewed enthusiasm for the game looks like England's best hope of victory. And at least the captain will enjoy service from the wings of team-mates present and past: Kieron Dyer, a colleague at St James' Park, and Jason Wilcox, now with Leeds but once a supplier of crosses at Blackburn.

For England, whatever the outcome, tonight's exercise will be worthwhile if the latest selection brings about an improvement in passing and movement, so poor against Scotland at Wembley in November. That at least would give Keegan a modicum of encouragement for Euro 2000.

England team to face Argentina in tomorrow night's Wembley friendly

Seaman (Arsenal)
Dyer (Newcastle)
Keown (Arsenal)
Southgate (Aston Villa)
Campbell (Tottenham)
Wilcox (Leeds)
Wise (Chelsea)
Beckham (Man Utd)
Scholes (Man Utd)
Shearer (Newcastle)
Heskey (Leicester)

Argentina

Burgos
Pochettino

Gonzalez

For England, whatever the outcome, tonight's exercise will be worthwhile if the latest selection brings about an improvement in passing and movement, so poor against Scotland at Wembley in November. That at least would give Keegan a modicum of encouragement for Euro 2000. fields.headline: The best intentions
fields.standfirst: Community leadership is at the heart of the new  local government bill. Beverly Hughes and  Stuart Etherington explain what a difference  it could make to your area
fields.trailText: Community leadership is at the heart of the new local government bill. Beverly Hughes and Stuart Etherington explain what a difference it could make to your area.
fields.body:
At the beginning of the 21st century, Britain is facing complex challenges that cannot be tackled by any one organisation acting alone. Con-certed action is necessary to address issues such as sustainable development, social exclusion, and crime and disorder.

The government sees local authorities as being in the best position to get an overall picture of the needs of their area and to bring together a range of public, private and voluntary bodies to tackle these issues.

To equip local authorities for the role of leading their communities, the government is introducing a wide-ranging modernisation programme. The new local government bill, currently before parliament, will put community leadership at the heart of local govern- ment, giving councils a power to promote the well-being of their areas.

It will also enable local authorities to join other agencies, as well as the private and voluntary sectors, to draw up community plans and agree strategies for tackling serious problems. In past years, a number of council services have been delivered in accordance with compulsory competitive tendering. CCT moved many local services away from direct council control to the private and voluntary sectors. For the voluntary sector, this change was most significant in personal and social services.

The problem with CCT, however, was that the primary focus of service delivery was on the lowest price and low cost doesn't always mean best quality. Those involved in local service provision - local authorities, the private sector, and the voluntary sector - have been calling for a new approach to service delivery, an approach to take greater account of the wishes of service users, and the quality of local services.

Best value, a key part of the government's modernisation agenda, is the new approach. It will be introduced for local authorities on April 1 and is designed to bring about a drive for continuous improvements in council services and to give local people more say in the services they receive.

The best value approach requires local authorities to review all their services over a period of five years and, when need be, demands a radical reassessment of services offered and the outcomes achieved.

Government has already demonstrated a commitment to the voluntary sector, with the launch of the compact on relations between government and the voluntary sector, and more recently the chancellor's announcements about tax relief for charities.

Best value offers another opportunity to build on the relationship between government and the voluntary sector. It opens up a range of possibilities for local government to work in partnership with other public bodies, including voluntary organisations.

Voluntary organisations are key partners in tackling the needs of the area. Some voluntary organisations speak for communities and client groups. Others deliver services for local people. Some do both. Best value provides both challenges and opportunities for voluntary bodies.

For example, Bradford city council is running a pilot project that focuses on community safety, which public consultation identified as a major area of concern for local people. Bradford has used neighbourhood youth forums to select young people to interview their peers in streets and clubs. The young people were given training and a set of questions but translated these into appropriate language.

Consultation is at the heart of best value, because best value is a duty owed to local people. This is an area in which the voluntary sector is well placed to contribute. Voluntary organisations have particular skills in reaching communities who may be overlooked by conventional consultation. For example, when Brighton and Hove council reviewed its residential and home care services for older people, it asked the local pensioners' forum, run by the local council for voluntary service, to consult with users and carers. The council felt that that consultation would have more credibility than if they had conducted the consultation themselves.

Best value is already starting to achieve results. Thirty-eight best value pilot projects have been running since April 1998. Many of these have featured initiatives to work with voluntary bodies. Southampton city council ran a pilot project that was focused on the quality of life for older people in the city. They established an older persons' consultative forum to advise the council on the needs and priorities of older people. An improved library service for older people is among the initiatives introduced as a result of the pilot. Many of the older people rely on volunteers to bring library books to them and the council is working with the WRVS to increase the number of volunteers and the number of people who benefit from the scheme.

The best value pilot programme has shown that it has potential for achieving significant improvements in quality and reductions in costs. However, it presents a considerable challenge to all those involved. It requires a major cultural, managerial and technical change for local government. Moving forward to being an outward looking, citizen focused organisation is difficult. Voluntary organisations also have to prepare if they want to ensure that their voices, and crucially the voices of their users, are heard when decisions are made and that they continue to participate in the delivery of local services.

Voluntary organisations, with their roots in the community and their roles in representing client groups and providing services, are key partners in turning the best value vision into reality. This is why NCVO launched a guide to best value for voluntary organisations only last week. The guide provides a clear and practical introduction to best value, which we hope will be well read and widely used.

 Beverly Hughes is parliamentary under secretary of state at the department of the environment, transport and the regions; Stuart Etherington is chief executive of the NCVO. Best Value: A Guide for Voluntary Organisations is available (free, plus 26p sae per copy) from Policy Team, NCVO, Regents Wharf, 8 All Saints Street, London N1 9RL.

webTitle: Euro climbs above dollar parity as doubts dog Dow

fields.headline: Euro climbs above dollar parity as doubts dog Dow
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: Europe's single currency yesterday clawed its way back above parity against the US dollar for the first time in four weeks but analysts remain to be convinced that its long awaited rally is under way.
fields.body:
Europe's single currency yesterday clawed its way back above parity against the US dollar for the first time in four weeks but analysts remain to be convinced that its long awaited rally is under way.

The euro fought its way from just under 99 cents overnight in London to $1.0070 by the close of business yesterday - driven by a combination of an improving economic outlook for the eurozone, tough talking from European central bankers and continuing falls in US share prices.

Although analysts are predicting that the euro could threaten $1.10 this year few are prepared to be drawn on the exact timing.

Part of the impetus for yesterday's move came from comments by the Bundesbank president, Ernst Welteke, seen as signalling that the European central bank has room for further tightening of monetary policy plus a report in a German magazine suggesting that the country's unemployment figures would fall sharply in the spring.

That caught some dealers short of euros and they were forced to buy to cover their positions. "I think [the euro] was oversold. It was due a bounce and any excuse will do," said one currency futures trader.

Some analysts think sentiment has shifted in Europe's favour. "I think we are entering a period of a weaker dollar," said David Bloom, global currency strategist with HSBC Markets. "The bearishness on Europe is coming to an end."

Alison Cottrell, chief international economist at PaineWebber, said the rise had come at a time when there was little economic news from the US to distract investors' attention from what was happening in the eurozone. She cautioned that the rise was "not so much a euro rally, more that the dollar is slipping", but she added: "Success breeds success. The more it moves up the more potentially it can do, provided governments and central banks will let it."

One factor dragging down the greenback is the continuing weakness on Wall Street. The Dow Jones average fell almost 300 points on Friday night and has fallen nearly 13% over the last four weeks.

Part of the fallout from the slump in US equities is being felt on the foreign exchanges as investors switch out of American shares and into assets not denominated in dollars.

fields.headline: Sids, please call and collect £14m
fields.trailText: Tens of thousands of Sids, the small shareholders who rushed to buy into the old British Gas when privatised in 1986 but kept their stock, have gone missing - and they are owed a lot of money.
fields.body:
Tens of thousands of Sids, the small shareholders who rushed to buy into the old British Gas when privatised in 1986 but kept their stock, have gone missing - and they are owed a lot of money.

BG, the gas pipelines and exploration group spun off from the former state monopoly, said it had identified 150,000 shareholders who had failed to cash in their dividends.

Philip Hampton, BG's finance director, said after the restructuring and share buyback scheme BG had a shareholder base of just 1.1m compared with 1.7m on demerger with what is now Centrica.

The missing 150,000 hold between 20 and 30 shares each. Mr Hampton and David Varney, the chief executive, appealed to the missing Sids and relatives or heirs to claim back the up to £14m owed them.

This emerged as BG, announcing flat £1.2bn pre-tax profits for last year which were ahead of City expectations, set out a series of projects at home and abroad to attract investors and boost its share price.

Mr Varney, a keen formula one fan, said the group planned to market new hi-tech, dual fuel engines capable of running on compressed or liquid natural gas as well as petrol or diesel for polluted urban transport networks.

BG, which has helped Lotus develop the Elise, believes the engines developed by BMW, Mercedes and Volvo could, for example, power London's buses and taxis.

Projects are already running in Argentina and Egypt, where the energy group supplies gas to domestic consumers and transport authorities.

BG, which expects earnings to be boosted this year by the delayed impact of the surge in oil prices, also hopes to break further into the liberalised Eu ropean market as consumers demand lower prices and better service compared with those on offer from state or regional monopolies.

Mr Varney said BG's pipeline business, Transco - which already supplies parts of Europe through the interconnector to Belgium - had the sophisticated IT systems that enabled 60 shippers to deliver gas over the consumer network. Europe's systems, in comparison, were "like a Sunday outing".

BG's chief executive confirmed that it was talking to a number of telecoms companies about using its pipeline network to install high speed telephony and internet access, both here and abroad.

Mr Varney, refusing to comment on reports that BG would team up with Energis, cable company Telewest or Freeserve, the internet service provider, said the goal was to produce one or more alliances later this year.

fields.headline: Capital punishment
fields.standfirst: A formal complaint demands a devilish response
fields.trailText: I received a formal complaint this week. The Professional Conduct Committee, which is the barristers' watchdog, forwarded a copy of it to me - with a scary covering letter.
fields.body:
I received a formal complaint this week. The Professional Conduct Committee, which is the barristers' watchdog, forwarded a copy of it to me - with a scary covering letter.

It is from a litigant-in-person against whom I defended a sex discrimination case some months ago.

In it, she said: "Ms Counsel asked me questions in an angry and sneering voice. I was unable to sleep for three nights after this and the Stress has made me very ill (see Report from my Doctor). I will be taking advice from Solicitors about bringing an action against Ms Counsel for Personal Injuries under the Human Rights Act and the Harassment Act."

NB: Watch out for the tell-tale invasion of capital letters into your prose if you're ever having concerns about your mental health.

Looking at the letter (heart rate still decelerating from the aeroplane-plummeting-10,000-feet speed it had reached when I first opened the envelope), I struggle to remember the case. My roommate, who was on the receiving end of a complaint himself recently, has already made more cups of sympathy tea than Kath from EastEnders in her heyday.

I am trying in particular to think whether I might have come across as angry and sneering. Ms Complaint's case, as I remember it, was an object lesson in how to dissolve your working relationships through paranoia. There was a slightly critical appraisal, a training day Ms Complaint wasn't invited on, a job description for her reorganised post which she thought her boss had allowed her arch rival to write - your basic routine horror of perceived slights and conspiracies.

All I can remember feeling about the whole thing at the time was boredom and some depression. Apart from the day when I ran into Ms Complaint at the train station on the way home and she screamed: "Stop following me," causing a crowd of little boys to entertain themselves by repeating the phrase for half the journey to London.

And I think, I hope, that I was as gentle in questioning her as conducting the case would allow. But I'm not sure. Because it's hard, sometimes, not to be exasperated by the waste of time and money and life as you sit in a stale room listening to a load of stale fantasies. And easy to forget that the case is only one episode in the X-files of someone's life.

So I am feeling thoroughly guilty and rotten about my possible failure to walk a mile in Ms Complaint's moccasins, when I reach her last paragraph (illustrated in the margin by a ballpoint pen drawing of Jesus on the cross with bloody teardrops rolling from his side).

It goes as follows: "When we got outside the Tribunal after the case was concluded she spat on my Shoes and gloated over her Victory. As a Christian I found her behaviour offensive. I told her God was watching her and she would be rewarded with Hellfire."

I begin to type: "Dear Sir, Ms Complaint is mistaken about the incident which took place outside the tribunal. What actually happened is that HAVING BECOME TEMPORARILY POSSESSED BY DEMONS, I SPROUTED SEVERAL EXTRA HEADS, SOME OF WHICH INADVERTENTLY SPEWED FIRE AT MS COMPLAINT, FOR WHICH I AM TRULY SORRY."

I pause, take a swig of tea, turn off Caps Lock and start again.

webTitle: Sell-off threat for big five grocers

fields.headline: Sell-off threat for big five grocers
fields.trailText: The big five supermarket chains could be forced to sell off stores if the Competition Commission finds evidence that they are operating against the public interest.
fields.body:
The big five supermarket chains could be forced to sell off stores if the Competition Commission finds evidence that they are operating against the public interest.

The chains - Tesco, Sainsbury, Asda, Safeway and Morrisons - could also be forced to adopt a more transparent pricing policy and to abide by a new code of conduct to ensure that they do not abuse their buying power at the expense of small suppliers.

But the threatened sanctions, said the Competition Commission, are entirely "hypothetical" as it has not yet decided whether the big grocers are acting against the public interest - or even started the hearings to take evidence.

The commission's decision to state the potential remedies before deciding whether any action is required is unprecedented, and yesterday it was being viewed as a move by the watchdog to bring the supermarket pricing saga to an end.

The supermarkets have now been under investigation for nearly two years and the inquiries - which most supermarket executives believe have been politically motivated - have cast a long shadow over their shares. In that time they have underperformed the FTSE index by 24%.

Earlier this month the commission wrote to 19 operators including Iceland, Waitrose and Marks & Spencer, saying it did not believe they acted against the public interest.

But it wanted to look further into the activities of the big five, which control 70% of the £90bn grocery market.

The commission said the supermarkets operated complex monopolies but there was no evidence they were against the public interest.

It conceded prices had fallen and there was no evidence supermarkets were generating excess profits, and admitted that consumers were happy with the service they received.

Yesterday David Bremner, chief executive of Sainsbury's, criticised the watchdog. "It is wrong to dwell on the remedies before even identifying the existence of a problem", he said, describing new inquiries as "lengthy and distracting". He insisted that "today's free market ensures a better deal for our customers than any state intervention ever could".
