webTitle: Brown targets red tape that strangles start-ups

fields.headline: Brown targets red tape that strangles start-ups
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
BT
fields.trailText: Britain will be the leading e-commerce economy within three years, the chancellor, Gordon Brown, said yesterday.
fields.body:
Britain will be the leading e-commerce economy within three years, the chancellor, Gordon Brown, said yesterday.

Speaking in New York, Mr Brown promised to slash red tape to make it easier for new companies to start up and to help existing companies to go online. "We are determined that Britain will lead in the next stage of the internet revolution. Our target is within three years to become the world's best environment for electronic commerce."

Brown found himself at the centre of a row last week between BT and Oftel after leaking a speech which disclosed plans by the regulator to open BT's local network for competition earlier than agreed.

Oftel is due to examine ways of bringing forward the date of July 2001 for BT to give up its monopoly of the "local loop", long seen as a barrier to the growth of internet business.

Mr Brown also called for the next major European summit - which begins in Lisbon at the end of the month - to set a date for breaking down the last remaining barriers between EU economies in telecommunications, energy, aviation and financial services.

He said: "The aim is to set a new goal - to make the European Union the world's most dynamic and competitive area, based on innovation and knowledge. Britain is leading Europe with reform proposals."

Growing euro-scepticism was threatening jobs and prosperity in Britain, Mr Brown warned. "I believe those who seek to renegotiate the very basis of our relationship with Europe, even when they simultaneously protest they do not want to leave, put at risk the stability that is so central to modern business and investment decisions."

Earlier, in a BBC radio interview, Mr Brown rejected suggestions that the government had failed because it had not done more to make the case for Britain's EU membership.

"I don't accept that we've failed on this because I think people do see the 750,000 companies exporting to Europe, that 50% of our trade is with Europe and that millions of jobs are part of our membership of the European Union," he said.

fields.headline: Romantic flop
fields.standfirst: Royal Philharmonic/ Vernon Handley Royal Albert Hall *
fields.trailText: Just where does one start with Frederick Stocken's Symphony for the Millennium, commissioned by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, and premiered by the RPO under Vernon Handley at the Albert Hall on Monday? What normal criteria can be applied to a work that would have been regarded as hopelessly old-fashioned at the turn of the last century, and would have hardly seemed ground-breaking 50 years before that?
fields.body:
Just where does one start with Frederick Stocken's Symphony for the Millennium, commissioned by the Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea, and premiered by the RPO under Vernon Handley at the Albert Hall on Monday? What normal criteria can be applied to a work that would have been regarded as hopelessly old-fashioned at the turn of the last century, and would have hardly seemed ground-breaking 50 years before that?

Stocken caught the headlines in 1994 when he became a spokesman for a sad group of disaffected musicians calling themselves The Hecklers, who organised protests - pretty well-mannered ones, it has to be said - against what they saw as the iniquities of contemporary music. Their 15 minutes of fame duly came and went when they strenuously but ineffectually booed a revival of Birtwistle's Gawain at Covent Garden. Now, apparently, Stocken wants to put all that direct action behind him and let his own music do the talking. If this symphony, with each of its four move ments based upon a painting by Lord Leighton, is what he wants to say, then his message is a pitiful one.

Stocken is a born-again early romantic, writing in a style somewhere between Beethoven and Mendelssohn, as if to attempt anything more complex, let alone vaguely chromatic, would be too threatening to the audience he craves. Yet there's no sense of ironic distance in his use of this style; everything is to be taken strictly at face value. Even if it were pastiche, or written as a student exercise, it would be a fifth-rate effort. The symphony's melodic invention is earth-bound; its structure is clumsy, with blocks of indifferent material juxtaposed without any sense of crafted transitions; the scoring is muddy. There isn't a single memorable moment in the entire 30-minute piece.

In this postmodern world stylistically anything goes, and there are no longer any prescriptions for what composers can or cannot do. But whatever language they choose to use they still need some spark of originality, and to possess the technical equipment to reveal that they have something worthwhile to offer. On this evidence Stocken can't summon up any of those qualities, and what the RPO and Kensington and Chelsea thought they were doing in promoting him in such a way is impossible to imagine.

fields.headline: Raucus and Roll
fields.standfirst: Muse Manchester University Students’ Union ****
fields.trailText: There is something inevitable about the progress of Muse. In contrast to those other epic balladeers, Radiohead - whose OK, Computer has become a somewhat jaded coffee-table classic - Muse offer a raucous vitality, an uncompromising urgency which is all the more remarkable considering they’re a three-piece with an average age of 20.
fields.body:
There is something inevitable about the progress of Muse. In contrast to those other epic balladeers, Radiohead - whose OK, Computer has become a somewhat jaded coffee-table classic - Muse offer a raucous vitality, an uncompromising urgency which is all the more remarkable considering they're a three-piece with an average age of 20.

This is their first headline tour, and their vigorous set hitched post-adolescent pinings to a histrionic guitar, an intelligent bass, and drums which were by turns stomping or spasmodic. Over these convulsive arrangements, Matt Bellamy's tremulous vocals aspired to operatic intensity. His full-throated warbles belied his slim-fit frame and proved more than a match for his wailing guitar which he played as if trying to break every string.

Sunburn, their new single, exemplified the band's style. A lugubrious bass held together a melody which travelled from intimacy to brashness as Bellamy's exaggerated gasping ended such despairing lines as "I can't face this pain". In spite of the lyrics, Muse are far from maudlin. Their thrashing energy and huge sound overcome the introspection. Indeed, at times they approach the fury of Rage Against the Machine.

Elsewhere, there's a defiant jauntiness to their melancholy. Uno's cheeky Latinate rhythm mocks both the screaming guitar and Bellamy's hysteria, while the insidious last single, Muscle Museum, has a feedback intro followed by a melody that wouldn't be out of place at a Greek wedding. Both were successful live, and they revealed a band confident enough to strip down a verse to a slow and simple arrangement, before building up towards extended, hard-rocking choruses.

This versatility was taken further when they transformed themselves into a folksy-blues bar-room outfit. The singer reached for a stool and an acoustic guitar, an electric double-bass appeared, and, at one point, the drummer was happily shaking a maraca. In this set-within-a-set, Bellamy's calmer, more delicate voice aimed for the ethereal tones of Jeff Buckley, especially in Falling Down. In Unintended, the Thom Yorke comparison was inescapable.

But Muse are more convincing when playing songs with all the nervous clamour and charge of Showbiz, the title track of their debut album. A sinister bass-line and uptight riff combined with another rallying chorus to provide a blistering, strobe-lit finale to a three-song en core. On this form there'll be no stopping them.

Muse play Princess Charlotte, Leicester (0116-255 3956), tomorrow and ULU, London (0171-344 4444), on Friday.

fields.headline: The clockwatcher
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Travel scribble
fields.body:
Travel scribble

Tube travellers might take a moment to consider the modus operandi of the network's most satirical graffiti artists. One advert, depicting a man reading a book on a roller coaster to advertise an online bookshop, has won consistent decoration from the magic markers. "Boring prat," reads the commentary on a poster halfway up the escalator at King's Cross, with an arrow pointing to the man's head. What intrigues, here, is the speed at which the escalator is travelling. The execution of this defacement would have been impossible in one go. Even with speedy handwriting, "boring" is as far as you'd get before being ripped out of range. So, imagine if you will, this urban terrorist riding patiently to the top, taking the down escalator back to the bottom and reascending to finish the job. Perhaps his tag-line on the poster was an expression of solidarity.

Humour at 30,000ft

Passengers on a flight to Berlin last Wednesday were kept amused by Tom Salmon, the flight attendant, whose liberties with the script squeezed out a laugh even in business class. Safety procedures, Salmon-style, involve a contest to see which of the cabin crew can tie the best double bow on the lifejackets. "And the winner is, of course, David, whose prize will be to serve you all a hot meal single-handed." Passengers are then invited to guess which of the crew has a degree in business administration and which was plucked from obscurity as an au pair in Oxford (David, again). But it's the final farewell that best combines customer care with brand awareness. "If you're having a business meeting I hope it goes well," says Salmon, coolly. "If you're here on holiday, I hope it's superb, and if you're taking a connecting flight, I hope it's British Airways."

fields.headline: Tricks of the trade
fields.standfirst:
12. How I deal with difficult clients

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: 12. How I deal with difficult clients
fields.body:
Karen Small, 24 PR account manager

I worked on a project for a client where the artwork had to be approved by three different people, something she hadn't told me before. As a result I got behind with deadlines. She got on the phone and started yelling at me and I found myself apologising. With hindsight, I realise that I wasn't to blame but I mistakenly thought the client was always right. Now I would take a more professional, logical stance and I would point out calmly that the mistake was partly hers. It's important with difficult clients to hold your nerve. However, the situation has not arisen since because now I build in three extra days for any new projects.

Alison Johnson, 38 Manager director

Whenever I've had an unhappy client, I've dealt with the problem face to face rather than by telephone or in writing. That way there's less chance of any misunderstandings. I think the emphasis of the conversation should be on the nuts and bolts of how that problem should never recur rather than on offering platitudes. Clients must always feel they've been heard. I had a problem with a Japanese client a few years ago when a product was delivered to them in a terrible mess. I got to the root of the problem and stopped using that delivery company as a supplier. I then thoroughly researched a replacement and involved the client in my final decision. That way, he felt reassured.

Sian Jones, 28 Careers consultant

I run a service whereby I advise people how they can move up the ladder. A solicitor came to see me who was looking for very specific advice. She wanted to stay in law, but needed to shift the emphasis of her work. I didn't have the level of knowledge she needed and she wasn't happy with my work. She really needed to see someone who specialised in legal jobs. There are three things I learned from this. Firstly, I would never again take on work that I couldn't do to an excellent standard. Secondly, I would research the area thoroughly before the client parted with any cash, and thirdly, I would make it absolutely clear to the client what I do and what I can deliver.

Gary Powell, 43 Head of sales development

I work for a delivery company and we won the business of a big US publishing house which had a formidable president. She had staked her credibility on employing us, so it was really important that our first delivery was perfect. Unfortunately it wasn't and some packages weren't collected from the airport. We knew that the mailing house we worked with were partly at fault, but we decided to take it on the chin because we'd employed them in the first place. Amazingly, at the end of a most uncomfortable meeting, she told us we still had the account. Later I found out that she had gone to the mailing house beforehand, and they had blamed us for the error. I think we kept the business because we were honest and accepted full responsibility.

Bryan Rowlands, 52 IT manager

A few years ago I criticised a client's company, saying that its products were overpriced compared with the competition. He overheard what I'd said and confronted me, which was all very embarrassing. Rather than apologising out of shame - which was very tempting - I took a deep breath and turned what had been taken as an insult into constructive criticism. I gave him reasons for my opinion and cited examples so he could see what I meant. I apologised at the end of our conversation and admitted that my behaviour had been inappropriate. I partly salvaged the situation, and I think he respected me for standing up for myself.

webTitle: The sack race no one can win

fields.headline: The sack race no one can win
fields.standfirst:
As thousands face job losses at Unilever, Norwich Union and Ford's Dagenham plant, Oliver Burkeman considers what it's like to work in the shadow of redundancy

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: As thousands face job losses at Unilever, Norwich Union and Ford's Dagenham plant, Oliver Burkeman considers what it's like to work in the shadow of redundancy
fields.body:
First come the rumours. Weeks, months, even years in advance, whispers of a profit slump, a cost-cutting merger, a radical "restructuring" whip workplaces into bubbling crucibles of speculation. So that, when a swingeing round of redundancies is finally announced - as this week at Unilever, which plans to sack 25,000 workers worldwide in the next five years; at insurers CGU and Norwich Union, due to shed at least 4,000 posts when they merge; and at Ford's Dagenham plant, where 1,500 job losses were announced last week - the immediate, visceral response can be an entirely incongruous surge of relief.

"At least, when the details come, you finally have an idea of what you're dealing with," recalls Helen, a senior employee of a major corporation based at Canary Wharf, who kept her post when her employers implemented a harsh round of job cuts in 1997. "Living in limbo, knowing the axe is going to fall but not on whom, is particularly grim."

Nobody who has experienced redundancy needs telling about the often huge personal and financial costs of losing one's job. What's less widely appreciated - though employers are finally beginning to heed the warnings of occupational psychologists - is how much damage can be done between the time when numbers are announced and the notices of redundancy received, even for those who hang on to their jobs. If the nation's employers had deliberately plotted a system designed to foster maximum insecurity and bad feeling in their workforces, they could hardly have come up with a better method than the current strategy of rumours first, numbers second, and specific names a long, long time afterwards.

"Fear and bewilderment," says Simon, a banker working at the south-east division of a high-street bank, when asked to recall his colleagues' response to a recent announcement of impending redundancies. "Why us? Why now? Why, when the bank is making such huge profits, are they making us redundant?"

Office camaraderie vanishes in a trice as workers struggle to second-guess the management's impenetrable logic. "There's not an awful lot of team spirit now," says Simon. Conflicts of loyalties escalate into full-scale wars as employees try to balance solidarity with self-interest. "Especially for those with families to support. It's 'What am I going to do if it's me?' Everyone's looking at everyone else, and wondering: 'What if I'm next?'"

But the problem is that an employer's logic isn't always particularly logical. "The odd thing is that you can guess, but what you're thinking is often unfair: that this person isn't going to be sacked even though they're completely crap, because management can't afford to pay them off," says Helen. "There was always a feeling that it was going to be the Indians and not the chiefs, the workers who were actually producing rather than the paper-pushers and memo-writers. On the other hand, my salary was so incredibly low that I thought I'd be too cheap to bother firing."

If there are still any neanderthal senior managers who believe that the paranoia of job-cut limbo keeps workers keyed-up and competitive, they're very, very wrong. Psychological studies show that productivity plummets during the grim wait for letters of redundancy - not least because levels of health decline drastically. In a 1995 study, researchers from University College London analysed 10,300 civil servants, and found vastly increased levels of ill health among those who worked through years of threatened unemployment. (Female employees proved disproportionately at risk from psychological illness, while males were more likely to suffer physically.)

The findings held good even disregarding the effects of excessive drinking and smoking and lack of exercise - although, Helen remembers, there's plenty of that too. "Productivity fell by about 80%. It took over the office, and brought everything to a standstill - even though everyone knew bloody well the decisions had been made, they would be in the pub every night discussing it. People were terribly hung over for an awful lot of the time."

A brave face is not an uncommon response. "People over 50 had badges printed saying they were 50 and didn't care if they were made redundant, because they'd get a pension," says Mike, who was laid off two years ago by a water company that is still slashing staff numbers. But appearances can be deceptive, Helen says. "The people who at first said they'd be glad to take a cheque and get out were the ones in tears when it came to leaving."

How the news is communicated can make all the difference, according to Jenny Summerfield, business psychologist and author of a book on workplace counselling. "Organisations find it difficult to be upfront, but that's what they've got to do," she says. "People may, over time, stop resenting the fact that they lost their jobs, but they will never forget how they were told. If they're taken aside in small groups, given explanations and immediate support, they will remember that the company treated them humanely, even though it fired them."

This, though, is an ideal rather than the reality. Mike's experience was more typical: "The company likes to get rid of people at the end of March, which, because of the notice period, meant people were always made redundant just before Christmas," he says. "There was a lot of despondency, and illness among workers but also among their families." Helen, too, shudders at the memory of her company's insensitive "dawn raid" methods. "People were called before they left for work, and asked to come and see a manager. My friend recorded her conversation on her answering machine, and on the tape you can hear her fighting back tears."

Counterintuitively, among those most detrimentally affected may be those who appear, at first, least deserving of sympathy: the ones who remain. In America - borrowing rather inappropriately from psychological studies of the Holocaust - they call this "survivor syndrome"; whatever you call it, Summerfield says, its effects are hard to deny. In extreme cases, employees who keep their jobs - with increased workload, insecurity and paranoia - end up suffering from post-traumatic stress disorder's sister condition, prolonged-duress stress disorder.

"One way to get over post-traumatic stress is to remove yourself from the situation, but with prolonged-duress stress you can't do that," she explains. "People have to keep coming into work every day. Employers will often assume that people are grateful just to have kept their jobs, but the levels of demotivation can be huge."

Mike knows exactly how it feels. "By the time I was made redundant, our department covered an area three times bigger than when I started. Because there was no theory behind the redundancies, people just didn't understand how those jobs were going to be done when they left." And judging by the tone of his voice, he's not entirely unhappy that he got out when he did.

 Some names have been changed.

"There was always a feeling that it was going to be the Indians and not the chiefs, the workers who were actually producing rather than the paper-pushers and memo-writers. On the other hand, my salary was so incredibly low that I thought I'd be too cheap to bother firing." If there are still any neanderthal senior managers who believe that the paranoia of job-cut limbo keeps workers keyed-up and competitive, they're very, very wrong. Psychological studies show that productivity plummets during the grim wait for letters of redundancy - not least because levels of health decline drastically. In a 1995 study, researchers from University College London analysed 10,300 civil servants, and found vastly increased levels of ill health among those who worked through years of threatened unemployment. (Female employees proved disproportionately at risk from psychological illness, while males were more likely to suffer physically.) The findings held good even disregarding the effects of excessive drinking and smoking and lack of exercise - although, Helen remembers, there's plenty of that too. "Productivity fell by about 80%. It took over the office, and brought everything to a standstill - even though everyone knew bloody well the decisions had been made, they would be in the pub every night discussing it. People were terribly hung over for an awful lot of the time." A brave face is not an uncommon response. "People over 50 had badges printed saying they were 50 and didn't care if they were made redundant, because they'd get a pension," says Mike, who was laid off two years ago by a water company that is still slashing staff numbers. But appearances can be deceptive, Helen says. "The people who at first said they'd be glad to take a cheque and get out were the ones in tears when it came to leaving." How the news is communicated can make all the difference, according to Jenny Summerfield, business psychologist and author of a book on workplace counselling. "Organisations find it difficult to be upfront, but that's what they've got to do," she says. "People may, over time, stop resenting the fact that they lost their jobs, but they will never forget how they were told. If they're taken aside in small groups, given explanations and immediate support, they will remember that the company treated them humanely, even though it fired them." This, though, is an ideal rather than the reality. Mike's experience was more typical: "The company likes to get rid of people at the end of March, which, because of the notice period, meant people were always made redundant just before Christmas," he says. "There was a lot of despondency, and illness among workers but also among their families." Helen, too, shudders at the memory of her company's insensitive "dawn raid" methods. "People were called before they left for work, and asked to come and see a manager. My friend recorded her conversation on her answering machine, and on the tape you can hear her fighting back tears." Counterintuitively, among those most detrimentally affected may be those who appear, at first, least deserving of sympathy: the ones who remain. In America - borrowing rather inappropriately from psychological studies of the Holocaust - they call this "survivor syndrome"; whatever you call it, Summerfield says, its effects are hard to deny. In extreme cases, employees who keep their jobs - with increased workload, insecurity and paranoia - end up suffering from post-traumatic stress disorder's sister condition, prolonged-duress stress disorder. "One way to get over post-traumatic stress is to remove yourself from the situation, but with prolonged-duress stress you can't do that," she explains. "People have to keep coming into work every day. Employers will often assume that people are grateful just to have kept their jobs, but the levels of demotivation can be huge." Mike knows exactly how it feels. "By the time I was made redundant, our department covered an area three times bigger than when I started. Because there was no theory behind the redundancies, people just didn't understand how those jobs were going to be done when they left." And judging by the tone of his voice, he's not entirely unhappy that he got out when he did.  Some names have been changed.

fields.headline: Royal London buys rival
fields.standfirst: Door shuts for troubled United Assurance
fields.trailText: Troubled door-to-door insurance group United Assurance is to be taken over by mutual rival Royal London in a £1.5bn deal which is expected to take a heavy toll on jobs .
fields.body:
Troubled door-to-door insurance group United Assurance is to be taken over by mutual rival Royal London in a £1.5bn deal which is expected to take a heavy toll on jobs .

The deal, likely to prompt an investigation by the authorities, will draw a veil over United Assurance's short-lived history after its formation in 1996.

It also marks the largest ever acquisition by a mutual of a public company and prompted 140-year-old Royal London to insist yesterday that it had no plans to list the combined entity on the stock market.

In an effort to quash speculation that Britannic Assurance was poised to launch a counter offer, Royal London claimed it had control over 23% of United Assurance shares.

Britannic had been regarded as the most likely bidder for United Assurance, which has suffered a turbulent relationship with the stock market after the 1996 merger between Refuge and United Friendly. But, it is increasingly expected to stay on the sidelines after United Assurance's decision to back the offer from Royal London which is paying 445p in cash to each United Assurance shareholder.

Confirmation of the takeover lifted United Assurance's shares 45p to 465p. Analysts explained that it matched the offer by Royal London because it also included the payment of a 20p dividend announced by United Assurance with its profits figures yesterday.

The price offered by Royal London, the equivalent to United Assurance's "embedded value", was regarded as generous and prompted one source to question whether Royal London's policyholders might object to the deal.

The combined Royal London, which will ditch the United Assurance name, aims to cut costs in the tough "home service sector".

But Mike Yardley, Royal London's chief executive who will retain that position, refused to indicate what impact this would have on the 3,100 people employed by Royal London and the 3,0000 at United Assurance.

Many visit customers homes to sell life, pension and other products. At a time when many other firms are reducing human contact in favour of the internet and the telephone, Mr Yardley insisted there would be huge demand for "face-to-face" advice.

Royal London intends to merge this field forces, which combined employs 1,750 advisers in 175 areas, and merge head office and administrative functions, putting the head office in Colchester, home to Royal London. It said an administration centre would be retained in Wilmslow, Cheshire, United's headquarters.

Royal London will pay for United Assurance out its own stash of cash and a £400m loan from Dresdner bank.

United yesterday reported a 16.5% rise in pre-tax operating profits to £286m, excluding exceptionals.

fields.headline: Desk therapist
fields.standfirst:
We showed desk therapist Donna Dawson the desk of Glenda Jackson MP

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: We showed desk therapist Donna Dawson the desk of Glenda Jackson MP
fields.body:
This cleared, tidy desk qualifies for the businesslike, organised category. The decks are cleared for action and a thinking space has been purposefully created. This desk owner doesn't want to give away too much about herself.

The shape and style of the lamp suggests someone elegant, strong, focused and female; yet the mug of pens suggests someone down to earth. The organised letter-rack with crested stationery brings the words dignified and orderly to mind.

Having said that, this isn't a bland desk: there is colour and warmth in the gold-brown wood, suggesting a person who can be versatile, creative and friendly.

The two chairs pushed near each other facing the desk are intriguing. Do people come here to take orders, receive information, or to be interviewed rigorously? Are they pushed against the front of the desk in a practical attempt to save space?

This woman is an interesting mix of the stately and the down-to-earth, the dignified and the practical, a hard-working businesswoman who doesn't suffer fools gladly. Could she be a politician? Is this the desk of Glenda Jackson?

Did our expert get it right? Glenda Jackson responds

She awards me brownie points I don't warrant. The decor and the lamp, for instance, are decided upon by the sergeant-at-arms and uniform throughout the building. There are things that I recognise and others that I don't. I don't regard myself as having authority, but I am incapable of working unless the environment is tidy.

fields.headline: Cancer's visible scar
fields.standfirst: Gone to LA Hampstead Theatre, London ***
fields.trailText: Arlene Croce in the New Yorker once wrote a famous essay about "victim art": work that, by offering an unmodulated account of suffering, sought to bypass critical judgement. At first sight, Lolly Susi's Gone to LA - a first-time play about breast cancer by a woman who has herself experienced it - seems to fall into Croce's category. But, though far from perfect, it rises above victim art by analysing rather than exploiting the heroine's fear and pain.
fields.body:
Arlene Croce in the New Yorker once wrote a famous essay about "victim art": work that, by offering an unmodulated account of suffering, sought to bypass critical judgement. At first sight, Lolly Susi's Gone to LA - a first-time play about breast cancer by a woman who has herself experienced it - seems to fall into Croce's category. But, though far from perfect, it rises above victim art by analysing rather than exploiting the heroine's fear and pain.

One takes on trust the absolute accuracy of the reactions of Susi's heroine, a theatre director called Ella, to the discovery of her cancer. She treats it like a dark secret, leaving messages and sending postcards pretending she has gone to LA. She guiltily feels that the cancer is, in some obscure way, a punishment for past sins. Given a particularly aggressive form of treatment, she is also much possessed by death: she is not only stalked by its literal presence in the shape of a saturnine chap in black leather but even hears the word "die" echoing subliminally through a specialist's histology report.

For all the grimness of the subject, Susi manages to invest it with a certain black humour: most especially through the show-stealing character of a fellow-patient, mordantly played by Melanie Hudson, who is tethered to an immobilising oxygen-tank and who at one point announces "I'm leaving - it's just hard to tell." But it is significant that the minor characters, including an absentee Irish teacher who is Ella's fanatically loyal chum, gradually take over the play. As Ella's treatment progresses, she becomes dramatically less visible. That this needn't happen is proved by Margaret Edson's very similar Wit, an off-Broadway play scheduled for London later this year, in which the academic heroine's love of metaphysical poetry counterpoints her fear of extinction.

Susi, in fact, spins out her tale with dubious expressionist devices, including her heroine's morphine-induced vision of heaven. But, if one test of a play is that it takes you inside another person's experience, then this one mostly succeeds: it enlarges one's knowledge without manipulating one's emotions. Rupert Goold's production is swiftly and clinically staged on a traverse stage specially designed by Ruari Murchison for Hampstead's Arts for Everyone season. And it is well acted by a shaven-headed Ingrid Lacey as Ella, oscillating between positive defiance and mute resignation, by Clare Cathcart as her tenacious Irish chum and by Adrian Lukis as the ever-present man in black.

Until March 11. Box office 0171-722-9301. This review appeared in some editions of yesterday's Guardian.
